      \n
      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 1)

      24 March 1925

      [Having cleverly maneuvered the PCs into a tight spot, we pick up with the PCs making their way back into the villa of Omar Shakhti...

      I say       maneuvered, but really: the point of having a vast conspiracy is to be more powerful than a rag-tag group of heroes. Shakhti saw an opportunity and took it, is all. This would be a theme of the session.]

      Shakhti invites Freddie to take a walk around the Masjid, the large central courtyard the villa uses as a mosque, with him. People are filling up the space gradually; Shakhti explains that they will have a special service that evening. He offers Freddie a glass of iced champagne, and drinks one himself.

      [Subtle hint that Shakhti was about to let the mask slip a bit--he'd been keeping the devout Muslim facade up before this.]

      "You interest me, Mr. Blakely."

      "I seem to do that to a great many people."

      "It's very strange, don't you think? No matter what happens, you seem to be at the center."

      "I believe that the only reason people think these things is that I'm so dashed good looking. I mean, you'd think that the person at the center of the plot would know what is going on!"

      "And yet, when Jackson Elias fled Cairo for New York, where did she go? Why, to you, Mr. Blakely. And when Dr. Blont and Mr. Chiu broke up the white slavery ring, who appeared at the press conference? Who employed them? You, Mr. Blakely."

      "Well, Jax knew me is all."

      "So what does bring you to Cairo?"

      "Oh, seeing the sights, helping out Dr. Mwimbe."

      "Ah yes. Mwimbe."

      "And, well, I know you try to stay out of politics, but I seem to have helped out on an election. Was Perksies' fault, really. Seems Porgie got himself in a spot with the locals, so I made a bit of a contribution to the Wafd."

      "Ah, the rabble."

      "Indeed. So, if you don't mind, I'll just have another drink and then be off to my room."

      "Please sir, take the bottle. I allow myself certain indulgences, as any gentleman might."

      Meanwhile Pearkes is led up to his guest room. This is a not-large but well-appointed chamber, with a sliding wooden door that leads out to an open corridor on the Masjid. An elaborate wrought-iron railing marks the edge of the walkway.

      As the servant prepares the room, Pearkes notices to his surprise that on his wrist is tattooed a small "Red Ensign" (the national flag of Canada during this time) and the date "31-10-17"--the same dates that Pearkes earned his Victoria's Cross during Passchendaele.

      "You! What's the meaning of that tattoo!"

      "La, la, la," mutters the man. Although covered up, Pearkes can tell he's European.

      [At this point, we discussed interpersonal skills. PP was thinking about bureaucracy--"What are you going to have him do, fill out a form?" I asked--under the theory that it would "put him in a military mindset", but we settled on Reassurance. I wanted to see if he would use Intimidate--I asked him what he would have done to a shell-shocked soldier at Passchendaele.]

      Approaching the man with open arms, Pearkes gruffly barks: "You, sir! What unit were you?"

      "No...no unit..."

      "Come on, man! Speak out!"

      "Major....Major Pearkes? Don't you remember me? Don't you remember Passchendaele?"

      "I remember Passchendaele."

      "It's me, sir, Billy, sir! I was in the unit next to your'n. We was pinned down, sir. You weren't even our CO, but you took command! We'd have all died, if it weren't for you!"

      [This is based on an incident from the actual Pearkes' VC citation.]

      "What are you doing working for Shakhti, Billy?"

      "It's the cult, sir. They took Billy, they did sir. He came to Cairo after the war, to make his fortune like he did in Afghanisatan..."

      Billy, who seems to be of rather questionable Sanity (and Stability), nonetheless convinces Pearkes that he can help him escape from the Villa, and that they should do so soon, because "Tonight's special, sir. Tonight's Ceremony." He also says he knows where Shakhti's gun room is; he only asks that Pearkes save Billy again.

      Freddie makes his way up to his room, which is similar to Pearkes' room, although in a different part of the villa.

      [Yeah. Shakhti wasn't keeping the PCs together.]

      He stares out at the Masjid, listening to a rather evil-looking blind cleric lead the service. Although the sermon seems rather standard, Freddie senses a mood of anticipation in the crowd--as if the service wasn't the thing they were waiting for.

      [Assess Honesty by FP]

      Freddie ponders the building. His knowledge of Roman architecture leads him to believe that there are secret passages to allow servants access to the villa without being seen, but he's unsure about exactly how to find entrance into these passages.

      [FP attempted to use Art History, but was out of spends. I'd have given it to him with a spend. I did let him see the schematic I made of the villa; I was going to do a map on Fractal Mapper, and even started, but I couldn't get it right; besides, I didn't want this to be a dungeon crawl.]

      Pondering his situation, Freddie leaves a glass of champagne on the windowsill, messes up his bed, and then moves two doors down the hallway. Jostling the door hard eventually opens it up.

      [Freddie doesn't have locksmith, but these weren't really good locks, so Athletics did the trick.]

      Searching the room, Freddie finds a yellow robe in the closet that does not seem related to any branch of Muslim observance that he recognizes. He begins to put it on.

      [Preparedness roll by Freddie; FP asked for Preparedness, looking for something like a rope, but I gave him the robe--much more useful, in the long run.]

      A knock comes on Pearkes' room. Billy ducks out as Shakhti's major-domo invites Pearkes to meet the Bey in his private residence. Two burly servants indicate that this invitation is substantially less than a request.

      They traverse many of the halls that Shakhti showed them on their initial tour of the villa, and then one he most emphatically did not. This is a room dedicated to a Pharaoh unknown to Pearkes' knowledge of Egyptian history, lit by flickering torches, and dominated by the bust of a Pharaoh cut out of a strange black stone. Something peculiar about the way the light doesn't reflect off of the stone bothers Pearkes. Five large sarcophagi stand against the walls of the hall.

      Shakhti's office in his residence proves to be an astonishingly lavishly appointed room. The furniture is Second Empire and Louis XIV; heavy cut glass mirrors dominate the space. Pearkes notes a certificate from the coronation of Edward VII hanging on the wall.

      [Nifty detail provided by PP; his grandfather had been to Elizabeth II's coronation and had a similar certificate, which PP showed us.]

      The room seems to take up an entire floor of the residence, with balconies at either end. Shakhti stands with his hands clapsed behind him on the balcony overlooking the courtyard, which is filling up with people; in the dim light (it is the last day before the new moon), Pearkes can't see much detail.

      "Ah, Colonel Pearkes. Come join me."

      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nMay 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 2)

      "This is a rather extravagant room, Shakhti."

      "Well, I do allow myself certain indulgences."

      "It's very civilized."

      "Well, we have been civilized for quite some time."

      "I studied some Egyptology on the way over, you know."

      "It is an almost inexhaustible subject, don't you find?"

      "Indeed. I thought I knew all the Pharaohs, but I didn't recognize the one in the hall."

      "You speak of the Black Pharaoh, Nephren-Ka. I think you'd like him; he ruled with an iron will. This was long ago, when Egypt was a great empire."

      "Empires are in the habit of falling."

      "Yes they are, Colonel Pearkes! Yes they are! Especially empires composed of shopkeepers and shipping clerks."

      [FP: Ah, you speak of the Dutch.]

      "So tell me, Colonel. Why are you in my home? Why are you in Egypt?"

      "I was asked to come by a gentleman, and when one is asked to do something by one's betters, one goes."

      "But I find you to be a most independently-minded officer, as befits a cavalryman. We were a great cavalry power once, you know. I'm sure you've heard of the Mamelukes? Came a cropper against Napoleon. They did not adapt with the times, sir. Adapting with the times is key, don't you think?"

      The courtyard is being filled with people bearing torches. They are wearing yellow robes. In the flickering light, Pearkes can make out an ancient obelisk in the center of the vast paved expanse. Something about it troubles him; he is fairly well versed on ancient religions, but cannot think of one that would require iron rings to be driven into the sides of an obelisk.

      "That's an interesting obelisk, Shakhti."

      "Yes, it's quite old. It dates from thousands of years ago. We Egyptians were civilized while the Britons were still chasing sheep, for what purpose one can only surmise. Do you know what I dislike about the British? I include you even though I know you are Canadian now. It is an empire of petty merchants and shopkeepers. I have been to your Empire, sir. I have been to East Africa. Ten thousand [racial slurs] being commanded by a clerk from Winslow...."

      Shakhti motions to Pearkes. "Come sir. Let me show you what an Empire really is. What power really is."

      Pearkes steps onto the balcony. Below, a row of people wearing yellow robes are kneeling down.

      "Those are our catechumens. They have spent years preparing themselves for entry into our Brotherhood, passing many trials and showing the utmost dedication. Behind them stand their parents, who sponsored them, and who have striven for years to ensure their safe entry into the Brotherhood."

      Shakhti nods at the crowd.

      Without a word, the people standing behind the kneeling cultists begin to swing spiked clubs. The kneeling catechumens do not resist, but instead give orgiastic shrieks of joy.

      "That is real power, Colonel! That is Empire!" Shakhti draws himself up menancingly. "In Uruk...five thousand years ago...I ruled as king and was worshipped as a god! I stood on Sargon's right hand as we forged the world's first empire, our bronze swords shining red in the rising sun!"

      Shakhti's eyes begin to glow red. Pearkes quails for a moment, feeling his will being beaten upon by unseen forces.

      Then he stabs the Bey in the head with the sword concealed in his swagger stick.

      Shakhti stares for a moment, then steps back. The sword slides out of his face with a sickening sucking noise.

      "There's only one way, sir," says Pearkes.

      "Is there?" says Shakhti.

      His eyes glow an even more intense red.

      Pearkes swoons for a second. And then his will is no longer his own. His body has become Shakhti's puppet.

      [Domination spell by Shakhti. To Pearkes' credit, he was genuinely surprised to be stabbed; it just doesn't faze him.]

      "Oh Colonel, whatever shall we do with you? Whatever shall we do? Ah. I know. I shall send you to the wives. They will enjoy you."

      "If they're anything like you, [racial slur], I won't enjoy them."

      Shakhti mutters instructions to Pearkes, including a password--"hetep"--that he is to use if anyone tries to stop him. Compelled to move, Pearkes begins to head towards the wives' quarters.


      Back in the vacant bedroom, Freddie is trying on one of the robes. He hears a scratching at the door, which he ignores, as he is not supposed to be in that room.

      The door slides back, and a small white cat steps in. It regards Freddie quizzically.

      "Mee-reow?" Freddie recognizes the cat as the one Shakhti played with in the sitting room. The cat sits very prettily in the center of the room.

      Then its tongue flies out and wraps around Freddie's neck.

      The tongue begins to reel Freddie in. He fights back for a second, then lunges forward, grabbing the cat and wrapping the tongue around one of the posts of the bed.

      The cat begins to grow larger, and vaguely humanoid.

      Still choking, Freddie grabs at the cat, which slashes at him viciously with its claws.

      As the cat continues to gouge him, Freddie leaps through the window, vaults the railing, and plunges towards the Masjid, where the cleric is giving a reading on charity.

      At the last second, he catches the railing with his foot. The now six-foot tall cat-demon sails away from him, flailing weakly at him.

      [Interesting strategy by Freddie, although as PP pointed out, he risked giving himself the long drop and breaking his neck. Still, Athletics covers a host of sins; I made his success more dramatic with catching his left foot; meanwhile FP narrated a great scene for a 3-point pool refresh (another Night's Black Agents rule I lifted.)

      Surprisingly, the crowd gathered below do not seem to be too disturbed by the sight of a man in elegant evening clothes and a yellow robe hanging from the tongue of a cat demon. Freddie manages to pull off the tongue off of his neck, discovering at the last second that now he is dangling by one foot from the railing.

      "Brother, we will help you! Hetep is mad, it is true--he culls too many of the Brothers." The crowd helps him down. "The great gods are coming tonight! Come, Brother!"

      Speaking his best rough Egyptian Arabic, Freddie mutters, "I was worried I would be f***ing late."

      Hetep shrinks back to cat size and crawls sickeningly up its own tongue.

      It is soon apparent why the crowd did not think Freddie's appearance to be unusual--he's not the only man in evening clothes in the crowd; he recognizes several high-ranking Egyptian government officials, as well as some Europeans.

      As Pearkes walks through the halls, he stumbles upon Billy.

      "Colonel, where are you going?"

      "To the wives' quarters."

      "Oh no, sir, oh no. Don't go there sir, they're terrible sir."

      "Don't really have much choice, Billy. Help me."

      "What should I do, sir?"

      "Whatever it takes. Knock me out."

      "All right, sir...."

      After dithering for a second, Billy shouts a Pashtun battle cry and leaps on Pearkes, tackling him.

      "That's it, Billy. Keep going!"

      Billy grabs a heavy vase. "Sorry sir!"

      He bashes Pearkes on the skull.

      The colonel comes to in a back room of some kind. A rickety table holds some half-finished glasses of tea and the remains of card games--both playing and tarot cards litter the surface.

      Some yellow robes hang from pegs on the wall.

      "Sorry sir. Sorry sir. Sorry sir. Billy's sorry, sir."

      "It's all right Billy. Do you have anything for my head?"

      "I'll make you a glass, sir. A nice cuppa will do you well."

      Sipping his mint tea, Pearkes takes out his VC and thinks back on what he had to do to earn it, and all the good men he saw fall. He feels a renewed sense of purpose as the last traces of the spell falls from him.

      [PP called for a Symbol stability refresh--I was so proud. I ruled the Dominate spell would end now that he had refreshed Stability.]

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 3)

      24 March 1925

      Billy takes Pearkes into a large room. Pearkes whistles appreciatively: hanging on racks on the wall are hundreds of guns of all kinds of makes and models.

      Then he pauses, considering. Shakhti has hundreds of servants, many of whom serve him unwillingly. And yet the door to the gun room has no lock. He either does not worry about them rising against him--or he has no fear of ordinary weapons.

      [Me: Any light civilian arm you can find automatically. Preparedness rolls will find better weapons, up to and including military hardware...]

      Pearkes finds a pair of Colt .45s, a weapon he is familiar with since it is the Canadian service sidearm.

      [I introduced a rule from NBA allowing a +1 to damage with a weapon you have specialized in; PP took the Colt and his sword.]

      Then he begins to look for military weapons.

      [PP: Does he have a pintel-mount Browning fiddy cal?
      Me: ...which you can't carry. It's huge, man.
      PP: I just need to put it in a window.
      Me:....dear God, are you planning to massacre the entire courtyard?
      PP: They're clearly evil.
      FP: This is Colonel Pearkes.
      Me: I don't even want to begin to calculate the Stability cost.

      (Let S be the total Stability cost, n be the number of people affected, Cs the normal Stability cost of the action, and Q(Im) be the number of human beings considered equivalent to a single Imperial person. Therefore, S=log((n*Cs)/Q(Im)))

      PP: For what? They bashed their kids brains in.
      FP, tongue-in-cheek: And they're [racial slurs]
      PP: I have to stop them before they hurt my beloved country
      Me: I'm sorry, you can sugar it up no matter how you want, but this is still going to be a Stability s*** sandwich. You can't just machine-gun a crowd of people and be like "my psyche is completely unaffected!"
      PP and FP, in unison: He spent four years doing just that!
      Me: And that's why he can't do it anymore.]

      On the wall, he finds a military surplus Browning .50 caliber machinegun, and two boxes of ammunition.

      [Preparedness target of 7, and he made it. Allowing players narrative control is a cruel mistress...]

      Pearkes tries to hand Billy the gun. "Take this."

      Billy boggles. "I can't carry that! It's heavier than a dead Pashtun!"

      "Fine then, carry the ammo."

      Billy slides into the shoulder straps, muttering in Pashtun. He and Pearkes begin to look for a convenient window to set up the gun. Occasionally a cultist looks at him, but Pearkes imperiously declares "Hetep!" and strides past.

      \u201cHow come he gets a machine gun?\u201d one of them asks his supervisor. Astonished, the supervisor heads off to find the Bey.

      Meanwhile, Freddie has decided to pass himself off as a confused Turkish official. He grabs someone from the crowd and demands that he help him find his room.

      [Reassurance buy from FP to fast talk his way out of the crowd.]

      They go up to Pearkes' room, but the Colonel is of course missing.

      "Wait, you are the English?"

      "No, I must have the wrong room."

      "Well, hurry. I'm late to bash in some brains. And the Old Gods are coming tonight."

      "What do you think I want to do? But I don't have my club. How can I participate without it?"

      Dithering, the cultist finally decides to leave Freddie on his own. "Hurry, or you will be late."

      [Reassurance from FP, again.]

      Relieved, Freddie decides to go and collect Dr. Mwimbe. He swings out onto the railing and begins to climb up on the roof. Unfortunately, he loses his grip several times and ends up taking a long time to clamber up on the roof. Some people in the crowd below point at him and chatter loudly in Arabic.

      Freddie rolls over the roofline and begins to crawl towards the Wives' Quarters.

      [Failed Athletics roll by FP; I decided it was better to let him succeed with consequences than just fail. He made a Stealth roll to get back out of sight, but folks were looking for him.]

      Billy and Pearkes reach the Hall of Nephren-Ka. "We have to go through there, sir, to get to the garage or the residence. Unless we go up on the roof, sir."

      "Come on, then, Billy."

      "Billy don't like this, sir. Billy don't like it one bit..."

      As they cross the dimly lit room, there is an ominous scrrrrape from one of the sarcophagi.

      "Right," says Pearkes. "The roof it is!" He glances around. Billy has already fled, leaving the ammo boxes. Ditching the machine gun, Pearkes dashes after him.

      Overall, I think this worked pretty well; it simplified things, allowed the PCs to take a quick refresh of Stability as they went along (I am happily able to report that I got two PCs negative this time), and seems less likely to be abused. Of course, FP immediately wanted to have a mobile Safety ("Wherever the Aunts chew me out"), but I dodged that for now.
      \nYeah, no. If he wants that as a symbol, I could see it. If he wants the Aunts as solace, absolutely. But the Aunts are NOT a Safety.

      \n This has been a great thread. A good few years back, I co-GMed an Amber campaign that started with the PCs stuck on Earth where this was all happening. Being Amberites, they were generally able to take on most of the opponents as equals. Though they drastically miscalculated the potency of a certain ritual in Kenya.

      \n Lisa,

      It's a bit weird, with regard to the aunts; I previously told FP that I wasn't sure they aunts could be Sources, because I am obligated to threaten Sources, and I couldn't think of anything--even in the Mythos--that could threaten Bertie Wooster's aunts.

      Of course, I could just agree with FP, and simply never have the aunts move anywhere; but that seems a bit underhanded :-)

      Lee,

      I think you hit on something the group is still coming to grips with. With the exception of the original Call of Cthulhu game me, FP, and PP played in, we've been a d20 group. In d20, the social contract is that the opposition is ultimately not as powerful as the group combined (that's the meaning of Challenge Rating, after all.) And our CoC game was very heroic.

      While I'm happy running a pulp game, where the PCs can have a reasonable expectation that they can settle all difficulties by beating them up, it's important to note that the opposition is significantly more powerful than the PCs, and not afraid to use that power. This comes up later in this session. It also means I finally stumbled on the way to keep FP's natural machinations working with, rather than overriding, the story.

      Now back to the adventure!

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 4)

      Pearkes clambers up on top of the roof. A narrow walkway along the outside of the villa keeps him and Billy concealed from the courtyard. Shrieks and cries--of pain and exultation--torture their ears.

      Then they hear a new sound. A distant, otherworldly piping, like manic flutes, coming closer, closer.

      Billy shrieks, covers his ears, and turns to run.

      Pearkes panics for a moment, then fishes into his pockets and digs out some sealing wax. He crams it into his ears.

      [Preparedness roll from PP, slightly prompted by me. (PP: I'm looking for something like a Will save, so I don't listen. Me: Yeah. It's called a Stability check...) I ruled that blocking his ears would wipe out the +1 to the test TN from being a Mythos shock.]

      Despite muffling the noise, Pearkes slowly feels his will crumbling. He turns towards the courtyard...

      ...and sees horrible, froglike beings materializing out of thin air, playing long, alien flutes like maniacs. They approach the obelisk, where naked men and women have been chained to the iron rings, and proceed to violate them in the most obscene and disgusting manner possible. The poor humans are literally rent to pieces.

      Pearkes feels his sanity reel.

      [So despite that, PP blew the 5-point Stability test anyway, dropping him to -1 and thus dropping his Sanity by 1. (I offered him the fainting route, but quoth PP: "George doesn't faint!"]

      Billy begins to run away, but Pearkes tackles him and forces him down the ladder and back into the villa.



      On the other side of the courtyard, Freddie creeps along the roof. He too hears the otherworldly music. "My goodness, that's terrible," he thinks. "That's not even twelve-tone." He takes out the custom pair of earplugs he had made for concerts, lectures, and political rallies and puts them in. Humming bits from "The Merry Widow," he continues towards the Wives' Quarters.

      [Freddie also has a high Preparedness, and made his Stability roll.]

      Freddie rolls over the roofline as he approaches the Residence section of the villa. "Dash it all, there was a walkway the whole time." As he slides onto it, he sees a man in a yellow robe tackling another man across the courtyard. Shrugging, he opens a trapdoor and climbs down a ladder to the Wives' Quarters.

      [I gave Freddie a Stability refresh from his Drive here--it's bad luck to head completely the opposite direction of the the rest of the Party.

      BTW, GP couldn't make it this time, and CP was late, which is why the early part of the session is only about Freddie and Colonel Pearkes.]

      The ladder ends in a sheltered bay just off a main corridor. He risks a quick glance around the corner. Two huge men, whom he takes to be eunuchs, are standing in front of an elaborate door. Their scimitars are particularly long and sharp.

      Freddie shudders, and then thinks back to a night in Paris, during the war, when he and Jackson had fled across the rooftops from the gendarmes. He smiles, and then turns the corner.

      [FP invoked his symbol here.]

      Striding up to the guards, Freddie puts on his best arrogant aristocrat voice and says in Arabic, "I am here for my wife."

      "Your...wife?"

      "Yes. The Mwimbe woman. Bring her to me swiftly!"

      The guards glance at each other uneasily. Finally, one says "Wait here," and goes through the door.

      Freddie scowls at the other guard, who shifts nervously. The faint sounds of a angry conversation come through the door.

      Finally the first guard returns. "She comes."

      After a moment, Dr. Mwimbe steps out.

      "Come, woman." Freddie strides imperiously away.

      Mwimbe follows. "But--"

      "Not now, my wife. Do not dishonor me by speaking. We are late for the ceremony."

      After they turn a corner, Mwimbe hisses at Freddie: "You are in enormous danger."

      "Yes, I've already been strangled by a cat."

      "Ah, Hetep. Of course."

      "You know, we must talk about this more when we are safer."



      Pearkes climbs down the ladder, spouting racial insults directed at the cultists. He shoves Billy up to the entrance to the Hall of Nephren-Ka. "You're going in there with me, Billy. You're going to pick up that ammo."

      "No! No, no, no!" screams Billy. He lapses into Arabic. "La, la, la!"

      "You're going to pick up that ammo, then we are going to set up in the next room and you will take out all your anger on the cult."

      "Billy's not angry, Billy just wants to go home."

      "The way home is through there. You want to go home, don't you?"

      "Yes, Billy wants to go home but not through there. I don't want to go in there."

      "Then you don't want to go home, then! Pick it up!"

      "No! No! We'll go back to the cloakroom, we'll get the cars."

      "You said that the only way was through this room!"

      "We can go back out on the roof, I thought that's what we were doing before...Billy's scared."

      "Is that what they said before Waterloo?"

      "The French, maybe!"

      [I ruled that Billy's Sanity was so fried that the only way to get him to go in the room was to make some kind of Interpersonal spend, but Pearkes' hurt Stability kept him from doing so.]

      Exasperated, Pearkes studies the room himself, then dashes in. He makes a perfect sliding tackle to sweep by the ammo boxes and scoop them up, then shoulders the gun and scrambles for the door a the other end of the hall, dragging the ammo boxes.

      [After much discussion, I ruled a 2-point Athletics spend would allow Pearkes to pick up both boxes of ammo (otherwise he could only get one--altogether the boxes and machine gun weigh well north of a hundred pounds.) He then spent his last two points of Athletics to try and reach the exit before getting caught by, as I put it it, multiple opponents.]

      Just short of the door, he feels the heavy touch of a hand on his shoulder. One of the mummies has left its sarcophagus and has grabbed him; the other four are just behind.

      Swinging the Browning amidships, Pearkes executes a precise cross-check on the lead mummy, knocking him backwards into his companions. The Colonel flops backwards, scrambling with his legs into the room beyond. A swift kick slams the door shut, and the bar drops neatly into place.

      [Scuffling spend by PP, and I used NBA's rules for pushing/throwing opponents.]

      It's a bit weird, with regard to the aunts; I previously told FP that I wasn't sure they aunts could be Sources, because I am obligated to threaten Sources, and I couldn't think of anything--even in the Mythos--that could threaten Bertie Wooster's aunts.

      \nAh, I see -- genre clash. If we're in the Lovecraftian genre, then, of course the mythos can threaten the Aunts. But, you're finding them too firmly set in their own genre, were they're basically untouchable, correct?

      \n
      \n Genre-clash seems to be unavoidable if you call your campaign "The Post-Modern" anything :-)

      But yeah. To stay true to FPs vision of playing Bertie Wooster, then I'm stuck with the Wodehousian vision of the Aunts as unstoppable forces of nature. If I kill 'em off, then we're back to Lovecraft, but I've drop-kicked FPs vision. So in that a sense, they could actually work as a Safety, given that the Aunts never leave wherever the heck it is that they live; especially so since NBA explicitly notes that visiting the Safety basically burns it and puts your contacts there in danger. So that could work--they Mythos can't hurt them unless Freddie brings it to their door.

      In any case, you can see me developing a line among the NPCs that Freddie simply can't be as stupid as he appears, and since he's played by FP, I think that will eventually bear out. (Despite FP not caring for Bertie's sketch, the Wodehouse character Reggie, Freddie is much more like Reggie than Bertie--he develops his own schemes, and they tend to work.)

      \n I think, then, that one thing to do for post-modern play is to decide which genre takes precedence when there are clashes or whether there will just be a disconnect and how it will be handled in play. My Cthulhupunk game does not have horror as primary, but when I ran straight CoC with Tatters of the King, horror was front and center.

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 5)

      As they wander the corridors of the villa, Freddie and Mwimbe finally come across Pearkes and Billy.

      The Colonel regards Mwimbe, who has been properly veiled during her stay in the Wives' Quarters. "Mwimbe, I like the look! Very conservative."

      "Good God, man," says Freddie. "Why on Earth are you carrying around plumbing supplies?"

      "It's a gun, Freddie."

      "Goodness, that's the biggest gun I've ever seen! And who's your friend?"

      "This is Billy. We served together in the war."

      "Ah, then I feel sorry for you, Billy."

      "Lor' bless you, guv'ner."

      "I say, Colonel. Will that thing kill Bedouins?"

      "Why not?" says Mwimbe bitterly. "Brownings have been killing Africans for decades."

      "Say, Mwimbe, I thought you didn't like Bedouins?"

      "What? No, they are an oppressed people, we should all work together."

      The group makes their way down into the cloakroom. Billy leads them into the basement. They ignore the vast spaces around them, filled with who knows what horrors, and enter a narrow tunnel that leads, according to Billy, to the garage.

      After a while, they emerge into a spacious building filled with modern vehicles--touring cars, limousines, motorcycles, and even a half-ton truck. In one of the touring cars they find Charleston and Gilbert, passed out (or drugged.)

      "Didn't you tell me Bedouins attacked your village?" says Freddie, picking up the conversation again.

      "Bedouins? No. It was the the British who attacked. Just one more atrocity they have committed against Africans."

      "Oh, I see. But you're Zanzibari, yes?"

      "Of course."

      "And part Persian?"

      "Yes, yes. I have Persian ancestry..."

      "But aren't Persians white?"

      "I...you..."

      As she sputters, Freddie turns to find the Colonel, who has commandeered the truck and is searching for a bracket to attach the Browning to the back.

      [Preparedness roll by PP. I was a bit relieved over this use of the Browning--massacring the courtyard was pushing my boundaries a bit.]

      Freddie jumps in the cab, and they roar out into the darkness.

      In the truck bed, Pearkes convinces Dr. Mwimbe to hypnotize him in an effort to put his mind at rest. After a while, he wakes from a trance feeling relieved.

      [I don't generally give the NPCs useful skills unless the PCs have them as well, but this fit into my overall plan so it wasn't a problem.]

      As they turn towards the road that leads back to Cairo, they behold a large crowd of the plantation's workers, holding torches. "Shakhti...Shakhti...Shakhti..." they chant. Freddie shifts gears and tears off across the fields, making for the open desert.

      Soon they notice a cloud of dust behind them, and then catch the faint noise of engines. A crowd of motorcycles is pursuing them, with a half-ton truck in the middle. Mounted on the truck is a wicked looking Browning Automatic Rifle.

      Freddie glances back and then nails the gas pedal to the floor. Meanwhile, Pearkes opens up with the .50 cal, scattering the motorcycles.

      [I wanted to use the chase rules from NBA, but then blew it by giving Freddie and company too big a lead; I didn't have to, but decided to stick to my original formula for calculating the lead (something like Skill Test-4) because I had other content in wait, and wasn't sure how exciting a chase would be. PP used the suppression fire rules from NBA, which worked well enough. In any case, any spends are useful in lowering PC resources!

      FP was using Fleeing here, not driving. He had a few points in Driving, so I was okay with that; Fleeing should be broadly useful in my opinion, although I'll consider the ratings in other skills for things besides pure running.]

      The BAR opens up. Shrapnel flies into Pearkes' face as bullets chew up the truck bed, but he is largely unhurt as they escape into the darkness.

      They drive for a few hours in the mysterious silence of the desert. As dawn approaches, they pass into a dry wash that offers them some cover. Suddenly, Freddie jerks over the wheel, having seen a glint from one of the rock outcroppings. Moments later a shot rings out, and the front tire of the truck blows out.

      [Sense Trouble by FP, followed by a driving roll. The assailants had more than enough Firearms to make the called shot, but the Sense Trouble success prevented a messy crash.]

      "Freddie of the English!" a voice calls out.

      "Ah, hello?"

      Shots ring down at the truck, pinning everyone inside it.

      "It is I, Wazim. If you surrender now, we will give you a quick death. Or, you can wait until sunrise, and we will attack. You will have a chance to die with honor!"

      "Well, that's an interesting offer. Why don't we make an agreement, and then we will break all our promises, and probably kill you in the process!"

      "Ha! You amuse me, Freddie! Dawn it is, then!"

      The sun slowly climbs over the horizon. There is a sudden violent shaking all around them, followed by the screams of horses and men.

      Wazim and three other Bedouin dash across the sand and jump in the truck bed next to Pearkes.

      "Look!" pants the Bedouin leader.

      Tentacles erupt out of the sand, linked to a horrendous squid-like body. One tentacle lashes out at one of the Bedouin, and a hideous sucking noise ensues. The man grows pale as his vital fluids are drained by the bizarre creature.

      [Homebrew conversion of a Cthonian, summoned by Shakhti Bey to finish off the PCs. Not a full-adult, but still plenty tough.]

      Billy screams and jumps out of the truck.

      [Me: He served in Afghanistan. His fleeing is very high. (This is a comment on contemporaneous British experience in the Big A, of course, not that of our time.]

      Freddie slides into the truck bed and begins to look around for something to use against the creature. He grabs a gas can and throws it in the air. A tentacle catches it and the can collapses in on itself as it is drained.

      Tossing a flare pistol he found at Pearkes, Freddie tells him to shoot at the gas-filled tentacle.

      [FP made a bunch of neat Preparedness checks here.]

      Pearkes jumps off the truck and strides towards the creature. The tentacle drops the empty can and lashes out towards him.

      Pearkes fires the flare gun. The tentacle explodes, and the creature shrieks.

      [PP used Intimidation here to get a combat bonus on the called shot, which I thought was neat.]

      Wazim mans the Browning and opens up on the creature, but fails to significantly damage it. The remaining Bedouin also open fire, but both are hit by tentacles.

      [FP: Eventually we will run out of ablative Bedouin.]

      Freddie kicks open a box in the back of the truck bed. Like any good farmer, Shakhti maintains a stock of dynamite. Freddie takes the sticks out, unsure how to use them. Wazim grabs them from him and begins to mount the fuses.

      Pearkes and the old Bedouin launch lit dynamite sticks at the creature. A tentacle blows off. The thing writhes in pain.

      It throws a tentacle at Pearkes, who falls to his knees in agony as the creature begins to suck him dry.

      Freddie tosses more dynamite. The Bedouin open up again with their rifles. Finally Pearkes throws his last stick. The explosion knocks him down, but the creature, having lost another tentacle, turns away and burrows into the sand.

      Everyone heaves a sigh of relief, except for the remaining heavily-wounded Bedouin.

      "What...what could have caused a jinn of the desert to attack us, Freddie?" gasps Wazim.

      "I would say it was the man you work for."

      "What? Truly you say this? That Shakhti Bey called up the jinn?"

      "I'm afraid so, old sport."

      "Give me your word as an English...wait. As a gentleman. I've known too many Englishmen."

      "I give you my word, sir."

      Wazim ponders this. "Well, then, to hell with the Sheikh! I work for Freddie Blakely now!"

      \n\nLee_Short \n\n\n

      \n\nMay 2013 \n

      \n
      \n

      I think you hit on something the group is still coming to grips with. With the exception of the original Call of Cthulhu game me, FP, and PP played in, we've been a d20 group. In d20, the social contract is that the opposition is ultimately not as powerful as the group combined (that's the meaning of Challenge Rating, after all.) And our CoC game was very heroic.

      While I'm happy running a pulp game, where the PCs can have a reasonable expectation that they can settle all difficulties by beating them up, it's important to note that the opposition is significantly more powerful than the PCs, and not afraid to use that power. This comes up later in this session. It also means I finally stumbled on the way to keep FP's natural machinations working with, rather than overriding, the story.
      \nYeah, this caused some mismatched expectations for us, as well. The default Amber expectation is that characters with Amber blood can walk all over characters from a 'shadow' world like Earth. The players did eventually figure out that the presence of Cthulu cultists meant that their real opposition wasn't actually from earth (we ruled that both Shakti and M'Weru had some otherworldly blood). IIRC, we had to hint at this a bit harder than we had hoped to.

      Sadly, that campaign died of scheduling issues before they made it to the Far East.

      \n Lee, I never played Amber (FP has, but then he's played most systems). I agree with Lisa, that sounds pretty epic.

      Whether the players realize it or not, the power level I'm basically going for is that as a group they have a chance to take on Big Bads (albeit with risk), but organizationally the opposition is much stronger. Shakhti has, like, oodles and oodles of cultists and his group has penetrated both the Egyptian and British administrations; it's trivial for him to allocate a large amount of spies to watch the PCs and seek out any hidey-holes. (And he gets to use racism and imperialism against him, under the old "nobody notices the servants" method of intelligence gathering.)

      FP is generally very good at moving the pawns around the chessboard, but here my basic stance is that when not opposed by POV characters, the conspiracy generally succeeds at whatever they want to do. FP hasn't quite grasped this, I think; or maybe he's used to the Pathfinder campaigns we've been in where magic allowed him to be in multiple places at once. (Curiously, they haven't tried using technology, although there's some obvious ways it could be used--radios to allow the PCs to be "in" multiple places at once, airplanes to allow for quick reaction and air superiority, etc.) Like I said, this comes up towards the end of the session.

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 6)

      With the help of Wazim, and Qusay, the remaining Bedouin, the truck is soon repaired and they all drive into Cairo together. The city is a hornet's nest of resentment and open riot: although the Wafd won a clear majority of the seats in Parliament, rumors are already circulating that the King will never allow a government headed by Zaghloul to take power.

      [Actual historical event; the constitutional crisis dragged on for years, with several Royalist puppet prime ministers ruling by decree. We decided that thanks to Freddie, the election was even more one-sided and resentment obviously higher.

      In case I haven't mentioned it, the campaign officially takes place in an alternate timeline, so I am not beholden to historical events, although the divergence is currently pretty low. (The one that I know about is that Walter Rathenau was not assassinated in 1921 and is currently a candidate for Chancellor of the Weimar Republic.]

      Arriving at Shepheard's, they push into the salon, dust from the desert shaking off of them. Wazim glares at the soft Europeans, while the wounded Pearkes puts on his best stiff upper lip.

      [I told the players to visualize the scene in every action movie where the heroes come striding in, filmed in slow motion.]

      "Ah, Mr. Freddie!" says the bartender. "I heard you were dead. Good to see that you're still with us. There's somebody you should meet--"

      Just then Sheila runs up to Freddie. "Mr. Blakely!" She grabs him into a tight embrace.

      "I say, Abigail--"

      She pushes him away and slaps him. "Don't ever do that to me again! I thought you were dead!" She breaks down.

      "Hah!" shouts Wazim, in Arabic. "He cannot control his [gender slur]."

      "She's not my concubine," replies Freddie in the same language. "She's my assistant."

      "Ah, I do not hold with these 'Modern Women'. My daughter is one such. She lives in the city, studies at the university, has forgotten our ways."

      Freddie quietly orders Sheila a drink. "So who is it I should meet?" he asks the bartender.

      The bartender nods at a tweedy, donnish-looking man sitting at the end of the bar. He glances up at Freddie, light reflecting on his thick glasses and his bristlebrush mustache curling up into a smile. "I say, Freddie Blakely!"

      "Indeed. And who do I owe the pleasure?'

      "Clive, sir, Dr. Henry Clive, of what they're calling the Clive Expedition. Sent down here from Paris by the Penhew Foundation people, don't you know."

      "Quite. What brings you to Cairo?"

      "Just a bit of R & R, up from the digs. I hear you're quite the man to talk to up here."

      "Everybody says that, but I really don't know why."

      Freddie studies Clive with the cold condescension of the gentry. Although the man affects a plummy Oxbridge accent, it's clear to Freddie that he's not well-born, however much he obviously strives to be perceived as such.

      [Freddie's Credit Rating is absurdly high, so I gave this to him.]

      Soon Clive and Freddie fall into reminiscences about Oxford; it turns out they were both at Exeter College. "I say, do you remember old Tolky?"

      "You mean Jerry?"

      "No, Johnny."

      "Yes, John Tolkien. Called him Jerry from his initials."

      "That's the one! Daft old chap.

      "Always spouting off about Welsh and Finnish."

      "Never amount to much."

      A sandy-haired man in his twenties sits down next to Clive. He has a smug expression that Freddie and Pearkes immediately dislike.

      "Ah, Blakely, this is my man Winfield. Dr. Martin Winfield, Freddie Blakely, Colonel George Pearkes."

      "Charmed," says Winfield smoothly. Pearkes eyes him cautiously. It's obvious to him that this man is a killer, one who has killed before and will kill again--the type of man, in short, who relishes delivering pain.

      [Gave this to free to PP based on his military career. Winfield is a piece of work, no doubt.]

      "So how goes the dig, gentlemen?" asks Freddie.

      "Smashing," says Clive. "We dug up in Giza first, you know. Found an ancient burial chamber for a queen near the Great Pyramid. Looks like it was a reburial, you know; scrolls indicated that the mummy wasn't anybody special. But, here's the damnedest thing, the mummy got stolen! Bloody grave robbers. Since then we've kept our security high, especially since we moved down to Luxor to work on excavating a temple.

      "But you know, Freddie, I'm wondering what brings you here to Cairo?"

      "Oh, the usual, seeing the sights, helping out Dr. Mwimbe there."

      "I know her by reputation."

      "Yes. Well, the thing is, I'm planning to marry her."

      Clive looks agahast. "But, old man, that's simply not done!"

      "Certainly not in England. Which is why, you see, I'm in Cairo."

      Clive and Winfield boggle together. "That seems...quite dubious, old sport. Are you sure you know what you're up to?"

      "I'm never sure, actually. Oh, have you heard about that railroad they're trying to build from Egypt to Persia?"

      Clive blinks. "That...that would be of critical importance to the Empire."

      "Quite. A man could get very rich, were he to invest in such a thing. Of course, I have no interests in such a venture. I understand the negotiations with Persia are very tricky."

      "A railroad, you say," mutters Clive. He and Winfield exchange glances.

      "I believe Dr. Mwimbe is part Persian," says Winfield.

      "Is she? Small world. Well, we should probably let you get on. I hope you'll let me call on you down by the dig, if I'm ever in the area."

      "Of course, sir! It would be our pleasure." Clive and Winfield excuse themselves and head to their rooms.

      "Allison," says Freddie to Sheila, "Do I own any railroad stock?"

      "Yes, Mr. Blakely."

      "Amazing. Do you think I could buy some more? Here in Egypt?"

      "I...I don't know, Mr. Blakely."

      "Could you find out?"

      "I'll ask around to see if I can get you access to the Bourse, Mr. Blakely."

      "Excellent."

      Freddie goes to Mwimbe's room.

      "Yes, Mr. Blakely?"

      "Hello, Mwimbe. Hope you're relaxing after your ordeal. Oh, by the way, I may have given it out that you and I are going to get married. But if anyone asks, I need you to tell them that it's absolutely not true."

      "That should not be very difficult at all, Mr. Blakey."

      \n Incidentally, the Egypt to India railroad was an actual British ambition of the period; it was ultimately thwarted by Persia not granting thruway rights, mostly because of Russian interference. The Great Game centered on Persia, after all.

      FP is a history geek like myself, which makes a game like this a real pleasure to run with him.

      \n
      \n Love it, Lisa :-)

      In play, I assumed that Tolkien was a don at Oxford by this point, but he only returned there to teach in 1925. We weren't clear in play about whether he was a teacher or not, but for the transcript I've made it clear he was a fellow student.

      I tend to stick in as many historical personage cameos as I can, because its a joy of historical RPing or historical fiction; you want to meet these guys. Provided it doesn't strain things too much, I think it adds to the game.

      Of course, that could just be me. My first CoC character was an East Tennessee lesbian tomboy aviatrix (thus my handle) who had what I liked to call "Six Degrees of Joyce Summers" (that being her name.) I used to drop into casual conversation how she had met somebody who wasn't famous yet in the 1920s (or was famous, but she didn't recognize him), usually to the groans of the other players.

      "Met a fella down at the speakeasy last night. Said his name was George, and he played for the Yankees, but I didn't believe him. Too fat to be an athlete."

      "Ernie? Yeah, I met him in Paris at Scott's place when I was there for the airshow. Think he's compensating for something."

      "Lindbergh? That peckerwood? That boy is in more dire need of a **** *** than any white man in history."

      Und so weiter :-)

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 7)

      25 March 1925

      The next day Sheila reports back that she has located a man who can help Freddie buy stocks on the Egyptian Bourse: Nigel Wassif, the editor of the Cairo Bulletin, a local newspaper that focuses on celebrity gossip.

      Freddie checks in on Wazim and Qusay. They have transformed their room into a fair imitation of a tent.

      "Well, Wazim, are you enjoying yourself?"

      "Bah. The son of a camel downstairs told me I could not bring my gun upstairs. I pointed out that his head would barely stop my scimitar."

      "I could see how that might make him more amenable. I like what you've done with the room."

      "It was Qusay. He is skilled in these arts!"

      "Qusay, I'm impressed. If you ever decide to give up hitting people on the head as a trade, you could do very well for yourself as a decorator."

      "That is such a stereotype of the Bedouin lifestyle! I am not a violent man. Although, if people insist on crossing our territory without paying the tolls, a man is justified..."

      Wazim snorts. "They are too soft here. People should not live in cities. I could take fifty...no, fifty-two of these soft Egyptians."

      "I think you'll find, Wazim, that even if you can take out fifty-two, the fifty-third will probably kill you."

      "Bah. If it is written, what can I do."

      [FP: I like Wazim.
      Me: Yeah, well, he kinda lives like a murderhobo PC. (in Wazim voice) "I killed your waiter. And took his wallet."
      FP: Just goes to show how psychopathic the average PC is.]

      Charleston is feeling better by this point, so they motor down to the offices of the Bulletin. Nigel Wassif turns out to be a handsome man with impeccable English. He wears the most fashionable of suits. Offering his guests whiskey, he turns and toasts a large portrait of George V.

      "Gentlemen, the King."

      "And to King Fuad," says Freddie.

      "Of course, although I must confess a certain affection for George. I was born in England, you know."

      "We were all born in in England," says Pearkes, who is a Canadian immigrant.

      Charleston shrugs.

      "My mother was a chambermaid for the King," continues Wassif. "She got to know him quite intimately."

      Freddie glances at Wassif, then studies the portrait for a long time. "You know, I think I knew your brother Bertie at school."

      "I...have no brother."

      "No, of course not, of course not. So I was wondering if you could help me conduct some business on the Bourse..."

      "Yes, yes, my man of business is very capable. But it strikes me that this is not why you are in Egypt."

      "No?"

      "It strikes me that much like Jackson Elias, you are here following the trail of the Carlyle Expedition."

      "Ah. Bit of a bunch of stuffed shirts, weren't they?"

      "They were strange people, to be sure. I covered them extensively. They were good press.

      "Carlyle was the strangest, him and the woman M'Weru. She always wore an Egyptian burial mask. Was most disconcerting."

      Charleston thumbs through a set of clippings about the Carlyles. He notices something strange. "These pictures--they claim to have been taken a month apart, but the date on the calendar is the same! You recycled them?"

      Wassif shrugs. "To tell the truth, Roger Carlyle ended up not being very useful to me. He spent a great deal of time sick in his hotel room. Often when I watched his hotel, I would see the shadow of a woman in the room."

      "Miss Masters?" asks Freddie.

      "Perhaps. Certainly they gave out that he and Miss Masters were involved with each other. As men of the world, however, I think you understand how unlikely that was."

      "M'Weru, then."

      "Perhaps; or perhaps a third woman. I do not know. In any case, one day the Carlyles were simply gone; nobody saw them for over a month, until they suddenly reappeared in Zanzibar, on their way to Tanganyika. I often reused photographs of them during this period."

      "I see...and now the Clives seem to be following in the Carlyle Expedition's trail."

      "Indeed. You do not believe, of course, Dr. Clive's ridiculous story about the mummy that was stolen. My sources tell me that Clive identified it easily enough--the remains of Queen Nitocris, of evil legend."

      "Yes, we've heard of her. Why the deception, then?"

      "The Cult of the Black Pharaoh no doubt has interest in her. They have been gathering of late, near the Sphinx; they seem to be planning something very big. And that is very bad news, gentlemen; it means Shakhti Bey himself is involved."

      "We've enjoyed his hospitality."

      "Then you are lucky to still be alive. I tell you, sirs: the man is pure evil."

      When they get back to the hotel, Freddie asks the concierge to send Shakhti a bottle of champagne, with a note:\n
      Shakhti Bey,



      Thank you for an unforgettable evening. I apologize for leaving without speaking to you, but I think you'll agree the circumstances left me little choice. I'm returning a bottle of champagne to you.

      Best,

      Roland Blakely, Esq.

      PS If you're ever in New York, don't drop by.
      \n

      \n
      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 8)

      When they return to Shepheard's, Mwimbe speaks privately to Charleston. "Dr. Kafour's death was a tragedy. However, it occurs to me that a great treasure of lore and artifacts are now left without a custodian at the museum. I was wondering if you might be willing..."

      "Not interested," says Charleston. He immediately goes into the car bay and begins to lay out his safecracking equipment.

      "Bon jour," says Anton.

      "Oh, what do you want."

      "Easy, easy. I just want a piece of whatever you're planning."

      "Why do you think I'm planning anything?"

      Anton languidly gestures at the tools with his cigarette. "Hey, it's all right, you ignore that I'm robbing the guests here blind, I ignore your little projects. But I'd like a piece. I can help out, drive or serve as a lookout."

      [Anton is GP's Solace, so I was slightly uncomfortable using him to help Charleston. However, logically he'd be in on it, and Charleston definitely needed some assistance. I planned to give Anton some slight plot immunity.]

      "Fine. You can drive. Just understand--I keep anything with writing on it."

      Later that night, Anton pulls up in a late-model Rolls Royce. "Don't worry, I stole it."

      "Real subtle! Everybody is going to see us!"

      "Au contraire. They will see a rich Chinese businessman and his chauffeur. And people here are trained not to stare at wealth."

      Charleston inspects the car. "Is this going to be big enough?"

      "Big enough? It's a Rolls! Look, you steal the small stuff that is very valuable! What do you want, to steal a sarcophagus?"

      "If it has writing on it--weren't you paying attention?"

      "We can steal a sarcophagus, but I'll need more guys. I can get them for you..."

      "Scope creep," sighs Charleston, shaking his head.

      They drive to the Egyptian Museum and pull up at the kitchen. The door easily springs, and they slip into the museum. Evading the patrols is slightly harder, but for two such experienced thieves there is little danger.

      [I only called for one check here; they're good at what they do, and Cairo is pretty chaotic at this point.]

      They arrive at Kafour's office. A massive safe dominates one corner. Someone is moving around inside, very quietly.

      "Would a mummy ransack an office?" mutters Charleston.

      Anton creeps away. "Sorry, I am what you call, a coward."

      Charleston steps into the office..

      He sees a cloaked figure whose face is obscured with a scarf. Charleston gestures with his Thomspon. "Easy, easy. Who are you."

      "I am Noor. I was Dr. Kafour's assistant!"

      "And why are you here?"

      "Because I seek truth. That is why I work for Dr. Kafour."

      "And how did you get past the guards?"

      "She's a Bedouin," says Anton. "Brigands of the desert."

      "I am not a brigand! That is a sterotype--"

      "Look, I was a hired assassin for the Triads. So we're all brigands here."

      "Really?" says Anton. "Did you know Mr. Lee?"

      "This is not the time," says Noor. "There are many dangerous books here. I came to make them safe."

      Charleston gives her a searching look. "Have you found anything?"

      "The most valuable items are kept in the safe. I have disabled the spell, I think, but I don't know the combination."

      Charleston begins to work on the safe. With Noor's help, he manages to open it in a few hours. Inside are many talismans and obscure objets d'art, and several books. Noor grabs for one, but Charleston takes it from her.

      The book has been rebound several times, but the pages are immensely old. The writing inside seems to be Arabic.

      Charleston recognizes the book from his occult studies. The Al Azif.

      The Arabic Necronomicon, written by Abd al-Hazrad himself.

      "Be very careful with that book, sir. It is very evil and very powerful. Dr. Kafour very rarely let anyone look at it. I myself only got a brief glance at it once."

      Charleston practically drools over it. "We should go somewhere to read it."

      "I could help. After all, you have the book, but I speak Arabic! Together we can decipher it."

      "I have other books as well."

      Noor brightens. "I would be delighted to see your collection."

      "You're not frightened of me?"

      "I am far more scared of that book."

      As they begin to head back to the car, the sounds of a patrol heading their way can be heard. "Run!" says Anton.

      Guards shout from behind them, but they dare not fire weapons in the Museum.

      Dragging Noor along, Charleston dashes into the Rolls. Anton slides behind the seat and they peel away.

      They abandon the car in the Old City. Anton parks it in the road and tosses the keys inside. A short walk later and they are back at Shepheard's. Freddie is playing ragtime at the piano, swigging from a bottle of whiskey in between tunes. Sheila is trying to get him to stand upright, but he valiantly resists.

      Charleston takes Noor up to his room. He sweeps the corners, checks the balcony, locks the doors, and checks under the bed. He takes out the books he got from Erica Carlyle, desperate to show off to somebody who understands what they are.

      "Ah! The Livre d'Yvon! And Life as a God! That is a very valuable source on the Cult of the Black Pharaoh."

      "So let's translate this book into English."

      "You cannot be serious! If you read the whole book, you will go mad!"

      "I read all these other books."

      "This one is worse than all of them put together."

      "That's why I saved it for last!"

      [This is quite literally true; 4-point Sanity loss for the Al-Azif. FP opined that this must be how all the translations happen--some idiot thinks nothing could go wrong.

      Incidentally, if Charleston were to succeed at reading the book, his Sanity would drop to 3. However, as CP pointed out, he lost his Pillar of Reason as a result of reading the other books. So this is totally in character.

      So: I gave the PCs the most dangerous and valuable Mythos tome there is. I'm actually not all that worried, though. It gives Scary Potter (Charleston) access to a lot of spells, but he still has to       cast them and that's not easy. (And I generally require a Mythos spend to get access to a particular spell, rather than some less useful incantation.)]

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 9)

      26 March 1925

      The next day, Pearkes and Freddie decide to set out to investigate the Clive expedition. Cairo seems a bit too hot for them, especially as Freddie has received a reply to his note: a bottle of champagne, and the message "We will meet again." He forwards the bottle to Mustafa Pasha.

      Freddie drops Saad Zahgloul a note telling him he can always count on him for a favor.

      Charleston wakes up in his room; at some point during the night he must have finally passed out from fatigue. Half-finished sheets of paper with English and Arabic text litter the table. Noor is asleep, nuzzled up to his shoulder.

      He sees a tall Bedouin pass by the door, and then suddenly stop. The man looks back and forth between Charleston and Noor. Then he draws his scimitar.

      "You will die for making a [gender slur] of my daughter!"

      Charleston picks up his Thompson from where he dropped it next to his chair. "She's not a [gender slur]. Call her that again and I'll perforate you."

      "I admire your moxie!" says the Bedouin.

      "Ah, Charleston, I see you've met Wazim!" says Freddie, rushing into the room.

      "Why does he have my daughter with him?" demands Wazim.

      "She's an academician," says Charleston.

      "Bah! She left the desert, left our ways, for books!"

      "That's because she isn't an idiot like you."

      "I expect that she is working with Charleston to loot the museum," explains Freddie.

      "These things need to be done properly," says Wazim. "He should have come to me, or her older brother. Or her husband--"

      "I'M NOT MARRIED TO HIM YET!" screams Noor.

      Freddie introduces everyone, defusing Charleston, who wants to hit the books again after breakfast, but Freddie tells him that he'll have to do it on the boat. "I assure you, Wazim, that Charleston has almost no interest in women at all!"

      "Ah! He is like a Circassian!"

      "I suppose."

      "As your Paul says, 'some men are eunuchs by nature, others are eunuchs for Issa'!"

      "Hey!" says Charleston.

      "Not at all, Wazim. Charleston likes killing people and taking photographs and not much else."

      "If he rode a horse instead of taking photographs, he could be a Bedouin."

      Pearkes arranges for all of them to ride down to Luxor on a British military transport (basically, a contracted civilian steamer.)

      On the way to the docks, they noticed they are being followed by four men, who wear inverted ankhs. Freddie stops at the harbormaster's office and speaks with the local garrison commander.

      "Sir, there are four ruffians out there insulting the honor of both our Sovereign, and the Queen. You'll recognize them easily, as they wear this symbol."

      "Right you are, gov. We'll round them up."

      As the transport leaves the dock, British MPs grab the four men. Pearkes, displaying his best stiff-upper lip, waves regally at them.

      "See you later, a**holes," says Charleston, who's American.

      Freddie goes to the purser. "There's something wrong with my cabin. This room is supposed to be it, but it's clearly the walk-in closet! I mean, I can reach across it with arms outstretched!"

      Noor and Charleston huddle together in their small stateroom, planning things to do to drive themselves mad.

      [If you want a comic interlude here, picture Wazim walking by, seeing them sitting together close enough that their knees touch, drawing his scimitar and being restrained by Freddie and Pearkes--all while Charleston obliviously studies on.]

      29 March 1925

      Three days later, the transport ties up at Luxor in the late afternoon. As it turns out, they are close to a village called El Wasta. According to Warren Besart, this is the home of people who rescued him, an old woman named Nyiti and her son, Unbar.

      [El Wata is actually much closer to Cairo, but this worked better narratively, especially since I moved the Clive dig from Dhashur to Luxor.]

      Pearkes commandeers some transport--an old British touring car--and they motor off. El Wasta is difficult to find, and the locals give contradictory directions until they finally meet a villager who knows them.

      Pulling up at their hovel, they are greeted by a man whose entire right side has been horribly mangled. Using his most patient tones, Freddie manages to understand Unbar's Arabic (his jaw is in terrible shape.) Unbar says that they were expected, and takes them inside.

      Nyiti is even worse. She has no jaw at all, and is horribly burned and scarred. Both her hands have been cut off. She looks at each of them in turn, finally settling on Charleston. She makes excited sounds.

      "She says you have the eyes of a sorcerer," says Unbar.

      Nyiti pulls a heavy basket out from a corner of the room and hands it to Charleston. A blanket covers the contents; when he pulls it back, he finds a strange symbol combining the eye of Horus with an inverted ankh.

      "What is this?"

      "It positively reeks of magic, Charleston," says Noor.

      They motor back in the desert evening towards Luxor. As they pass through a canyon, Charleston suddenly gets a bad feeling. Senses honed by years of Triad warfare do not fail him--as he pulls into an hand brake spin, shots ring out. The windshield shatters and Wazim groans in pain.

      Another shot rings out, winging Charleston, who grunts and floors it.

      "ABBA!" screams Noor, as she rushes to help the old warrior.

      "No fear," says Charleston. "Remember all life is a lie."

      "I know that, but Daddy!"

      "Relax! I can bring you all back now!"

      They drive away in a cloud of dust. Soon they are back at the hotel in Luxor.

      "I see you have had an accident," says the bellhop.

      "We had a bit of weather," says Charleston. "Lead rain."

      "It is an all too common occurrence around here." He glances at Wazim. "Oh. A Bedouin got shot."

      Freddie hands him some Egyptian pounds. "Perhaps you can say that in a different tone of voice."

      "Oh! A Bedouin got shot!"

      "May I remind you that he is my servant."

      "I will get a doctor."

      Ensconced in a hotel room, being attended by a doctor, Charleston commends Wazim. "You did a great job, bullet sponge."

      Wazim, who is in significant pain, mutters "Remind me to cut you when I feel better."

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 10)

      29 March 1925

      The next day, Freddie, Pearkes, Charleston and Noor motor out to the Clive Expedition dig. Officially the dig is excavating a large temple.

      [Indeed, it's the Temple of Hatshepshut, the female Pharaoh, which was slowly uncovered throughout the 1920s and 1930s. I liked this better than the Dhashur site, and have moved the encounter with the Big N to another area.]

      Surprisingly, the dig area is fenced in, and there are armed guards at the gate. Freddie tries to talk his way past.

      "Sorry, but there is no admittance."

      Pearkes narrows his eyes. By their accent, he knows them to be Boers, probably from the Rhodesian colony.

      "I understand perfectly. Could you do me a favor and deliver my card to Dr. Clive? He did say that we could call on him at any time and I just want him to know we're in the area."

      They motor away from the dig and tour the area, trying to see if there's another way in. There are other active excavations in the region, run by different expeditions; as they pass one such site, an older gentleman steps out of a tent, notices them, and waves.

      Charleston stops the car. "Hello," says Freddie.

      "Howdy," drawls the man. "Can I help you?"

      "You're an American!" says Freddie with delight.

      "Yup. Dr. Abner Ravenwood. I was just going to have some coffee; why don't you come and sit a spell?"

      "Thank you very much!"

      They disembark and enter Dr. Ravenwood's tent. "Marion!" cries the old archaeologist. A woman in her late teens with dark hair enters, carrying a coffee service. "This is my daughter, Marion. I'd introduce you to my post-doc, Henry, but he's out in the field."

      "Ah, Henry Ravenwood?"

      "No, Henry Jones. Although I think maybe one day soon Marion's going to be changing her name to Jones--"

      "Dad!"

      "I'm just saying, you and Hank do get along..."

      "You know he doesn't like to be called--"

      "I say, not Henry Jones, Jr.?" interjects Freddie. "I believe I've heard of his father."

      "Dr. Jones? Yes, Henry's a good friend, I work with him back in Indiana. Good Grail scholar."

      "Well, we must all have a fixation. Personally, I think the Grail is lost forever, although the Germans seem to think they can find it."

      "Ah, that's Wagnerian nonsense. The state of German archaeology has fallen off since Schliemann."

      [FP sussed out who these folks are--Dr. Abner Ravenwood, his daughter Marion Ravenwood, and of course Dr. Henry Jones, Jr., better known as "Indiana." Pulp Fiction, baby!]

      They talk on for a bit. Dr. Ravenwood explains that the Clives have been much more security conscious since the disappearance of the sarcophagus. Ravnewood knew the Carlyle expedition, although he has a low opinion of "that peckerwood" Roger Carlyle; he thought much better of Sir Aubrey, whom he describes as quite an excellent amateur Egyptologist. He also mentions that the Penhew Foundation finances quite a few digs all around the world, although they concentrate on "flashy stuff."

      "Bernie--I can call you Bernie, yes?"

      "Sure. Can I call you Freddie?"

      "Of course! Everyone calls me Freddie."

      "Yes sir, Mr. Blakely. We all do," mutters Charleston.

      "Do you think you could get me up to see Clive?"

      "I suppose so, as a professional courtesy. Ah, here's Henry! He can take you up."

      "Ah, Dr. Jones, I presume!"

      A rather dashing man enters the tent, an old gas mask bag slung over one shoulder. "Who wants to know?"

      Abner introduces them all around, and soon Dr. Jones is leading them up to a side entrance. "I think I know your father," says Freddie brightly.

      "Too bad for you. Dad and I don't get on."

      [I just want to interject that I thought I did a decent Harrison Ford impression here.]

      "Well, Indiana--can I call you Indiana?"

      "Only my friends do. How did you know that, by the way?"

      "Dr. Ravenwood said you were from there."

      "No, Abner's from there. I just like the name. I guess I'll call you England, then."

      They approach a side gate to the Clive dig site. A nervous looking man is standing there, chain-smoking. This turns out to be Dr. James Gardner, who explains that he's a Paleopsychologist, interested in the psyches of past civilizations. Freddie chats him up, and gradually Gardner begins to talk about recent events at the dig.

      [Reassurance buy from Freddie.]

      Pearkes notices that he is armed, although he doesn't strike the Colonel as somebody who knows his way around guns.

      According to Gardner, the sarcophagus they found was positively identified as Nitocris, a fact that Clive immediately concealed. He also says that he thinks it was removed via a secret passage to a space under the Pyramids. "In fact, I think there's a whole hidden city--"

      He abruptly breaks off as an athletic-looking blonde man comes striding down the slope to the gate. "Good afternoon, gentlemen," he says, betraying a German accent.

      "Dr. Johannes Sprech, I presume?" says Freddie.

      "Indeed. Mr. Blakely?"

      "The same. We were just chatting with James here and wondering if we might drop in on old Clivesy. I hear you're doing simply fantastic work out here."

      "Well," says Sprech, obviously flattered, "it is fascinating what we are finding. I can't see any harm in bringing you up to the camp."

      [Flattery buy by FP. He also did a quick CR buy to have some info on Agnes Broadmoor and Martin Winfield.]

      As they climb the hill, Sprech describes his work. "I've always had a facility with codes and ciphers. Since I was a young boy, I have been able to read hieroglyphics on sight. This stood me in good stead during the war, where I had the honor to serve against men such as the Colonel."

      "You fought well," says Pearkes, grudgingly.

      "As did you. The Canadian infantry set a standard for excellence. I enjoyed listening to your coded transmissions on several occasions."

      They come up to the main campsite, which consists of several semi-permanent tents rigged up on platform as well as some shacks for storage. As they enter Clive's headquarters, he and Winfield are poring over a map, which Clive quickly folds up.

      "Why, Freddie, old man! What a surprise to see you down here."

      "Just in the area, old sport, thought I'd drop in to take a look."

      "Of course, of course! You're always welcome. Martin, why don't you show our friends around?"

      Just then an elderly woman in a loose caftan, with a scarf tied around her head enters the tent. She goes up to Winfield. "I had a vision about you, Martin. You were alone, all alone in the darkness!" She suddenly seems to become aware of the strangers in the tent. "Why, Freddie Blakely! It's been a month of Sundays!"

      [FP's spend pays off here; Agnes was a minor sensation during the War, when quite a few spiritualists were in vogue.]

      "I'm surprised you remember me, Mrs. Broadmoor. Was it Elizabeths' where we met?"

      "I believe so. How delightful to see you again. You must let me do a reading for you."

      "Smashing! We're just in town, pop around tonight."

      They spend the rest of the afternoon being guided around the dig carefully by Winfield. Charleston takes several pictures under the ruse of being portraits.

      "ABBA!" screams Noor, as she rushes to help the old warrior.

      "No fear," says Charleston. "Remember all life is a lie."

      "I know that, but Daddy!"

      "Relax! I can bring you all back now!"

      \n FP is an awesome player, no doubt, and one of the most creative people I know at twisting around dilemmas into benefits. (He's also brilliant in real life, a history and linguistics geek and I almost always learn something talking to him.)

      His "Freddie" accent is perfect, BTW; I promise I'll try to get a clip of it up.

      I should note that these write-ups do seem to have Freddie in most of the important conversations. This is a bit of an illusion--CP in particular is also quite vocal (I didn't include his whispered conversation with Noor wherein he proposed sacrificing Marion for a ritual, a suggestion Noor reluctantly turned down)--but FP is the party face and so does the lion's share of interaction. (Also, he's living out his fantasy of being a Wodehouse character, so he's greatly enjoying himself.)

      Recording the session was an awesome idea but it also means I know what all the details are; that's why this is taking so long. And the next session should be this weekend! Yikes!
