      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 11)


      That evening, back at the hotel in Luxor, Agnes Broadmoor arrives. "My dear Mr. Blakely," she says, taking Freddie's hand. "I was to give you this." She hands Freddie a note. "Do not read this unless you are alone," it begins:\n
      Your lives are in danger. Something terrible is going to happen at Giza. The Sphinx knows.

      Meet me at midnight, in the dry wash north of the dig.

      --Gardner
      \nFreddie whispers the contents of the note to the others as they settle down into the seance. "Is there anyone you wish to speak to in particular?" asks Agnes.

      "Roger Carlyle?"

      "I call upon thee, Horus, Anubis, gods of the dead..."

      Her incantation goes on for a while, but then she falters. "I cannot seem to reach him."

      [Dum-duh-DUM! Foreshadowing!]

      "Is there anyone else?" asks Agnes. "I sense a great sadness in you."

      "Well...Miss Jackson Elias. Er, Elisa Olney."

      Agnes begins the incantation again, but this time something changes--about halfway through, she stops, and her eyes roll back into her head.

      "Do not ask me to do such trivial things," she intones. "I am the Gateway. Ask me your questions."

      Charleston watches uncomfortably, recognizing this an actual supernatural event.

      "They are going to raise the Great Evil," continues Broadmoor in a strange, hollow voice.

      "All right, what can we do to prevent it?"

      "The Girdle. The Girdle of Nitocris. It is at the Mosque of Ibn Tulun. They search for it. Broadmoor and Gardner will be killed."

      "She speaks to the Al-Mithal," mutters Wazim. "To the spirit world..."

      "Do you know that mosque?"

      "Yes, it is in Cairo."

      "Damn. Seems a bad idea to go there. Agnes, one last thing: what is it about these serpents who breathe fire? The ones that attacked Nyiti?"

      "They do not breathe fire. Shakhti summoned the fire to attack them."

      "Interesting. Oh, and who is it who possessed our Mrs. Broadmoor?"

      "I AM Agnes Broadmoor," the voice says. Shortly thereafter she snaps out of it.

      "I say, Agnes, it seems the people you are working for are planning to do you in."

      "Oh dear!"

      "I think you should stay with us. Gents, we need to get out of here."

      "We can ride," chime in Pearkes and Wazim.

      "Right, let's get ready..."

      "Gentlemen," says Pearkes. "We have a duty to Dr. Gardner."

      [At this point an incredibly long planning session ensued, with the players actually making things seem much harder. FP assumed that it would be impossible for Gardner to evade Winfield and Sprech. This wasn't completely accurate--he had a plan--but FP managed to argue his point.

      CP was absolutely against the rescue--"This is the sort of thing that ends up with people mowing down other people," he said, mostly in character.

      PP just wanted to ride in, which I supported with the help of Wazim. (When CP objected that he wanted a motorcycle because he couldn't ride, Wazim merely said "It is not your fault you are not a man.")

      I probably should have intervened, but I didn't want to make it look like I was short-circuiting the PCs. OTOH, I could have perhaps interjected that Pearkes didn't think much of the camp's overall security. (CP also kept insisting that they make some kind of plan, although I pointed out that Pearkes was a cavalry officer--"Having no plan IS the plan!")

      I think next time I'll intervene--a gentle "this is an action movie scene" might have done the trick.]

      It takes a while but slowly a plan emerges--Pearkes will ride down to grab Gardner, while Freddie and the Bedouin will lie in wait to ambush anyone following Gardner. Meanwhile, Charleston will ride a motorcycle around the camp, armed with dynamite bombs. The motorcycle is quickly provided by Qusay, following a healthy infusion of cash from Freddie. Charleston, remembering the rumbles he encountered in Chinatown, shakes his head over the recklessness of the plan, but reluctantly comes along.

      As they approach the camp, they see that one of the tents is on fire. Men rush around inside it, trying to put out the blaze. Seizing their chance, the group sprint for the dry wash Gardner told them about. Soon they see him, running with his pistol out, bleeding from one leg.

      Pearkes rears his horse and plunges down the canyon slope in the starlight. Riding at a level gallop, he grabs Gardner and slings him onto the back of his horse.

      "Hurry," gasps the archaeologist. "They're after us."

      Moments later, Sprech and Winfield, on horseback, rush into the canyon. Charleston lights a bomb with the cigar he keeps clenched in his mouth and lets fly. There is a loud report, and the horses throw their riders to the sand. They stagger around clutching their ears. Charleston guns his engine and soon meets up with Pearkes and the rest of the rescue party.

      Gardner climbs into the sidecar of Charleston's motorcycle. "I hope you don't smoke," says Chiu.

      "Hunh? No, I don't," says Gardner, already reaching for his pack.

      Charleston gestures down at Gardner's feet, where several dynamite bombs lie, fuses ready to be lit. The doctor turns pale.

      Grinning, Charleston taps the ash of his cigar to the sand and drives off.



      They are less than an hour from the landing on the river where a rented boat waits for them when a dark shape slides across the stars. A thin wailing seems to come from the sky.

      "Hey Gardner, check out what's making that noise," says Charleston.

      Gardner looks back and begins to scream.

      "Oh, it's you," says Charleston.

      "Incoming," screams Pearkes, sliding his horse around.

      A great winged serpent rushes from the air and races past Wazim. Its tail flicks out and wraps around his neck, hoisting him up in the air.

      Charleston halts the motorcycle and digs out the Al-Azif. Frantically flipping through the pages, he finds an incantation and begins to chant.

      The serpent regards him with baleful eyes.

      Then it blinks.

      Then it bows.

      [OK. This is probably not legal. There's some question as to how you could try to bind a bound Hunting Horror--I have no idea if that's even possible. On the other hand, the Al-Azif has some oomph to it.

      Truth be told, I hadn't run a contest before (I do one later in the session much better), and I'm still picking up the magic rules. So I kind of blew it. However, the thing to do when you mess up, is to make it a plot point--Charleston succeeded here, so       somebody or something helped him. Who? and Why? Play to find out!

      In the future, I think I can grant a pool of magic points granted by the Al-Azif.]

      "Put him down," orders Charleston. He turns to the others. "So, you want to ride back into town in style?"

      "You will all die," says the serpent. At least, that's what Charleston hears; the others hear only a guttural muttering.

      [Either the spell granted Charleston the ability to understand Aklo, or he's picking it up unconsciously.]

      "Who sent you?" asks Charleston.

      "Humans all look alike to me. His title in Aklo is Archaeologist. He had a mustache."

      "Clive," mutters Charleston. "What were you sent to do?"

      "Kill you all. It's generally what I do. The Dark Lord will feast upon your souls."

      "I wouldn't know what that feels like."

      "They say its a peaceful feeling, like an enema."

      "Are you from the Outer Realms?"

      "Do I look like a local?"

      "Say, do you guys explode? Because I saw one like you once who we think exploded..."

      "We don't explode."

      "All right. Go eat Clive, then go to Hell or whatever. Just don't come back to me."

      "I make no promises." The serpent vanishes.

      As they finally crest a ridge and come sight the Nile, the wind carries the faint sound of explosions from the Clive camp. They ride down to the river, where the flickering lights of a steamer wait for them.

      \n I think it'd be legit in Call of Cthulhu to have a POW vs POW if two dueling sorcerers tried to command a creature, bound or not. I mean, even if it's not the way it is in the CoC rulebook, it's a variant I'd never blink at.

      For Trail of Cthulhu, it's an interesting question because it's a game of chicken with a pool of points, and... I'm just not enamored of that, possibly because the non-investigation parts of Gumshoe just never clicked for me.

      \n For sure, Lisa; that's the most likely way it would work. Checking my conversion notes, I see Clive with 10 magic points, which means he'd be down to 1 after the Binding incantation; that's good enough to justify Charleston stealing the critter away, especially since he was using the baddest of bad books to do so.

      I'll have to come up with some kind of pool of magic points for the Al-Azif before the next session.

      In any case, Charleston stealing the Hunting Horror was the most interesting consequence, so I ran with it. Plus it gives the party a false sense of security! Next time, the opposing sorcerer might not be so weak...

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 12)

      30 March 1925

      Charleston finds Noor on the deck of the steamer. The dark waters of the Nile flow past the boat.

      "Hey Noor, leave the desert, come with us. You know too much. We're going to continue to search for more interesting things. I need a partner, I need somebody I can trust..."

      "I don't like the desert!"

      He tells the story of the encounter in the desert with the winged serpent. Noor is impressed. "You spoke Aklo? But how is it you bound this thing?"

      "I don't know, but it obeyed my commands!"

      1 April 1925

      Early in the morning of April 1st they tie up just south of Cairo. Freddie makes some discreet arrangements and soon they are ready to rent a villa to stash Broadmoor and Gardner. As a precaution, they put it in Wazim's name.

      "What? I live in a tent."

      "Well, now you'll own a villa."

      Grumpy at having been corrupted by the Europeans, Wazim stomps off to rest from his recent wounds.

      [This is rather typical of FP's play style--misdirection and avoidance of confrontation are his hallmark. He was already planning to leave Egypt right after they returned from the Clive dig; only Gardner's note, and Pearkes' insistence that they help him, kept them from running.

      Normally I'm happy to reward his cleverness, but it's less optimal for Masks, although I think quite a bit of my reaction is because I have Cool Stuff I want them to see. But on the other hand, if they want a pulp adventure, then they have to respect the conventions and confront evil. Freddie's Drive is Bad Luck, which is not so useful for me; I lack the direct handle other Drives give me.

      OTOH, Bad Luck is the perfect excuse for his plans going awry, as they do in this case. Plus, I don't think FP has quite grasped the Rules of Engagement; it's very difficult, at this point, for them to escape observation by the Cult, even without resorting to supernatural means.]

      The civil unrest in Cairo has burnt down to a simmering resentment by this point--mostly through the crushing application of martial law. The major European powers have cordoned off their section of town and actively patrol it.

      [Not really historical, but I liked having a Boxer rebellion feel.]

      Freddie arranges a meeting with Saad Zaghloul. The would-be Prime Minister is busy but takes time to speak to one of his biggest backers.

      [Credit Rating spend by Freddie.]

      "Saad, old man, I'd like to give you a large donation of British Railway stock. Please feel free to use it to found a fraternal order of your co-religionists."

      "A Brotherhood...of Muslims?"

      "Good name. In return, I'd like an introduction to the Mosque of Ibn Tulun."

      "Oh, the madhouse? I see...you meddle with powerful forces, my friend. But take this to them, they will admit you to those you seek."

      [So in Alt-Earth, Freddie Blakely founded the Muslim Brotherhood. And the short-lived Paris Soviet! I think at some point the Foreign Minister might take note...]

      The Mosque is nearly a thousand years old, its magnificence having faded with the centuries; currently it is being used as an insane asylum. The faint screams of the patients mix with the distant cries of mullahs as they arrive. A young talib takes the note from Saad and then leads them deep beneath the earth.

      They are introduced to an ancient man named Achmed Zehavi. "What can I do for you gentlemen?"

      "We are looking for a belt."

      "There is no belt."

      "A girdle," clarifies Charleston.

      "One that will prevent a great evil from returning," says Freddie.

      "I will show you, the Girdle is in no danger," says Zehavi.

      He leads them to another chamber, one locked behind a heavy iron door. Inside, a strange belt of linked gold chains sits on a pedestal under a crystal cover. The clasp is a single uncut ruby, which seems to pulse and change color as they stare at it.

      Surrounding the Girdle are six ancient men, armed with enormous scimitars. One of the men steps over to meet him. His sword is made of a peculiar gray metal; it is one of those blades that appear so sharp that you fear you will cut your eyes looking at it.

      "I am the Nessim."

      "Nice swords," says Pearkes.

      "This one is particularly special. It is the Sword of Akmallah. It will cut any creature, be they from Heaven or be they from Hell."

      "Ah, like those Irish swords that strike you dead with a single touch," says Freddie.

      "No, no, you have to cut them more than once. But it will cut them."

      The Nessim explains that in order to raise the evil queen, the cult must have the Girdle, Crown, and Necklace; because of this, they have been commanded by Allah to protect the Girdle with the Sword of Akmallah. And as they can see, it is quite safe.

      Of course, Freddie and company disagree--they point out that Cult knows where it is, and that Shakhti can summon a jinn quite capable of tunneling through the earth to the Girdle. Freddie suggest various schemes; he asks if it is possible to modify the Girdle, so that it may be hidden in plain sight.

      "The Girdle does not allow itself to be altered," says Achmed.

      This throws everyone for a bit of a loop, but Freddie then proposes to copy the Girdle. The Nessim shakes his head. "It would be trivial for the Powers of Darkness to perceive the true Girdle," he says.

      [FP, in his usual rerouting mode; but as this is a Mythos artifact of significant power with a major plot token value, I felt justified in shooting these ideas down. In any case, they would undoubtedly have been tried in the four thousand years the Ulama have been guarding the Girdle.]

      "What should we do, English? Allah tells me to guard the Girdle. What does Allah tell you?"

      "Unfortunately, Allah doesn't talk to me."

      "We share a covenant," says Pearkes.

      "Ah, yes, the Christian god. We understand how that works with you. As People of the Book, it is forbidden to war with you; but you do not subscribe to a similar belief."

      "Technically," says Freddie, "we all share a god. Unless you're a Buddhist or something, Charleston."

      "Oh, I follow a different faith," says Charleston.

      Freddie finally prevails upon them to speak with Saad and move the Girdle around from place to place, so as to hide it from the Cult.

      [FP with a Reassurance buy, I think.

      FP: I like how I keep coming up with mundane solutions for paranormal problems.
      Me: Yes, but those don't always work...]

      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time For Sunrise (Part 13)

      Not content with just moving the Girdle, Charleston begins to research a way to destroy it. He and Noor hit the books.

      Hours later, Freddie finds Charleston, sitting calmly in his room. Scrawled notes line his desk.

      "I say, Charleston old man..."

      Chiu sits there, smiling gently. As Freddie turns to go, he says: "It's very easy."

      "What, old man?"

      "Destroying the girdle. We just need a dagger. A magical dagger."

      "Well, we happen to have one, don't you know!"

      "No, not that one. We must make it. Of a single element. The same kind of dagger as can be used to summon a creature of the outer world."

      "Oh....is that all..."

      "Yes. I can cast the spell. I will, later."

      [Cthulhu Mythos spend by Charleston; no major revelations, so just a 2-point Stability loss. They looked at what kind of metal to use; CP pointed out that Aluminum is Atomic Number 13, so they were interested in that--albeit, Aluminum is very reactive, so that's hard to do.]

      "Great, old sport, I'll work on getting us the dagger."

      "One other thing. We have to kill a human being with the dagger. I'll let you work that out too."

      "I...see. I say old man, is there any way we could just hide the Girdle? Conceal it from the Powers and that sort of thing?"

      "I will see if I can find out. Come back later."

      [Not verbatim conversation, but in the spirit of CPs description. This spend was a bit troubling to me. It seemed clear to me that this question could reveal that Nyarlathotep is planning to essentially wreck the planet, and that everything Charleston believes to be true is only the tiniest piece of the real world. As one of Charleston's Pillars is "Belief in Science," this could be a Pillar-shattering moment that would cause his Sanity to circle the drain.

      I dithered for a while, but decided it was too early to blast him out of the water, so charged 4 Stability and 1 Sanity. In any case, as far as Charleston is concerned, this       is science.]

      Later, Freddie drops in again. Charleston is sitting facing the wall, gently smiling.

      "Any luck, old man?"

      "The great god Nyarlat-hotep is behind it all. He sees All, knows All. You cannot hide the Girdle from him, if he so wishes. Eventually he will devour our souls. What is for dinner?"

      "Uh...Beef Wellington, I think."

      "Excellent."

      2 April 1925

      The next day, Freddie, Charleston and Pearkes head out to get a dagger made. Freddie finds a silversmith.

      "What you ask, it makes no sense. It will tarnish if I make it of pure silver, and cannot hold an edge."

      "It won't need an edge," says Charleston. "The knife is not what cuts."

      "Look, old man, it's crucial we get this. Can you do it?"

      "Come back in a week."

      "Let me emphasize how urgent it is," says Freddie, handing over a bushel of Egyptian pounds.

      "Come back tomorrow."

      To throw off the scent, Freddie stops in different stores, ordering forks and other utensils of silver, Egyptian pottery plates and crocks, and other dinner service items. Finally, he stops at a clothmakers and orders a banner with the sigil of Shakhti Bey's family.

      "I will not make such a thing," says the shopkeeper. "And I will not do business with one who asks."

      Soon Freddie discovers that nobody in the bazaar will sell him anything anymore. He heads back to the hotel. Soon they realize they are being followed by people wearing the Cult emblem.

      Freddie passes out some coins to the local urchins. "Throw these at the feet of these men following us. Do this until you run out or they stop following us."

      Sure enough, scattering money at the feet of ruffians causes some to stop, and others to be mobbed by beggars. Whistling nonchalantly, Freddie and company head back to the hotel. Along the way, however, Freddie notices that several small children have begun to follow them.

      Somewhat disturbed by this sign of a powers battle, he arrives at Shepheard's.

      "Ah, Mr. Blakely. We missed you. Of course, we kept your rooms and billed you for them."

      "Very well!"

      As he walks into the bar, Freddie finds Shakhti standing there.

      "Shakhti Bey!"

      "Mr. Blakely. Shall we step outside?"

      As they reach the terrace, Freddie says, "So Shakhti Bey, did you know that Dr. Clive is in the most interesting sort of business."

      "Really? I am not surprised. He sends his regards, by the way."

      "Oh, so he does work for you."

      "Not at all, I merely help coordinate things for him. He wired me from the dig yesterday."

      [Oddly enough, FP thought they weren't working together and was planning his usual tactic of setting his enemies upon each other.]

      "Too bad. I was rather hoping he'd develop a headache."

      "No, he is quite good at keeping his head."

      "As are others," says Pearkes, knowingly.

      "And this must be Mr. Chiu," says Shakhti.

      "Must it?"

      "I am sorry you were indisposed when you visited us. It is a terribly feeling, not being disposed of."

      "Shakhti old man, you wouldn't happen to know anything about a mummy of Nitocris that was discovered?"

      "Nitocris is an ancient legend."

      "Well, sir, you are an Egyptian historian."

      "Or Egyptian history," says Pearkes.

      "Ah. If we are to drop pretense, I did not get along well with Nitocris. She was an alien and not even Egyptian. Of course, neither am I, but I have lived here for millennia."

      "Well...I suppose my only question is, why? How do you keep interest?"

      "I have a role to play."

      "Well, I'm barely thirty and I'm usually bored to death."

      "That is because you do not perceive, sir. I see a larger world than you."

      "Well, why come to us?"

      "I just wanted you to know that you cannot possibly win."

      "I assure you, I really do not know what is going on."

      "I begin to suspect that, yes. However, I will give you this last chance. Leave Egypt."

      "We were planning to do so. Could you do me the smallest favor?"

      "Probably not."

      "Could you give us safe passage to the Canal."

      "Ah, do you bargain with your god, Mr. Blakely?"

      "All the time."

      "That is why you fail. Oh, Mr. Chiu, aluminum is very clever. Too bad about the silversmith. His wife will mourn him."

      \n
      \nEpisode IV: Champagne and Battle Cries, Just in Time for Sunrise (Part 14)

      "So much for the dagger," says Charleston after Shakhti leaves.

      "Wait a moment," says Freddie. "Audrey?"

      "Yes, Mr. Blakely?" says Sheila.

      "Did we bring that silver? The wedding set I had made up for when I was going to marry Miss Elias? The one that was pure silver?"

      Put out, Sheila leaves and returns with a battered box. "Here you are, sir," she says coldly.

      [Massive Preparedness buy here by FP.]

      "This work for you, Chuckles?"

      Charleston examines the knife, and finding it workable, he leaves to go begin the spell.

      "Now for the murder," mutters Freddie. "Perhaps one of the guardians will agree to make this sacrifice." He arranges with Saad to set up a meet, and is told to go to one of the markets later that day.

      In the afternoon, Freddie and Pearkes make their way to the tent they were told to go to. Inside, they find one of the Ulama, lying on the floor, a horrible head wound providing clear cause of death.

      A crowd gathers outside.

      "You should call the religious authorities. An Ulama has been killed," says Freddie in Arabic.

      "Shakhti...Shakhti..." chants the crowd.

      "Hetep!" says Pearkes imperiously.

      "That's the apostate we were supposed to kill first!" says someone in the crowd. They produce spiked clubs and advance. Pearkes and Freddie take off.

      As Freddie sprints down the alley, Pearkes on his heels, the crowd momentarily is blocked by the narrow space. Pearkes takes advantage of this to roll a grenade he keeps in his satchel at them.

      [Preparedness by PP.]

      Several fall down, but others swarm over them. Pearkes runs out into the marketplace. Freddie has already run far ahead, another band of cultists hot on his trail. As they run, the cultists shout, "Kill him! He raped a girl! Death to the white devil!"

      Freddie yells back at them, in Egyptian Arabic, "They work for the King! They betray you all!"

      Bemused, the onlookers decide not to help either group.

      Pearkes sprints down another alley. He flips a grenade into a flour basket as he tears by. A tremendous explosion knocks him down. Pearkes gets up, dusts himself off, and makes a final sprint and running leap onto a tram that is just leaving its stop. He waves regally at his frustrated pursuers.

      Meanwhile, Freddie dashes down another alley. At one end is a large awning, spread out to block the alleyway. As he burst through it, he discovers that the reason it was rigged like that is to prevent people from running into several large water jugs. With a drunkard's grace honed by years of running from the bobbies, Freddie slides through, tripping on them and knocking them over. He slips, lands on his feet, and keeps running as the cultists slip and flounder through the wet pavement.

      [I'm using the "narrate cool stuff for a point refresh" rule from Night's Black Agents; FP narrated this bit, and it was great.]

      Freddie dashes up to several French Gendarmes guarding the European quarter. "Never been so glad to see a gendarme in my life," he says jauntily, sauntering past them.

      * * *

      Meanwhile, down at a villa on the Nile, James Gardner is working in his upstairs bedroom, resting his wounded leg.

      Downstairs, Agnes Broadmoor is laying out Tarot cards. She crosses the Hanged Man with the Tower.

      "Oh dear," she says. A shadow falls over the table.

      "Hello, Agnes old girl," says Clive.

      Upstairs, Gardner hears the smack of leather on leather. "Took you long enough," he says resignedly, as Winfield steps into the room, slapping his gauntlets together.

      * * *

      "Note for you," says the bartender.

      "Thanks a bunch for taking care of our friends! Very best, Henry Clive" the note reads.

      "Damn," says Freddie.

      Charleston finishes the dagger and begins to clean his Tommy gun. He and Noor discuss their plans, and what spells may help them.

      In his room, Pearkes lies next to his elkhound, MacDonald. He looks at his VC. He'll never get a citation for it, but he thinks attacking the Sphinx will earn him a bar for his medal.

      Freddie sits at the bar, remembering the night Jackson told him she was going to the front.

      "You can't be serious."

      "I am. I want to find out what is going on up there, to find out who I am and what kind of a writer I can be."

      "It's insane!"

      "It's my duty. Don't you believe in anything larger than yourself?"

      Freddie lit a cigarette, then stubbed it out in anger.

      "One other thing," said Jackson. "It will be easier if I have a member of the gentry sign the order."

      "I suppose that's me."

      "Will you do it?"

      Freddie grimaces, remembering that moment. He'd signed, of course. Damnit, maybe Jax was right. Maybe there were bigger things than yourself. He asks Sheila to join him for a bottle.

      "I'm very fond of you, old girl," he says.

      [Final refreshes before the end of the session, and all pretty darn good!]

      \n As far as having a villa and a quick Get Out of Egypt go, I'm totally fine with FP doing that. There's plenty of stuff to see and do elsewhere, and Masks is one of those campaigns where a) you can go back to a place you've visited earlier and b) odds are good no party is going to be able to see everything.

      This won't keep the cultists from being able to track them. In other words, it isn't a Get Out of Plot card. And Freddy's Bad Luck is very, very useful. You don't even need the PCs to make a mistake in trying to stay off the radar; you just need Freddy's Bad Luck. Sure, reward folks with a Stability refresh, maybe an ability refresh or three as well (as you're sweeping up the whole group in Freddy's Bad Luck) -- this won't hurt a thing and will let the group continue on, which is what you probably want.

      Nitocris's Girdle is a tricky call. I like that FP's player is trying solutions that don't involve "and then the PCs loot the place, like they always do, because PCs know best, and everything can be done by PCs, and nothing can be done by NPCs". This is a combination of cleverness and lack of hubris, and one would like to reward it.

      But, as you noted, one doesn't want cultists or protectors being idiots. All of these ideas would have been tried before. And, one also doesn't want the players going, "*Eyeroll* Sigh. No matter what we do, the bad guys will get the thing and resurrect the big bad."

      It's a tricky call. I think what I might do is have the guardians try what Freddy suggested and have it work for a while -- and when it ceases working, then have the last survivor manage to send it off to the PCs. They're not forced into becoming thieves. The good guys aren't being morons. The best bet is to send it far away. Yes, this only buys time, but right now, that's what they need. And, this means you add more bad guys to follow the PCs around, since Freddy's Bad Luck will ensure that the Egyptian Cultists find out about this sooner than one might expect.

      Hm... if there is still stuff in Egypt you want them to see, if the bad guys manage to capture the PCs (I don't know how likely this is -- if it's a thing you want, a) tell the players this is the inevitable "get captured and moved to lair so you can learn bad guy plot and be in position to thwart it" trope, b) give them a seriously good chance to have the PCs escape and do just that, and c) maybe bribe them -- in Fate, I hand out Fate Points for this. In Trail, maybe Refreshes will do the trick. But it's all in keeping with Pulp mode), they can ship them and the Girdle back to Egypt so that the PCs can thwart what needs a-thwarting (or not, depending on how things go) and see more of what you want them to see.

      (Hm. If the PCs fail to thwart Nitocris's resurrection and you don't want to go all Purist, there might be something to be said in having her try to cut deals with them, but that's an odd path for a very, very different day.)

      Mind, given that there are ways to destroy the thing, the guardians do have a certain lack of imagination or information, or both.

      Anyway, it's easy to babble from the outside, where I'm not running it. I'm having a lot of fun hearing about how you're running it. (And tomorrow, I run a CoC adventure from Cubicle 7's Scotland book for my Kerberos Club Fate book -- one of my players explained how one does an instant death attack if one really wants one in Fate.)

      \n I'm hoping "Wow, good!" Lisa :-) In any case, we're all caught up, just in time for Saturday's next session!

      I do appreciate what you wrote. Generally, I reward FPs clever thinking; the history of my Pathfinder game was one of him maneuvering all the NPCs like pawns, and then setting them up for a horrific fall. When we played "Masks" together, he solved the JuJu house problem by having his character, a mob hitman, drop in on the cops and use his contacts with them to get them to raid the place. The Keeper rewarded his cleverness, as he should have. (I might have been a bit crueler and not handed over the Mask of Hyama etc., but I'm a bit more genre-aware.)

      In this case, however, the solutions ran smack into the problem of dealing with the supernatural in any Cthulhu game--it's hard to do, unless you use the supernatural against it. There's essentially no way to conceal the Girdle that a clued in cultist (or ultimately Shakhti) can't see through. His plan of moving things around was the best option, and I didn't give them too hard a time on making the means to destroy it.

      I'll admit, I do want the bang of having them at the resurrection scene. It's a great moment, and I have some major reboot stuff in it. (Plus it serves as the gateway to some of my own content, and I'd like them to get there.) I've basically got that scenario, but I'm going to give them a bone or two for being clever. I haven't said how many of the Ulama are dead, and the Sword of Akmallah is still out there--I plan to give them an opportunity to have it.

      As for the snatch of Broadmoor and Gardner, well, if I want the rez scene, I need them in Shakhti's hands. Some good plot will come out of it (basically, the lead to the Sword), so it wasn't a complete failure. I mostly wanted to use it as another example of something I'd been trying to get over to them: things are different when viewpoint characters are involved. If one of the PCs had been at the villa, I would have given them a real chance to escape with B & G, or even just whack the oppo. What I emphatically DON'T want them to do is to rely on offscreen help to handle their crises. This game must, in my opinion, be about sacrifice--about the price you're willing to pay to save the world--and that involves some real hard choices.

      I'm of course not claiming this as original--it lies at the heart of all fiction, but especially American pulp fiction. Ken Hite very brilliantly caught this in his essay "The Man Who Shot Joseph Curwen", but you can see it any genre. What are the Chandler novels if not the tale of a man who gives up his own happiness and satisfaction in pursuit of truth and idealism? As cynical as Marlowe claims to be, he clearly sacrifices connection to get the truth. (It goes deeper, of course--part of his problem is his fear of the weakness that he finds in connection--but it's still mostly the story of the man who puts himself outside the normal world in order to win Truth.)

      And from a practical viewpoint, it simulates the power of the Cult. They can be everywhere at once, and are more than capable of dealing with ordinary opponents.

      I found what you wrote about Freddie's Luck to be really, really useful. The main issue I've had with Bad Luck as a drive is that I a) can't use it as a handle and b) it doesn't give the player a lot of choice. I basically have to hose Freddie from time to time, and that feels like it is just going to frustrate a player like FP, who needs to feel like his plans work.

      What I'm thinking of doing is to use Bad Luck more like a standard Drive. So what I might do is offer a bit of a *World kind of option for Freddie. When I think one of his ideas is a significant plot point, I'll offer him a choice, something like:

      --The plan fails (minor Stability refresh)
      --The plan partially succeeds (Stability LOSS)
      --The plan succeeds, but there are major consequences (minor stability loss or even a stability refresh)

      ...and then use some moves. (Maybe, 1 move and 1-point of Stability refresh? 2 Moves and 2 points? Or 2 point loss and one move, or 4 point loss and no move?)

      I'll have to see how it plays out, but I think it will work--will preserve some player autonomy without allowing FP to simply outflank everything. And it will reward creativity. I hope.

      Thanks much for the commentary, Lisa. I'll have to really think hard about it. I'm finding fighting my own storyTELLER feelings to be one of the harder parts of GMing this...

      --The PCs finally go to an insane asylum

      --Charleston sells his soul to the Dark Powers

      --An unexpected friend drops by

      --Live from the end of the world....it's...Ny---arrrrr--laaaat--hotep!

      --To your scattered fictions, go!

      Not as good as an outline, but a start...

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 1)

      2 April 1925

      While they wait to pointlessly sacrifice their life, Alphonse and Anton hear a huge commotion up front. Billy, shouting in Pashto, hobbles into the bar with Wazim slung over his shoulder.

      "Freddie...they have taken the woman and the useless archaeologist."

      "Who?"

      "The Clives. Qusay fought them off and allowed us to escape. But I heard them. They said the Nessim was at the Mosque of Ibn Tulun. And they were going to send the wives."

      "I know who the wives are," says Billy in a disconcertingly bright tone. "They're Shakhti Bey's wives. Not very nice people at all."

      "I think I know who to ask about this," says Freddie. He heads upstairs to Dr. Mwimbe's room. "Wife? Are you in?"

      There is a crash, and then Mwimbe cracks the door. "We are not married yet."

      "Well, just trying to keep up appearances."

      "I am keeping up appearances, Mr. Blakely."

      [FP wondered about using Dr. M as a Source here. I had to remind him that since nobody wanted to use the old system (ahem), I had streamlined it.]

      "What do you know about Shakhti Bey's wives?"

      "Can we talk somewhere else?"

      "Of course! We are married."

      In Freddie's room, Mwimbe addresses Freddie and company. "They are not just his wives. They are also his children, if you understand."

      "Ah, they are bloodsucking vampires like him."

      "He is not a bloodsucker, although they are. Shakhti promotes women who interest him to wife, and gives them great power."

      "Mwimbe, Shakhti didn't promote you, did he?"

      "No. They did not try to marry me."

      "Ah, they tried to eat you."

      "It was...a dark time."

      "That's very mysterious."

      "I'm very mysterious, Mr. Blakely."

      [Verbatim exchange.]

      "I'd thought you academic types would be more freely disseminating of information."

      "Have you read your Wittgenstein, Mr. Blakely? 'That which we cannot speak of we must pass over in silence.'"

      [There followed, IRL, a ten minute discussion of Wittgenstein (FP finds him derivative), Russell (FP doesn't have a high opinion) Rousseau (anybody surprised PP isn't a fan?) and my own defense of the French Revolution. Immersion be damned.]

      The group prepares to make their assault on the Mosque. Theorizing that wolfsbane may serve as an anti-vampiric agent, Freddie drops in on a German pharmacy. They're all out.

      [FP failed the roll, but I thought I might throw in some consequences.]

      Informed by Gilbert that they're trying to kill vampires, the pharmacist calmly points out that a stake of ash is more traditional and sends them to his brother's wife's cousin, who owns a high-end carpentry store. There they acquire some ash stakes. Meanwhile Freddie picks up a "souvenir" scimitar and a sawed-off shotgun from Anton's more disreputable friends.

      They arrive at the mosque at sundown. It is a Thursday, so except for the call to prayer, many of the stores are shut for the weekend. The many pillars of the mosque cast blue-black shadows in the red rays of the setting sun.

      [FP: Perfect time to go vampire hunting!
      Me: Yes, strange how that worked out.]

      A young Taleb meets them at the entrance to the sanctuary. The dim sounds of inmates screaming mix with the calls of the muezzins.

      "What ho, young student."

      Without looking up from his Qaran, the student says with a resigned air, "Visiting hours end at sundown."

      "Well, it's not sundown yet."

      "Ah, you speak the language of the Prophet."

      "We're here to learn about your religion. I'm tired of being an apostate."

      "Come by tomorrow for lessons."

      "Was hoping to pray tonight."

      He heaves a sigh. "Very well."

      As they enter the sanctuary, Freddie asks about the Nessim.

      "I do not know what you mean."

      "Well, we think the wives of a certain gentleman are after him."

      "Women are not allowed."

      "They don't tend to ask for permission."

      "You speak in riddles. Can you not speak plainly?"

      "Yes. They're vampires, and the wives of Shakhti Bey."

      "Shakhti Bey is a powerful man and a bad Muslim, but vampires do not exist."

      "Well, they certainly think they do!"

      "I must return to my studies."

      "I'll come with you!"

      Pearkes heads upstairs into the asylum area. Carefully searching, he finds a blood trail and marks it. He turns to head back to the sanctuary.

      [Outdoorsman spend by PP]

      Billy is nervous. "Billy don't like this. Billy was in a madhouse once. Lost his head."

      Freddie is sitting with the Taleb, annoying him, when a knock comes on the door. "I must get rid of this pest," says the young man. Freddie tags along with him.

      The student opens the door. "The mosque is--"

      A shotgun blast drops him.

      Freddie snaps up his sawed-off and shoots off both barrels, sawing the gunman in half. Two men with pistols drawn are standing behind him. "It's Blakely! Kill him!" they shout in Arabic. He slams the door shut and latches it.

      Gilbert heads towards the front, slamming hard into Freddie, who is dashing into the sanctuary while staring back at the entrance. Gilbert's gun goes flying. As he stands up, he hears an unearthly singing.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 2)

      Upstairs, Pearkes hears a woman's voice. He recognizes it immediately: his fiancee Constance.

      He finds her chained to the wall in a cell. "Billy, what do you see."

      "Pretty white lady. Got black hair..."

      "Help me, George! They took me! They said something about Jackson! Help!"

      Billy quickly unlocks her, and Pearkes embraces her.

      "Don't worry. We'll get out of here."

      Down in the sanctuary, Freddie hears the singing too now. Gilbert sidles towards what he thinks is the source. Suddenly he stops.

      His gun comes up as he turns to face Freddie.

      Blakely dives behind a column, as Gilbert shoots at him.

      "Of course, Gilbert," purrs a feminine voice in the Frenchman's ear, "you must kill him. He is against our Love."

      As Pearkes, Constance, and Billy head towards the stairs, he sees four or five men with rifles, wearing inverted ankh necklaces, coming towards them. Pearkes fishes his last grenade out of his pack and flips it at them. Several drop, but the rest continue to rush up the stairs. Pearkes gathers his charges and heads the other way.

      "Billy's excited, sir! This is just like fighting in Iraq!"



      Down in the sanctuary, Freddie calls out: "Alphonse, can you hear me?"

      "Yes. Yes I can."

      "Could you shoot that singer, not me?"

      "No, Alphonse," whispers the voice. "That would be against our Love."

      "Really, Gilbert, a man like you? A Soviet commissar? Helping a monarchist?"

      Gilbert fires. "That's why I have shoot the capitalist!"

      "All we be equal and shared in our love, Alphonse! Now kill him!"

      Pearkes leads his group into a room that is clearly a holding chamber for some of the asylum's more unfortunate charges. They babble to themselves from the wall where they are chained.

      As they try to dash for the door, the chains suddenly all fall off. All the inmates suddenly look, in unison, at them.

      "Shakhti...Shakhti..." they chant.

      In front of the door, a figure drops from the ceiling to the floor.

      [At this point I gave PP a point of Stability for defending his fiancee, and for being a good sport about the inevitable reveal.]


      "Bertie!" calls out Freddie. "Would you like a raise?"

      Gilbert shoots the pillar again, then pauses to reload.

      [Both FP and GP were trying to figure out ways to break the spell. FP threw out a Bargain attempt here, but no go. I ruled that anything GP did to resist would be a Hard Driver--he could do it, but it would be an effort. He went for it here to try and break the spell, but preceded to blow the roll. I warned that eventually it would be a Hard Driver to resist the command to use Firearms spends.]

      Freddie squints through the gloom. He thinks he sees, perched up on the pulpit, a beautiful woman with pale skin--Turkish, or maybe Circassian. The way she sits on the pulpit--crouched forward, like a gargoyle--disturbs Blakely, but he decides to take advantage of Gilbert reloading to sneak closer to her.

      Gilbert tries to resist the unrelenting command to shoot his boss, but the unearthly singing continues to sap his will.



      Upstairs, Pearkes confronts one of the wives. "I'm just here for my fiancee. I have no quarrel with you."

      "I have no quarrel with you either. So I just think I'll kill you."

      "Couldn't we just call it a draw?"

      "I tell you what. You have a point."

      She throws a dagger at Constance's heart. Pearkes twists himself over, but fails to block it. Constance slumps to the floor.

      [Athletics contest vs Al-Lamia, Shakhti's wife. And also a Stability check.]

      The inmates pounce on Billy as he tries to flee. There is a flash of steel, and his kukri begins chopping at the limbs holding him down.

      Pearkes dashes at her, drawing his sword as he does, and slashes at her throat. The vampire moves incredibly quickly, trying to block his sword, but his blow slashes right through her wrist, severing her hand.

      "That hurt," she growls. "My turn."

      She picks Pearkes up and throws him against the wall.

      [I'm using the NBA critical hit rules, and I gave PP a refresh to weapons for the cool visuals.]


      Downstairs, Freddie lets both barrels off against Aaliyat, the vampire. He blows her off her perch.

      Gilbert blinks. "Our Love abides," rasps the woman. "Slay Blakely."

      Desperate, Freddie remembers the picture Gilbert keeps of him and his comrades from the Paris Soviet, the one he takes out and fingers sometimes.

      [We found Gilbert's Symbol! "Le Sovi\xe8te du Paris, Novembre 1918" I had ruled in the past that refreshing Stability gives at least a chance to break a domination.]

      Freddie begins to sing, in broken French, the Internationale.

      [I couldn't resist singing most of it; I know it in French, but not English.]

      As Freddie reaches the chorus, Gilbert's eyes fill with tears. He fishes out his photograph and unfolds it with trembling fingers.\n
      C'est la lutte finale
      Groupons-nous et demain:
      L'Internationale
      Sera le genre humain!
      \n[Refresh accomplished! New Stability check. GP spent himself below zero, and got exactly what he needed; Aaliyat was out of magic points.]

      Gilbert sprints forward suddenly. He grabs the woman's arm just as she, with unearthly grace, flips up in the air from a supine position. As she flips around, he jams his shotgun at just the right angle--the one he honed during his year with the Soviet commisariat--and fires both barrels at her neck.

      Her head flies off and she collapses. Blood drenches Alphonse.

      [Athletics spend, Scuffling roll, Forensics spend to get a bonus on the Firearms roll. Then he did boxcars for damage. And critted.]

      Freddie embraces Gilbert, who continues to fire his now empty shotgun.

      [Five point Stability test for the encounter. GP failed that roll too, and got Blasted.]

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 3)


      Pearkes struggles to his feet. Faster than his eye can follow, Al-Lamia is by his side. She flips him over her head and across the room. As he rolls over her head, Pearkes slashes out but she simply moves out of the way with blinding speed.

      She yawns. "You English are so boring."

      Billy, covered with gore, continues to make quick work of the pile of inmates on top of him.

      [I generally don't bother running combat for NPCs and just narrate it; in this case, the inmates were all Health 0 and as cracked as Billy is, he's more than their match.]

      Pearkes rolls over and draws his pistols. Standing up, he marches towards Al-Lamia, firing continuously. She rocks back as the Colts bark out, but continues to walk towards him.

      "That was uncivil," she says, knocking the pistols out of his hand. "Look into my eyes."

      Pearkes stiffens, his will sapped.

      "Sister, shall we feast?"

      Constance rises up behind him. "Don't worry, George. We'll live forever, together."

      Pearkes embraces her. She begins to feed on his neck.

      "Get back," snarls Al-Lamia. "I want to drink."

      "He's mine," says Constance. "My husband."

      They begin to fight.


      Billy comes downstairs. He laughs maniacally, while muttering in Pashto.

      "Billy, stay here with Gilbert."

      Billy eyes Alphonse with a demoniacal glint in his eye.

      "No! Keep any women from coming. Gilbert..."

      "Hrum?"

      "Comrade Gilbert!"

      "Yes!"

      "Stay here with Billy." Freddie turns to the stairs.

      Gilbert follows. "I'm Billy," cackles Billy, and follows them as well.


      Freddie steps into the hall. He sees a one-handed woman fighting with another woman, who does not look like Constance. He shoots the one-handed woman, and drops her to the floor.

      "George, he killed our sister! Kill him!"

      "...you don't have a sister!"

      [Made this a Hard Driver as well: do what "Constance" said and gain 2 points, or don't and lose 4 points. Either would have been in character, but losing points would have Blasted him, so he went for obedience.]

      Freddie chops off Al-Lamia's head. Pearkes raises his own sword.

      Billy vanishes again.

      Gilbert clubs his gun and rushes Pearkes, who he sees attacking his boss.

      [Blasted Stability forced flight or fight; Pearkes was the obvious threat.]

      Pearkes swings at Freddie, and then falls unconscious.

      "Hello," says Freddie.

      "Look into my eyes."

      "No thanks. Mwimbe has spoken quite highly of you, and warned me."

      Faster than the eye can track, she is next to Freddie. "Tell the doctor I said hi," she says, and throws him across the room.

      Gilbert draws a stake and begins to slowly walk up behind her.

      "You know my dear," says Freddie through bloody lips, "you're really quite beautiful. I can see why you're Shakhti Bey's favorite."

      "Well, I'm certain I'm his favorite now."

      "Yes, that Turkish girl didn't have anything on you."

      She shrugs, and slams his head into the wall. "Father can always make more wives."

      "Yes, well, this is a real opportunity for you. I'd be entirely delight to speak with the Bey. I understand that he's focused entirely on Egypt. I do have contacts..."

      "Egypt is where the Dark God has assigned us. But I agree with you, Mr. Blakely. We could use a new ally."

      And she bites his neck deeply.

      [Flattery spend by FP; it did allow Gilbert to get up behind her.]

      Gilbert jams the stake into her heart. She shrieks, and then turns around.

      "That hurt. But I am not European!" she hisses.

      Freddie staggers up, and slams his stake into her. She hisses, falls down, and dessicates before their eyes.

      [Health spend by FP to keep conscious.]

      Freddie cuts her head off. "Bertie?"

      "Blarrrgh?"

      "Right. I'll just bandage my own wounds."

      Soon the sound of people speaking French and English comes up the stairs. Freddie drags Gilbert, Billy, and Pearkes into a cell, and closes it behind them. French military police, led by a British lieutenant, find them.

      "I say, you're jolly well covered in blood!"

      "It seems some crazy women got in here and began attacking people with knives..."


      As the MPs sort things out, Pearkes asks Freddie, "Where's Constance?"

      "She went back to the hotel old man. Did you find anything up here?"

      "Oh yes. Do you think she's all right?"

      "Right as rain."

      They find the blood trail again. In a cell, the door slightly ajar behind him, they find the Nessim, bleeding heavily.

      "You were right, Mr. Blakely. They took the Girdle and killed the Ulamma. I will join them soon in Paradise."

      He hands Freddie the Sword of Akmallah. Freddie holds it limply in one hand and gives it to the Colonel.

      The Nessim grasps Pearkes' hand. "Beware. The sword has only one edge, but it cuts both ways. The sword cuts in the direction of its owner. Be very sure of what you are cutting."

      Pearkes buckles on the sword.

      "I'm sorry, Freddie. I'm very tired now. I think I will sleep."

      Blakely closes his eyes as the Nessim breathes his last.


      At Shepheard's, Lord Allensby meets them "Well, Pearkes, this is pretty much a disaster."

      "I should think so," says Freddie. "Cults running around Cairo!"

      "I don't know anything about that, old man, and if you were smart you wouldn't either."

      Pearkes convinces the front desk to put a call in to Montreal, where Constance is staying with the wife of another officer on overseas duty. He sinks into his bed with relief after speaking with her.

      At midnight, while Alphonse and Anton are drinking wine and winning money from the other guests in a fixed game of poker, there is a tremendous row outside. "Blakely!"

      Freddie finds Shakhti Bey being held back by MPs. "You think you can take something from me? I will take something from you. You have made a mistake tonight. Before, we were two players at the chessboard. Now, it is personal."

      As he leaves, Freddie mutters "I thought it was already personal. Ponce."

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 4)

      Friday, 3 April 1925

      A loud shriek rouses Freddie from his drunken slumber the next morning. He rushes to Noor's room. Inside, Dr. Mwimbe knocks an antique oil lamp to the floor and covers it with a blanket.

      "Foolish girl!" she hisses. Noor lies mumbling on the floor. "She has lit the Oil of Alhazrad," says Mwimbe. "It gives visions..."

      Noor sits up. Her eyes are spinning aimlessly. "Nyarlathotep," she intones. "The Black Pharaoh. The Bloated Woman..."

      She sits for some time, reciting hundreds and hundreds of words--names?--before finishing, over an hour later.

      "Yog-Sothoth. Yog-Sothoth! YOG-SOTHOTH! AZATHOTH!" She collapses into Freddie's arms.

      After some mint tea to brace her, she says what she saw in her vision. In two days, the star Algol--al-Ghul, the Ghoul's Head--will be in the correct position. Then the ritual will happen at the Sphinx. She saw a stele in her vision, near the Sphinx, that somehow leads to the city beneath the sands.



      "Sheila!"

      "Yes, Freddie? I mean, Mr. Blakely?"

      "I have a sneaking suspicion that Shakhti Bey wants to kill you. I think the thing to do is that you should spend as much time with me as possible. At least that way I'll be there to die heroically trying to save you."

      Sheila mists up. "I...I think I'd like that Freddie. I didn't know you cared about me like that."

      "Well, you're the only one who's stayed with me--most people have run off, or are like Pearkes. I mean, the three people closest to me are a French psychopath, a Chinese sociopath, and you. You're the only one who isn't...violent."



      Colonel Pearkes pays a visit to the fort to speak with Lord Protector Allensby. "What is it this time, Pearkes? We've got a bloody riot all through the old city."

      "We'll have another riot if you don't send troops to the Sphinx."

      "Old man, let's talk. You were a good commander in the war, but I don't think you're all there anymore. You were in a bit of a tiff at Shakhti Bey's, last night we found you covered with blood in an insane asylum, and then there was that riot in Alexandria. I've seen it happen, men come back from the front and they're fine for years, but slowly they just...slip. I mean, I still have nightmares about Iraq, and look at Lawrence--fine soldier then, now a total crackup! Have you heard the latest? He wants to drive a tank!"

      "Just give me two platoons."

      "With the city in riot? I can send you a squad with Enfields. Eight rather jolly fellows, just the thing."

      "Couldn't you send a machine gun car?"

      "To an antiquities site? Really old man, really. You can requisition anything reasonable from the motor pool. Now one other thing. This Blakely fellow--I'm afraid the Foreign Office is very interested in this man. Seems he's making a habit of bankrolling revolutionaries and enemies of the Crown. Spending time with Blakely may be deleterious to your career. There are plenty of officers on the inactive list, after all."

      [Bureaucracy spend by Pearkes, and not a bad idea although I gave him a bit of a hard time. I had decided before hand that I wasn't going to get in the way of PP drawing upon British military resources; he has the Credit Rating, and it's in his character concept. Plus, I felt I had neutered him a bit before, and the Alexandria incident was a GMing low on my part.

      That said, I had to tread a fine line here, although maybe I should have just given him the two platoons and seen what happened, after charging an appropriate amount. Of course, what is an appropriate amount for pushing other PCs out of the spotlight? I'm not sure. If we had been closer to the final bit of the Cairo arc, I probably should have handed over the soldiers; but as it was, I think it wasn't genre-appropriate at this beat.]

      Pearkes makes sure to requisition sabers for his soldiers, although they are puzzled about why they need a "wrist-breaker."


      Back at the hotel, Gilbert gets a hypnotherapy session from Dr. Mwimbe which leaves him feeling great.

      [Eight-point psychoanalysis spend by Mwimbe.]

      While Pearkes rests (except for breaking up fights between Billy and the other soldiers), Freddie heads to the embassy, where he is ushered in to the Ambassador.

      "Rummy!"

      "Why, Roly-Poly, how are you! What can I do for you?"

      [CR spend by FP to make the Ambassador another Oxford man.]

      "I'd like to speak to your...your man of intelligence affairs..."

      "Ah, the spook! I can do that for you. However, I've received this strange notice from the Foreign Office--detain in country, do not allow to pass, all kinds of rubbish."

      "Do you know Shakhti Bey? I think he's pulling strings."

      "Impossible. It says something about you meddling in Egyptian politics. I'm going to tell them that Freddie couldn't meddle with his socks without a servant. Though you should stay out of politics, you know."

      The intelligence attache proves to be one of those ramrod-straight, bloodlessly competent British officers. "What ho, Colonel!" says Freddie. "Shakhti Bey wants to kill me because I killed his wives."

      "You shouldn't have killed his wives then."

      "Well, he sent them to kill me! They're some kind of extra-dimensional killers! My God, man, aren't you the spy? Don't you know what's going on around here?"

      "I am in charge of maintaining Imperial secrets, and what I know or don't know doesn't concern you."

      "Well, what should I do about Shakhti?"

      "My normal advice to Europeans who want to interact with Shakhti is to not interact with Shakhti. And in your case, if you go poking an anthill, it is best not to coat your arm in honey."

      "Well, that's why I came to the types who can hire an anteater! So where's your anteater?"

      "Our resources are rather strained."

      "Well, howabout just letting me out of the bally country?"

      "Ah, yes, that. It seems you're an intimate with Saad Zaghloul, who is opposed to our interests here. And you have a history of sympathy to Red causes. However, I can't but admit that many parties will be happy to see you leave Egypt. So keep your nose clean and I'll see what I can do..."

      "Well, dash it all, you lot should really stop giving me contradictory orders! I mean, really, ask your superiors!"

      Freddie leaves the Colonel bemused, happy that he may have succeeded in getting M's attention.



      They prepare. Pearkes tests the Sword of Akmallah and discovers that it slices through bricks like reeds. Freddie finds himself disturbed by how obsessed Pearkes is getting with the weapon. Alphonse uses his contacts to get some firebombs. The soldiers amuse themselves while on guard duty.

      Sunday, 5 April 1925

      They motor out to the Sphinx. The local security patrol tries to keep them away but Pearkes waves them away. Nestled between the paws of the Sphinx they find the stele that Noor told them about, but Mwimbe's translation of the inscription leaves them unenlightened.

      [With CP late, nobody had Cthulhu Mythos, and if Mwimbe noticed the incantation that activates the magic gate she didn't tell them.]

      Gilbert searches around for evidence. He can tell that there have been gatherings here in the past, and he doubts that they are tourists. He seems to be able to make out a faint trail leading to some nearby ruins. With no other lead to go on, they drive out them. In the foundation of one of them, they find a stone slab that looks like it has been moved.

      "Should we open it? We ain't supposed to mess with the antiquities," says the squad's corporal.

      Gilbert gestures with his cigarette for them to lift the slab.

      Beneath it, a narrow stair leads down into the earth.

      "Any volunteers?" asks Pearkes.
      \n

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 5)

      "Now sir," says the squad's corporal, "I was an infantry officer on the Western Front--"

      "An officer?"

      "Yes sir, got demobbed and reupped, but there ain't much call for first lieutenants what got a battlefield commission. And what I learned, sir, was that there are times to advance, and times to sit in a ditch trying to keep from having your head blown off. And this is a ditch time, sir. Proper ditch time!"

      Pearkes insists. After a last cigarette, the soldiers take a pistol each from Gilbert for close quarters fighting. One private elbows another. "I told you this would be a bleeding bug hunt."

      They descend the stairs fifty or sixty feet at least down into the earth. They find a constricted tunnel that slopes gradually down. After a while, they reach an intersection. One passage slopes up, while the main passage continues down. Pearkes, studying the ground, determines that something heavy has been dragged down the upward-sloping passage and down through the main tunnel. They follow the trail.

      [I actually did roll out a few of the random encounters on the list, but they proved to be as boring as I feared they would be, so I won't waste your time relating them.]

      The main passage eventually opens out and a monumental staircase of glistening black marble leads down to a pair of enormous ebony doors. Seven wooden statues, carved to resemble the traditional half-human, half-animal forms, stand alongside the stairs.

      Pearkes begins to descend the stairs, following the drag marks.

      The statues spring from their niches and begin to attack!

      One grabs Gilbert, knocking him down. The wiry Frenchman pulls his sawed off and fires. Bits of the statue fly off--and Gilbert shrieks, as he realizes that they are not statues, but mummies--and not mummies sewn together as a taxidermy project, but the actual mummies of some unknown and long-forgotten race.

      Pearkes draws his pistol and fires into a mummy grappling him, disintegrating it in a shower of dust. Then he unsheathes the mighty Sword of Akmallah. It catches the light eerily as he swings it at two mummies, neatly separating their heads from their necks.

      Freddie fires his sawed off shotgun at a mummy as it bites him. To his left, a hippo-headed monstrosity's fangs slice into Gilbert. The soldiers concentrate their fire on one mummy, destroying it, even as two of their own are ripped to pieces.

      Pearkes slices the head off of another mummy, and the remaining soldiers kill the last one. Freddie gathers their remains and sets them on fire.

      The corporal grabs Pearkes. "Right, none of us signed up for this. It's suicide, and we're leaving."

      Pearkes puts on his iciest stare. "You leave now, and you're finished! I will hunt you down!"

      The soldiers look at one another uneasily. "You can take that colonelcy and jam it up your arse," says the corporal, but three of the soldiers fall out and remain with the group.

      [It didn't seem far-fetched that the soldiers would want to bug out after their first encounter with the supernatural. PP made a 3-point Intimidation buy, so he kept three of them.]

      Freddie pushes the doors open. It is difficult to see inside, but the room is vast, and made out of the same reflective black marble. The walls on either side are so far away that he cannot see them in the light of his torch. Cyclopean pillars hold the vast vault up. Staring at the ceiling, Freddie notices that their tops seem to sway in the wind.

      Far off, they see a dim glimmer of torchlight. As they approach it, they pass some steps that lead down into an unwholesome red light. Beyond that they encounter a black, still reflective pool.

      Gilbert notices that the surface seems to ripple slightly. The pool is alive with leeches. Much to his disgust, he finds a small skiff tethered near some steps leading into the pool. Using the skiff's pole, he discovers that there are shoals of some kind of material in the pool. He prods one with the pole.

      A human skull floats up. The shoals are the bones of the leeches' victims.

      Beyond the pool they find a huge altar of some eerie, alien green stone. A broad walkway leads down from high on one wall to an enormous throne made of the same green stone.

      On top of the altar, they find a sarcophagus. They try to open it with all their might, but the lid stubbornly refuses to move. Pearkes swings the Sword at it, but it is deflected harmlessly away.

      [I was a bit railroady in this session, starting with the House Call To Adventure and continuing through the ritual. Folks seemed happy to board the train, but I'm not happy about it. I wish I could say it gets better later...]

      Beyond the altar is an enormous hole in the wall. Pearkes throws a pebble at it but doesn't even hear it hit the ground. Freddie takes one of the fire bombs and uses it to set the leech pool on fire, which has the beneficial effect of illuminating the room; unfortunately, the room fills with a sickening smell.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 6)

      Suddenly they hear the sound of footsteps coming down the stairs, along with voices speaking in Arabic. The group scatters behind pillars as men wearing yellow robes and carrying torches march in. "What a terrible smell," one says. "They must not have taken out the last victim!"

      "Usul probably set him on fire, he likes to do that."

      They seem to be setting up for a large gathering, laying out priestly robes and roping off sections of the hall. "I can't believe we got stuck with this duty," one grouses. "I had to take off work for this ritual!"

      Soon a large crowd of yellow robed cultists have filled the hall, including two high-ranking British officers, Starr and Barret, that Pearkes recognizes. The crowd is tensed up and anticipatory.

      Suddenly, the horrible clangor of drums and trumpets is heard! Shakhti Bey appears at the top of the processional walkway, leading priests of the Cult who bear the Girdle, Crown, and Necklace of Nitocris.

      Next come an honor guard of warriors stripped to the waist. In the middle of them is Broadmoor, clearly drugged to the gills, and Gardner, smoking a cigarette and trying to put on a bold face but clearly terrified. Behind them come the Clive expedition: Henry Clive, wearing the look of a man who has committed to do something but now is clearly over his head; Winfield, grinning like a maniac in anticipation of the evening's blood entertainment; and finally Sprech, his face open in mystic wonder.

      And then, the trumpets blare again! An African woman in regal robes, wearing an Egyptian burial mask, descends the walkway. "M'Weru! M'Weru!" the crowd chants as she takes her place next to the altar.

      Shakhti holds up his arms, as if embracing the moment. "NYAR GASHANNA!"

      As one, the crowd shouts back, "NYAR SHTHANT!"

      Shakhti continues in Arabic: "Tonight we are gathered to bring our Lord one step closer! For tonight, Nitocris will rise! Nyar Gashanna!"

      The soldiers nervously look at Pearkes. "Steady men," he says.

      [Actually, he started with a threat; I tried to remind him that he really needs to start doing this in the fiction, rather than just spending points--I was trying to do some Apocalypse World principles this session, and several times said "If you want to do it, do it." ]

      Shakhti sweeps his hands to one side, and the lid of the sarcophagus falls off. Freddie shakes his head. It was just that easy?

      "Decorate the body," says Shakhti. As the accouterments are fastened to the mummy inside, Sprech injects Broadmoor with another drug.

      "I'm coming...I'm lost in space but I'm coming...I'm close...so close that I can see you! I can see you!"

      Freddie and Gilbert throw their fire bombs at the altar. As flames splash on to the mummy, Broadmoor's voice changes. "Well, what shall I call you now? Gilgamesh? Al-Jiljamish? I know! I'll call you Jilly!"

      Fire erupts around Shakhti as the look on his face changes from triumph to shock. "You never understood, did ya Jilly! Yeah, in Budapest in 1502, that was me projecting my mind forward in time! But the rest was me! You stupid, stupid man!"

      The mummy stands up out of the sarcophagus. "You'll never believe what I put in there," says Broadmoor. "What the hell am I speaking, anyway? English? It's been a long time since I spoke that!"

      Freddie shoots at Winfield. "Master?" he cries, as the mummy--still on fire--begins to attack Shakhti's priests.

      M'Weru begins to laugh uproariously, continuing as she dashes up the processional ramp. Shakhti says some kind of spell on the mummy, which vanishes--only to reappear nearby, attacking.

      Shakhti brings down his hands. Many people in front of him simply drop dead and fall off the processional. Pearkes' soldiers begin firing into the crowd. "Shoot the Europeans first," says Pearkes. They advance in fine form.

      [Someday I'll write about how the Milgram/Stamford Prison Experiment keeps getting repeated in RPGs.]

      As Clive and Sprech sprint away, Freddie and Gilbert dash up to rescue Broadmoor and Gardner. "Not so fast, this time," hisses Shakhti when he sees Freddie. A coruscating beam of black light lances from his hand towards Freddie, who shrieks in agony as he feels himself withering under the spell.

      [Shriveling spell. Shakhti is old school. FP passed it off as "all my baby fat drops off, and my hair gets salt-and-peppered." Which I liked!]

      "You keep swinging, and keep missing, Jilly!" taunts Broadmoor. In the crowd, Charleston drops the hood of his yellow robe and begins to head towards the altar.

      [CP finally arrived, so we wrote him in as having attended the crowd in disguise. Me: "Well, you really did want to see the resurrection ceremony."]

      Freddie hears a pistol cock behind his head. He turns to see Winfield, a gloating look on his face, which slowly changes to one of shock and surprise. He crumples to the ground. Behind him stands Gardner, with a bloody knife in one hand.

      "Let's go," he says.

      "You cannot hid from me, [gender slur]!" shouts Shakhti into the air. "I know where to find you! The City of Pillars cannot hide you forever!" He grabs the sarcophagus lid and crushes the mummy with it. "Come with me," he shouts at his priests, and they run down the stairs into the red light. There is a horrible cry and the head of one of the priests bounces up into the hall.

      "So long, Jilly!" says Broadmoor, and then like a puppet with the strings cut she collapses into Freddie's arms.

      The soldiers lead the charge up the processional bridge. They follow the tunnels back to the entrance in the ruins, blasting anything that gets in their way.

      As Pearkes pulls himself out of the ground, a rifle is cocked in his face. A man wearing a uniform that resembles British battle dress, but with no insignia visible, straightens up. "It's all right, ma'am, it's the Colonel."

      Freddie, Sheila, Gilbert and Charleston are soon standing in the ruins. A small group of soldiers rings a woman in a rather out-of-date white dress, leaning on her parasol. She has a scarf tied tightly around her neck. "Well, Colonel, you seem to have done all right for yourself."

      "Thank you, M."

      "I see you got my message," says Freddie. He hands her the Girdle, Crown and Necklace.

      "These were not as useful for our friends as they thought," says M with a grim satisfaction. "It seems Shakhti knows his next destination--Irem, the lost city."

      "Very good," says Freddie. "Well, I'm sure you can find some other operatives to--"

      "I'm afraid I'll need your help on this, Colonel." Freddie smacks his head.

      [Well, it's a train. But it's a Peace Train, right?]

      "So far you haven't done too badly," continues M, "in that nobody very important is dead."

      "Just where is it we're supposed to go?"

      "The Lost City is supposed to be in the Empty Quarter of Arabia."

      "You want us to go to bally Arabia!"

      "There is a matter of time," says M, opening a pocketwatch.

      "Um, M, you do know I seem to be unable to leave Egypt..." says Freddie.

      "The way we're going, that won't be a problem."

      "I was afraid of that."

      "I think we need to be there in...say, twenty-four hours."

      "How are we going to get there in twenty-four hours?" demands Pearkes.

      * * *

      The unrelenting sun beats down on an arid and rocky mountain range. Below it, the vast desert stretches out to the horizon. A small tan scorpion makes his way along the rocks under the watchful eye of a falcon.

      Suddenly, the bird takes to the air. The scorpion scuttles for a hiding place.

      A thrumming comes from beyond the mountains, growing ever-louder until with a roar an enormous dirigible plunges over them and out across the desert, heading towards a distant destination.

      \n
      \n So a couple of thoughts before I pick up the story again:

      I've expressed some discomfort in my comments with how railroady this session got. I feel fairly bad about this, even though the session as a whole hummed and everyone, me included, enjoyed themselves. And the irony is, I had been reading a lot of stuff on Dungeon/Apocalypse world about letting players control the fiction more! Why, the next bit of the session I barely prepped at all--I went under the idea that I would "draw maps & leave blank spaces" and they would tell me what was on the map.

      But in the end we went with what had basically been in my head about where and what everything is. Plus, I nakedly railroaded them with M showing up.

      So, lessons, maybe learned. One thing that occurred to me after the fact is that when you're dealing with a group like this one, that is used to more traditional GM/player interactions (GM states fact, players react), it's not enough to just ask plenty of questions: you have to structure those questions even more meticulously than you might in a more story-game oriented crowd. And occasionally, at first, I might need to break immersion temporarily in order to get the Players (not the PCs) to work on building the fiction.

      Take Pearkes and the soldiers. If I just say something like, "what do you want?" or even "How many troops does Allenby give you?", the player may respond in a more trad way and go for the most stuff possible--a D&D, "most toys" approach. (I have privately grumbled to myself that the only genre of storytelling where you go from victory to victory and just get better and better without confronting any tough choices is D&D--not all D&D, but it's in the bones so to speak.) But if I had stepped back and said, "Do you, PP, think that Allenby would give you two platoons? You were in the military, does that make sense? If he did, what might he expect? Would he give you any restrictions?" etc.--or even, since I notice that already I'm pruning back his request, something like "What will you do with that many soldiers? How do you plan to use them against the cult? What do you think the cult might do?"--to help the players keep inside the fiction. It's a bit odd, having to think about breaking immersion for the sake of strengthening the fiction; but on the other hand, I've seen that sort of thing happen a lot in Fiasco, at least in the early going, when folks are spitballing.

      Of all the members of the group, FP gets the idea that he can introduce elements into the fiction the most intuitively, and he applies the most social pressure on the other players when they go a bit off-script. PP gets it but still likes to go for the power-play; CP more or less still relies on me to cue things, and GP tends to follow whoever's in the scene with him. This is a good sign, I think; in any case, they are a very good group and we've been playing together (except for GP, who was recruited for this campaign) for almost three years now, so we do tend to know how to work with each other.

      Now back to the session!
