      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 7)

      Monday, 6 April 1925

      A large, fluffy, white cat regards Freddie. "Mee-reow?"

      "Go away, you furry pest." He shudders for a second, then turns back to watch Qusay paint the canvas walls of the dirigible. "M?"

      From the "study", a few rooms away, a woman says in a measured tone, "We will have tea shortly, Mr. Blakely. Please don't bother me til then."

      Freddie shrugs. Across the lounge from him, Dr. Mwimbe and Sheila are chatting; they have grown very tight over the last few days. Another cat walks by, and Freddie wonders just where the crew for the blasted airship is hidden.

      Noor tells Charleston about her lighting of the Oil of Alhazred: "I had a vision! And it helped everyone! Also, I saw the Dark Lord and he threatened to drink my soul!"

      "Let us talk about how we can bend him to our will," whispers Charleston. Freddie shakes his head again, takes out a cigarette, and then remembers at the last second not to light it.

      The fluffy cat walks in, and nods its head--the signal for tea. "You do know you're absolutely terrifying, don't you," says Freddie.

      They sit down around M. "Irem of the Pillars was a legendary city, now only remembered in fragmentary glimpses of the Quran and the 1001 Nights. We do not know where it is, but an explorer recently found a site we call the Nameless City. We believe Irem to be nearby. It is my personal belief that Irem is also closely associated with the City of Brass."

      [If you know your Lovecraft, that's the nutter who found the titular city in "The Nameless City."

      In prepping the campaign, I came across the story of the City of Brass in the 1001 Nights--and that sucker's practically a Cthulhu story, what with the madness and supernatural events.]

      "M, just what do we do?"

      "Simple. Find the city, find the queen, and prevent Shakhti from bending her to his will. As it so happens, we have a weather station in the area, and you can start your search there."

      "I see. M, how can we get in contact with you?"

      "I believe Colonel Pearkes knows the answer to that."

      "She'll be in touch with you," says Pearkes.

      "Precisely. Now, gentlemen, time to hit the silk."

      The dirigible begins to climb.

      "We'll be at jumping altitude shortly," says M.

      "What?" says Freddie. M nods towards a set of parachutes that have been neatly packed against the wall.

      "You want me to jump out of a perfectly good dirigible?" says Freddie.

      "It's perfectly safe."

      "Then you do it!"

      "I have on a number of occasions."

      "No, I mean now!"

      "I'm afraid my business does not lie here. Two minutes, please."

      Later, standing on the gangplank, looking uncomfortable in his harness, Freddie shouts back at M: "Just one question: what in God's name do you have on my Aunts to make me do these things?"

      "You ask the wrong question, Mr. Blakely: it's what do your aunts have on me that you should wonder. Adieu."

      They tumble through space. As he drifts down, Freddie spies some smoke coming from the hills to the north. Pearkes, with MacDonald strapped tightly to his chest, can detect sure signs of caravan trails leading to the north and west. Sheila tries to keep near Freddie as she floats down. Charleston sees a large salt pan to the southeast, and a large dust cloud approaching from the west--whether a storm or a group of people is impossible to tell. The weather station itself is almost beneath them--just a few tents, some water tanks, and a small biplane.

      [Simple Athletics test for the jump.]

      They spend some time regrouping. As they crest a dune, they see someone who Pearkes believes to be a soldier with a terrible sense of uniform discipline--he is wearing shorts, a bush hat, and a shirt with a garish Polynesian pattern.

      "Hello, you'd be the Colonel?"

      "Yes."

      "G'day, then. Name's Jakes. I have the honor of being a sergeant in His Majesty's Australian Army Corps."

      "Were you in the war?"

      "I was sir, I was at Gallipoli."

      "That was a good fight."

      "No it wasn't, sir, it was a bloody turkey shoot and we were the turkeys! If you don't mind the pun."

      The weather station is even less impressive close up. In addition to the water and gas tanks, there is a beaten-up desert touring car. A sandy-haired man with a small blond mustache is working on the biplane. He introduces himself as Maxwell, the pilot.

      After some discussion, they decide to send a small group north at evening to investigate the smoke they saw on descent--it is probably a Bedouin camp, and they may be able to get information about the area. So as the sun sets, Freddie, Pearkes, Gilbert, Charleston and Wazim set out in the car.

      The dust cloud peters out around this time, still distant from the camp.

      As the stars come out, they approach what is indeed a Bedouin village. The delicious smell of roasting lamb fills the air. As they walk in, the sounds of rifles being cocked surround them.

      A tall man with an enormous beard walks up. "What ho," says Freddie in Arabic.

      "You talk like an Egyptian idiot."

      "I learned my idiocy in Egypt."

      "That is unfortunate. Egypt is a terrible place."

      They sit down to eat. Wazim and the Bedouin sheikh circle each other cautiously. "You are looking for something in the desert?" asks the sheikh.

      "You wouldn't know anything about a city of pillars?"

      Everyone stops talking at once.

      "You should not go there. It is haunted by the jinns. Anyway, you will not find anyone who can help you. Why, certainly no foolish young boy would resist the word of his sheikh."

      A rather jaded looking boy looks up. "No, it would certainly not be me!"

      "And could we hire him?"

      "No," says the sheikh. "He is our best goatherd, I cannot spare his labor."

      "This is a rather poor box," says Freddie, offering the sheikh a set of pistols.

      "No, I cannot accept. However, the Colonel has a very fine rifle."

      "It is not a good rifle."

      The sheikh takes the rifle and fires off a round. "You are right, it is not a good rifle. However, I will accept these gifts as a sign of the peace between us. And I will give you the boy Abdulqasir as a slave."

      [Preparedness roll by FP to have the pistols, then Bargain.]

      "Congratulations," says Freddie. Abdul puts down his comic book. "Thank you kindly master," he says in English.

      [Abdul is not properly an Arabic name, although I used it in session; I've added "qasir"--"Slave of the powerful" is the full meaning of the name--for the writeup; now that he's with the Anglos, I'll just use Abdul, as they did.]

      Tuesday, 7 April 1925

      The next day they motor back to the station. "This is really dangerous," says Abdul from the back of the car.

      "I say, did the sheikh send you to get a better education, or to get rid of you?"

      "Probably the latter. Nobody in the tribe likes me."

      "You have an American accent, Abdul."

      "I learned English from American oil survey crews."

      Once they reach the camp, Freddie tells Abdul that as he's on sovereign British territory, he is now free. The twelve-year old boy lights up a cigarette in response. "Will you still work for us?" asks Pearkes.

      "Well, I could go back to my uncle who sold me into slavery. What do you guys do?"

      "Well," says Freddie, "I'm a dilettante, Porgie there is a British soldier, Gilbert is a French valet, and Charlie is an American sociopath."

      "I changed my mind. I want to go back."

      [I enjoyed playing Abdul as a very dry-witted, laconic kid wise beyond his years.]

      "We're looking for the city of the pillars."

      Abdul stubs out his cigarette. "I know a place where a crazy American archaeologist went. It's out in the salt-pans. I can take you there, probably take a day."

      They decide to set out that night.

      \n Having hit both extremes -- being over-prepared and railroading / saying "Here is your evening's plot" ad beig under-prepared and having a group flounder, as we're all unsure of what to do -- being over-prepared and railroading is probably better, and definitely better if folks enjoyed themselves.

      Definite sympathy when you've got a player who will respond to "Okay, now you take control and put in your bit" with "Okay, my allies give me All The Toys". Hm. I think one possibility is to decide the most you're willing to give or to come up with two or three options, e.g., "You can have two men and a rocket launcher, four men and a tank, or two squads of men, but no special equipment." (Or whatever -- I am not up on this sort of thing.)

      Another, as you said, is to trust the player to be honest when he's slowed down and ask him, "Realistically, now, what do your military experiences tell you that your PC could get from this situation, and what would it cost you?"

      Another is to let things go way, way off track, let him go hog-wild with All The Toys, and have mythos stuff show that it doesn't matter. I'm not sure you want to do that. It takes very good calibration, and may also involve railroading. It's a tricky, tricky call.

      Hm, there's also the "I will give you all the toys, Mr. Jones, if you will do me a big favor first..."

      But, with all of this? You may want to make sure that GP gets a scene somewhere in there where he can have his troops be wonderfully effective and things can go right.

      I think a lot of this comes from differing ideas about how the game world works. You can reiterate your ground rules (Magic trumps science; cultists are everywhere; anything else I'm forgetting) and keep the dialogue going. And you can take a deep, deep breath and ask people, as a group and as individuals, what's working for them, what isn't, what could be done to make the game more awesome for everyone.

      If you've got them looking out for each other on the meta-level -- making sure each player gets spotlight time and awesome time, everyone being a fan of everyone else -- then you're doing great! Let the game world burn! Or, er, um, not burn!

      \n
      \n Lisa,

      Much good there, and I agree with it! Ah, but there's many a slip between...adventure design and rolling the dice...uh...aphorisms are hard :-)

      A minor caveat: while I agree that reminding the players occasionally of How the World Works is a good thing (and I did in my last after-action report), I think there's also a disconnect between how the storytelling works. If you come from a trad D&D, video game background, you're going to expect to accumulate All The Toys and never lose, not really; so whenever you're offered a chance to Upgrade Power, you'll take it.

      Telling a different kind of story is an adjustment process under those conditions.

      I do tend to agree that it is vital that players get to see their PCs succeed. I can speak from experience: nothing is more frustrating than building a character to express something or be able to do certain things and then not get to do them. (My ex played a martial PC in a homebrewed D&D 3 game that made the caster-martial disparity worse; needless to say, she was pretty frustrated.) So Pearksie absolutely needs his moments to shine, to lead his platoon of tough-as-nails soldiers into battle.

      In fact, this was the reason I had resolved to allow PP to draw upon the resources of the Empire, and gave him a squad to play with. Maybe I should have even let him have the Maxim gun (hey, what's a Stability check for if not to measure the results of gunning down hundreds of people?) Taking away a big chunk of the squad was a tough call for me--on the one hand, realism and the setting pretty much demanded that the soldiers try and quit after fighting mummies; on the other hand, we're back to nerfing PP. I suppose there's some question of what interpersonal skill you use--is Reassurance better than Intimidation there? Should I treat them as mechanically equivalent, or does the fiction interact with them? My judgement was that trying to frighten frightened people didn't work very well, but was that me letting my agenda take precedence?

      These are tough questions :-) There does seem to be some kind of agenda conflict here and I have to think about it and how to respond in a more player-centric way.

      Anyway, more adventure to come. I lost internet at my place last night, and I don't have the writeup work I did offline, so your patience while I sort that out.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 8)

      Wednesday, 8 April 1925

      They have little trouble reaching the salt pan\u2014a vast expanse of white, rime-encrusted sand. It strikes Charleston as unusual that there is evidence of so much water in the past.

      The dust cloud suddenly is seen once again to the west, closing leisurely.

      \u201cAbdul, how long until we get there?\u201d
      \u201cIf we drive all night we can be there at dawn. Just in time to all die. We should not go any farther.\u201d
      It takes most of the day to cross the pan. The dust cloud is still visible, much closer.

      In the late evening light, they discover a region of low, extremely weathered and ancient buildings. Most are barely higher than the waist of Freddie. The entire area has an air of extreme age, even when compared to Egypt.

      \u201cHere we are, kindly master. THE NAMELESS CITY. As you can tell, it\u2019s a real going concern. They say Irem was nearby. Maybe they were built on top of one another.\u201d

      Various sinkholes or pits exist between the buildings. Freddie lowers himself to the bottom of one. There is not much to see except six low openings\u2014maybe three feet high--leading off the shaft. A cool wind blows through them, chilling Freddie eerily.

      \u201cWhat ho, Nitocris!\u201d he shouts into one of them.

      Tocris\u2014tocris\u2014tocris\u2026 whispers the echo.


      Meanwhile the rest set up camp. Abdul sits smoking a cigarette, shaking his head.

      \u201cAbdul, what do you expect to happen here?\u201d

      \u201cOh, not much kindly master. We\u2019re going to die tonight. The jinn usually come at night.\u201d

      They have finished the last of the leftover lamb when suddenly Charleston gets a funny feeling. Something is moving out in the dark. They all stand up. Freddie catches a glimpse of something vaguely human, crawling around as if on all fours.

      \u201cHello?\u201d he says?

      One leaps on him. It bites him savagely as he levels his shotgun and fires.

      Three of them charge out of the darkness at Charleston. His Tommy gun barks out, shredding them. He begins to circle the camp, spraying the darkness indiscriminately. In the strobelight of his muzzle flashes, the ground seems to be crawling with creatures.

      [I let CP just spray here, making one roll a turn while doing great execution, as they say. When he finally missed, that was when the drum\u2014Charleston uses the 50-round drum magazine\u2014ran out.]

      The one on top of Freddie pulls out a bronze knife. In the dim firelight, all Freddie can make out is a noseless face with enormous crocodilian jaws and a pair of devil-like horns jutting out of its head.

      [Our friends from \u201cThe Nameless City,\u201d the Masqut.]

      Another pounces on Gilbert, who jabs his sawed-off into its guts and fires, causing it to collapse into dust.


      Pearkes draws the Sword of Akmallah. He leaps on top of a wall and swings at two of the creatures, neatly separating their heads from their shoulders. He pounces on the other one\u2014another swing and another head drops to the ground.

      [\u201cYou separate its head from its shoulders\u201d became the Sword of Akmallah catchphrase.]

      Meanwhile Charleston continues his Chicago Typewriting course. A few more blows of the Sword of Akmallah and the assault is over.

      Pearkes sheathes his sword and saunters over to Freddie.

      \u201cAh, Colonel\u2026the sword is still out.\u201d

      \u201cIs it?\u201d

      \u201cYes, old man.\u201d

      \u201cWell, you have nothing to worry about. I mean, we\u2019re friends, right? We are friends\u2026right?\u201d

      Freddie gulps. \u201cWell, it\u2019s just that in camp, you shouldn\u2019t have weapons drawn\u2026\u201d

      \u201cOh. Right.\u201d Pearkes walks away, murmuring to the weapon.

      Thursday 9 April 1925

      The next morning they track creatures back to another sinkhole. They are discussing what to do next when the dust cloud suddenly appears in the morning sun, much closer.

      Pearkes pulls up his binoculars. In the midst of the dust cloud, Pearkes sees a half-tracked vehicle, with a rather threatening looking cannon mounted on the back.

      \u201cI need a rifle,\u201d says Pearkes.

      \u201cWe traded it to the Bedouin!\u201d says Freddie.

      Pearkes studies the vehicle more. The driver is wearing some kind of brown uniform. \u201cI think they\u2019re military,\u201d he says.

      The cannon on the half-track barks, and a shell drops behind the group\u2019s camp. Pearkes frowns\u2014that was a message that they are already in range of the gun.

      Freddie pulls out a white handkerchief, while Charleston and Gilbert run for sinkholes and leap in. (Slipping and sliding, they both reach the bottom unscathed in their respective holes.)

      Soon the half-track pulls to a halt in front of Pearkes and Freddie. Two men step out and cock heavy Tokarev pistols.

      \u201cAre you armed?\u201d one says with a heavy Russian accent.

      \u201cYes.\u201d

      \u201cPlease give us your weapons. Or we will shoot you.\u201d

      While Pearkes hands over his pistols and his Sword, a man in a fedora, with a handkerchief tied over his face to block out the dust, steps out of the vehicle.

      \u201cAh, Colonel Pearkes,\u201d he says. \u201cI\u2019m looking for Mr. Gilbert and Mr. Blakely.\u201d

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 9)

      "Haven't seen them in a while," says Pearkes.

      "I find that rather hard to believe. They seem attached to you at the hip. Tovarischii..."

      "Hello!" says Freddie, stepping out from behind a low wall.

      "Ah, Mr. Blakely! You may remember me. I am Mr. October. Where is Mr. Gilbert?"

      "Funny thing that--you know in Egypt, he tried to shoot me? Something about raises and capitalism. I'm being honest."

      "I find it hard to believe you are ever honest. What is it that interests you in these ruins?"

      "Oh, I was told to go here. Something about the F.O. being unhappy with me messing with the locals."

      "I take orders too, from the Central Committee, who tell me to be interested in you. And I am interested! Now, where is Mr. Gilbert?"

      Freddie shrugs. Some Russians tie his hands behind the back. He sits down on the halftrack next to Abdul, who is chatting in Russian with the guards.

      Looking at the four sleeping bags on the ground, October asks Freddie who his companions are. "Well, Pearksie, Bertie, and my driver..."

      "Where is your driver?"

      "I imagine he's hiding from you, reloading his machine gun."

      There is a surprised shout. Two soldiers reappear, dragging the corpse of one of the creatures who attacked the camp the night before.

      "What is that thing?" says October.

      "Oh, you've found the jinn. Some kind of mummy."

      "That is not a human being."

      "No, I guess it's not."

      Soon the sinkhole the creatures emerged from is discovered. October orders the halftrack moved over and the winch set up to lower everyone inside the pit.

      "So, is it Comrade or Mister October?"

      "Mr. October is fine."

      "What is it you want from Bertie?"

      "Mr. Gilbert was ordered to appear before the Central Committee of the Internationale. He instead fled to America to engage in petty brigandry."

      "Well, he did do that."

      "He also absconded with books, treasury, and military secrets we entrusted with him."

      "That does explain how he got to America so easily."

      [FP made a Flattery buy to engage October.]



      Three guards stand nervously around the winch, smoking. The entire area creeps them out, which is saying something for active-duty NKVD troopers.

      There is a noise of dragging from further out, near one of the sinkholes. The guards look at each other and finally one decides to check it out. He approaches the edge of the pit and suddenly stops short.

      One of the desiccated mummies is sitting up on the edge.

      The soldier stumbles forward, trying to see into the darkness below. Suddenly, there is a blinding flash of light. Stunned, he gropes forward.

      A hand seizes his wrist.



      [Photography buy to give a bonus to Scuffling.]

      The two guards remaining at the winch jump in shock as their comrade suddenly falls into a pit. One rushes out while the remaining guard cocks his Thompson gun.

      He hears something behind him. He whips around, jerking the machinegun around.

      Nothing.

      Relieved, he turns back and nearly bumps into a man with glowing red eyes.

      "Wouldn't it be nice to take a dip in this pool next to us? Just take a step..."

      [CP blew all his magic points and a chunk of his Stability to cast Dominate.]


      The scream brings back the last guard. He looks around wildly, and then throws himself against one of the ruined buildings, back to the wall.

      Someone drops to the ground from the top of the wall. Before he can get his gun up, a fist smashes into the back of his neck and the world goes black.

      [Intimidation buy by CP, then a called shot to the head. GP had to leave at this point, which is why Charleston went all ninja solo.]

      Leaving Gilbert to guard the winch, Charleston lowers himself into the ground.


      At the bottom of the sinkhole, October, the NKVD, Freddie and Pearkes find a low opening that was probably quite a tall hallway for the denizens of the Nameless City. They advance down it, past strange wall murals that resemble no human style of art.

      Suddenly, two of the Russian soldiers are seized by the ankles. Strong inhuman arms drag them into low holes at the base of the wall. Their screams don't last long.

      "Maybe we should leave," says Pearkes.

      "Maybe we should keep going as fast as we can," counters October.

      Far away, they hear a faint noise like the roaring of the sea.

      \n Sorry the last two have been so short--haven't had as much time to work on them at night. We're fairly close to the end, although there's about two and a half hours of recording remaining in this session. Some big revelations to come, and a couple of fights.

      Been meaning to mention this, but you may have noticed that I reference songs in the episode names (after the first, "The Passion of Jackson Elias" which kind of suggested itself.) This is a crochet of mine--I like allusions--but it also probably has some unconscious meaning in how I frame the episodes, as I usually have a good idea what the title will be before the session.

      For the record:

      Session Two references the first line of the French version of the Internationale

      Session Three quotes the title (and chorus) of Night Comes On by Leonard Cohen

      Session Four was a reference to David Bowie's Aladdin Insane. (I'd been listening to a lot of Bowie at the time. Still figuring out how to work in Life On Mars.)

      Session Five returns to Leonard Cohen, somewhat fitting as it closes the Egypt arc. Also, while You Know Who I Am probably references Big-G God, some of the words fit the Big N pretty well: "I am the one who likes changing/From Nothing/To One"...

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 10)

      Charleston spends a moment rigging the winch so that he can detonate it from the bottom of the pit if necessary, then has Gilbert lower him down.

      He soon hits the trail of the Russians, passing a puddle of blood in one long corridor. Up ahead, he hears voices and begins to rush towards them.



      Freddie, October and company emerge from the long gallery into an enormous cave. Gigantic pillars fill the space, holding up the vaulted ceiling.

      "Irem of the Pillars," whispers October. "I did not believe it existed..."

      The faint sound of the ocean seems louder.

      "Comrades!" someone shouts from behind them. Charleston sprints up to them. "I think I was being followed."

      "Nobody is coming now," says October. "And what happened to the three guards I left up there?"

      "This is my driver," says Freddie, explaining nothing.

      "I'm a journalist," says Charleston.

      October cocks a pistol and holds it to Freddie's head.

      "Hey, wait, you need me," says Charleston.

      "Indeed," says October. "Just give us your gun."

      "Well, just a moment..."

      "May I offer a compromise?" says Freddie. "You give them your gun, and they don't shoot me in the head."

      Charleston hands over his gun, but keeps his camera. He begins to take pictures. "Mr. October, here's one of you! 'The Hero' we'll call it."

      October turns away; Charleston notices he is still keeping his mouth covered with a bandanna. (Freddie has speculated this is because of World War I wounds.) "No, Mr. Chiu. I must work from the shadows. Darkness becomes me, don't you think?"

      The area around them, while showing signs of having been made by some completely unknown human civilization of great antiquity--predating all of recorded history--is still obviously of human construction. The next section, however shows no such sign. Whether it is the angle that stones have been cut at, or the subtly misshapen archway, the entrance they come across now is clearly alien or at least non-human. And it does not resemble the ruins they found on the surface at all.

      The roaring noise is closer. Charleston feels a mental pressure on his mind, as if something was pressing in on him.

      They follow Charleston's lead deep into this strange complex. The black stone of the walls seems to reflect the light...wrong, somehow. Guided by his sense of presence, Charleston leads them at last to a strange archway. Some kind of enormous room lies beyond.

      The sound of the ocean is very loud now.

      [Right about now I gave CP a point of Stability for following his new Drive, "Thirst for knowledge."]

      "Men, stay back and guard," says October.

      Charleston studies the archway. Alien characters are inscribed there. He remembers, dimly, having seen something like them in the Al-Azif...

      [Cthulhu Mythos buy by CP; 1 Sanity and 3 Stability was the cost

      "Here...lies the High Priest...waiting the end of days...when the stars are right...when that which is dead...awakes and returns..." he reads, but in Aklo, so no one can understand it.

      "Why don't you go in," suggest October with a wave of his gun.

      "Certainly," says Charleston. He turns around and walks in backward.

      "Very amusing Mr. Chiu."

      Charleston feels a force boring at the back of his neck.

      "Turn around, Mr. Chiu, or I will just shoot you. I grow tired of your escapades."

      "All right." Charleston spins around, closing his eyes as he does. "Yes...yes...riches and knowledge," he says, walking forward, eyes still sealed.

      [I had to think very hard right here as to whether CP would get a Sense Trouble roll. He finally convinced me he should.]

      Suddenly he stops, one foot poised in the air. He has suddenly realized there's no more floor in front of him.

      He looks down and cracks open one eye...

      He sees a great, slimy, scaly, green leg, of enormous size. It stretches below him, as if some gigantic figure was standing at waist-height in front of him. Slowly, as if compelled, he lifts his eyes, looking at the gigantic torso, the flabby bat-like wings, to a great tentacled head...

      The tentacles lash at him, but strangely Charleson realizes that it is somehow imprisoned and if he just stand still he is safe.

      Words form in his mind:

      I AM GLAD THAT ONE WHO CAN HEAR ME CAME TINY MIND SO LACKING IN KNOWLEDGE I WILL GIVE YOU KNOWLEDGE IF YOU SET ME FREE

      Everything except the roaring noise of the ocean is drowned out. Charleston grimaces under the mental onslaught, like a spike being driven into his brain.

      He turns around to see if the Russians are still there. They start at the sight of his terrible visage, twisted with more than human knowledge.

      Charleston looks around. There is a freizework surrounding the great circular pit the creature is standing in. For some reason, although the symbols are nothing alike, it reminds him of the pink stone Nyiti of El-Wasta gave him. He suspects that breaking the inscription would somehow free the monster.

      DO NOT DELAY RELEASE ME

      "Wait, how do I do that?"

      YOU ARE AS FOOLISH AS THE OTHER HUMANS BREAK THE INSCRIPTION FREE ME

      "I think we should just shoot him," says October to Freddie.

      "You should probably check to see if it is warded," says Freddie.

      "How? I see only air?"

      "Trust me. Just shoot a little off to the side."

      October fires his pistol. The bullet passes easily through the archway and close to Charleston's ear.

      He turns around. "Now who did that? That was rude!"

      "What is you see, Mr. Chiu? Perhaps you better step outside."

      Something seems to reach inside Charleston's mind and his will snaps like a twig. He whips around and drops to his knees.

      DO NOT MAKE ME FORCE YOU

      "Force me to do what?"

      FREE ME FREE ME FREE ME



      Freddie asks October for a rope. The NKVD agent pauses, and then asks one of the guards to give the Englishman what he wants.

      Freddie makes a simple lasso, tosses it around Charleston, and drags him back through the archway. When he is almost through, Charleston stands up and walks in without resisting.

      October comes up and puts his pistol at Charleston's head. The sometime journalist rolls forward suddenly, kicking the pistol out of October's hand, spins around, and catches it.

      "All right Comrades, everybody put your guns down."

      Pearkes grabs the Sword from the guard near him.

      KILL THEM KILL THEM ALL

      Charleston shoots Freddie.

      "For God's sake, man!"

      The Russians dive for their guns. Pearkes comes up behind October and cross-checks him through the archway. He falls back, stumbles, then looks up.

      He stands up, and then kneels and bows.

      Then he begins to attack the freizework with his knife.

      Meanwhile, Charleston shoots Pearkes. The colonel shrugs it off and decapitates two of the Russians with the Sword of Akmallah.

      The other Russians pause for a second, staring wide-eyed at Pearkes.

      [2 point Intimidation buy from PP.]

      The archway suddenly collapses behind them. There is a tremendous rumbling and the corridor begins to collapse.

      "Well, don't just stand--" shouts Freddie as he sprints past them.

      Taking the hint, the Russians take off after him.

      Charleston, the mental control relaxed, sticks the pistol in his belt, scoops up his Thompson gun, and follows them.

      Chaos ensues. As they rush through the hallways, arms snatch at them from--the mummies have returned. Two more Russians fall to them.

      Freddie, running in sheer terror, finally manages to find a passageway sloping up. He burst through into daylight, followed closely by Pearkes.

      Charleston rushes after them, but pauses frequently to look at the strange murals. They seem to show a city in the sands, a city that somehow is there and not there. He begins to slow even as the corridors shake and walls buckle.

      He is standing there, enraptured, when the mummies find him.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 11)

      Freddie looks at Pearkes. "Charleston?"

      Pearkes shakes his head.

      They find Gilbert and Abdul near the half-track, and spend a cold and cheerless night alone in the vast desert.

      Earlier...

      The mummies pounce at Charleston. He tries to ready his Tommy gun, but there are so many around him. They grab his arms and drag down his legs.

      Suddenly a tentacle lances through the air, pulling three of them off of Charleston. They disintegrate in a puff of dust. Another tentacle wraps around the young journalist, hoisting him in the air and eye-to-eye with the creature from the pit, now escaped.

      WHY DID YOU RUN

      "Because the place started to collapse..."

      YOU COULD HAVE HELPED ME YOU CHOSE NOT TO

      "Yeah, because I sacrificed the other guy to you and wanted to reap the benefit!"

      [CP makes a 4-point Bargain spend here. I thought that deserved for him to drive the bargaining--the Xothian was in the mood to listen. As expected, he makes a worse bargain than he might have otherwise got...]

      "Hey, listen! Wait, we can make a deal! In return for incremental portions of your knowledge, I will corrupt a pure mortal once a year and send its soul to you, to use as you see fit."

      I WILL GIVE YOU NO KNOWLEDGE I WILL GIVE YOU YOUR LIFE

      I WILL GIVE YOU WHAT YOU LOOK FOR

      "What am I looking for?"

      YOU HAVE GIVEN ME A SERVANT I AM PLEASED

      "Do you want more servants? I'm just trying to set up a payment plan here!"

      WORSHIP ME

      "I'm really an atheist."

      I AM NOT A GOD

      "I will recruit worshipers for you..."

      DO NOT WORSHIP ME WORSHIP MY GREAT FATHER YOU KNOW HIS NAME

      [At this point I pointed to the cover of the rulebook.
      CP: Your father's name is Trail Of?]

      "What does worship of this fine person, whose name I am not comfortable saying, entail?"

      YOU WILL KNOW OUR RITUALS IN TIME

      "What does he symbolize? Cruelty? Betrayal, dishonesty?"

      POWER

      Both Charleston and the creature begin to dematerialize. Charleston stares in horror as the building blocks of the universe seem to fall away. For a moment he has a vision of a great city in the sands, and a strange formula suddenly fills his head...

      Friday, 10 April 1925

      The next morning at dawn, they find Charleston, arms folded neatly across his chest, sleeping peacefully on top of a dune--a dune in a place where Freddie is sure there was a sinkhole the night before.

      Charleston sits up suddenly. He looks in very good health. "I know a new spell," he says. "The Dho-Hna Formula. I need Noor. Bring her to me."

      [I should mention in passing that I took much of the details of Irem/the Nameless City/The City of Brass not only from Lovecraft, but from the 1001 nights, especially the next section. In the 1001 Nights, the party searching for the City of Brass finds a jinn half-buried in sand--and as it turns out, there's supposed to be a Xothian in Irem! So it worked nicely.]

      "You see," continues Charleston, "sometimes there's a city here, and sometimes there's not. Sometimes there's another city, I think. Maybe its three cities. Anyway, I can bring it here."

      He writes something in the sand. "Here, you went to college, you should be able to follow this."

      "Old boy, I don't even know what numbers you're using."

      "Numbers? You can't write this in numbers. Like...you know how 2+2=4?"

      "Yes?"

      "Sometimes it doesn't! Look, think about it like this...say there's this cat, in a box with poison..."

      [Turns out Schr\xf6dinger didn't come up with the cat idea til 1935! Looks like seeing the world nine-dimensionally has benefits.]

      Freddie radios the weather station, and not long afterward Maxwell lands his biplane on the salt flat. Noor gets out.

      "Charleston, you look different?"

      "Thank you. I haven't bathed in three days."

      They rig up a tent, and Charleston explains what happened to him.

      "Charleston, you have done a terrible thing! You should not have done it!"

      "You are correct. However, we are going to cast a spell. You take the good, you take the bad, you take them both, and there you have it."

      They begin the ritual, which seems to consist of writing things on a long strip of paper. Then Charleston says a Word, which resounds like a thunderclap in everyone's mind. A wind springs up, blowing down the tent, and kicking up a sandstorm. The sand seems to hang in the air, solidify...and suddenly a wall is there, with a gate in it.

      Freddie pulls up the halftrack and uses it to clamber up to the edge of the wall and peek over. He freezes for a moment, then stands up and walks forward.

      He falls off the wall on the other side, vanishing from sight.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 12)

      Pearkes rigs a rope to Charleston, who climbs up to the top of the wall. At first he sees nothing. Then, suddenly, a man in a black suit is standing next to him.

      "Hello, Charleston."

      "Hello. Are you who I need to see?"

      "Me? I'm just the Messenger. Why do you wish to go into the city? There's nothing here for you. Forget your friend. He's lost. We'll take care of him."

      "Well, that's just it, I need to find him. We need him."

      "What do you think you'll find in the city?"

      "Freddie Blakely."

      "You may find Freddie there. I can't guarantee it. You'll find many things in the city."

      "Is that your message?"

      "No. My message is, Give up now, your cause is lost, you should just go home--I here you have a lot of things to do, now. In return, I'll tell you a few things about the universe."

      [CP wanted to Assess Honesty, but I had to tell him that it wouldn't work on a non-human entity. For a spend, I told him that he was an extra-dimensional being, and that he was lying, but there was no way to know what he was lying about.]

      "I'm going over, I'm going to find Freddie."

      "Okay...I could have told you some things. But you don't want to know, no problem for me."

      Charleston topples over the wall. The rope pulls him up short and he is able to drop down near Freddie. He gives the Englishman a kick in the ribs. "Freddie, are you awake? You seem to have landed on your ribs!"

      "You're not three beautiful women..."

      Charleston helps Freddie up. The area is beautiful--the buildings are furnished with gold and silver fittings, the wood is made of teak, pleasant fountains of alabaster stand in broad marble-tiled squares.

      Together, they open the gates from the inside, and Pearkes and Noor enter the city. "This is out of the Arabian nights!" says Noor. "If I remember my stories, in the center of the city, you will find a mummified queen!"

      The city is truly astonishing, like something out of the Quranic stories of Paradise. The craftsmanship is literally supernatural. They notice, however, that the city is extremely quiet--even the fountains have a hushed sound.

      At the center of the city they find a fabulous pillared pavilion that rises into the sky.

      At the center of the pavilion, inside a tower, they find a catafalque covered in rubies on a dais. Four enormous statues of armed guards, carved out of a mysterious black stone with scimitars raised, stand on each corner of the dais. In the center of the catafalque, in a shaft of blinding sunlight that obscures her features, is a woman in a white gown.

      "What ho, Nitocris? We're here because of this Shakhti Bey fellow."

      There is no response.

      Pearkes raises his sword in salute. The statues bow their heads in response.

      Freddie fishes into his pocket and comes out with a pair of dark spectacles.

      [Preparedness buy by FP.]

      Putting them on, he can finally see the face he is staring at:

      Hypatia Masters.

      "Hypatia, old girl! What are you doing here?"

      She makes no response. Her eyes are closed and she remains as immobile as if she was dead.

      Freddie cautiously ascends the dais. Hypatia's eyes fly open, and she steps out of the light. She says something that only Freddie can make sense of, and only dimly--it's been a long time since he'd studied Koine Greek:

      "What year is it?"

      "1925. Do you still speak English?"

      "1925?" she blinks, and suddenly seems to recognize who she is talking to. "Why, Freddie Blakely, as--well, mostly live, and mostly breathe."

      She looks at Pearkes, Charleston, and Noor: "Don't know you...don't know you, but I want to...silly little girl, I don't care about. Freddie Blakely! 1925! Wow, I knew it would happen eventually, but I really never thought I'd get past 1919 again. Been a very long time."

      "Indeed. By the way, were you talking to us the other day, during some kind of resurrection ritual?"

      "Was there a mummy?"

      "Yes."

      "Oh, yeah. I left that. It's kind of like a recording."

      "You've met Gilly then?"

      "What? Jilly's around? Oh, he's always good fun. I hate that son of a bitch. I've hated him since I first met him. Do you know what it's like to hate somebody for 3500 years?"

      "What?"

      "Oh yes, I met him around...2500 BC? I didn't have a calendar."

      "Hypatia, when I last met you, you didn't seem like somebody who was 3500 years old."

      "Oh, I wasn't. I was about...19 back then?"

      "Don't think about it too hard," says Charleston.

      "Your amusing little friend, he has the right of it. It's nine-dimensional."

      "I assume you're some mystical creature," says Freddie.

      "No, I'm human. Mostly."

      "I see. Well, can you do anything about Gilly? He seems to be bent on hurting you."

      "No...not now, not when he's already in the city."

      "He's in the city?"

      "About five minutes away."

      "Fantastic! Do you know any way to stop him?"

      "Cut of his head? That usually works for a while."

      "A while? A human lifetime?"

      "Depends on the Dark Lord. When did I last see him? Muscovy, 1722. Boy, he was an ***hole in Russian too..."

      "I'm afraid you've left me a bit behind, Hypatia."

      "Well, sorry Freddie. I think differently than you do. I like, use my brain. He gets it." She looks at Charleston curiously. "When did you Awaken?"

      "Just recently!"

      "Oh...oh, you're so young! Poor baby!"

      "I say, Hypatia," continues Freddie, "is there anywhere we could go while you and Gilly have it out?"

      "Oh, I don't want to talk to him, actually, so if you can find a way out, we should take it."

      "Could we just leave?"

      "Walk out? Sure, we could try that. I mean, I know some tricks, but I don't want to have to bring the Dark Lord into this, that's always a drag."

      "Oh, him again," mutters Charleston.

      "Hey! There's no him again when it comes to the Dark Lord. Hey Freddie, give a girl a drink."

      Freddie hands her his flask. "Ah! I don't know if it was worth waiting 1500 years for, but it was pretty good." She pets him on the head. "He's like a puppy dog!" she says. "Why, I could just eat you up!"

      "I'd prefer if you didn't!"

      At that moment, Omar Shakhti strides in.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 13)

      He coolly looks around the chamber. Then he glances back. "Dog!"

      Henry Clive scampers in. "Yes, Master!"

      "Shakhti Bey, how good to see you again," says Freddie.

      "I wish I could say the same."

      "I was just having the most interesting conversation with Hypatia..."

      "Ah, yes. My queen. How marvelous to see you again."

      "Look, I'll just let you two talk things over..." says Freddie.

      "No, I really don't want to say anything to him," says Hypatia.

      Nobody moves for a second. Pearkes twitches.

      Shakhti turns towards him with a snarl. Black tendrils wrap themselves around Pearkes' head, and he shrieks as his life force is pulled out of him.

      "Strange," mutters Shakhti. "My children need to drink blood, where I just enjoy it."

      Pearkes staggers up from his knees. As he reaches for his sword, a tongue lashes itself around his neck. Hetep growls as it begins to change in to its humanoid form.

      "Really, Shakhti? Really?" drawls Hypatia. A coruscating beam of light lances out at the wizard. He raises a hand and it splashes away from him, but Hypatia continues to hold the beam on him.

      Freddie skulks into the shadows and comes up behind Pearkes, who is struggling to keep from choking. Blakely neatly slides the Sword of Akmallah out of its sheath.

      Pearkes draws his revolver and fires a shot at Shakhti and a shot at Hetep. The bullet bounces away harmlessly from the Egyptian, but Hetep snarls as the shot hits home.

      To Charleston's nine-dimensional sight, the shield of power surrounding Shakhti is weakened slightly by Pearkes' bullet. He cocks his Tommy gun and sprays the Bey indiscriminately. Bullets pool at the base of Shakhti's feet.

      Bleeding, the humanoid Hetep slashes viciously at the Colonel, who screams in pain as he reaches down to his belt and slashes at the tongue with one of Billy's kukris, but the blade can't cut through the otherwordly fibers of the strange appendage.

      [Preparedness roll by Pearkes to have a knife.]

      Freddie nonchalantly walks up to Shakhti. "Blakely, your death will come soon!" growls Shakhti.

      "God, you're melodramatic," Freddie says, and slices at his neck.

      [Reassurance buy by FP to get a bonus, followed by a critical hit! Unfortunately, he rolled snake eyes...]

      The sword stops at the edge of the shield, and then to Shakhti's astonishment it begins to slide through. There is a snapping noise and the shield breaks.

      "You'll pay for that," says Shakhti.

      "You've been saying that for weeks--"

      Shakhti picks up Freddie and throws him into a wall. The Englishman staggers up for a moment, and then collapses.

      [As FP is fond of saying, Freddie is not a combat character, although he mixed it up in this game. He tried to make a health spend to stay conscious, but failed and collapsed.]

      Charleston raises his Tommy gun.

      "Now wait! We can talk about this!" says Shakhti. "I can teach you so much--"

      The gun blazes at him. Shakhti is hit multiple times, staggering back. Charleston takes a step forward, and then stop as the Bey looks up at him, eyes flashing red.

      Pearkes drops to his knees. "Hypatia--" he says thickly.

      "Oh...oh....all right." She flicks a bolt of black light at Hetep's tongue, severing it, and then kicks the Sword of Akmallah over to him. Filled with bloodlust, Pearkes slowly stands up using the Sword as a prop, then he leaps in the air, slashing down viciously at Shakhti.

      The sword slices cleanly through his neck. He vanishes in a puff of dust as Hetep shrivels up into a mummified cat corpse.

      "Nice work, Pearkesie," says Hypatia.

      "Thank you."

      "Yeah, you owe me one. Hey, Chuckles," she says to Charleston, "tell me what the world is like. It's been...three thousand four hundred and...eight-six years since I was around."

      "Let's see. It's the 1920s. Things are booming. The economy cannot possibly go wrong..."

      "How long is hair worn?"

      "Shorter."

      "I knew I left too soon."

      Charleston waves his hands seven-dimensionally. Hypatia nods, staring at an image only she and Charleston can see.

      "I mean, it all depends on what you want to be," says Charleston.

      "I'm Hypatia. Haven't you seen my work?"

      She waves her hands and the light comes up in the room. Behind her are mosaic portraits on the walls, of Nitocris, of Cleopatra, of Hypatia of Alexandria. All bear a strong resemblance to her.



      Together Hypatia and Charleston revive Freddie. A strange music begins to filter through the air.

      "Where's that music coming from," says Freddie groggily.

      [It was "In the Mood" by Glen Miller, actually, which makes is an anachronism--wasn't written until the 30s.]

      "Down the hallway," says Hypatia.

      "Are we correct in assuming that you're Nitocris."

      "Yup. That was my first job, back when I went to Egypt. Just the bunch of us back then--me, Sir Aubrey, Roger...yeah. Roger, he was...well, he was something last time I saw him. Something else, that's for sure."

      "Am I correct that you've lived an entire life?"

      "A life?"

      "Well, multiple lives."

      "No, I just didn't stop living."

      "How long will Shakhti be gone?"

      "Not up to me, friend. Above my pay grade--that's up to the Dark Lord. He'll probably be a bit ticked--I think Jilly was off playbook here. He was probably told to bring me back, but he wanted to make sure he could order me around because he was--well, it's ungenteel to say what he was."

      "So you work for the same person?"

      "No."

      "You work for opposing interests?"

      "No."

      "You work for different--"

      "I don't work for anyone, honey. People work for me."

      "Well, you say 'The Dark Lord' and the people we've met who say that usually are working for him--"

      "Well, I mean we're friends. He was very good to me."

      More music begins to play.

      ["Moonlight Serenade", another anachronism.]

      "That's an interesting tune," says Freddie. "I don't recognize it."

      "Yes, we should cut a rug."

      "All right." Freddie holds up his arms.

      "No, not here. Let's go to the club." Hypatia waves down a carpeted corridor, lit by electric lamps. Freddie shrugs and holds out his arm.

      "Noor, come," says Charleston, holding out his arm.

      "This positively reeks of magic!" she says.

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 14)

      As they walk down the hallway, Freddie glances back. There is no sign of the room the were just in. People begin to mill around them, dressed in evening clothes.

      A waiter crashes into Pearkes, spilling a tray of drinks on him. "I'm so sorry sir! Let me clean you up."

      They go into a nearby men's room. "Let me just get a towel, sir," says the waiter. As he approaches, Pearkes stares at him shock: the waiter is his old attache, Sam Steele, murdered two months previously in New York.

      [Stability check, obviously. I am not ashamed to say I stole part of this from "The Shining".]

      "Been a while, Sam."

      "I'm sorry, have we met?"

      "What's your name?"

      "Sam sir. Have you been here before? You look familiar."

      "I think so. Maybe we'll meet again soon."

      "Just keep coming to the club, sir. We can always use your patronage, Colonel."

      "You should look into joining the Canadian Army. Military life probably becomes you."

      "Oh, I'm not a military man, sir. I'm--I'm through with my fighting, sir."



      George rejoins the rest in the main room of a bustling night club. Freddie can't place it--it looks familiar, but he can't tell if it's because he's been here before, or if it just looks like a standard New York nightclub.

      They suddenly realize they are all dressed for evening. "What is this I am wearing?" says Noor.

      "Come on, I'll teach you to dance," says Charleston.

      An Asian man approaches Freddie. "This is a strange place," he says.

      "It is."

      "You are not speaking Mongolian."

      "I'm going to guess that you are not speaking English."

      "I am not. My name is Timur. Would you mind sitting down? I'm a bit lame."

      "No, I think I'll be sitting way over here." Freddie strides away, and then realizes that he hasn't seen Hypatia since they entered the club. As he scans the crowd for her, he suddenly recognizes his aunts sitting at a table.

      "Freddie!"

      "Hullo, aunties."

      "Roland. This is a most disreputable place."

      "If you don't mind me asking, what in the blazes are you doing in a nightclub?"

      "Just taking in the sights," says Dahlia.

      "It was her idea," says Agatha.

      "Let me rephrase then. What in blazes are you doing in a night club in a city in Arabia?"

      "We're not in Arabia," says Dahlia. "It's complicated, Freddie. Anyway, the singer is about to arrive. This is a great moment for us all."

      "That sounds rather ominous. Am I sitting with you?"

      "If you wish. Dinner is about to be served."



      Noor and Charleston are still on the dance floor when the music stops. "Ladies and gentlemen, the Arabian room is proud to present--our very special guest--you know him--you love him--NY! AR! LAT! HOOOOO-TEP!"

      A man in a tux strides out on to the stage and takes the mike. "Imagine me and you..." he begins:\n
      I do...
      It's only right...
      To think about the world you want...
      and crush it tight...
      So happy together....
      \n"Hi folks, so great to see you all tonight. It's really going to be a wonderful evening. I've been looking forward to meeting some of you for so long--Adolf! Could you please stand up?"

      A short man with a stubby mustache stands up. A spotlight catches him, leaving him looking uncomfortable.

      "That guy--he is going to do some amazing things for us! Seriously, seriously. It's a night like this that reminds me that...\n
      I can't see me loving nobody but you, world...
      For all of Time...
      \n"...because when we're together, oh baby, the Stars will be right!"



      "You work for this man?" demands Freddie of Dahlia.

      "Work for him? I should be so lucky! Oh, good, the dinner is here!"

      A huge salver is placed on the table. The cover is lifted and the parboiled corpse of Jackson Elias is revealed.

      "Do eat up, Freddie."

      "Roland, for the love of God, don't do it," says Agatha. "You know I hate you as I hate few people. But you should not do this."

      "Freddie," says Dahlia impatiently, "you must eat."

      [OK. So I designed this part to go after some Pillars of Sanity, thus Pearkes and Sam, and now Freddie's core Pillar coming under assault.]

      "Aunt Agatha, if I were to walk out of here where would I end up?"

      "I don't know, but I don't think it would be someplace you'd want to be. But if I were you, I'd run away from us as fast as possible."

      "Cheerio."

      Freddie leaps up, vaults a railing, and slides out the secret entrance to the speakeasy...


      Pearkes sees Freddie run out. He starts to follow him when he is spun around by someone putting his arm around his shoulders. "Hey, Pearkesie! Call me N. I understand you have a thing for initials. Let's talk, you and me."

      "Nyarla--"

      "Hey, hey! Just N. No need to get all formal. Take a look at this."

      N waves languidly at a map of the world carved in bas relief high on one wall. Five uncut rubies dot areas around the Indian ocean. "Isn't that beautiful?"

      "As long as the British flag waves over it--"

      "You are such an amusing little insect! I see why they keep you around. Listen, you want to find out about the Carlyles. Let me tell you about the Carlyles, let me show you what happened to the Carlyles."

      A screen unfolds and a color moving image begins to play on it. Before Pearkes can react to the novelty of color images, he is shocked by the scenes of horror that unfold. The Carlyle expeditions, all its members easily recognizable, are moving through the bush in Africa. Nightmare monsters descend upon them. A five-headed horror shreds each of them horribly.

      "So," says N. "What you should do is stop. You think you can stop? I hear," he whispers, "that you're good at taking orders."

      "I don't take orders from the likes of you."

      "Oh. Well, okay then. You're free to go. Go on. Right through that door."

      Pearkes walks over to the exit, turns, and gives a salute with his sword. He steps through the door...

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 15)

      Charleston and Noor are still dancing when suddenly the singer appears next to them. "Can I cut in?" he says, pushing Noor aside and taking Charleston in his arms.

      "No."

      "Wasn't a question. Don't make me have to do the marionette thing, okay?"

      "Look, I'm already spoken for."

      "Oh, him. Listen, why don't you trade up."

      "To who?"

      "Hey, who's got all-embracing cosmic power and at least two thumbs! Come on, I'll give you so much better stuff. What do you want, power? followers? I can use people like you. And who recognizes your ability? Blakely? Please. Mr. Lee, your old Triad boss? He kicked you to the curb. Hey, how would you like to learn how to bring his heart smoking into your hands?"

      "I can do that without magic."

      "You know, you amuse me. Really. Most people don't, but you do."

      "Listen Mr. Thotep--"

      "No, wait. Hotep. That's really a pet peeve of mine. Ny-ar-lat-hotep. It's Egyptian. Sorry, it just bugs me."

      "You have to understand, I never think about anything before I do it."

      "I know! That's why you should be working for me. You know what they call me? Like a locker room kind of thing? 'The Crawling Chaos'. Think about it. Chaos, my friend, chaos."

      "Chaos isn't a thing you follow or worship."

      "I know! I'm like a force of nature! So resisting me is what they call stupid. Don't be stupid. I know you're not."

      He pours himself a drink that makes Charleston uncomfortable to look at. "I tell you what. What would you like to do. Give me one thing you'd like to do. Anything at all. I'll give you the power to do it. One-time offer, no strings attached."

      "I decline."

      "I'm sorry, what?"

      "I respectfully decline."

      "Wait, I thought I just heard you say no."

      "It's the most chaotic choice."

      "Oh, man, you have to work for me! You want to see sunrise on Sirius?"

      "I'll take a pass this time."

      "Well, what can I do for you? What do you want? I promise, no strings attached. Outer God's Honor!"

      "You just don't do it for me, baby."

      "You're going to go squid? Let me tell you something about him. You know that City of Brass, that keeps fading in and out? That was the center of Squidboy's cult here on Planet Earth. And the people, they came and worshiped, and you know what? There came a point where they stopped saying my name when they did their little rituals and cast their little spells.

      "Me! I'm the guy who talks to Azathoth. I'm the Conduit! People don't do s*** unless they say my name. So I picked up that city and shoved it into another dimension.

      "And you know what he did? The Great Squid? He rolled over in his little undersea grave and cried into his tentacles. Because you do not. Want. To. Mess. With. Me."

      "Sounds like an issue you have with him."

      "I don't have an issue with him. I have an issue with people who think they can get away with doing stuff without saying my name. I am the conduit! The skein that floats on the surface of the universe! I'm what makes it possible for you to do things with your tiny, tiny, little monkey brains. So, monkey brain. What's it going to be? You want power? You want worship? You want to be able to make the sky just a little more blue today? You don't talk to him. You talk to me!

      "You come work for me. Let me show you what we're working on. See that map? You see those points? We're doing lots of stuff there. When we're done, we open the Gate, cosmic weirdness comes down to planet Earth. Don't you want to be in on that? Or do you want that when that day comes you're just another sorcerer we toss on the sacrificial altar? You want a beach party in Colorado, or do you want to be the clambake? Your call, man."

      "Tell you what. Leave me your number and I'll get back to you."

      "All right then." He hands Charleston a card. "You call this number from anywhere in the world, and I'll be there. You're free to go."

      Charleston takes the card and turns towards the door.

      "You going to take your little monkey-girl with you?"

      "Oh, right."

      "Hey, Charleston, gotta let you know, the offer of a trial power? That was no strings attached. Saying no to me? Strings."

      As Charleston opens the door, he hears the Dark Lord call out one last time. "I'll see you in the funny papers."

      \nEpisode V: You Know Who I Am (Part 16)

      Freddie steps through the door and finds himself in London. It seems to be winter, and he shivers inside his thin evening clothes. He looks around.

      London seems to have been bombed. Houses and apartment buildings lie shattered in the street.

      [In my Pathfinder game, towards the end the PCs managed to end up vanishing for 20 years, so immediately the group assumed I had done the same here.]

      A man passes by. "Look at you! You look quite the toff! Is this fancy dress?"

      "Um, yes, it was."

      "I didn't hear anything about that on the televisor. Is this a party thing? Because I don't like to get mixed up in party things. In fact, I think you're dangerous to my health, and I'll be going along."

      "Now, now, my good man," says Freddie. "No need to worry."

      [Reassurance use by Freddie.]

      "You've got a weird accent," says the man.

      "I'm from a different part of England."

      "England?"

      "This is London, isn't it?"

      "Of course it is! Capital of Airstrip One!"

      "I'm from a different part of Airstrip One. You wouldn't happen to have the paper, would you? Was on a bit of a bender last night..."

      "No, I don't go for the papers."

      "Where could I get one?"

      "At the party store, I guess, if you're in the party. Down on Chatham Square."

      Freddie follows his directions and reaches a part of London that has been rebuilt, it seems, but in some horrible utilitarian style. As he walks, he sees banners hanging over the street:\n
      WAR IS PEACE
      FREEDOM IS SLAVERY
      IGNORANCE IS STRENGTH
      \nA large person in a black uniform checks Freddie into a wall with his truncheon. "What are you wearin'?"

      "Party clothes."

      "That's not party clothes. That's thoughtcrime I see. That's crimewear I see. Think I'll take you down bout the Ministry."

      "Who do you think you are! What's your rank?"

      [Bureaucracy buy by FP.]

      "Constable."

      "Well, if you don't want to go back to scrubbing toilets, you'll take your hands off of me."

      "I think we should go and see my sergeant."

      "I think we both should go see your sergeant."

      "Lead the way, sir," says the constable, jabbing Freddie in the back with his truncheon.



      Pearkes steps out of the door...

      ...and lands in the ocean.

      Seconds later, a ship explodes behind him. Wooden splinters rain down around him, and he blacks out.

      When he comes to, night has fallen. He is clutching a plank, all alone on the ocean. Looking at the stars, he guesses he is near the equator.

      Far away, he hears the sound of a violin, and as the waves lift him up, he makes out some lights. He begins to swim towards it.

      The ship proves to be a square-rigged frigate of some kind, flying a naval ensign that he dates to the Napoleonic wars.

      A sailor on the deck of the ship catches sight of Pearkes. "Man overboard!" he shouts.

      The music stops, and the door to the great cabin opens. A tall, heavyset blond man steps out, strips off his shoes, and dives into the water. In a few powerful strokes he is next to Pearkes, whom he drags to the side of the ship and helps up on to the deck.

      "Sorry about that," he says as Pearkes flops to the deck. He holds out his hand. "Jack Aubrey."

      "George Pearkes. I'm an officer in His Majesty's army."

      "Really! Well, sir, welcome to His Majesty's Ship Surprise. You look a bit rough, if you'll pardon me. Send for Doctor Maturin!" he shouts at a sailor.

      "I see you took care of a friend earlier," says Pearkes.

      "Too bad we couldn't take her as a prize," says Aubrey, leading him into the cabin.



      Charleston and Noor step through the door...

      ...and onto a street in a city. They are on a high hill, and have an excellent view of a beautiful bay. Sunlight sparkles off of it. In the distance, they can see a long suspension bridge, painted an unusual red color.

      A man bumps into Charleston. "Oh, I'm sorry, so sorry, I didn't mean...oh. You're Chinese."

      "What of it?"

      "Hey, back off. I don't have to take anything from a [racial slur]. Get lost before I report you to the Kempeitai."

      "What the hell is that? Some Japanese word?"

      "Whatever. Why don't you go run a rickshaw?"

      As if on cue, a few rickshaws come dashing down the street.

      "Where are we, Charleston? This doesn't look like any city I know."

      "Let's find out." They walk up to a newsstand. A Chinese man regards them listlessly from inside the kiosk.

      "Pardon me, sir. Konnichiwa--"

      "Don't worry, man, I'm Chinese too," says the man in Chinese.

      "Can I pay for a paper with one these?" says Charleston, slapping down a 1924 penny.

      "If you give me another nine."

      "Ten cents for a newspaper?"

      "What can I tell you? It's the economy. Hard for an honset [racial slur] to find work."

      Charleston looks at the front page:

      April 4, 1962

      GERMAN CHANCELLOR BORMANN REPORTED CRITICALLY ILL
      President of Pacific States of America to Meet German Ambassador

      "Hey, you new in town?" asks the newsseller. "Your accent is weird--doesn't sound like you're just in from the mainland, but you look new."

      "Yeah, well its hard out here."

      "Don't have to tell me, man. I thought it was bad back home, that's why I came to the Pacific States, but its the same everywhere, the [racial slur for Japanese people] run everything. I guess it's better than being in the Eastern states--they have to deal with the Germans. Hey, is your friend Arabian?"

      "Sort of."

      "Didn't think there were many of those left. Anyway, if you need a place, why don't you stay at my cousin Wu's? He owns a boarding house, has a female dorm too for your friend."

      [And somewhere, in some other plane, the laughter of the Dark Lord rains down on them...

      This was the end of the session, and an interesting pickle. As it turns out, Gilbert leaving early not only didn't require me to find a fiction to stuff him into, but it gives me a way to get everybody back into the "real" world. I am going to be interested in how they pull it off...]

      \n Lisa:

      Well, finally! And it's awesome you can get the beta for free! I glanced at part of it this morning, and there's some good stuff, including (ahem) the idea of making Jackson Elias better known to the PCs :-)

      It is focused on a more "straight" version of the game than what I'm attempting, but there is definitely a lot of good stuff there.

      Bill,

      I'm glad you did! I had to pull the date on the newspaper OMA--I skimmed my copy last night but contrary to what I thought, there doesn't seem to be any reference to the date in the book, except that it's probably 1962.

      I'll have a bit more on the whys and wherefores of this episode when I get a chance to write. This was a pretty pivotal section and a big chunk of my reboot changes are revealed here, most especially with Hypatia Masters. Let's just say that the passive baby incubator version of Hypatia wasn't really to my taste.

      \n Yah, that annoyed me -- to be fair, as written, Roger Carlyle is also a shattered non-entity. But, I mean, Hypatia's not even interestingly insane as a baby incubator. She's just a sack. An alternative would have been having her active, determined to defend her unborn child against all comers, including pesky investigators. But, I like her having been Nitocris and Cleopatra. Does she have the dies-but-gets-brought-back deal that Shakti has?

      I like what you did with N. It's much more interesting than the pyramid scene as written, especially as, while it makes sense to be utterly brutal and have him kill anyone dumb enough to sit in his throne, as written, this is problematic in actual play. In your game, I'd put money on it being Freddie sitting in the throne, and bumping him off for that breaks the tone you're going for. I mean, yes, things can get much darker and likely will, but that's a line you can't uncross. If not Freddie, I'd guess Charleston, but bumping him off for that would be boring. Showing him sanity blasting visions would be much more fun, but he's already doing that to himself. I suppose you could have an NPC like Alphonse in the hot seat, but again, it's a sudden shift in tone.

      I look forward to the analysis.

      \n Lisa,

      Thanks! I have some interesting plans for Roger as well. As for N, well, I have a thing for trying to play deities with a sense of jokey menace. I mean, the Big N is so vast and incomprehensible, just showing up and doing a powers test isn't that big a deal or even that frightening. (And it practice, it tends to make players even more belligerent.) But making an extradimensional nightclub? That allows the PCs to access him on terms they sort of understand, and lets him get to them insidiously.

      You're dead on about the tone. If the overall shape of this reboot owes a lot to Ronald Moore's Battlestar Galactica reboot, it's getting pretty clear that the tone of the campaign owes a lot to Joss Whedon. That is, smart, jokey, very capable heroes who shrug off most of the horror around them--but every now and then get hit by stuff that even makes them scared. So I have basically invented Buffystar Galactica, which come to think of it is a game I would play. Play so hard :-)

      More anon...

      \n Oh, and about Hypatia: I'm not really sure, but I think she just picked up the secret of immortality somewhere and has been just living on and on. At least some of the time she uses the Great Race ability to swap minds with people, but she also just flits from time to time. She's been hiding out in Irem for a while now, using the Great Race spell to check on the world, but mostly hiding from Shakhti/Gilgamesh. (This was part of her taunt to "Jilly" under the Sphinx; he thought she used the Great Race spell exclusively, and thus could resurrect her from her body; she just never stopped using her body.)

      Inasmuch as I think about it, Shakhti's plan was to resurrect her in such a way as would allow him to control her. In this he seems to have been, as Hypatia put it, "off-playbook" and working his own schemes; the Dark Lord certainly wants Hypatia back for the conclusion of his great scheme, but that didn't include her being the puppet of his second-favorite servant. Hypatia must have figured that Shakhti would eventually try something like this, which is why she left the mummified Dimensional Shambler for him to find, along with some artifacts to make sure she could gloat when he did.
      \n

      The cool thing about your Hypatia is that she's... well, probably a villain, more or less, but also an odd ally for the PCs.

    The Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep [Trail of Cthulhu]

    \n
    \xab1234567\u202611\xbb

      As for the Shambler, yeah. She doesn't play fair :-)

      \n
      \n Damn, having promised some analysis, where to begin?

      This episode contains, ironically, some of my earliest and latest thoughts on the reboot. I checked my notes, and I have an entry saying to use Hypatia as Nitocris from back in November. As I said above, the Hypatia-as-incubator thing is my least favorite part of Masks, so it's not any surprise that changing her fate was one of my earliest ideas.

      Having made that decision, I now found myself with another problem: assuming I wanted to keep the Nitocris Resurrection plotline, how was that going to work? I toyed around with the idea of having her just get resurrected as per the original, but by this point I was already beginning to move stuff around and had begun to plan to have Irem be part of the Cairo section. The Arabian Nights bit about a mummified queen worked perfectly for this, so I decided to have Hypatia show up there.

      But then what the hell was in the sarcophagus? It took me about two months to figure that one out; it wasn't until very close to the beginning of the campaign that I finally hit on the idea that Hypatia left a trap for people who wanted to try and bring her back. Given that I'd already established in my notes that Shakhti and M'Weru didn't get along, it didn't seem much of a stretch that Hypatia would also be uncharitable towards Omar. Somewhere along the line I decided that she would leave the mummy of a Dimensional Shambler inside her sarcophagus, and that Broadmoor would channel her mockery of Shakhti during the ritual. It was great, if railroady, theater.

      (There are hints in the resurrection scene of just what the mummy is--it consistently teleported away from attempts to throw it or immobilize it.)

      In my retelling, Hypatia is a bit of a free agent. She's not going to take over the leadership of the cult like Nitocris is supposed to do in the canon Masks. She clearly quit the Big N's project a long time ago, but she wouldn't be around if she hadn't figured out a way placate him. (Nyarlathotep has another mother for his child; I haven't cut that bit, just mixed it up some.) I pretty much planned to have her be a potential ally of the PCs, if not a very reliable one (or one particularly interested in helping them all the time.)

      While the rather fudgey nature of the fight with Shakhti offends me, in retrospect (in addition to freeing him from Hetep and kicking him the sword, Hypatia transferred four points of Pearkes' Stability to Health--I feel bad about that one), with a bit of perspective it makes a lot of sense for Hypatia to help the PCs there. They're her catspaws; she uses them to get rid of Shakhti, whom she hates, without it being the case that she took out one of the Dark Lord's minions on her own.

      That brings us to Nyarlathotep, and the encounter in the nightclub. I knew I wanted to do something different with that encounter, especially since I suspected I would move it. (In fact, I planned to have it available in any of the locations, depending on where the PCs went. It actually occurred slightly earlier than I wanted, but seemed to fit organically--in any case, Irem was always the best place for it.

      I'm not sure how I settled on the nightclub act; it's not in my notes, so it may be a fairly old idea, although I kept refining it. The plan to attack the PCs' Pillars of Sanity was a very recent idea--I didn't come up with it until after episode IV. Nyarlathotep's song was a direct result of me messing around with "Happy Together" during my piano lessons; I realized that with a few word changes it would make a goofy/creepy theme song for the Big N's appearance. (I also toyed with the idea of having a cleaning woman show up at the end of the show and prove to be the real Nyarlathotep, but it didn't work out that way in play; but I'm keeping that one in my pocket.)

      Okay, okay: Nyarlathotep as a lounge singer isn't exactly cosmic horror. I don't think it was exactly comic relief, though; I tried to keep up the subtle sense of menace throughout his appearance. (I couldn't transcribe it, but I made him talk in a kind of run-on manner, with his sentences following so fast they almost overlapped; that and a lot of changes to dynamics gave him what I hoped was a kinda supervillain demeanor.) I'm hoping that in some way the PCs pick up that N is so powerful, so confident, that he can even afford to look a bit silly--just don't laugh to his face.

      The idea of pushing the PCs into fiction had its germ in a very old idea that got refined over time and didn't take its final form until the campaign started. I had toyed early on with the idea of the PCs not getting sent back just to Egypt, but other times; Pearkes seemed a natural to go back to Napoleonic days. While the ground rules of the campaign's fictional world were still in flux, I thought about making the events of the Aubriad actual history. Somewhere along the line I decided that it would be more interesting to have the worlds N could put the PCs be fictional even in the campaign's world. This eventually led to the idea of each PC (possibly Freddie and Gilbert as a unit) going to their own world.

      The Aubriad was the first one I came up with; not sure when the meeting with Pearkes takes place, but probably either after HMS Surprise or The Wine-Dark Sea. Not sure when I settled on Nineteen Eighty-Four, but it seemed natural to shove FP's toff into the crapsack dystopia. The Man in the High Castle was the last one, chosen mostly because I re-read it for a book club. But in fact it has a lot going for it (I mean, in my game, not just as a novel!) as the whole reality vs fiction motif and the ultimate derivation of The Grasshopper Lies Heavy let me play with metafiction on a grand scale.

      In terms of Lovecraft's fiction, the book-worlds are manifestations of the Dreamlands--although they may also represent possible futures/pasts for the campaign world.

      In terms of how I ran the session, I think it was a bit too railroaded. I'm glad I got the bangs in and fun was had, but I was clearly running the circus. I'm going to try and cycle back a bit on that now; I've got the biggest bits of my reboot mythos in play now, and I'm hoping the temptation to be such a "Classic GM" will abate. Also, I talk it out here, and I'm my own worst critic, so I think things will look up now :-)
      \n

      \n I missed the teleporting bit -- I need to reread that. I hadn't realized the nightclub was a moveable piece. That's great!

      I think that as the players learn to play less "classically", you'll learn to be less of a "classic GM", and vice versa.

      What did Hypatia do to placate the Big N?
      \n
