      \n In re the Dimensional Mummy, I may not have been super clear about what was happening in the written account--it made sense in play, but I do compress my descriptions somewhat when I make the transcription.

      I agree with you wholeheartedly on the change over necessary :-) Of course, the group is more or less happy with a traditional GM/Player setup; but I think it's worthwhile to explore new modes, so I keep pushing to open up the narrative space more. FP gets it the most, as I've noted, and GPs lack of experience helps him get more in the spirit, I think.

      I have no idea what Hypatia did. Must have been something, right? If this comes out at all, it will come out in play & I hope the players have a hand in creating the explanation. I'm going to stick with the "we're just friends" explanation for now--if the group meets Hypatia again (they probably will), they can ask her--just make sure to know who the session players are in her band, as the Big N may occasionally drop by for a set...

      I didn't see any reason not to make the nightclub a movable feast. Encountering the Big N should just happen. There's absolutely no good reason to hold that encounter back from the PCs, nor is there any reason why Nyarlathotep should be limited by pesky things like the space-time continuum. (I have some ideas on what N is, or at least what he says he is, that may come out in the next session, which is theoretically this Saturday.) My general feeling in this campaign is that I'm going to try and give them all the content possible.

      \n Well, that kind of thing wasn't done back then, you know :-)

      Been browsing the Masks Companion. Ton of good stuff, but sadly I've broken too many things to make much use. The Shanghai stuff will probably be okay. It's interesting to see just how tied to simulation CoC tries to be. I am quite comfortable that I didn't end up running this campaign with it.

      Still in negotiations, but I'm pretty sure I'll be running the next session on Saturday. I finally found the title: "The Windmills of Your Mind." I was going to go with something book-themed--I had tentatively decided to look at "My Back Pages." However, last week I decided, as I do sometimes, to use Spotify to acquaint myself with artists I remain shockingly unexposed to; this time it was Dusty Springfield. Her rendition of this-trippy-even-for-Michel-Legrand ballad is so amazing that I knew I'd found the theme for the next session.

      So it's interesting--I mentioned that when I choose a title, it tends to influence my thinking about the next installment. Certainly I'm now thinking along the lines of lost love, and surreal dream imagery. Which I was headed for anyway, but it does focus the mind some.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n

      \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I think through writing, with pen and paper. I brainstorm, I make notes, I copy my notes, and somewhere in that process, I'm preparing. I'm almost always using a published scenario and tweaking it round the bend. If I'm not doing that, I'm probably swiping a plot from a manga or something. I've never tried to work with a musical theme like you're doing, but I know a couple of other people who have, one of whom used one particular album for plotting his game. (I don't recall what system or setting it was for, let alone what album he used.)
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n My prep varies. Generally, for any game, I let my brain kick out what I think might be cool scenes. I try hard not to think how they'll play out, just things that make the scene interesting: a location, a situation, a confrontation. If I'm on my game, I subconsciously frame them a bit like Robin Laws does in DramaSystem: get a grasp on the conflict, who's the petitioner and who's the granter.

      In the Pathfinder game, I had two steps at this point: first, I would do a wireframe of "nodes" (see Justin Alexander's very interesting "three clue" rule & node based design), with the connections between each scene plotted out. I usually just did a basic key, writing down a quick summary of the clues and where they led to.

      Then I would plan the encounters. This took the most time, partly because I could never efficiently read the Paizo monster stat blocks. I ended up grabbing a spreadsheet from the SRD site and built a Word merge document that put everything in a place where I could read it. (I also blocked out hit points in groups of 5, so I could just cross off boxes & not do much math.) Beyond the formatting, setting up balanced encounters was always a pain in the butt, even with me reskinning monsters frequently.

      For the Masks campaign, I don't usually bother with doing wireframes, as the campaign book already has done most of that kind of work. I sometimes make a few brief notes on the major NPCs for that session, and jot down some ideas for extra scenes--for example, the raid on the Mosque of Ibn Tulun in the last session. (I had actually prepped the three vampires for Session IV, but they never came in play.) I tend to run things on the fly anyway, so I can get away with a low amount of prep. (And since I record the sessions now, I'm not likely to forget stuff later.)

      The musical "inspiration" I sort of blundered into operates on a very subconscious level, but it is in there somewhere; I'm kind of interested to see if it will play out in this session, given how I've been obsessed with the title song for a while now, and that I'm actually conscious of trying to use it as inspiration.

      I'm actually trying to do a "credit sequence" for this session; if I manage to finish it, I'll see if I can find a way to post it here. (I also owe you guys some clips of the sessions themselves; again, it's finding a place to host it that's the main issue right now.)
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n Didn't finish the credit sequence, but if I get a tiny bit of time I'll try to (I'm off on Wednesday for my Four Capitals whirlwind tour of Europe.)

      We didn't have GP, so my thought that Gilbert would jump through the various novels didn't come to pass. Still, some cleverness on the part of the PCs, the Big N made a few reappearances, Freddie got an interesting new citizenship, and there was some offstage pruning of NPCs. Then on to Paris!

      Found out that PP is moving earlier than we thought, so we may or may not get another session in with him, and I'm going a-recruiting again...

      More anon!

      \n
      \n
      \n Depends when you would join, Lisa. And Jack Brady makes a passable PC :-)

      I do have a couple of people from the Tuesday group I'm in who might make a good match.

      We had another one interesting incident, and since the writeup will be piecemeal, I'll discuss it briefly here:

      The PCs get in to meet Edouard Gavigan, the head of Fondation Aubrey Penhew, the Paris-headquartered charitable foundation created by Penhew's estate. They make some inquiries. FP mentions that he's talked to Hypatia, but Gavigan seems unflappable. (As will be revealed, his suave exterior belies a pretty tough inner core.) They mention Jackson Elias, and he flinches a bit but says he barely remembers talking to her.

      Having run out of threads, FP suggests that PP use Interrogation. I point out that for Interrogation to work, you need to at least convince the target that he is in your power. I also mention that he can tell there's some kind of way through the closets in Gavigan's office to a room beyond--he can see the light coming in.

      So Pearkes locks the door, draws his gun, and demands that Gavigan answer some questions.

      Gavigan very obviously presses a hidden button on his desk and smoothly says that the interview is over.

      Pearkes punches him, Charleston secures him, and they go into the storage room next door. Gavigan tells them that everyone in the Expedition is dead except possibly Brady, and that Elias was insane. Then the police arrive and arrest the PCs.

      I am of a couple of minds about this and how I handled it.

      From a purely narrative/fictional stance, I don't think I was all that unreasonable. Gavigan is a hard nut to crack, and pulling a gun in his own sanctum isn't going to scare him or let him think that he's in somebody else's power--all he has to do is hold out for a little while, and the law and his own servants will arrive to help him.

      On the other hand, Pearkes has the skill, and interrogation is a bit difficult to use in a lot of situations. Plus, there are plenty of examples in fiction where this kind of thing can work.

      I'm just not 100% convinced this was one of them. Against a lesser target, it might well have worked.

      But on the gripping hand, am I being too hard on the players? This is one of those fine line questions.

      Personally, I think that what keeps getting me is that there seems to be an expectation that the PCs can act like this and then resume normal life, even though I telegraphed in the New York chapter that naked violence would have consequences, if precautions weren't taken. Had they grabbed Gavigan off the street & then spirited him away somewhere, I'd have been happy to let it work. But threatening a guy who regularly has dinner at the Elysee Palace, in his office, in broad daylight? When the guy in question has a very shady past and is extremely well-connected? I dunno.

      I'll probably give them some leads from this, so that I didn't nerf the skill, and FP & PP made some buys (Credit Rating from FP to find a suitably-connected avocat and then Bargain from PP to pay the exorbitant civil settlement that resulted) that will allow the heat to die down somewhat. But it was still a tough situation and I'm ambivalent about my response--but also about what to do with the inevitable future recurrences of this situation.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n So a couple of things before I begin the writeup.

      I had one of those fridge moments just now. I was near the fridge, but not actually using it. Anyway.

      I've been striving, with spotty success, to change up how I run games. To be less railroady in general, to allow more narrative control. To that end, I prepped practically nothing for the session. I had a couple of cool "this might be an interesting element" scenes in mind, but I told my players that I was interested in seeing how they got out of their situations, and I meant it; I honestly didn't know.

      In practice, however, there was a lot of deus ex machina. Now, given that there's an actual deus involved, maybe that's not unexpected. But still.

      The other thing that happened is that I made a hard, threatening move against one PC. I think it was justified in the fiction. In practice, it channeled him towards a choice (the next destination) that I was happy with. So: did I railroad? Is there a difference between a hard move and railroading in this case? (Yes, I know the common distinction between hard & soft moves, plus I just ordered Vincent's pdf package to read on my trip, so I'll have an even better idea shortly.)

      If you give a player a shove, without taking away their ability to move or not move, and they move (because you shoved them), did you rob them of agency? Or are they harmonizing with the fiction?

      I honestly don't know. So I'll try to write it up and see what you guys think.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Prelude)

      December, 1947

      [This was a scene that played out between me and FP. It would potentially have led to one possible way to tie together and resolve the "to your scattered fictions go!" storyline--Alphonse Gilbert entering each of the fictional worlds to retrieve his friends--but it didn't play out that way since GP was unexpectedly absent. So it goes.]

      Waves pound the shores of Jura, in the Hebrides. The day dawns with sunlight filtering through a ragged sky, and cold winds lash the moors.

      In a small cottage, a large, bustling housekeeper enters a darkened room. She opens some blinds, revealing a man sleeping in a tousled bed. The sunlight illuminates a large typewriter.

      "Guid morning, sir. Did ye get any writing done last night?"

      "No, I had the most ridiculous dream. Something about albatrosses."

      "That's terrible. Oh, Mr. Paul is here to see you."

      "Bring him up."

      Moments later, a young man steps into the room. "Morning Eric."

      [Paul Potts, a young novelist of the era.]

      "Morning."

      "Feeling any better, old man?"

      "Not in the least. I feel like everything that's happened in the world is just going to get worse and worse."

      "Is your cough any better?"

      "No. I expect to die any day now."

      "That's not the spirit, old man."

      "Since when have you known me to be an optimist?"

      Paul sits down. "I was down in the village yesterday and I ran into a doctor who was on holiday. Frenchman, specialist in respiratory illness. He mentioned he would be happy to come and check on you--says he's interested in how the new drugs are working."

      "He's welcome to come up."

      "Good, I brought him over this morning. I'll send him in."

      Paul leaves, and eventually a gaunt, extremely Gallic-looking man in a white lab coat enters. "Good morning, Mr.--I keep wanting to say the other name, but you are Mr. Blair. I am a great admirer of your work."

      "I don't see why. Nobody reads it."

      "Not at all! I thought your book on Paris and London was excellent."

      "People say Dickens did it better."

      "Ah, but Dickens was...how to say..."

      "A Romantic?"

      "He had a bourgeois mentality."

      "Ah, I see. A Socialist?"

      "Me? No. I know Socialists, but I am not one. I am not optimistic enough to be one."

      "I understand. Come in. You wanted to speak of drugs?"

      "Yes, you are taking streptomycin?"

      "Yes. I expect it will kill me faster. Certainly I vomit more often."

      "Are you writing?"

      "Indeed. I find it takes my mind off my illness."

      "I have a favor to ask..."

      "You wish to be a character in my new novel?"

      "No, not me. But it would be a great favor if you could write about my poor brother. Even if it was not a scene in the published work, he would appreciate it..."

      "What is his name?"

      "Alphonse, Mr. Orwell," says Anton. "Alphonse Gilbert."
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJune 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 1)

      Somewhere in 1984...

      Freddie is shoved roughly into a police station and thrust up against a large counter. A clerk who looks very much like David Warner glances at him.

      "Number."

      [So FP wanted a Party ID and made a ridiculous Preparedness roll here. I had to think about it, but I decided to let him have one--it amused N.]

      Freddie tosses an identification packet at him. The clerk looks at him, and then at the ID. He gestures to some constables, and they shove Freddie into a chair. Freddie leans back, relaxing.

      The clerk goes into a back room. Glancing around, Freddie notices that people are staring at him. One young clerk nearby picks up the phone and seems to be in an animated conversation with someone. Freddie tries to read his lips:

      "No, he doesn't...yes, he does...No, he isn't...I'm not sure. Younger."

      Then the clerk gets up and leaves.

      Freddie takes out a notepad and begins writing. David Warner nods at one of the guards, and they take the notepad.

      Freddie takes out another one. The guard takes that one too.

      "You do know that I have an almost endless supply of these?"

      "The prisoner will refrain from writing," says David Warner.

      "That will make it difficult for me to write my report," says Freddie.

      "And what report would that be?"

      "You have my bloody ID in front of you."

      "I know your ID says you are Party Member O'Brien. This does not explain your dress."

      [FP was trying hard to weave himself into the fiction-within-a-fiction here. Unfortunately, Nyarlathotep certainly didn't set things up that way, so I couldn't quite give it to him. I did let him push things a bit more later on.]

      "As I recall, I don't need to explain myself. How do you explain your reaction to it?"

      David Warner nods at the Thought Police thugs. They pull Freddie out of the chair. At that moment, two more constables walk in. "We have orders from Comrade General Jeremias to take this man," they tell the desk clerk.

      "I have orders from Comrade O'Brien to hold this man."

      [I gave FP the option to decide which group he wanted to go with.]

      Freddie quickly decides that the new thugs look like his better play. He grabs his notebooks back and leaves with them.

      They throw him into a truck and sit facing him with pistols drawn. The truck drives for a long time through the dusty streets of London.

      \n Ack: My text is too long! I'll break this up.

      Okay, just got back from a filking convention, so I've not read the latest update.\n
      I do have a couple of people from the Tuesday group I'm in who might make a good match.
      \n
      From a purely narrative/fictional stance, I don't think I was all that unreasonable. Gavigan is a hard nut to crack, and pulling a gun in his own sanctum isn't going to scare him or let him think that he's in somebody else's power--all he has to do is hold out for a little while, and the law and his own servants will arrive to help him.

      On the other hand, Pearkes has the skill, and interrogation is a bit difficult to use in a lot of situations. Plus, there are plenty of examples in fiction where this kind of thing can work.

      I'm just not 100% convinced this was one of them. Against a lesser target, it might well have worked.

      But on the gripping hand, am I being too hard on the players? This is one of those fine line questions.
      \nI'm honestly not sure. I'm seeing a pattern hear with Pearkes's player, one you're also aware of -- he comes up with something, you deny or partially deny, and on the one hand, aren't sure you've nerfed him, but on the other, you're convinced that he was asking for something unreasonable.\n
      Personally, I think that what keeps getting me is that there seems to be an expectation
      \nAnd it's all about expectations, correct? This is an ongoing clash. No blame to anyone, but this has been the case for a while and needs some better tools to address it. I'm just not sure of what tools those would be. And, if you knew, you'd be using them.\n
      that the PCs can act like this and then resume normal life, even though I telegraphed in the New York chapter that naked violence would have consequences, if precautions weren't taken. Had they grabbed Gavigan off the street & then spirited him away somewhere, I'd have been happy to let it work. But threatening a guy who regularly has dinner at the Elysee Palace, in his office, in broad daylight? When the guy in question has a very shady past and is extremely well-connected? I dunno.
      \nIf it were me and IF I were thinking on my feet, I'd probably be saying some of this before the point of no return, e.g., "You do realize that you're doing this highly anti-social thing in broad daylight, when this guy is well connected and you can't prove he's done anything wrong or that you're anything other than a thug? You might want to do this somewhere more private, where perhaps you control the environment, rather than him."

      \n
      I'll probably give them some leads from this, so that I didn't nerf the skill, and FP & PP made some buys (Credit Rating from FP to find a suitably-connected avocat and then Bargain from PP to pay the exorbitant civil settlement that resulted) that will allow the heat to die down somewhat. But it was still a tough situation and I'm ambivalent about my response--but also about what to do with the inevitable future recurrences of this situation.
      \nThere's also a mechanics expectation. If you're allowing a spend, it must be effective. Otherwise, don't allow the spend. If you're allowing the roll, make sure everyone is clear about what success and failure mean. If what the players want from a success is not something you are prepared to permit, don't allow the roll.

      This may mean slowing down and saying, "Okay, wait. What do you want to happen?" Then, once you have the details, figure out whether you're good with that or not. If not, "No, that won't happen because [insert explanation, perhaps countersuggestion]." If so, "Okay, and this is what a failure means." Right now, in my arrogant opinion, you need to slow down because communication is not 5 by 5 here, and I think you're both frustrating each other.

      Another thing to keep an eye out for is the X-Y problem. That is, if the player wants to do X to get Y outcome -- e.g., threaten Gavigan to learn where the next ritual will take place (or whatever), don't focus on threatening Gavigan, on what it will do, on why it will or won't work. Look at Y. What does the player hope to get? This will help you countersuggest if the player's way off base.

      But, complicating this, there's a part of Y that you're hearing, correctly, I think, and that complicates things. It isn't just "I want information on where the ritual is" -- it's that AND "I want to look cool doing it and get a bit of spotlight". And that's part of where you're feeling conflicted. You want to make the PCs look cool, but not at the expense of your suspension of disbelief.

      And you may need to give on the suspension of disbelief. You may need to go a little more pulp. I can't tell. If this is a matter of communication and matching expectations, it's entirely likely that you guys can find a good balance. You might be able to do more of "Okay, you're a policeman / you're Gavigan, and the NPC does what you just did. Honestly, now -- what follows?"

      But, it may be that you're stuck too much on what you think should happen. I can't tell. I can tell that I am seeing this as a pattern in what you've been saying (roughly, "I feel bad about the decision I made, but that seemed to be the only logical decision that didn't negate the way the world works"), but you're venting, you're analyzing and critiquing yourself, and, most importantly, you were there and I was not. I've played with honest, well meaning players who simply push for as much as they can get away with, with absolutely no malice -- but also no understanding of the genre conventions a game's dealing with (and I'm including various modes of realism as genre conventions).

      Fr'ex, I ran one scenario where the PCs had essentially won the day, convincing some serpentfolk that it was possible to coexist with humanity without needing to crush or cow it. (This is my Kerberos Fate game, and not any flavor of Cthulhu gaming.) So far, so fine. Then, one player tried to convince the serpentfolk that he was a Secret Serpentfolk Operative (he could shapechange) and got increasingly frustrated as he failed to have them eating out of his hand.

      He eventually decided that his character had been trying to outclever himself, something entirely in character, and we wrapped things up with a happy resolution. But, there was definitely a communications issue.

      First, he wasn't aware that one particular event was now unstoppable. This had been in the control of another player's PC, and his PC never had the option to interfere directly. This was not clear to the player, and it was so clear to the rest of us that we utterly failed to understand he didn't realize it.

      Second, he was making some giant assumptions about serpentfolk culture with no data. And I was saying over and over to myself, "Why does he think that's the way they work? It isn't." (It would have helped if I'd said that out loud, as players cannot be expected to read minds.)

      Am I throwing my weight around deciding "Nope, that's just how the world works, and you can't convince the serpentfolk you're a secret intelligence operative, because they didn't have anyone in that role who'd be acting the way you're having your character act"? Is he being unreasonable expecting that he can get sentient beings he'd never encountered before to follow his lead without question merely because his shapechange skill no longer requires that he study a target before taking its shape? (Comes right out of the rules for Kerberos Fate, plain as day.) Do I tell him to roll the dice again and set an absurdly high target number?

      Ideally, I would have stopped him and said, "Okay, first of all, you can't stop what's going on. Second, you don't have to. Third, you don't know enough about their culture to take over. Fourth, you don't have to -- you guys have won."

      There's an additional factor in this case. Gavigan's one of those smart villains that can be a real pain for GMs. Play him too effectively, and the players don't have a chance. Have him make mistakes, and you run the risk of him feeling too dumb. It can be tricky to find a middle ground.

      But, it's not impossible. First, playing Trail of Cthulhu means the PCs will find the core clues they need. Okay. What are those clues? How can they find them? Forget diaries and intimidating one particular person. Clues = Bits of Information. What do they need? Once you know that, the actual information can be planted wherever you need it to be.

      Second, Gavigan can make mistakes. If I recall his backstory, he's a self-made man who started off poor and resents folks who were born with a silver spoon in their mouth. One of them's just annoyed him, right? Freddy has Bad Luck. So, he can try to sic thugs or monsters on the group in such a way that can give Pearkes a chance to fight them, correct?

      And what kind of boss is he? What kind of cultist leader? Might there be a disgruntled employee who wants to help the PCs take Gavigan down a peg, and willing to supply information, not realizing how dangerous this is? Might there be a cultist who wants to take Gavigan's place? If so, that's someone who can be dumb enough to make all the mistakes Gavigan would never make.

      I've been striving, with spotty success, to change up how I run games. To be less railroady in general, to allow more narrative control. To that end, I prepped practically nothing for the session. I had a couple of cool "this might be an interesting element" scenes in mind, but I told my players that I was interested in seeing how they got out of their situations, and I meant it; I honestly didn't know.

      In practice, however, there was a lot of deus ex machina. Now, given that there's an actual deus involved, maybe that's not unexpected. But still.
      \nFor me, prepping helps me roll with it when the players drive the plot off the rails. And, for me, overprepping slightly is better than underprepping. But, YMMV.\n
      The other thing that happened is that I made a hard, threatening move against one PC. I think it was justified in the fiction. In practice, it channeled him towards a choice (the next destination) that I was happy with. So: did I railroad? Is there a difference between a hard move and railroading in this case? (Yes, I know the common distinction between hard & soft moves, plus I just ordered Vincent's pdf package to read on my trip, so I'll have an even better idea shortly.)

      If you give a player a shove, without taking away their ability to move or not move, and they move (because you shoved them), did you rob them of agency? Or are they harmonizing with the fiction?

      I honestly don't know. So I'll try to write it up and see what you guys think.
      \nStill haven't read the write ups, so the particulars may change my opinion, but I think shoving is like a Magician's Choice -- there's no real choice. Okay, that's not entirely true, but it sounds like it's definitely steering things. This may or may not be a problem.

      I'm not sure Hard Moves is the way to think for CoC / ToC, although I'm not sure it isn't. But, also think Dogs in the Vineyard -- the information will come out. Your core clues must come out. Supplementary clues don't need to come out.

      At this point, where you are right now, not where you were before the end of the most recent session, what are the PCs trying to do? What do they know? What do they need to know to keep the plot moving? This may be "nothing" -- we're talking "How do PCs find the plot?", not "How do PCs succeed in thwarting it?" -- but, complicating this, Masks may be less satisfying if the PCs don't ever find out what they should be doing.

      What are player expectations? What are your expectations? Right now, how much of a clash between these two exists? For me, my PC burning all bridges to a normal life isn't a dealbreaker, but doing so to meet with only failure and frustration in thwarting the bad guys (as opposed to going out with a bang, a noble, but failing effort) probably would be. But, I wouldn't come up with a PC like Pearkes. I'm not sure what I would come up with for Masks, but Pearkes isn't my style.

      \n Okay, I'm now caught up. Is FP more on a wavelength with you than PP? That is, you've got four players. I can't get a good sense of GP. CP seems to be happily digging his character into a deep, deep hole, and so long as he's happy, it's golden. FP seems to know how to match expectations -- or how to convince you that his expectations really are compatible with yours, and it's hard to see whether they just are, whether he's charismatic, whether it's because he's playing a character good at social skills, rather than military skills, in a game of ancient and deadly conspiracies which seem more socially than physically vulnerable.

      Again, I'm seeing through a glass darkly and enjoying the write ups. I don't know how much of the advice I'm spouting is actually relevant.

      \n Lisa,

      You have a ton of good stuff there. I'm going to think about these things deeply. Also, I have Dogs and Apocalypse World in pdf form (Thanks, Vincent!) which will make good airport reading!

      I may need to come back and forth to your points, but let's start with a few things.

      First, on Gavigan: what they found out at the end of the session from Mickey Mahoney (in my reboot, the publisher of an Irish Nationalist paper and also pretty clearly an intelligence operative for the Irish Free State) is that Edouard Gavigan, the suave, well-connected graduate of the Ecole Diplomatique who dines twice a year with the President at the Elysee Palace, was actually born Eddie Gaffigan in Ireland--"Ulsterman, and a bad 'un" as Mahoney puts it. By 1915 he was a bomb-maker and assassin working for one of the militias that would form the Irish Republican Army; but in 1916 he was a member of a British Army unit commanded by Colonel Aubrey Penhew. During the Rising he seems to have betrayed a Republican patrol to the British, resulting in their massacre.

      Sometime after that he suddenly appeared in his M. Gavigan persona, as Penhew's rising protege.

      So clearly Gavigan is a pure survivor, ambitious as Satan and cold as a lizard. Mahoney tells the PCs that there have been at least three attempts, by operatives who knew what they were doing, to assassinate Gavigan; not only did all of them fail, but the ops were never heard from again.

      This isn't the kind of guy who gets phased just because somebody sticks a gun in his face.

      Now, I knew that but the PCs didn't. OTOH, I hadn't given them the results of the research yet--but that was intentional, as Gavigan wanted to meet them at an advantage. I simply didn't anticipate them going full-on aggro with him, mostly because what the hell?

      Maybe it's because I played a lot of classic Traveller when I was a kid. Trav actually had rules (Law Level, official harassment) to deal with local police. In Traveller, if you're planning illegal activities, you always take the police into account. (And, you know, that's a genre convention as well. In the post-game period, I considered the pulp examples of coming into a guy's office and sticking a gun in his face; my sense is that it tends to work if its the minor guy, or the businessman in over his head, but if its the Big Bad, you do so with an expectation that the cops will eventually show up and you'll need an explanation; Chandler is rife with examples.)

      But I think you're right. I'm getting caught up on "don't just deny an action, because that's nerfing player choice" without considering that not giving a PC full info is also nerfing choice. Tough, innit? I mean, I did tell them the requirements for Interrogation, but they interpreted that as "we need to lock the door" and I should have probably guided them away from it. (Really, the best thing to do would have been to say, "Guys, here's where you are: most of your interpersonal skills won't affect him at this point, until you have something on him; and by the way, he got slightly rattled when you mentioned Hypatia.")

      So why didn't that happen? I have a few thoughts, but for your consideration, here's a pretty much verbatim transcription of the exchange in question; I've left in all the OOC speech, so you can see what was going on.

      FP, to PP: You have Interrogation, why don't you ask some leading questions?

      PP: Why, yes I will!

      Me: Interrogation requires that the person at least believe he is in your power. [Note: that's not the actual rule; I bent it slightly to make it more useful!]

      FP: You can't do a coffee shop interrogation, like in Cold War movies?

      Me: No, that's other skills.

      FP: Could we use Reassurance? Get him to drop some clues?

      CP: Yeah, seems easier than trying to kidnap him.

      PP: Where are we, in a coffee shop? ...

      [Okay, break. Problem the first: PP had just driven home from Canada that day, and his fiancee had come home about an hour earlier; he was tired, it was late, and he had been taking care of some stuff as the game wound down. Human reaction: I was a bit annoyed he'd checked out. Humane reaction: I should have taken this more into account.

      [at this point I describe the artifacts on Gavigan's desk and mention that there's a room beyond the closets.]

      PP: I will stand up, move over to the door, and lock it. [to Gavigan] I think we should have a private conversation. Ask you a few questions.

      Me, as Gavigan: [miming pressing a concealed button] I think that this interview is over.

      PP: I think it's just begun.

      CP: I reverse the chair under the door.

      PP: I punch him.

      FP, in character: Oh Good God!

      Gavigan: Aidez-moi, aidez-moi! Au secours!

      [pounding on door]

      CP: I got this. Do I have anything sharp on me?

      PP: I don't need that. I pull my gun.

      CP: That will be loud...

      PP: I'm not going to pull the trigger, I'm just going to intimidate him.

      Aieee, this is the first time I've really listened to the recording. That sure sticks out!

      But maybe you can see how this escalated gradually, and it wasn't so easy for me to just step in. The proper time to do it was when PP declared he was going to hit Gavigan, although even then things hadn't really gotten to the point that he wouldn't have just let them go. It was ultimately pulling the gun and dragging him into the storeroom that did it, that and the police arriving.

      Anyway, I'll have more anon. I think the major issue for me is to slow down more. This is hard, since in Robin Laws' typology I'm a straight up Method Actor and I tend to get very caught up in the character I'm playing at the time, leaving me less room to step back.

      \n Of course, another way of looking at this is that one player decided to grab the scene, and the other players fell in line supporting him--as, in fact, did I, by not cutting him off.

      Which is to say: we allowed PP to make a choice, and then we all supported that choice, including me, with the notable proviso that my support of that action would (by nature of my role) include providing the consequences of that action.

      I have to think about his more. I've never done improv (although I'm getting interested in maybe taking a little acting on the side) so I don't know what kind of a situation this is. It looks like the rest of us were saying yes to PP, but PP wasn't letting us say "Yes, but..."

      But that's my three-cups-of-coffee interpretation. Talk to me after cups four and five :-)

      \n Still no extra cups of coffee, but another observation (transcribing this actually has been really useful): when there is trouble with PP, it is pretty much always a case of him escalating directly to confrontation/violence, with a side order of these moves tending to be forcing and irrevocable.

      Some history:

      --In the second session, while the other PCs were laying an ambush at the Ju Ju House and planning to stealth in and see what was going on, Pearkes drove up in his car and just walked straight in, shutting off the other options.

      --In the third session, he forced a fight with the vampire Polidori by unilaterally attacking him as the other PCs were trying to disengage.

      --Also in that session, one of my lowpoints in GMing came about in a similar fashion. Pearkes was gathering material for a stretcher to carry Freddie back to town. He doesn't have Stealth, so I ruled (correctly, as it turns out) that he made enough noise to rouse the shop owner whose awning he was stealing. He tried to pay the guy off (and here's where I should have de-escalated) but the shopkeeper chose not to accept the Englishman's money. This spun out of control into a mob scene.

      --Session Four did involve his plan to machine-gun the crowd at Shakhti's place, but that was just role-playing.

      OTOH, channeled he can be fantastic; he wasn't that meta at all when confronted with "Constance", he's always had Pearkes demonstrate personal bravery. But there's some flaw in the social contract between us. He's constantly looking to escalate into dominance and intimidation, even in situations where logically that won't work. Actually, especially in situations where that won't work. The rest of us don't want to not support his choices, so we fall in line with what he does to the fiction; but that tends to leave me in the uncomfortable position of having to slap down the consequences.

      There's also a playstyle mismatch going on at a personal level. I've played mean, even psychotically power-hungry characters. In fact, two of my favorite characters to play are a fire sorceress/con-artist, a street kid who longs for the ultimate power as a way to never get hurt again, and a combat-focused bard who specializes in interrogation and torture. Both are quick-witted, but both would definitely betray people if they needed to. (I temper this in actual play by having both of them be fairly loyal to the people they like.) But I have no illusions about either of them: they're anti-heros, and a bad end is almost certainly in the cards for them. And I'm okay with it! When I play the sorceress seriously, her story is that of a damaged person who could be either truly evil or truly repentant. (Probably evil.)

      But then, I'm comfortable with--hell, demand--moral ambiguity in my playstyle.

      PP is different. He likes moral clarity, and I think a big kick for him is to get situations via the game that he can't get in real life--clear cut right and wrong situations, or at least situations where he can solve them with a simple criterion. He also likes the chance to play characters who can act in dark/anti-heroic ways while holding themselves up as morally sound. (His paladins are always Lawful Intolerant.)

      In fantasy games--well, in Pathfinder--this gets papered over because there actually is moral clarity available, via the alignment system, even if in practice my games tend to be a lot more ambiguous about right and wrong. (When I run d20 games, I ask the players to define what their alignment means to them, since just about any behavior is justifiable under just about any alignment.) But this game...this game is, you know, reaching for postmodernity, with a lot of relativism. The Big N isn't pure evil (he's beyond human morality, but even given that he isn't what you think he might be.) Some people have done terrible things for good reasons. Others have done good things for terrible reasons.

      So it goes.

      FP is content with this; he basically likes a world of rational actors, so morality is fluid for him. CP likes playing characters who sink into their own depravity, but don't tend to take anybody with them (in the Pathfinder game he played an incredibly abrasive goblin wizard--but then, his charisma was like 5, so well done.)

      In terms of what you asked about FP seeming to get it more, I think that explains why, that and his enormous RPGing experience. Plus, given that he's a classic Tactician, he's totally content to use his narrative input to get his kick of routing around opposition; but since suspension of disbelief is important to him, he doesn't take it too far.

      I'm venting (on the internet!) its true, and probably not in an interesting way, but sadly writing stuff down is my way to work through stuff. I'm going to post this because I am interested in your reactions...

      \n Couple of other non-venty things.

      I agree that slowing down, and focusing on outcome not action is going to help. Now, while I love the "to do it, you must do it" theory, Gumshoe isn't set up perfectly for that kind of thing because of the need to declare what ability you want to use.

      The main problem, as I framed at considerable length above, is that in the gameplay as it exists now, this will require stopping the action and asking everyone to back up.

      Now, point of fact Gumshoe can help here--because I can ask people what they want to do with the skill, and then guide them a bit, or let them know where they have complete narrative control.

      If the scene had played out as PP asking, "I want to get more information. Can I use Interrogation?" then I would have prompted him about how that couldn't work because he couldn't get Gavigan in a place where he was under their control.

      "Can I Intimidate him?"

      "You don't think so, unless you can find some handle on him--he seems strangely unphased by your subtle hints of violence."

      ...Then we'd have some new information & clues coming in. I could even have dropped a hint about Hypatia. (Sadly, at the time I hadn't realized that Gavigan might be rattled by news that Hypatia was in play; I'll try to fix that next time.)

      So...what I need to do is to try and enforce some new guidelines on playstyle. Difficult. I'll need to get some flashcards or something :-)

      Plus, vacation! I can decompress while gathering material for the game (plenty of Egyptian artifacts in Berlin, and I can do some legwork in Paris.)

During the Rising he seems to have betrayed a Republican patrol to the British, resulting in their massacre.
      \nThat is very cool. (A reporter PC I played in a pulp game would probably decide to call him Eddie, and would probably be made to regret that.)\n
      So clearly Gavigan is a pure survivor, ambitious as Satan and cold as a lizard. Mahoney tells the PCs that there have been at least three attempts, by operatives who knew what they were doing, to assassinate Gavigan; not only did all of them fail, but the ops were never heard from again.

      This isn't the kind of guy who gets phased just because somebody sticks a gun in his face.
      \nThat doesn't necessarily follow. I mean, I'm fine with that being so for Gavigan, but it is not unreasonable to believe that even soldiers and assassins get nervous when there's a gun in their face. I could see PP thinking, "Okay, I have to control the environment and make him believe he's in my power? Well, what better way to do that than to put a gun to his head?"\n
      Now, I knew that but the PCs didn't. OTOH, I hadn't given them the results of the research yet--but that was intentional, as Gavigan wanted to meet them at an advantage. I simply didn't anticipate them going full-on aggro with him, mostly because what the hell?
      \nYah, this is clearly something you now know you need to factor in. I mean, even beyond the "Okay, players could go aggro, try to persuade, try to be sneaky...", as PP seems to turn to force a lot, even when the rest of the group doesn't.\n
      But I think you're right. I'm getting caught up on "don't just deny an action, because that's nerfing player choice" without considering that not giving a PC full info is also nerfing choice.
      \nYes, good point. And it can be really tricky to remember that what's obvious to you isn't to the players. That still trips me up.

      Anyway, more later, and enjoy the vacation.

      (Really, the best thing to do would have been to say, "Guys, here's where you are: most of your interpersonal skills won't affect him at this point, until you have something on him; and by the way, he got slightly rattled when you mentioned Hypatia.")
      \nYah, you need that last, because otherwise, however well justified, the scenario is denying players the chance to be effective -- it's a tricky thing, because if all of the NPCs can be walked all over by the PCs, it isn't a satisfying scenario.\n
      FP, to PP: You have Interrogation, why don't you ask some leading questions?

      PP: Why, yes I will!

      Me: Interrogation requires that the person at least believe he is in your power. [Note: that's not the actual rule; I bent it slightly to make it more useful!]
      \nI'll need to look up the actual rule. I'm reading Eternal Lies, and there's a section where the author's distinguishing between "soft" and "hard" interrogation.\n

      [Okay, break. Problem the first: PP had just driven home from Canada that day, and his fiancee had come home about an hour earlier; he was tired, it was late, and he had been taking care of some stuff as the game wound down. Human reaction: I was a bit annoyed he'd checked out. Humane reaction: I should have taken this more into account.
      \nOver the years, I've come to realize that real life can be annoying that way. We game on weekends or after a long day at work and are often tired. Players forget even basic stuff, which is why I was doing "Last week on..." handouts before Buffy existed. I welcomed PCs with eidetic memory as it justified the players having constant access to the clues. But yes, it can be annoying. Heck, in a pbem, one of my best players stunned us all by totally forgetting that the email to which he was responding was discussing a potential ally, not a known villain -- confusing two NPCs when the one under discussion was named. (Me: Just checking -- you really want to kill off NPC X? Him: What? No! He's much too interesting -- oh, is that who we were talking about?) This boggled me, as it was a short email, but so it goes.\n
      [at this point I describe the artifacts on Gavigan's desk and mention that there's a room beyond the closets.]
      \nAnd PP probably heard that as a hint that that was the place to take Gavigan for an interrogation, I'm guessing.\n
      But maybe you can see how this escalated gradually, and it wasn't so easy for me to just step in.
      \nOh, absolutely!\n
      Anyway, I'll have more anon. I think the major issue for me is to slow down more. This is hard, since in Robin Laws' typology I'm a straight up Method Actor and I tend to get very caught up in the character I'm playing at the time, leaving me less room to step back.
      \nAnd it's something a GM has to be able to do. But, that never makes it easy. (Also, the setting is a GM's character, ad the same rules about stepping back apply, but that's a side point.)

      I have to think about his more. I've never done improv (although I'm getting interested in maybe taking a little acting on the side) so I don't know what kind of a situation this is. It looks like the rest of us were saying yes to PP, but PP wasn't letting us say "Yes, but..."
      \nAnd it is sometimes appropriate to say, "No." But, I think what I'm seeing is a combination of him not hearing "Yes, but" instead of "Yes" and your "No, but" not necessarily being clear about the "but" -- and perhaps needing more, er, "but" in there.

      Again, part of this may be the material. I love Masks, but one part that drives me batty is where, to find Plot in Shanghai, the players must realize that their PCs must check out museums and ask for a particular type of expert, then sort through about 36 candidates, and then, after finding the right one, somehow figure out that they must tell this guy the truth, even though honesty may have gotten them badly burned elsewhere in the game. That convoluted and precise chain is the ONLY way given to find Brady, and without Brady, the Shanghai section is kind of pointless.

      Paid for some internet

      I agree (as usual) with a lot that has been written--even the parts I wrote

      After some long pauses, I don't think I was that off base about insisting on how the skill works--I had specifically told PP several times how it worked, in the past. Talking with FP, I think that I'll give Interrogation some other mechanical effects--the knowledge revealed is better and more focused, and will have lasting effects on the subject--he'll either fear or trust the interrogator.

      To some degree, there's nothing to be done with Pearkes. PP is always going to go aggro on people. I'll need to prep for it (not so much for PP specifically, since he's a short-timer now, but in general.) Though to be honest, Gavigan's response would pretty much always be the same. Guy's a bomber and assassin, and crazy enough to betray the IRA. He clearly doesn't fear death; and he'd take comfort in knowing a lot of people would go with him. This aint the first time somebody's stuck a gun in his face, after all.

      So what to take away? Plan for aggro--be ready to step back, and hand out clues as to consequences. (Though, again, the guy presses a secret button on his desk--what did PP think was happening there?) Also, I'm going to try next session to get the players to be more objective-oriented: don't tell me what you do, tell me what you want, let's pick a skill, and then narrate. A bit clumsier at first, but it avoids a lot of problems. (I'm also going to communicate to the players in stronger terms that this isn't Pathfinder; they gain nothing by trying to fool me or pull one off against me; I'm not in opposition!)

      Anyway, that's my thoughts for now...I'm beat (museums don't tour themselves, and are sometimes inconveniently far from each other!) I hope to come back soon with more tales from the fiction in a fiction, and the story of Freddie vs. Parliament!

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 2)

      Somewhere in the 1800s...

      Dr. Maturin (who is played by Alan Rickman in my version) examines Colonel Pearkes. "Your wounds are most interesting," he says, pulling an inch-long wooden splinter out of Pearkes' cheek. "You have been beaten, thrown against something with great force, and recently strangled. I find myself very curious about your injuries. Especially the strangulation."

      "A French chap tried to do something to me, but I soon put him right."

      Maturin shakes his head, and Pearkes has the strange feeling that he can tell he wasn't strangled by a rope.

      Aubrey bounces into the great cabin. "I say, Pearkes, do you play an instrument?"

      "Yes."

      "Violin?"

      "No. Er, nay."

      "That's dashed unfortunate. We have a first-class violist this trip. I got some Mozart sheet music when I was in London last, and was hoping we could try a string quartet."

      [FP: Tell him bagpipes! They'll throw you overboard!

      PP: I roll Preparedness.

      Me: For what?

      PP: A tin whistle.

      Me: Is that what you play?

      FP: It makes sense...]

      Pearkes whips out his tin whistle. Taken aback, Aubrey asks if he plays "the German flute." (As the traverse flute was known then.)

      "As long as it isn't a French flute, I'll play it."

      "Perhaps we can play some Corelli flute and strings...what do you say, Stephen?"

      Maturin glances at Pearkes over his colored spectacles. "I'd have to hear the gentleman play," he says dryly.

      [Gave PP a flat Preparedness roll here; he doesn't have Art, but I thought it was reasonable that Preparedness would cover having learned a piece in his youth. PP spent 5.]

      Aubrey sends for one of the Marines who plays flute, and gives it to Pearkes. The Colonel plays a somber Bach partitia.

      "I say, what was that? It was quite good."

      "Bach."

      "English Bach? Doesn't sound like him. His father? Sebastian Bach?"

      "Johann Sebastian Bach."

      "That's the fellow. I was at the music-seller's in London, and I bought some of his stuff. Was asking nothing for it."

      "This is extraordinary!" says Pearkes. In his trembling hand he holds an autograph copy of some Bach violin music.

      [That's an actual incident in the novels, btw.]

      "What do you say we give it a go!" Matarin is already taking out his cello. Pearkes listens with enjoyment--Aubrey is quite talented.

      Pearkes is quartered in the cabin for the night. He is able to gather from them that they are in the North Atlantic, cruising off the coast of America, which has recently declared war on England.

      [I let PP choose where they were, and when he settled on the North Atlantic (mostly so he could be closer to Canada, for verisimilitude for Pearkes' backstory, he also agreed that it should be in 1812, opening up the American war and pretty much assuring that this sequence would end with a confrontation between the Surprise and one of the American superfrigates.]

      The next day Pearkes walks the quarterdeck. He talks with one of the officers about the new American frigates. The leftenant is quite concerned, mentioning that the USS United States Constitution just pasted Java.

      [EDIT: Why did I think it was United States? Silly GM...]

      "Well, that's half the globe away."

      "The HMS Java, sir. And they were significantly larger than us. Good old Surprise, she's still the fastest ship of her class on the water. So we can run!"

      The marine commander also talks to Pearkes, The Colonel gets the feeling that he is being subtly felt out--the questions are all about different details of his military career, and Pearkes has the sinking feeling that he missed some important details.

      The sailors manage to whip one of the marines' officer uniforms into something appropriate for Pearkes to wear. Soon he too is baking in a red wool coat and waistcoat under the noon sun while Aubrey reads the Articles of War to the crew--it's Sunday, and this passes for chapel. Then they sit down and have a massive multi-course meal in the stifling great cabin. Pearkes gives the toast, stretching his brain to remember the historically accurate toast for the day.

      [I did not know about the toasts of the day--PP served for a while in the Canadian Navy, and so was familiar with the custom.]

      The officers are understandably interested in how Pearkes came to be found. "I was on my way back to Canada, and my ship went down," he says.

      "But...the only ship in the area was that area was that French ship we sank."

      Pearkes shrugs. "I'm not a sailor."

      Interestingly enough, last night in the Trav game I'm in we had another one of those situations somewhat like what happened with Pearkes above. (I was neither running it nor in the action, so it was ideal to watch what happened.) I was struck by how much of the ridiculousness (using a space goat to test to see if water was contaminated, somehow ending with the PCs going the full Romney and tying the goat to the top of our vehicle) was simply a function of interacting with the world in a strictly simulationist mode. That is, instead of working with the GM for an outcome ("I want to use this goat to test the water") it was all individual stages (catch the goat, tie up the goat, throw the goat in the river, retrieve the goat...) I'm still thinking about what happened there, and with my own Gavigan incident. (I was in the wrong there, definitely, but why I was in the wrong--what happened there--is still what I'm working on.)

      I've recruited possibly two players, although I'll leave the lights on for you, Lisa ;-) I'm wondering how to integrate them--my thinking is to try the Fiasco-as-background idea again (with a different playset) but I'm not sure I'll catch lightning in a bottle twice...

      I mostly have questions, you can see. Good place to be. Mostly.

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 3)

      Somewhere in the 1960s...

      Charleston and Noor walk to Cousin Wu's boarding house. Rickshaws plod through the streets beside them. At one point a bright flame ascends in the sky, looking for all the world like a giant firework.

      [There were German passenger rockets in The Man in the High Castle. For what it's worth.]0-po

      They notice many younger Japanese coming out of stores that sell Americana--records, antiques, vintage clothing. Automobiles more advanced than anything in Charleston's fevered imaginings race through the streets. Many seem to be German brands.

      Cousin Wu's turns out to be a rather typical San Francisco Victorian house. They knock on the door. There is a sound of frantic scrambling from behind the door. Eventually it opens and a long-haired, rather shabby looking man in his twenties opens it. Fragrant smoke billows around him.

      "Hello, we're here about a room," says Charleston in Mandarin.

      "Oh, okay man. Your lady friend can stay upstairs, and you stay down here in the basement with me."

      "Why can't she stay with me?"

      "Look, man, I don't need that kind of trouble. Women, top floor, you in the basement. I just need your papers."

      "What kind of papers?"

      "Are you just off the boat? Do you have your visa and your work papers?"

      "No."

      "What? Ah, man...let me guess, Sammy at the newstand sent you, right? If you don't have papers, this is bad man. I do not need any trouble with the Kempetai."

      "Now, now, before we go any further, I don't have any money either."

      "You don't have ten bucks a week?"

      "Forty dollars a month! That's outrageous!"

      "Well, what do you do? There's a black market for labor."

      "I have recently decided to become an author!"

      "Okay, but what else do you do? Are you a waiter, or something?"

      "I'm a rum-runner. Does that mean anything?"

      "That's kinda archaic, but okay. I can send you to Dancer Lee's outfit."

      "Dancer?"

      "He's like the Chinese crime boss around here. Can you shoot a gun?"

      "I might be a bit rusty, but I can learn."

      "Okay. Hey, your lady friend looks sick."

      Noor faints.

      Charleston slaps her awake. "I do not feel so good, Charleston."

      They carry Noor upstairs. Wu tells Charleston to head down to a laundry downtown. "Dancer's people hang out there. They take care of the whole community; somebody's gotta."

      "If you think you might be feeling better later," says Charleston to Noor, "here are the things I need you to research..."



      Charleston makes his way into Chinatown. He notices that the Chinese he encounters are mostly menial, low-wage workers. From the newspapers he reads on the way he discovers that the Germans seem to have set up a puppet state in the Eastern United States, with a buffer zone called the Rocky Mountain States in between the Japanese and German regions. He also notes that slavery seems to have been revived in the southern states.

      Entering the laundromat, Charleston's Triad reflexes spring to life: this is clearly a bunch of tough characters.

      "Whadya want?"

      "I was referred by Cousin Wu. I want to launder on your behalf."

      "You looking for a job? You got papers?"

      "What are these papers you speak of?"

      "There's a tea shop out back. Go have a cup."

      Charleston steps into the alley. Two thugs immediately grab him and force him into the basement, where he is confronted by a suit-wearing, cigarette-smoking lieutenant.

      "Where are you from?" he asks.

      "Uh, Nanking."

      "Your accent's not Nanking."

      "Right. Look, I don't have papers, I'm just getting accustomed to here. But I used to make deliveries. Nighttime deliveries, across borders..."

      "We can find something for you."

      "Good. Name's Charleston Chiu."

      "This is Dancer Lee's crew. You avoid Fat Tang's crew, they have it in for us."

      "So if I should make this 'Fat Tang' disappear..."

      "You'd have to clear that with the boss. He's in charge of all West Coast operations. I need you to make a delivery. Take this down to the wharf." He hands Charleston a smallish box. "Don't let anybody stop you. Don't get caught."

      "I can also drive rather well."

      "You know how to drive stick?"

      "Are you coming on to me?"

      "Brother, you are really lost. So, steal a car, make the delivery, and lose the car. Then we'll know something about you."

      "Is there a deadline or a drop dead date on this?"

      "Yeah. If you don't deliver it by dawn, you'll drop dead."

      Feel free to plunder anything from PMON, or at least avoid my mistakes...
      \nThanks. And I've got the advantage of the Masks Companion pdf.\n
      I'm going to be back soon with more writeup. Also, some point soon, I want to talk about trying to use AW-type Fronts in the campaign; I think it will solve a lot of the issues I've been having, but I'm still a bit foggy on how to implement them.
      \nThat's an interesting idea. Let us know how it goes? There's an AW hack called tremulus that's designed for Lovecraftian roleplaying. I've not yet read it, and such vague talk as I've heard about it has bee lukewarm.\n
      Interestingly enough, last night in the Trav game I'm in we had another one of those situations somewhat like what happened with Pearkes above. (I was neither running it nor in the action, so it was ideal to watch what happened.) I was struck by how much of the ridiculousness (using a space goat to test to see if water was contaminated, somehow ending with the PCs going the full Romney and tying the goat to the top of our vehicle) was simply a function of interacting with the world in a strictly simulationist mode. That is, instead of working with the GM for an outcome ("I want to use this goat to test the water") it was all individual stages (catch the goat, tie up the goat, throw the goat in the river, retrieve the goat...)
      \nYah. It's a bit of a X-Y problem. If someone asks me, "How high up from the ground is this room?", the question I should ask is "Why?" The player probably does not want to know X (how high up is the room) per se, but Y (likely: can the investigator jump out of the window safely).

      If I think this is a simulationist question about the height of a building and of one of the rooms therein, I am likely to give an answer I don't really care about either way, one that blocks the player's preferred course of action. If I know that the player wants the investigator to climb out the window, that's what I should be looking at. Do I have any reason not to want that? If not, I should probably say, "Oh, sure, you can absolutely climb out the window."

      Similarly, if I don't know why the PCs want the blasted goat, I'm likely to waste everyone's time with the wild goat chase, thinking that, for whatever reason, the players are having fun chasing a goat around to cause Wacky Hijinks. If I know that the players want to use the goat to test the water, sure! Fuck the chase; they get the goat, it drinks some water, and I rule on what the players actually care about.

      I don't know if it's just an assumption that one has to play out the goat catching; if it's a fear that if the GM knows The Plan, the GM will sabotage it; if the GM is blocking the action, fearing some kind of game breakage; some combination; or something else altogether.\n
      I'm still thinking about what happened there, and with my own Gavigan incident. (I was in the wrong there, definitely, but why I was in the wrong--what happened there--is still what I'm working on.)
      \nYou get more than your fair share of blame because you're the Keeper, but really, everyone should be helping everyone stay on the ball.

      But, briefly, you were moving fast enough that you made snap decisions, and both you and PP fell into a pattern that, even though neither of you probably likes it, neither of you is sure how to break. The other players either thought PP was right, were too shocked to protest in the short window they had, or sort of got sucked up in his wake.

      In this particular case, the ideal would have been to slow down and say, "Er, that wasn't the point I was trying to make. You want Y result? Okay, to get that, you need to do X / Okay, you're not going to get that, for these reasons, but you might get something useful if you do X." Possibly combine this with, "Okay, if you do that [and phrase it that way even if the player assumes it's already been done], these undesirable consequences will follow. Do you still want to do it? Does anyone else think this is a good idea, or does someone want to talk him out of it?" (Cf Over the Edge's essay where Jonathan Tweet notes that players sometimes freeze when one of their number has his or her PC do something really dumb. Remind the players to unfreeze.)\n
      I've recruited possibly two players, although I'll leave the lights on for you, Lisa ;-) I'm wondering how to integrate them--my thinking is to try the Fiasco-as-background idea again (with a different playset) but I'm not sure I'll catch lightning in a bottle twice...

      I mostly have questions, you can see. Good place to be. Mostly.
      \nHow often do you run, and what days? I'm realizing just how much of August I'm going to be out of town (Nelco, WorldCon, GenCon, and if I forgo all Sanity, Necronomicon).

      If I were to run Eternal Lies, would you want to play? Would your answer vary if it were pbem or used Call of Cthulhu instead of Trail or both?

      \n Lisa, we generally run on Saturdays, usually once or twice a month. (I'd like to get back to twice a month, but it's hard & scheduling blah blah blah.)

      PBEM intrigues me--never done it. My personal preference is to use GUMSHOE, since I like the system much better than Call of Cthulhu. I suppose it doesn't matter that much, although I don't envy you the task of trying to retrofit a ToC campaign to CoC.\n
      I'm going to be back soon with more writeup. Also, some point soon, I want to talk about trying to use AW-type Fronts in the campaign; I think it will solve a lot of the issues I've been having, but I'm still a bit foggy on how to implement them.
      \nThat's an interesting idea. Let us know how it goes? There's an AW hack called tremulus that's designed for Lovecraftian roleplaying. I've not yet read it, and such vague talk as I've heard about it has bee lukewarm.
      \nThat's what I've noticed as well. I did some cursory research on it today and I'm not sure they even use Fronts as we know them in tremulus.

      I started to try and define the Paris Brotherhood as a Front today. I think I mostly grasp the concept, and what I noticed right away is that the process was forcing me to clarify motivations and tactics--it was a very interesting experience. I think I'll end up having to try a bunch of different takes before I get the Fronts right, but it should be a good experience.

      Having finally read Apocalypse World, which was revelatory--it's one thing to mostly understand the concepts, quite another to actually get the whole thing in one go--I've been pondering ways to import AW techniques into the game.

      The Fronts are the obvious place to start--they're perfect for a conspiracy-type game.

      I've been listening to the recording of the last session again (beyond the parts I've transcribed so far) and I'm happy to notice that I was trying to get a lot of player input and riffing off their choices. Not nearly enough, but it's a positive sign.

      There's at least one major issue in trying to hack AW concepts on top of GUMSHOE: one of the most brilliant features of AW is the partial success; it's the pedal that keeps the plot running. But GUMSHOE is really binary, and designed to be so (in fact, it basically wants to remove chance from the equation at all.) Plus, of course, there's a big difference in the way the moves are structured and relate to each other in AW as opposed to ToC. Though maybe with some thought I could come up with...call 'em templates? Classes of actions, no matter what the skills involved are, that resemble *W moves? This is an interesting thought.

      I don't want to go too far, though; having chosen ToC, I should try and solve my issues within its framework. It's just that *W techniques are so damn tempting.\n

      Yah. It's a bit of a X-Y problem. If someone asks me, "How high up from the ground is this room?", the question I should ask is "Why?" The player probably does not want to know X (how high up is the room) per se, but Y (likely: can the investigator jump out of the window safely).

      ...

      Similarly, if I don't know why the PCs want the blasted goat, I'm likely to waste everyone's time with the wild goat chase, thinking that, for whatever reason, the players are having fun chasing a goat around to cause Wacky Hijinks. If I know that the players want to use the goat to test the water, sure! Fuck the chase; they get the goat, it drinks some water, and I rule on what the players actually care about.

      I don't know if it's just an assumption that one has to play out the goat catching; if it's a fear that if the GM knows The Plan, the GM will sabotage it; if the GM is blocking the action, fearing some kind of game breakage; some combination; or something else altogether.

      \nYeah, that's it precisely. In a lot of traditional systems (especially DnD descended ones) there's an implied contract of playing "gotcha" between the PCs and the GM. Breaking that concept is proving hard (on both sides, I should hasten to add) in this game. Not the least because I've only really become aware of it recently!\n

      You get more than your fair share of blame because you're the Keeper, but really, everyone should be helping everyone stay on the ball.

      But, briefly, you were moving fast enough that you made snap decisions, and both you and PP fell into a pattern that, even though neither of you probably likes it, neither of you is sure how to break. The other players either thought PP was right, were too shocked to protest in the short window they had, or sort of got sucked up in his wake.
      \nYeah. I shorthanded a lot of stuff in defining the question as "why". I'm pretty comfortable with your analysis; it's now more a question of, how does this kind of situation happen? how can I identify it? what steps can I take to minimize this? what strategies are going to be effective to avoid the whole problem entirely? and what issues will they raise?

      Again, Apocalypse World has a lot of ideas for how to do this. (If Lady Blackbird is a graduate-level seminar in game design, AW is the post-doc.)\n
      (Cf Over the Edge's essay where Jonathan Tweet notes that players sometimes freeze when one of their number has his or her PC do something really dumb. Remind the players to unfreeze.)
      \nCurses, I don't have OTE. I'm going to have to see if I can dig that essay up...not the least because OTE probably has much to say to ToC.

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 4)

      Somewhere in 1984...

      The van tumbles through London. Finally it stops. Two thugs drag Freddie out of the back and frogmarch him up into what at one time would have been a respectable townhouse. Freddie notices in passing that the neighborhood was quite well-to-do in his day. He catches a glimpse of vaguely pyramidal buildings on the outskirts of London, and then is forced inside the townhouse.

      The interior is well-appointed, if quite dimly lit, with elegant furniture and the first touches of luxury that he has seen since arriving in this place. A flat screen on the wall most astonishingly displays moving pictures in color, and with sound.

      As Freddie sinks into an overstuffed couch, he hears a news bulletin: "Comrades! The heroic forces of Oceania have once again emerged victorious in Africa, defeating the evil armies of Eastasia! Rejoice in our victory, and praise to our great leader!"

      In another room, he hears people talking.

      "You, in the chesterfield! Sit up straight!" blares the screen on the wall.

      "What are you talking about? It's a davenport!"

      "I'll report you, comrade..." mutters an angry looking woman on the screen. The image changes again to a news report.

      Two figures enter the room, but Freddie can't make out their features in the gloom. One sits down in an armchair, while the other continues to speak:

      "Oh, and O'Brien wants to do an operation on this Smith character. Says he has it all planned out and its a catch."

      "Fine," says the other figure. "O'Brien's always up to something."

      "What is it I'm up to?" says Freddie.

      "You are not O'Brien," says the person in the chair. "I am Comrade General Jeremias of the Thought Police."

      "I'm Comrade O'Brien."

      "You are not O'Brien."

      "That's news to me. I've been O'Brien for a while."

      "You are not Comrade O'Brien, or at least not the one I know. I work with him. He is my great rival."

      "And there's only one person named O'Brien in all of Oceania, I'm sure."

      "What I want to know is, who you really are, and why you have been sent to me."

      "My name is O'Brien, and when I showed my papers to the police at the local station, they sent me to you."

      "You are not O'Brien. I need to know if you are working for O'Shaughnessy or not. This is the sort of thing he would do."

      "I've never heard of him."

      "Look, right now we are having a very nice conversation. But if you don't tell me what I need to know, I will take other methods. I don't think you'll find that conversation so pleasant."

      "I have no doubt you can torture me into saying anything you want."

      "What I really want to know is why you look like Freddie Blakely."

      "Don't know who you're talking about."

      "You really don't know Freddie Blakely?"

      "That sounds like one too many names."

      "Of course, you can't really be him. He's been dead for twenty years."

      "Well, if I'm clearly not O'Brien, and can't be Freddie Blakely, why don't you tell me who he was? That way I can not tell O'Shaughnessy, whom I've never met."

      "Freddie was...very dear to me once. He was a good comrade." The figure leans forward. She is old, in her seventies.

      She looks, in fact, like a seventy-year old Jackson Elias.

      "You look like a seventy-year old Jackson Elias!" says Freddie.

      "How...who told you that name?"

      "The same person who didn't tell me about Freddie Blakely."

      "And who is this Jackson Elias?"

      "Well, she certainly wasn't a socialist who worked with the French underground during the Great War."

      "If you know so much about Freddie and Jackson, how did he meet her for the first time?"

      "Well, I got drunk at a bar in the Moulin Rouge."

      [Not sure where I got the idea to put Jax in the "1984" section, but it seemed too good an idea to pass on once I had it. I've enjoyed the interplay between Freddie and her greatly, so I thought this would be fun, and reveal a bit more about their relationship.

      Eventually I figured something else about who and what Freddie was in this retelling, but I'll save that for when it happens.]

      "You're dead. This is impossible."

      "Bit of a shock for me too, you know, since you died about three months ago. As far as I'm concerned, it's 1925, and you were killed. I've been on some kind of a vengeance tour, following up your last investigation."

      [Me: How does Freddie feel about seeing Jackson alive?
      FP: Oh, I'm definitely dreaming...
      Me: Still, you'll need to make a Stability check.
      FP: ...I fail. How much do I lose?
      Me: ...7 points. "You speak with someone close to you that you know to be dead."
      PP:       How much?
      FP: Do I get a discount because I think I'm dreaming?
      Me: Okay, 5 points.]

      Jackson presses a button on a stand next to her chair and the screen on the wall switches off.

      "Oh, right, spying," says Freddie.

      "That's kind of my job," says Jackson.

      "Well, you were always good at that sort of thing."

      "It's not a friendly world, I'm afraid. We tried our best, after the second war, to bring socialism to the people."

      "Second war? Oh, you're counting that dustup between the French and the Prussians..."

      "No, the Second World War. We didn't come to power until after the Third World War. That was the one we used nuclear weapons in."

      "If you're going to throw nonsense terms at me from Jules Verne..."

      [Decided to cut back to Pearkes here, as the encounter between Jax and Freddie seemed pregnant at this point.

      I had originally thought about making the arrival of Jackson some kind of thing--"The Comrade General from America" or something--but ended up going with Jax's faction kidnapping Freddie out of the police station.

      Of course, I shouldn't even plan so much ahead, yes? Maybe? GMing is hard, especially when you're changing paradigms...]
