      Lisa, we generally run on Saturdays, usually once or twice a month. (I'd like to get back to twice a month, but it's hard & scheduling blah blah blah.)
      \nI know how that goes.\n
      PBEM intrigues me--never done it. My personal preference is to use GUMSHOE, since I like the system much better than Call of Cthulhu. I suppose it doesn't matter that much, although I don't envy you the task of trying to retrofit a ToC campaign to CoC.
      \nWith PBEMs, I tend to go very system-light. ToC probably would be a better fit for PBEM, but... I just haven't clicked with the Gumshoe General Combat-and-Everything-Else part of the system. As a player, this isn't a problem. I just spend and roll. As a Keeper / GM, it's a huge problem. Ken Hite's told me that it's really very simple -- create a spend pattern, which can be simple (always spend 2) or more complicated (4-3-2 pattern, then 2 for each round thereafter, unless you have a reason). But, it always feels to me that I'm controlling the fight in ways I shouldn't, so that I'm deciding not just the spend, but whether the PCs will win or lose -- and even if I didn't consider that a problem, I suck at calibration, so I'd likely kill off too many PCs by accident or try not to and it'd be obvious. How do you run it?\n
      I don't want to go too far, though; having chosen ToC, I should try and solve my issues within its framework. It's just that *W techniques are so damn tempting.
      \nYou can switch over, but there are reasons not to. But, if you want to do a test run, do it when you're doing something like moving each PC into an alternate reality where the rule system can be different too.

      I haven't quite grokked Apocalypse World, but I think I could handle running Monsterhearts. Some of the hard move things plus the fronts might be all you need. For Relationships, the Pillars and Sources of Trail pretty much cover that.\n
      Yeah. I shorthanded a lot of stuff in defining the question as "why". I'm pretty comfortable with your analysis; it's now more a question of, how does this kind of situation happen? how can I identify it? what steps can I take to minimize this? what strategies are going to be effective to avoid the whole problem entirely? and what issues will they raise?
      \nHow? Things start moving fast and cross lines before everyone realizes it. People default to patterns they're used to.

      Slow down. This is tricky because we're not talking about a slower pace of action, and we don't want games to flow like molasses in winter. What we want is to stem the panic / split second decision, build in a loop that pulls us back into "let's think about this a moment", and gets us in the head space where we can see during the game all the stuff that's obvious afterwards. It's not easy, and it's always going to be a work in progress, but practice does help.

      Nice move with Jackson Elias in Orwell-land.

      \n Lisa, I handle the combat-spend stuff in a couple of ways:

      --Generally, I have the NPCs spend 2 or 3 all the time (2 if they're not combat focused/supernatural, 3 otherwise).

      --I reset expectations: at one point I explicitly told the players that any fight they haven't won by 3 rounds they should run from.

      --Generally, I don't think people feel I'm controlling combat--once they grasp that they can autosucceed, they quickly realize it works for the NPCs as well.

      But seriously, it's cinematic/narrative combat, so there's a natural routine people can map to--those fight scenes where the bad guys trade blows with the heroes for a while and then suddenly lose competence (when they run out of points.)

      Also, my game is extra-crispy pulp, so I've brought in some stuff from Night's Black Agents (critical hits, special moves if you have a rating of 8+ in skills) but there's no need to do that for most implementations.

      I agree with your notes about how to handle future situations. One thing I want to do more of is to get the players to be outcome-focused (which is really a stakes-setting mechanism, but I won't have to get too jargon-y) and also enforce some of the AW "If you want to do it, do it" thinking. That is, make the mechanics emerge more from the fiction, while also pointing the players towards thinking about how to direct their narration.

      Also, being a bit sharper myself! I think I need to make a cheat sheet like Vincent put in AW. Certainly clarifying my narration in terms of MC moves would be an improvement, I think.

      \n Hmm. Could you maybe talk a bit more about your block? I mean, I get it in principle, but maybe step through your concerns?

      I tend to make the combat very reactive unless there's an overwhelming reason not to--generally, supernatural. So, it was okay for Hetep to attack Freddie, since the big coolness with Hetep is "fluffy white cat==supernatural badass". Otherwise, I let the PCs choose targets and more or less direct the fight, basing the NPCs actions off of what the PCs do.

      I mean, here's the thing about Gumshoe--it's basically a diceless system. A spend of 3 pretty much guarantees success, with rare exceptions. Given that, combat is going to be nervy and deadly, with both sides tending to take a pounding very quickly. Most humans can't stand more than three rounds of combat, no matter what--at least, not without dropping below 0 health. Once the PCs recognize that, then your spends aren't super important--they know you're going to hit, just like they know they're going to hit. So it just becomes about narration and the occasional cool bit of advanced f*ckery.

      Hell, for critters with very high pools, I sometimes don't bother to roll, just knock off the points. Speeds things up slightly.

      The other thing is that unless you're using some of the crazy rules from NBA, damage is always decoupled from the hit roll, so even hitting all the time doesn't mean that much if your damage output is low. (In fact, I'm pretty sure the -1 and -2 damage modifiers were put there explicitly to cover the fact that moderately experienced players won't miss a combat roll.)

      I could see if I could step through one of the combat examples I recorded in greater detail if you think it would help--I think the fight vs. the vampires might be decent for a start--the vamps were pretty powerful and did a number on the PCs, but I don't think I was directing the fight. But maybe I'm wrong?

      One thing I'd definitely carry over from NBA is using Investigative skills to aid general ones, although in a purist scenario maybe not for fighting checks. Fleeing, though, that's a definite :-)

      'Course, I'm a bit biased--Gumshoe (despite the stuff I'm working through) is easily my favorite current system, and the one I'd run with any group looking for more crunch than *World games. Hell, I'd run Traveller under Gumshoe, if I could--it would be awesome.

      \n I have a disconnect with Gumshoe's general system, I guess. I mean, yes, you can spend for a guaranteed hit. Once or twice. Maybe three times. And, if you're a PC, your best Not Get Hit is likely to be 4, which means that getting hit is really likely, no? I mean, without pulling your punches on purpose, how do you manage not to wipe out PCs accidentally? If you actively don't want to wipe out PCs (because having them go down and get replaced every session kills cool arcs), how does that work with the mechanics? (The impression I get is that it doesn't and isn't meant to and GMs like me who want the PCs to survive much of the game are wimps.)

      There's also the question of when refreshes happen. I remember going Ack! when reading NBA -- this game, intended to be cinematic, has a gajillion different rules about which pools get refreshed when. Then, there was a post online about how players should totally spend to the max in combat because GMs will totally give them a refresh, so all's cool. This is not the impression I get in play -- at convention games I've played in, where the game was totally fun and totally cinematic, all the PCs would have bee totally dead if we spent the way the blog writer thought we should.

      (And having one's lockpicker suddenly be no better than a guy without Lockpick / Burglary because he's out of points is a disconnect I don't much like, but I'm trying to focus on the things that make me go "How do I run that?" rather than "I don't want to run that like that.")

      Maybe a long example would help.

      \n Okay, I will try to accommodate! I don't think there's a big combat in what I have left to write up, so maybe I'll try to get one of the earlier ones up in director's cut mode.

      So. Let's talk about this.

      First, one must remember that Gumshoe characters are actually pretty resilient. It takes quite a bit to actually kill them--most PCs can take between 18-24 points of damage before being dead, dead, dead. It's not even that easy to drop them--you need about two-three hits to get them to the point where the consciousness check is hard to make. Weapons just don't do that much damage--even a shotgun blast to the face only does about 7-8 points on average.

      Second, combat doesn't last that long. Like I said, three rounds and run should be the basic rule for PCs in Gumshoe. (Actually, a surprising amount of games--it's pretty true in d20 as well.) I don't think any of the fights I've presented so far in this AP have lasted longer than four rounds--my only candidates for that are the fight with Polidori and the fight with the Cthonian, and I'd have to check that.

      So maybe you see a pattern? Most fights won't last long enough to massacre the PCs. It takes a fair amount of opponents, with guns, to ice multiple PCs. In this AP, only the fight with Shakhti put multiple PCs unconscious. (That fight could have been worse--I mostly forgot about Clive, so we can assume he scampered, or was neutralized by Hypatia.)

      I have found that I don't need to pull punches; the system is deadly if you do stupid things, or against really tough opponents, but otherwise the PCs should be able to hold their own. But the fights themselves tend to be very nervy, and have plenty of suspense--this was commented on after the first two sessions by my players.

      Also, too. The whole "hit threshold can't get above 4" is a limiting factor on monsters. Sure, the Hunting Horror has like a Scuffling pool of 20. That just means that it can hit multiple people, or hang around in a combat for a long time. It's not going to do more damage. It's not going to be harder to hit. It just has a big pool.

      That doesn't mean pool size isn't important (it's initiative, after all), but it tends to have more impact at the lower end--if you give your mooks and low-threat level NPCs small pools, then they probably won't last long enough in a fight to massacre the PCs.

      Refreshes are easier. Basically, anything that's fighty refreshes daily. This includes stuff like Driving and Fleeing. So unless you tend to have multiple combats in a day, it makes absolute sense to pump your fighting skills and finish the combat quickly; that's what the essay (I think I read the same one) was getting at. NBA also has a specific, "narrate cool stuff to get a refresh" mechanic for people with ratings of 8+ in the fighty skills, which means that it's easier to get refreshes in it. (Also, one of the common Tactical Fact Finding benefits is a dedicated pool, so that's even more points.)

      You can also use the "find a safe haven" rule to refresh when you're in a tight spot. I actually think that's very cinematic--it's the scene where the heroes find a place to hole up for a while and take stock.

      The whole thing where your skill pool is low so now you can't do things as effectively is a bit disconcerting; I've found the best way to come to grips with it is to think of it in meta-plot terms (or as a guide to narration). You're in an aerial chase, but your piloting pool is empty? What that really means is that piloting isn't how this scene is going to be resolved. Maybe the guy with Mechanical Repair will have to supe up the engines. Or maybe the guys with the rifles will need to make some daring shots.

      Or maybe you have to lighten the plane by tossing something out of it--time for the guy with Scuffling to go to work! ;-)

      Or finally, maybe your luck is up. I don't think it's an accident that most of the Gumshoe games are horror games; they do the whole "eventually the bad thing happens no matter what" thing pretty well.

      It actually works out to be fairly cinematic, even with the Investigative skills. For example, in this AP, there was a point where Shakhti was taking the PCs through his villa. There was a portrait of Cleopatra in one of the rooms that bore a resemblance to Hypatia Masters, and would have been the second time Freddie had seen something like that--a fairly major clue about Hypatia. Unfortunately, he'd already spent his Art History point on the previous Hypatia image. I invite you to think about this as the camera slowly panning on the picture of Cleopatra/Hypatia as Freddie walks obliviously by...

      \n The overnight refresh explains why the blogger thought it was fine to burn points and why I thought he was insane. He's running for a home group; I was playing four hour convention one shots. We had two or three combats all in the same day, depending on which session we're talking. I'm guessing the home group had one combat a day.

      As for the Art History, that's not General, but Investigation. I have no problem with the Investigation rules. Was the portrait a Core Clue? If not, you're fine. If so, could Freddie get the information some other way? Clearly yes, because he did, so you're fine. If not, Freddie doesn't need to spend at all. He's in front of the portrait, and he has the relevant clue. If it were a core clue that Freddie didn't have the skill to find -- he didn't have Art History or whatever -- you feed him the information somewhere else.

      So, either Freddie doesn't need to spend -- he recognizes Hypatia -- or he doesn't need the clue, in which case, the viewer sees the picture over Freddie's shoulder, but Freddie is distracted or the picture's in shadow or something.

      \nGUMSHOE EXAMPLE: The Fight At the Mosque of Ibn Tulun

      [Welcome back, sports fans! Lisa asked for an example of how I run GUMSHOE combat, so I thought I'd oblige her with the following example. This goes back to Session 5; the PCs have gone to the Mosque of Ibn Tulun after getting a tip that the Nessim, leader of the guardians of the Girdle of Nitocris has returned there. They also hear a warning that Omar Shakhti's wives, extremely dangerous vampires, are leading the mission.

      For reference, I've listed the stats of the main combatants below.
      \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
      The Good Guys
      Gilbert\xa0\xa0Freddie\xa0\xa0Pearkes\xa0\xa0
      Athletics\xa07310
      Firearms\xa06410
      Health\xa01088
      Scuffling\xa01032
      Weapons\xa04\t10
      Stability\xa010126
      \nThe vampires had Health, Athletics, and Scuffling 10, and Magic 3. They had an alertness modifier of +2, Stealth of +1, and a Hit Threshold of 5--they were unearthly fast.

      Not sure that everybody was at full, but let's leave it at that for now.]

      Freddie is sitting with the Taleb, annoying him, when a knock comes on the door. \u201cI must get rid of this pest,\u201d says the young man. Freddie tags along with him.

      The student opens the door. \u201cThe mosque is\u2014\u201d

      A shotgun blast drops him.

      FP has Freddie draw his shotgun. I decided that would be a 1-pt Firearms spend to draw and shoot in this round, in addition to whatever he wanted to spend to take the shot. Freddie spends 2 and gets a 6, taking his firearms down to 2.

      He gets a 6, easily hitting, and rolls a 4 + 4 for damage--8 points (he fired both barrels at close range). I didn't give these guys any health, so 8 points cuts them in half.

      Outside are two guys with guns drawn. "It's Blakely, kill him!" FP wants to slam the "heavy wooden" door shut, latch it and run. Doing the first two is fine, but to get away, it's a 1-point Athletics or Fleeing spend. FP spends 1 Fleeing, going down to 9. He reloads as he runs inside.

      Upstairs, Pearkes hears the shots and draws his revolver. Gilbert runs towards the sound of shooting. Since Freddie has Bad Luck as his drive, Gilbert smashes into Freddie in the mosque's sanctuary. Gilbert's gun goes flying, but he's able to pick it up.

      At this point there's a strange singing.

      Pearkes runs down the corridor (he's upstairs, checking out the insane asylum section.) PP calls for a Preparedness roll to have earplugs; I just say Yes and let him continue. He does hear a woman's voice calling out for him--his fiancee Constance's voice, as a matter of fact.

      Pearkes and Billy go to free the woman, believing this woman to be Constance. [Gotta have at least one vampire using its disguise ability.]

      Downstairs, Freddie gets up and straps on the genuine antique scimitar he bought. GP decides to have Gilbert try and sneak behind one of the many columns in the room to get out of sight. The strange singing--actually, a form of the Dominate spell--is all around him. I call for a Stability check, opposed by the vampire's roll plus one point from her 3-point Magic pool. GP rolls a 4, failing. (I don't remember what I rolled, but it was above a 4.)

      This puts him under the temporary control of the vampire. Gilbert turns around and aims his shotgun at Freddie.

      Freddie dodges behind a column. He tries to see where the singing is coming from but it is too dim. [Being under cover is what prevented this from working--see below. Also she made a good Stealth roll.]

      Upstairs, Pearkes sees cultists with rifles moving up the stairs. PP calls for a Preparedness roll for "another grenade". I was getting a bit tired of grenades, but hey, it's his dime. PP spends his last point of Preparedness, makes a 6 on the roll, and so I let him bomb a thousand year old mosque with a grenade.

      Downstairs, Freddie calls out to Gilbert, trying to calm him down. [The way GP said "Yes. Yes I can." in answer to FP's question of whether he could hear him was spookily good.] Freddie asks Gilbert to shoot the singer, not him, but the vampire tosses that back.

      GP asks if he can stab himself. I don't rule yet, but it begins the theme of him and FP trying to break the spell.

      FP makes a Flattery spend, trying to play on Gilbert's past as a Soviet commissar to avoid working for "some century old monarchist." I allow a new Stability roll, and promptly gets a 1 on the die; meanwhile I have the vampire make another Magic point spend and she beats GP's roll.

      I rule that Gilbert shoots the pillar--I made the attack roll, but with no Firearms spend. At this point, though, I put GP on notice that eventually he'll need to make Stability rolls to prevent himself from making Firearms spends to shoot Freddie--I was going to basically make it a Driver of some sort.

      Pearkes leads Billy and "Constance" into a large room with asylum inmates chained to the wall. As they try to leave, the chains fall away from the inmates and they begin to chant "Shakhti...Shakhti..." A figure drops from the ceiling in front of the exit. Pearkes pushes Constance behind him. I give PP a point of Stability for protecting his fiancee, and being a good sport.

      Meanwhile, GP is trying to find a way out of his predicament. He checks his Drive--Loyalty--and its a bit problematic; has his loyalty been transferred to the vampire?

      FP has a new plan: he offers Gilbert a raise. I rule that Gilbert shoots the pillar again, and begins to reload. FP notes he can shoot Gilbert now, but "I like him." Freddie ducks his head around the pillar to look for the singer. I run through what skills he could use as "Perception."

      GP asks if he can use Filch to try and mess up reloading his shotgun. I say he can slow down the reloading (no skill roll required) but it's a Soft Driver, having decided that his loyalty has transferred to the vampire--so it costs 2 points of Stability, dropping Gilbert to 3.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJuly 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nGUMSHOE Combat Example: The Fight at the Mosque of Ibn Tulun, Part 2


      FP decides to spend his last unspent experience point for Evidence Collection, and makes a spend. He spies the vampire perched on a pulpit.

      FP: How far off?

      Me: Pretty far off in the dim light.

      FP: I have a double-barreled sawed-off shotgun. There's no way I'm hitting her from far away--I've actually fired those, and they're wildly inaccurate.

      [This was one of those times when FP's love of verisimilitude helped keep the fiction somewhere loosely tethered to reality.]

      Freddie has Stealth, so FP spends 3 points and gets a 9. This beats the target of 6--the vampires have a +2 Alertness modifier.

      Gilbert finishes loading his shotgun. He wants to spend Athletics to slow down aiming, but I once again rule it's a Soft Driver. He spends it, to drop to 1 point of Stability.

      Freddie is now in shotgun range, and I decide to cut back to Pearkes.

      Pearkes tries to talk to the vampire upstairs, but she decides to just kill "Constance" by throwing a dagger into her heart. PP asks for an Athletics roll to get in the way. PP spends 4 points on the roll, but only gets a 5; the vampire put 3 points into her weapons roll and once again I rolled well. PP asks if he can spend more points, but FP tells him this "isn't Pathfinder--there's no Hero Points." If you're looking for potential player discomfort, this was one situation--PP said he didn't know the vampire would put 3 points in or he would have spent more. Lesson: make sure your players understand that the opposition spends points too!

      I call for a 4-point Stability test for seeing his fiancee die. PP spends 2 and easily makes it.

      Me: You're fine, except for the fact that your fiancee was brutally murdered.

      PP: She's not dead yet.

      Me: I said "in the heart," but OK. [I rolled something high--6 points or so.] Yeah.

      PP: She's not dead yet.

      Me: She's dying and dying fast.

      FP: This is the 1920s. They don't have the technology.

      [Here's an interesting situation--PP was clearly angling for a chance to save "Constance." Now, I knew it wasn't Constance, but a vampire in disguise. But still--was PP signalling that this was an unacceptable alteration of his character? Or just not wanting to lose? I hope I'd make it clear that Sources of Stability were going to be menaced. The more I go over these, the more I'm struck by just how bad the communication was between us in-game. I think some of my frustration has been that this wasn't a problem with the other players.]

      Billy immediately blows his Stability roll. The inmates jump him--he's below 0 Stability and in Fight or Flight mode, so out comes his kukri. This also allowed me to let the mooks just be color and not complicate the fight. I think going forward I'm going to steal an idea from 13th age and just have mooks share a single pool.

      PP has George draw his sword and do a leaping attack at the vampire. Since we're using many of the combat rules from Night's Black Agents, I point out that it is possible to do a called shot to the throat.

      Me: It raises the difficulty by 3...

      PP: I spend 10.

      Me: ...you spend 10?

      PP: She killed my fiancee.

      So Pearkes hits her. The vamps are very fast--hit threshold of 5--but he rolls a 5 on the die for a final total of 15. At this point I break out the critical hits rules from NBA--but he doesn't crit. His damage is at +3, plus the unknown (and undefined by me--I usually just decided whether or not it killed people) damage bonus of the Sword of Akmallah. But he rolls a 1.

      Still, I wanted to reward him for such derring-do, so I ruled her hand was cut off trying to block the slash. It was so cool I also gave him a 2-point refresh to his Weapons pool. This is a rule from NBA but I recommend it if you're looking for a not-to-intrusive way to extend PC survivability in ToC. (Basically, if you have 8+ in a fighty skill, you not only get a benefit--usually +1 damage to a single weapon--but can refresh your pool by narrating some cool gun, kung, or sword-fu.)

      Then she goes. I just spend 3 points from her Scuffling pool; I had her spend 3 points every time. This knocks back Pearkes for 5 points of damage.

      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nJuly 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nGUMSHOE Combat Example: The Fight at the Mosque of Ibn Tulun, Part 3

      FP takes the shot, gets a 7, and hits. He does 9 points of damage. Unfortunately, all the vamps take half damage from physical attacks, so she's still up.

      GP wants to see if the attack breaks the spell. He makes a Stability test, but is afraid to make a spend. He rolls a 4, but so did I and I spent her last point from her Magic pool. At this point I remind him that in the past I'd ruled that refreshing Stability can at least allow a new roll to break the domination. I ask GP to define his Symbol, and he comes up with a picture of his old comrades in the Paris Soviet. He has it on him, and I intimate that if somebody can remind him of it, he might get to refresh.

      Freddie begins to sing the Internationale. Gilbert begins to join in, and tearfully pulls out his picture. He gets a 1-point Stability refresh, spends himself down to 0, gets a 4, and beats my roll of 3.

      At this point I decided to reward GP with another action. He asks me if he can run up, wrap her arm to brace, and use the shotgun to blow her head off. I rule, what the heck. I call for an Athletics roll; GP spends 4 and gets a 6. The vampire is incredibly fast.

      GP spends 8 points in Scuffling to grab her, and gets a 9. I cut to Pearkes.

      PP wants to know if he landed near his gun. I ask for an Athletics check, but he only gets a 3. He decides to attack with his sword, but her Scuffling pool is currently much larger than his Weapons pool so she goes first. 3 point spend, so she picks him up and tosses him against a wall for 4 points.

      FP: Cinematics--as she throws you you slash.

      Me: Yeah, that's cool.

      He spends two and rolls a 3. The vampire yawns.

      GP goes for the called shot--he needs an 8 to get the neck shot. GP asks me for anything he can do to get more damage--this was one of the reasons he asked to grab her arm. I ponder, then check NBA's extra damage rules--for 4 Firearms and 1 Stability he can do an extra die of damage. He puts all 4 remaining points into the shot, but still needs to get an 8. I point out that he can use an Investigative ability to potentially help. He mentions Forensics to give him a knowledge of anatomy. I let him refresh 3 points of his Firearms from a 1 point Forensics spend.

      FP: I'm thinking of something straightforward: when you were a commissar in the Russian Revolution, you had a preferred way of executing your prisoners.

      GP makes a 7-point spend, and just makes the roll, getting a 9 total. 2d6 + 4 + 1 later, he blows her head off.

      He then blows his 5-point Stability test; this included his possession and blowing somebody's head off. He drops to -6 and loses a point of Sanity. FP makes his Stability check.

      GP asks if he can get any of his Firearms back, but I point out he's had his big screen moment.

      Back upstairs, PP makes an Athletics roll to land near his guns. He gets a 9 and comes up with the guns in his hands. He spends 4 Firearms and a Stability point to get an extra die of damage. He does 9 points--not enough to knock out the vampire. "That's uncivil," she says. She smacks the empty guns out of his hands (another 3-point Scuffling spend) and tries to Dominate him--PP spends 2 but he doesn't beat my roll of 6. "Constance" stands up behind him to try and feed. I call for another Stability test, but change my mind, and make it a Hard Driver; PP gains the 2 points of Stability.

      The two vampires begin to squabble. Billy wanders downstairs, Stability blasted. FP tells Gilbert to stay downstairs, while Billy licks blood off of his knife. Freddie runs upstairs, but GP says "I'm just going to follow you." [Playing his Stability! Yes!]

      Upstairs, the vamps feed; I charge Pearkes a rating point of Health loss. FP has Freddie shoot the one-handed vamp. He does 10 points of damage, dropping the vamp.

      The Domination ends, but it's another Hard Driver for Pearkes to resist Constance; PP picks up the 2 points of Stability but blows his attack.

      Freddie draws his sword and cuts off the downed vamp's head. Then FP voluntarily rolls for Stability, making it. GP wants to attack, but is in Flight or Fight mode, so I tell him that he can only attack a target that is actually doing something--in this case Pearkes. However, at this point we remember that Pearkes needs to make an unconsciousness test. He fails, and drops to the floor. Gilbert just huddles in a corner.

      "Constance" tries to dominate Freddie, but he beats her Stability. She then spends 3-Scuffling and throws Freddie into a wall for 5 points. GP wants to have Gilbert attack "Constance", and FP evolves a plan--he makes a Flattery spend to distract the vampire while GP sneaks up behind her to stake her.

      I like that plan and so it works, but at the end the vamp decides to bite Freddie for 6 points of damage.

      GP wants to grab her from behind and then take the called shot to the chest. I call for a Scuffling roll; he spends 2 and gets a 6. Then GP realizes he won't have any points to attack with, but I let him change the first roll to Athletics. He spends 2 Scuffling on the attack and makes the called shot.

      Unfortunately, these vamps aren't European, and an ash stake through the heart doesn't kill her. Another 3 point spend, another 6 points of damage to Gilbert.

      Freddie, at -3 Health, spends 2 points on his unconsciousness check; he autosucceeds, but drops to -5. He makes a 4 point Weapons spend to jam his stake into her, and that's just enough--she drops.

      Whew! That was a lot. I'll let this simmer and try and come up with some notes later.
      \n

      GUMSHOE EXAMPLE: The Fight At the Mosque of Ibn Tulun

      The vampires had Health, Athletics, and Scuffling 10, and Magic 3. They had an alertness modifier of +2, Stealth of +1, and a Hit Threshold of 5--they were unearthly fast.

      Not sure that everybody was at full, but let's leave it at that for now.]
      \nI thik I've seen stats that were higher, probably in NBA -- those are the ones that make me wonder how PCs survive, despite having had my PC do so in a couple of NBA games. But even if I'm right, and these guys are less lethal than then might be, they get to be harder to hit than the PCs. Not a problem per se, but part of why I wonder how any Gumshoe PCs survive combat.\n
      Freddie is sitting with the Taleb, annoying him, when a knock comes on the door. \u201cI must get rid of this pest,\u201d says the young man. Freddie tags along with him.

      The student opens the door. \u201cThe mosque is\u2014\u201d

      A shotgun blast drops him.

      FP has Freddie draw his shotgun. I decided that would be a 1-pt Firearms spend to draw and shoot in this round, in addition to whatever he wanted to spend to take the shot. Freddie spends 2 and gets a 6, taking his firearms down to 2.

      He gets a 6, easily hitting, and rolls a 4 + 4 for damage--8 points (he fired both barrels at close range). I didn't give these guys any health, so 8 points cuts them in half.
      \nYou mentioned initiative in an earlier post -- how is that coming into play here?\n
      Outside are two guys with guns drawn. "It's Blakely, kill him!" FP wants to slam the "heavy wooden" door shut, latch it and run. Doing the first two is fine, but to get away, it's a 1-point Athletics or Fleeing spend. FP spends 1 Fleeing, going down to 9. He reloads as he runs inside.
      \nWait -- is it still Freddie's turn? Mechanically, I'm not sure what the initiative situation is.

      More questions later, I suspect.

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n

      \n\nJuly 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Lisa,

      What made the vamps tough in this is that they only took half damage from physical attacks, and did +1 damage with their claws. This is why Pearkes got tossed around so badly. Even so, it took three rounds to knock him to the edge of unconsciousness. He made some suboptimal spends during the fight, or he would have been dealing damage to her in turn. (Oh, I made a mistake up there--he didn't have the Sword of Akmallah yet. He got a +1 to damage because he specialized in his cavalry sword.)

      One of the time-honored ways to keep the PCs surviving is to give less Health to opponents, and treat them as out at 0 Health; I usually do something like that. Also, it usually requires 2 to 1 odds to ensure PC death, or a massive disparity of damage dealt.

      Initiative: I had to go look the rule up again, although I've been running it intuitively. One on one, the aggressor is the one who goes first; if nobody's sure who goes first, then it's the person with the highest current pool value in the skill they're using. In combats with more opponents, you go straight to the pool comparison. Initiative doesn't reset between rounds. I was correct, although for the wrong reason, in letting the vamp go before Pearkes after the first round--she was the aggressor, having started the fight by "killing" "Constance"; pool value didn't come in to it.

      As for Freddie and the door...well, it was a gimmee. Had the mooks outside been more important to the combat, I would have given them a chance to shoot. But since this fight was about meeting the Wives of Shakhti, I didn't have a problem with neutralizing the mooks, who were there largely for color and verisimilitude.

      There's also this post on rpg.net wherein somebody else had the daft idea to run Masks under Trail. He was a lot more purist than I am, though, both in style and in the damage done to the plot. But it's a super useful example of a combat where a PC gets iced; as the Keeper notes, it took 9 people two volleys to bring down one PC.

    The Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep [Trail of Cthulhu]

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 5)

      Somewhere in 1812...

      The next morning Pearkes is walking on the quarterdeck. He watches the midshipmen--most under the age of 13--learn how to use the sextant.

      "Sail ahoy!" shouts someone from aloft. Aubrey slides down a shroud as the first lieutenant hands Pearkes his spyglass.

      There's a large ship closing on them, flying Dutch colors.

      "Think we'll be able to outpace them?" says Pearkes.

      "I hope so," says Aubrey grimly. He begins to bark orders to the crew. Surprise begins to heel over as it picks up speed.

      "Are you beating to quarters?"

      "Not close enough yet. Besides, I think our best chance is to outrun them at this point."

      [Aubrey running? Well, he was generally realistic about when he was outclassed. Most of the crew suspects this is an American superfrigate.]

      "Is there anything I can do, Captain?"

      "Can you shoot?"

      "I can. I'm also rather good with a sword."

      "It may come to boarding, Colonel, and if it does I expect you to join me in the boarding party."

      "It would be a pleasure. Nothing would give me more delight than laying out some French heads on the deck."

      "Indeed."

      Maturin looks at Pearkes over his colored spectacles. "Indeed it would, now?"

      The other ship rapidly closes. As it does, it runs up the Stars and Stripes. Aubrey identifies it as the USS Constitution.

      "At least it will give us a chance to redeem Java," he says.

      Pearkes tries to read the crew. Constitution has nearly double their guns, and all of them throw heavier shells than Surprise.

      The crew beats to quarters. The decks are sanded, to soak up blood. The middies meet their sections by their guns, tiny boys next to large cannon.

      Pearkes draws the Sword of Akmallah and readies himself.

      "That's a most interesting weapon you have there, Colonel," says Dr. Maturin.

      "All the best weapons are."

      "Indeed. When I was at University, I used to go out myself once or twice a week. I never understood the British custom of not dueling."

      "Any time you wish to test your skills, I'm ready. It's very sharp, though. I wouldn't want to hurt your pretty face."

      "Colonel, had we more leisure, I would perhaps make you regret those words."

      "You may attempt your attempts."

      "Gentlemen, this can wait until after the batter. Then I'd be glad to second one, or both of you," says Aubrey.

      Pearkes decides to teach the middies and the boarding parties everything he learned about close quarters fighting from four years on the Western Front. By the end, the children are blinking back tears.

      [PP used History. Then he asked if he could use Intimidation. Sussing him out, I said that if he wanted a boarding action, there was only one person to talk to.]

      "Permission to take command of your marines, Captain? I am a bit of a specialist in this."

      "That's excellent, but we're going to engage them with cannons first."

      "This may seem a rather audacious plan, but given how outclassed we are with guns, perhaps we should take the fight to them first."

      "Colonel, no. The American ship probably carries 300 men."

      "But it would be a crown jewel to take as a prize. Fortune favors the daring--and you know that Java did not fare so well with traditional tactics."

      "We'll have to run her guns...they'll probably get off a couple of broadsides...we don't have a lot of men."

      "You have me," says Pearkes with a demoniacal glint in his eye. "You don't need a lot of men."

      [Intimidation spend by PP. Aubrey is convinced, probably because this insane plan resembles any number of his own insane plans.

      Haven't had time yet to work on the Make Some Fronts project, but I will update you all on that as it begins to come together.

      \n
      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 6)

      Somewhere in 1960s...

      Charleston goes out in search of a map of San Francisco. The public library turns out to be Japanese-only, so he drop by Sammy's newstand.

      "Hey, thanks for sending me to your cousin."

      "No problem, man."

      "I may even have a line on some work. Could I borrow a map?"

      "That's great man! Go right ahead."

      [CP asked me about the box Charleston was supposed to deliver. I told him how big it was--about 8" on a side, and when he asked me how heavy it was, I answered with a question--"I don't know, how heavy is it?" Turns out it was very light.]

      Charleston maps out a few routes to and from the waterfront. "Thanks again for your cousin."

      "Yeah, he's okay when he's sober."

      "Oh believe me, he got sober quickly when I showed up."

      Charleston thumbs through an auto-fancier's magazine to familiarize himself with the contemporary cars. His jaw drops in amazement--automatic transmission, steel-belted tires, advanced suspension...

      He walks around observing San Francisco. The Golden Gate Bridge keeps drawing his eye--he'd never seen such a long suspension bridge. He walks his planned entrance and escape routes. He discovers that his early 1920s gangster slang is considered "cool" by the young Japanese kids, even if he is not.

      Eventually he wanders down into the poor white neighborhood. He decides to steal a car and plant it as his getaway vehicle. Eventually, he settles on a 1940s vintage Packard. He waits until evening and then slips up to the car, which has new tires, and pops the door lock. He fiddles with the ignition wires and the car starts up.

      "OOOOOOwwwooooooooooooo! Broadcasting live from Mexico City, it's Wooooolfman Jack!" The car fills with an incredible racket like no music Charleston has ever heard. He flaps around at the dashboard until he manages to lower the volume. A radio inside a car--amazing!

      [I figured even in alt-Earth Wolfman Jack might be broadcasting from pirate radio stations--American "folk music", of course.]

      As Charleston peels out, the car's owner runs out of his house, shaking his fist. Charleston accelerates smoothly down the street, hardly believing the car's power--it's easily the best care he's ever driven.

      He figures out how to change stations on the radio. San Francisco has a very diverse musical landscape--he hears everything from koto music to classic American jazz introduced in Japanese. A Classical music program is broadcast from the Reich, and on one channel he hears an English comedian named Bob Hope (apparently living in Canada) telling jokes about the Germans.

      [Shout out to the source material--Hope is mentioned as broadcasting from Canada.]

      He parks the car near the waterfront and goes in search of a box truck. He steals a cap from a passerby, puts it on, and climbs into the cab of a parked truck. A Japanese policeman waves at him. "Come on mac, you can't stay there all night."

      He drives down towards the warehouse he was told to deliver the package to. Only one truck is parked there, although there are lights on inside the place. He stops the truck several hundred feet away, walks around to the back, and finds a heavy package. He jumps up onto the truckcab's running board, makes sure his delivery box is safely secured inside, slips the truck into gear, and drops the package on the accelerator, jumping off as it begins to pick up speed.

      As the truck tears off down the wharf, he begins to dash towards the Packard. A huge crash echos behind him as the truck crashes into the warehouse. Shadowy figures materialize in the fog, spraying the area with submachinegun fire. He dodges down some alleys and vanishes into the fog himself. As he nears the Packard, he hears a single loud report from a rifle. Shrugging, he jumps into the Packard and drives off at a deliberate pace.

      He drives back into the neighborhood he stole the car from and parks it about a block from the house he stole it from.

      He gets to the laundromat around midnight. "That was an interesting way to fulfill your mission. We thought you'd just deliver the package, but we got the killshot anyway."

      "I'm not completely incompetent. Just completely insane."

      "We saw how you drove that car. You clearly know what you're doing. You ground the gears a lot."

      "What's the deal with all those gears, anyway? And those Packards really haul!"

      "Right. Well, we told Dancer about what you did. He was amused, and then thoughtful."

      "Any possibility of more work?"

      "Yeah. As a matter of fact, he wants to meet you tomorrow at the club. Meantime, here's a couple hundred bucks to tide you over. We also have a guy who can help get you papers."

      "Do I really need them?"

      "Let's just say that if they catch you without your papers, deportation back to China would be the least of your worries."

      "You know, I've never been."

      "To China?"

      "Yes. I'm from Shanghai."

      "But that's in China..."

      "Not this Shanghai."

      [CP has said Charleston comes from the town of Shanghai, West Virginia. Which is a real place! Although in game-earth, it's probably called that because his Shanghailese parents moved there.]

      Charleston makes his way back to Cousin Wu's. "Here's your rent," he says.

      "Cool. Your girlfriend's still sick."

      "Can you call that sawbones?"

      "Sure. He's a traditional doctor, but he went to med school too. Oh, she gave me this list of books for you to get for her."

      The list includes a general history of the world, a map of San Francisco, and recent copies of local newspapers.

      "What! We're not even convinced that this is even realll....hey, Cousin Wu, I had a hard night, could I have some of that 'medication' you smoke?"

      "Hey man, that's not included in the rent."

      "C'mon man, we're buddies, can't we work something out."

      "Oh, all right. Hey, you want to listen to some folk music?"

      "What?"

      "American folk music. It's all the rage, man."

      Wu puts on an album that sounds remarkably like Jefferson Airplane as Charleston lights up a surprisingly strong joint. "Where's the brass section?" he mutters, looking at the album sleeve, which shows several defiant-looking young Japanese wearing colorful outfits.

      A couple of hours later Charleston staggers out and finds an after-hours noodle joint. A man in a fedora and a woman are sitting at the empty counter, while the Korean soda jerk cleans a glass. The place is called Hopper's. A sign advertises the Night Hawkers special--$1.50.

      Charleston orders fried chicken with a side of waffles.

      "Hunh?" says the soda jerk.

      "Habit I picked up in New York."

      "Well, we don't usually do ethnic food, but whatever. I'm glad I left the Eastern states, man. You know the [racial slurs] still sends Jews to the Eastern States when they find them? G*damn Germans."

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 7)

      Somewhere in 1984...

      "Jax, before I open up my soul to you, can you answer me one question?"

      "Yes?"

      "Who was it signed those papers letting you go to Archangel?"

      "Some British officer...Parkes? And Freddie Blakely."

      "Now I know I'm dreaming, since you're dead."

      "Funny, I have the same reaction, because you're dead. But here we are, we're all awake and talking to each other."

      "Maybe you're awake. I'm convinced I'm dreaming."

      "We're not."

      "Put it this way. Before I found myself back here in London, I was wandering around in the Year of Our Lord--"

      "Don't say that. Nobody says it like that anymore."

      "Well, in 1925. In Arabia."

      "What were you doing in Arabia?"

      "Tracking down your last story. Some hare-brained scheme involving Roger Carlyle and Jack Brady."

      "I was thinking about writing a book on Carlyle, but I never got around to it. Spent too much time with John Reed in Moscow, getting into politics. In the 1930s and 40s we were doing well in England, and then you came back."

      [The Jax of 1984 made different choices than the Jax of the regular continuity. So she's an alt-alt-Jax. As it were.]

      "The Thirties and Forties?"

      "Yeah, you could get us entry into all kinds of circles. You even ran for Parliament."

      "That seems unlikely."

      "I guess you can say I inspired you."

      "I hope it at least was the House of Lords."

      "No, Commons."

      "Commons! You must have bribed me with something amazing."

      "Well, we didn't call what we did together bribery..."

      "Hm. That would work."

      "We were together with all the old comrades. I still remember when Goldstein said thanks to you and your resources, you were like the Big Brother of the Party."

      [That idea hit me about two days before the session and proved an impossible temptation to refuse.]

      "Good God! I was a Communist?"

      "Well, you were a Socialist..."

      "I just hung out with Bertie, I didn't believe any of that nonsense."

      "Well, it was very bad in the Thirties, Freddie, remember?"

      "No. I'm from the Twenties."

      "This has to be something O'Shaughnessy set up. He must of found out about my history."

      "I don't know anything about that. For me, you died in the Twenties--found face down in Long Island Sound, while I was living in New York."

      "Listen, Freddie, or whoever you are--"

      "You can call me O'Brien if you want."

      "I'd prefer not to. I actually know him--he's one of O'Shaughnessy's men."

      "Then how on earth do I have his ID?"

      "I don't know...but it makes me think you were sent by O'Shaughnessy to take me down."

      [This was a slight nerf of FP's earlier Preparedness roll to get an ID. I should probably just have denied him the roll if I was going to nerf it. FP rolls with these things better than most, but I wince a bit looking back. OTOH, since the only way he could have had the ID was via the will of Nyarlathotep, maybe I wasn't unjustified? Bit of a grey area--I made my call and I'm not losing sleep over it, although I want to keep watching out for this stuff. The better way to do it would have been to force FP to justify his actions through the fiction.]

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 8)

      Somewhere in 1984...


      "Well, Jax, even though you are mysteriously alive and somehow much older, I have no desire to take you down. In fact, I'm strangely desirous of helping you."

      "Then...you should probably not stay here."

      "Excellent. Can you send me to Arabia?"

      "Arabia? Since its a war zone, yes."

      "It wasn't exactly peaceful when I was there."

      "All right. I'll have Alphonse make arrangements."

      "Alphonse? Bertie?"

      "Comrade Alphonse is my personal secretary." She nods at an elderly gentleman, who looks very much like an older version of Alphonse Gilbert.

      "Come." He motions at Freddie and they walk together downstairs and towards the entrance to the house.

      Freddie stares at Bertie as they walk. He is about to ask him something when the front door bursts open. A gunshot rings out and Gilbert drops to the ground.

      "Freeze!" says a man in a leather trenchcoat. Around him, five or six Thought Police goons with automatic rifles gesture menacingly at Freddie.

      "You too, Comrade General!" says the man as Jax comes downstairs.

      "Who do you think you are?" she says.

      "You have a date at the Ministry of Truth, both of you," gloats the man in the trenchcoat.

      Jax and Freddie are hooded and shackled, and then thrown into the trunk of a car. Soon they are trundling along.

      "Jax, do you want me to take these cuffs off?" says Freddie.

      "How are you going to do that?"

      "My goodness, you taught me how!" Freddie gathers himself, then manages to dislocate his thumb. Biting back the pain, he pulls his hand through the cuff and removes their hoods.

      [Filch spend by FP--he was going to pick the lock, but shied away when I told him it would be fairly hard. This was cooler anyway.]

      "So what's the plan, Jax?"

      "Well, they're going to take us to Minitrue--"

      "Torture us, kill us, yes--"

      "They might not kill us, but they'll definitely torture us."

      "So the sort of thing that you were threatening me with just fifteen minutes ago?"

      "In a nutshell. I imagine these are O'Shaughnessy's people. If I can't convince them not to do it based on who I am, then I think we're done for."

      "Does he consider you as much of a rival as you consider him to be?"

      "Yeah. He's an up-and-comer, wants to get rid of all of us Old Comrades. Doesn't remember the struggle...he'll probably have us vaporized."

      "Then you should come with me to Arabia. I know nothing of London, and that was true even when I lived here, so I'll need your help after we escape."

      [I'll say this about FP--he never lets go of an idea, and that fits Freddie to a T.]

      "What about the guards?"

      "Let me show you a trick my driver, Charleston, taught me." Freddie fishes in his pockets. Although he's been very thoroughly searched, his small nail-paring knife, hidden in the seam of his trousers, was not found.

      [Preparedness buy by FP, and a very low one.]

      He dislocates Jax's thumb and pops her free of her cuffs. Then he opens up his knife. He slices down a seam of the back seat, and peaks through. A guard is sitting in the back of the car.

      [Stealth spend by FP.]

      Gathering up his courage, he plunges the tiny blade into the man's carotid artery. Blood spurts everywhere as the guard slumps forward. Freddie pulls the dying man's pistol and puts a bullet in the back of the driver's head. The car begins to spin, and then with a sickening thud the car bangs into something, skids, and flips over.

      [Weapons spend, and a crit on the attack; Filch to take the gun, then Firearms to shoot the driver. Everyone took a die of damage from the crash.]

      Freddie crawls into the car through the slit. He takes both guards' guns, and the keys to the car and the handcuffs. He drags the unconscious Jackson out of the trunk and throws her over one shoulder.

      From the sky comes a curious thudding noise--thup thup thup thup. Never having heard the sound of a helicopter before, Freddie shrugs and looks for a place to hide. The sound of sirens can be heard, coming closer.

      He dashes through the Prole section of town and swings into an alleyway. A small carriage house, converted into an apartment seems to offer refuge. He bursts through the door.

      A pleasant looking old man is talking into a telescreen. "You may as well say good-bye. And by the way, while we are on the subject, "Here comes a candle to light you to bed, here comes a chopper to-- who the hell are you?" he says, turning to face Freddie.

      The picture on the screen is of two naked people standing back to back, with looks of terror.

      "Who the hell are you?" repeats the man.

      "I'm O'Brien."

      "You're O'Brien? What are you doing here? There's a platoon of Thought Police on their way."

      "Turn off the screen, damnit! I know all that! This is all O'Shaughnessy's doing--he's starting a coup."

      "I think I need to call this in..."

      Freddie shoots him. The old man drops to the floor.

      As Freddie ties the man up, the man and woman from the telescreen come downstairs, wrapped in a blanket. "We were getting arrested by the Thought Police..." says the man. He is holding a huge book.

      "What are your names?"

      "I'm Winston, and this is Julia."

      "Ridiculous names. You'd best come with us."

      "Is that General Jeremias?"

      "Yes, and I'm O'Brien."

      "You're not O'Brien! I know O'Brien!"

      "Did you think there's only one O'Brien in all of Oceania?"

      As Freddie revives Jax, Julia comes downstairs, dressed in her coveralls. She looks curiously at Freddie, and then sharply. She takes a coin out of her pocket and stares at it, and at Freddie. "With a mustache...and a little older...it can't be..." she mutters.

      "Where are we?" says Jackson.

      "Some house. The Thought Police are on their way. Where should we go?"

      "I know where to go, but you won't like it."

      "Is it my Aunts' house?"

      "No, no. You had your aunts liquidated--one of the first things you did as Chairman. The Ministry. Where my people will be able to help us, if it's not too late."

      She places a call, and soon a black car rolls up. Freddie hands her his gun. "Not terribly fond of these things."

      "Neither am I," she says, buckling it on.

      "I just ask one thing, Jax. If you shoot me, try not to do it slowly."

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 9)

      Somewhere in the 1960s...

      After eating, Charleston slips out into the night. He finds a local high school, and counting on being pegged as a janitor if anyone sees him, he breaks in and steals some history texts.

      By the time he gets back to Cousin Wu's, the doctor is finishing his exam. "You need ginseng," the doctor says to Noor, "and probably chemotherapy."

      "Do you know what's wrong with her?"

      "I can't tell. I'd really like to get her to a hospital."

      "Is that possible?"

      "Do you have your papers?"

      "No."

      "Then it's probably not a good idea."

      "So I guess I need to get some papers."

      "Do not worry about me," croaks Noor. "I will be fine."



      They dig into the textbooks. Apparently there was a second President Roosevelt. But he got assassinated in Miami in 1940.

      [The official divergence in The Man in the High Castle from our timeline.]

      Charleston flips through one of the books. "Hey, there's that guy from the nightclub! Turns out he became dictator of Germany. Before going nuts from syphilis." According to the newspapers, Hitler's successor Martin Bormann is on the verge of dying, and a power struggle is about to start between Dr. Goebbels and the head of security, Reinhard Heydrich.

      On the recommendation of the guys at the laundry, Charleston heads into the white section of town. He finds a small tailor shop run by what is obviously a Jewish former New Yorker--obvious to Charleston, at least, who lived near the Lower East Side.

      The man puts down the book he is reading, a novel called The Grasshopper Lies Heavy. Charleston had noticed people reading that book before, but there wasn't a copy in the high school, and the bookstore he stopped at on the way told him it was banned by the Japanese.

      So he stole a copy from somebody on the trolley.

      The storekeeper puts the book down and covers it with his thick copy of the I Ching--the other book Charleston had noticed everybody carrying around.

      "Hello there. My name is Frank Jones."

      "Sure it is. Nice shop."

      "It is a tailor shop."

      "I could use some clothes. And papers."

      "We don't do papers here. But why don't you take a look at my dry cleaning fees." He hands Charleston a small book. Inside are the prices listed for a variety of documents--ranging from ration books (relatively cheap) to passports (prohibitively expensive."

      "What would I need to get into a hospital?" asks Charleston.

      "Hm. Well, it would help if you were born in the Pacific States instead of China. American citizens have slightly more rights."

      "She's an Arab."

      "Really? I didn't think there were many of those left."

      "She could be Indian, you know."

      "Ah. That would make you both citizens of the the Greater Pacific Co-Prosperity Sphere...she's not Japanese, you're not Japanese...I could make you both Americans, give you some work papers...that at least makes you eligible for health care. For two people...say, are you from New York?"

      "Yes."

      "I miss it. It's really not the same ever since they tore down the Statue of Liberty."

      "Chinatown was where I was from."

      "Lower East Side. Those were the days. I was just lucky I got out. My cousin Frankl, in Poland--they're all dead. My wife Judit, she didn't make it out of New York.

      "Life doesn't work out when you lose the war you're fighting."

      "Tell me about it. It's been the story of my people for five thousand years." He looks around quickly. "I of course refer to the Welsh. For the two of you, because you're from New York, $500."

      "How long?"

      "Three days. Give me a week, it will be almost undetectable."

      "I need it faster than that. Rush job?"

      "I'll need half up front for that."

      "How's $200?"

      "Hrm....you know how to make an egg cream?"

      "Sure!"

      "Really?"

      "I won't tell you it's the best you'll ever have, but I will tell you it's the only one you're going to get."

      "Hah! I like your mox--your spunk. $200, see me in three days."

      [CP's tenderness and dedication towards Noor is really kind of touching--you wouldn't expect it given the way he plays the character at other times. CP does this kind of thing of lot--he likes to joke around (and has a bottomless supply of execrable puns), but he does some very subtle touches with his roleplaying. He made his abrasive goblin wizard (with the charisma of 5) both believably self-sabotaging socially but never a pain in the ass to be around.]

      Charleston returns to the house. Noor is sitting up in bed, reading. "We should be able to get you into a hospital in three days or so," he tells her.

      "That is good." She sighs and closes a book. "The passage of time does not seem to have improved this world."

      "How do you mean? The world was always terrible."

      "But my people are all dead!"

      "You never liked them anyway."

      "I didn't want them massacred by the Germans!"

      "Forget about them. I'm your people. These books--they're your people. They always were."

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 10)

      Somewhere in the 1960s...

      That night Charleston heads downtown to Dancer Lee's club. It's very busy, filled with a high-end clientele. Charleston recognizes the setup immediately from his experiences in other mob-owned clubs.

      The front is filled with young, well-to-do Japanese people. Some come in costumes as "classic American types" like cowboys. The occasional wealthy and sycophantic American can also be found there.

      The real nightclub is where the hip rich Japanese hang out, grooving to American "folk music". VIP barriers keep the strivers out while giving them a tantalizing glimpse of what lies beyond.

      Behind that is the Triad den, filled with tough-looking characters--all the members of the gang, except for a few who hang around the entrance to give the place some ambiance.

      Charleston is led into the private suite, kept atmospherically dark. He parks himself on a couch, and the servants give him his favorite drink--orange juice--without having to be asked.

      After a long while, an elderly Chinese man, wearing traditional robes, enters the room and sits down, shadows obscuring his face. A younger man in a business suit stands next to him. The old man begins speaking in rapid Shanghailese, with such a thick accent that Charleston can barely follow him.

      Fortunately, the man in the suit translates. "It has been so long since I spoke English regularly that I brought my man with me. I was very interested in how you took care of the problem last night. It immediately drew my interest, because it reminded me of what I would have done when I was a young man."

      [FP: It's you! You're talking to you!]

      The old man leans forward. His features resemble Charleston's--with the addition of some forty years.

      [Dancer--from "the Charleston", and Lee, from the name of the Triad family he worked for.]

      "My only question is, how is this possible that you are here?"

      "Well, I took a cab down here, and there were these lovely young people out front..."

      "Ah yes, I remember being as you are, when I was young. Before I had responsibilities. Of course, now that I have responsibilities, I tend to torture people who talk back to me. It's what Mr. Lee taught us, after all."

      "He taught me nothing! He threw me out!"

      "Ah. That is not what I remember."

      Charleston rolls up his sleeve, showing his Triad brands, and the symbol cancelling his membership in the family. Dancer nods, and rolls his own sleeves up, showing an unblemished brand.

      [Before the campaign began, I ran CP and PP through a CoC session where we did "Dead Man Stomp". It was the first time Charleston met Jackson Elias, and ended with her getting shot and him kicked out of the Triad. In this world, "Dancer" never met Jax, and thus stayed in the Triad.]

      "It's been so long since I left New York that I barely remember it."

      "Really? Feels like I left only three months ago."

      "I had to leave everything there. My wife did not make it out."

      "Your wife?"

      "Yes. The Germans were not kind to many people. Especially black women."

      [Charleston has a crush on Bertha, the owner of a Harlem diner.]

      Dancer leans back. "I would normally say you are an impossible thing, but there have been many impossible things happening of late." He brings out a copy of The Grasshopper Lies Heavy. "Do you know this book?"

      "Just got a copy. Haven't had a chance to read it. What's it about?"

      "A world where the United States and England did not lose World War Two."

      "I still don't get that war."

      "As it turns out, it is hard to keep a bad German down. And the Japanese went insane for a while, until the War Cabinet fell. Now matters are worse. Both sides have nuclear weapons now..."

      "What?"

      "Bombs that can destroy a city. The Germans invented them first. Uses the power of the atom. There are enough between Germany and Japan to destroy all life on this planet. Of course, you'd have to be crazy to want to do that--but the Germans are crazy."

      "Look, I'm just trying to get some work."

      "I have a mission for you. You will need papers. I will tell our tailor to hurry. You're going to need a travel pass."

      "I'm traveling?"

      "Yes. To Colorado. I want you to meet with a man named Hawthorne Abendsen."

      "Who's that?"

      "The man who wrote this book. I want you to find out why he wrote the book, and how he wrote the book. You are familiar with the Book of Changes?"

      "My mom used to use it sometimes..."

      "I remember. It has become customary in San Francisco to consult the oracle frequently. I asked the oracle once, 'Why was this book written?' I will write down what it said." He scribbles something on a paper, then seals it in an envelope and hands it to Charleston. "Ask the author why he wrote the book, and then give him that."

      "As you know, this is a bit outside my skill set. I suppose I should report back when I'm done?"

      "Yes."

      "So this is a mission I'm supposed to come back from, then?"

      "Ah. Yes, yes it is."

      "May I be so bold as to ask you a question? What other interesting books have you come across?"

      "I'm not much of a reader. You remember that."

      "I've become quite the scholar, actually."

      "You and I have followed very different paths, I think."

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 11)

      Somewhere in the 1800s...

      Surprise darts forward, into the withering fire from Constitution. Acrid clouds of smoke drift across the water. Pearkes stands near the bow. Around him men are torn to pieces by shell and flying fragments of the ship.

      [Me: Pearkes, it reminds you so much of Passchendaele that--wait for it--what's my favorite phrase? STABILITY CHECK!
      PP: I think my background means I don't need to make a check.
      Me: Amico, we've been through this--you know what you have to do if you want to stop making Stability checks for violent stuff.

      (It's a rule from       Night's Black Agents--basically, you can start avoiding some of the "violent stuff goes down" Stability checks provided you lower your Stability rating (or the rating of any one Interpersonal skill) by one point for every person you kill.)

      PP: I'm fine with that.
      Me: Really? Okay, let me know what you're dropping.
      PP: I'll take one from Reassurance.]

      Aubrey walks up to Pearkes, buckling on a cutlass and a brace of pistols. "Do you need a gun, Colonel?"

      Pearkes takes out his Colt Peacemaker. "I'm fine."

      "What in the hell is that?"

      "All in good time."

      "You're a strange man, Pearkes. Maturin told me I shouldn't take you with me, but I told him to get stuffed."

      "I'm a strange man who's going to win you this battle."

      "Very good then."

      With a colossal thud what is left of the undersized frigate plows into Constitution. Pearkes swings across to the American ship. As he lands, an American tries to take off his head with a marlinspike. Pearkes ducks and then swings the Sword of Akmallah at him, slashing his head from his shoulders, and then with a backhand stroke beheads the man's nearest companion.

      Aubrey looks over. His jaw drops for a moment, and then he waves Pearkes forward.

      George dashes for the quaterdeck, leaping up on the rail to dodge past the throng of American sailors. The mighty Sword sweeps out again, beheading two more sailors. A sharpshooter from the maintop wings Pearkes as he runs forward.

      [Bunch of athletics checks and weapons checks here by PP; I was letting him behead any mooks he ran across.]

      Pearkes glances back. Aubrey is surrounded by the Americans, but they keep a respectful distance from the bearish Englishman, bleeding from many wounds.

      "It's a masterpiece!" exults Pearkes as he swings up to the quarterdeck on a rope. He sees a man in a large hat dash down into the cabin. Some officers raise their hands up as Pearkes slashes viciously at them, and four more heads roll to the deck.

      Pearkes leaps down the stairs. A shot rings out, catching him in the shoulder and spinning him around.

      [4 points of damage dropped him to -3, and then he spent one on the roll to stay conscious.]

      The door slams shut behind him. The captain turns around slowly.

      "Pearksie! Good to see you." says N.

      Pearkes shoots him. Nyarlathotep catches the bullet in his hand. "Seriously?" he says.

      "Seriously! This is it? You create this alternate reality--"

      "Oh, I didn't create--"

      "--I go risking my life, we're making history, and you come along and ruin everything."

      "I'm not ruining anything. We're taking a little break from it is all."

      "Well--" Pearkes claps his hands loudly. "What is it? Seriously, I've had enough of this ridiculous--aaaagh!"

      "Oh, so you want to go somewhere else?"

      "I was enjoying myself, and now I'm not."

      "Ooooh, so you like killing things."

      "I'm very good at it. I was told to focus on what you're good at."

      "I could use a man like you."

      "But you're evil! I'm not evil!"

      "I'm the evil guy--says the guy who beheaded ten people."

      "They were--enemies of England."

      "Oh yeah, that makes it morally better. I especially like how you're fighting for fifteen century monarchy over democracy. Really morally superior. Anyway. You sure you don't want to work for me? You want to muck around here? By the way, the dentistry--you're not going to enjoy it."

      "Why would I need to enjoy it?"

      "And the surgery...not good."

      "Look, you're just going to do to me whatever you want--"

      "Whoa, hey, I'm not in charge of this trip."

      "Oh come on."

      "Hey, I'm just an Outer God asking some questions."

      [This was a riff on my common rejoinder to when folks expect me to be a more traditional, top-down game master--"I'm just a gal asking some questions, is all."]

      "So why did you send me here?"

      "I don't know. Why do I do anything?"

      "A question I ask myself," mutters Pearkes.

      "So you don't want to leave."

      "I don't want to come work for you. So why don't we just quit now, you send me back to where I'm from, and we'll call it even."

      "Yeaaaah...and why would I want to do that for you?"

      "Because if you're going to play around with my life you might as well do it in my own time. It will be more entertaining."

      "Well, I can think of a lot of entertaining things I can do to you any time. What are you going to give up to go home?"

      "I don't know what would interest the curiosity of an Outer God."

      "Hey, I'm just asking some questions here..."

      "I'll give you the Sword."

      [I believe I kept my jaw from dropping pretty well. I had no idea that PP was going to give up the Sword so quickly--he seemed to enjoy its vorpral goodness. Not sure if he thought I was going to screw him for keeping it or not.

      For the record, I wasn't, although since he had started to use it to kill human beings it was going to start acting like a driver on him, to pursue more bloodshed in the service of his sense of righteousness...]

      "Seriously? For realsies? You'll give me that sword?"

      "Yes."

      "You think you can?"

      "I don't know! You're the Outer God, and you're asking the mortal questions?"

      "You want to go home...ok. And you want to give me the sword...ok. I can do that deal. So, give me the sword."

      Pearkes stabs him with it.

      "Are you f***ing kidding me?"

      "The sword told me to do it!"

      "Yeah, this really makes me well-disposed towards you. Fine. Congratulations. You're home!"

      Pearkes finds himself in the middle of a sandstorm, still dressed in his bloodstained 19th century infantry uniform. He begins to dig a shelter. Soon he is relatively safe, in the midst of the howling chaos.

      [PP: I spend 5 Outdoorsman.
      FP: No, no, spend 1 or 2.
      Me: Yeah, I don't even want to think about what a spend of 5 would look like...
      PP: I'd find water....
      FP: Yeah, we'll find you sitting in the middle of your inground pool...]

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 12)

      Somewhere in 1984...

      "Comrade General, Comrade O'Shaughnessy wants to see you."

      "Good," says Jackson, "I want to see him as well."

      Freddie flops down into a dilapidated office chair. After a long wait, a man enters the office.

      "Good day, Comrade General. And to you, Mr. Blakely," says O'Shaughnessy. He turns to face Freddie.

      Freddie stares into the features of Omar Shakhti.

      "Oh for God's sake," he mutters.

      "We don't say 'God' here."

      "Yes, yes, all right. I get it, you're most impressive."

      "I am impressive, true."

      "Wait a moment...do you remember meeting me? My little trip out to your estate?"

      "Most clearly, Mr. Blakely."

      "Well, no one else seems to know what I'm talking about!"

      "No one else is quite like me."

      "What the hell are you two talking about?" demands Jackson.

      "Apparently this O'Shaughnessy is that Egyptian I was telling you about."

      "That's not important," says Shakhti/O'Shaughnessy. "What's important is that my guards have seized control of this building, and your guards are dead or imprisoned. And you and me--and her--have a date in Room 101."

      [A bit heavy-handed to drag Freddie back to MiniTrue for safety and then yank it away. I was trying to wind things down a bit and get back to the regular continuity, but still it could have been done more gracefully. Like, having player input or something.]

      "Oh, more good news. I've been arrested again!" says Freddie, as goons surround him. "Shakhti-Bey, can you be sure you killed all the guards? There seems to be an inexhaustible supply of them."

      "Oh, but these are my guards."

      "How can you tell? They look exactly alike!"

      "A shepherd can recognize his flock. Men, take Mr. Blakely to Room 101. As roughly as possible, if you please."

      "For God's sake," says Freddie, as he gets thrown down a staircase, "is there some purpose in this, or are you doing it because it amuses you?"

      "The second one."

      They are taken into a dark, subterranean room. Freddie and Jax are strapped to tables and wired up to strange machinery. Shakhti stands on an elevated platform, next to a large dial.

      He turns the dial slightly. Freddie feels horrible pain course through every nerve in his body. "Aagh!"

      "Ah, you cried out. But would you cry out if I did this?" He turns the dial again, and Jackson shrieks in agony. "We're going to try this again. And if you cry out, I will inflict the same pain on her."

      Horrible pain floods Freddie's body again, like a dentist's drill on a healthy nerve.

      [Me: This is how it works. If you make a Stability check, you keep yourself from screaming in time. If you fail, Shakhti stops hurting you but starts inflicting pain on Jax--which will trigger a Stability check, for causing pain to your Source.
      FP: But she's not.
      Me: But she       looks like she is.
      FP: She does, doesn't she.
      Me: Now, you can spend Health as well as Stability on this roll.

      [Aside to the aside: I was trying to see what Freddie would do to save somebody not himself, and of course if you set something in       1984 you need a torture scene of some kind; my plan was to handle it mechanically as much as possible, because I don't like torture porn. This was probably all over not one of the best ideas I've ever had, but then FP smashed it good.]

      FP: I've got a solution.       (in character) "Shakhti-Bey, this little plan of yours only works if I'm alive, yes?"
      Me (as Shakhti): "Yes..."
      FP: "Shock me again."       (out of character) I spend 13 health.
      Me: (smacks gob)

      [Ok, reader: I used the last refuge of a scoundrel and hid behind the rulebook; you can't spend yourself below -11. What I       should have done is insisted that FP rationalize his action in the fiction; howinahell do you spend yourself down to -11 while strapped in a chair? FP's premise was that this was a dream, and I didn't want to necessarily take that from him, but I had decided this was horribly, horribly real. I guess if I was a Traditionalist I'd have offed him then and there, but it's not that kind of game and I'm not that kind of GM.

      Had I been more up on my AW principles/MC moves, I could have       Told them the possible consequences, and asked. Like: "FP, so far everything has seemed perfectly real and not at all dreamlike, except for the fact that you're here at all. And you've seen magic do stuff. So, are you sure you want to risk dying here? It might be permanent." That would have been cool! But instead I panicked a bit. Young GMs out there, beware--players will sometimes, even in the coolest of narrative environments, try to beat you around the ears with the fiction--especially if they're as tactically gifted as FP.]
