      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 13)

      Somewhere in 1984...

      Freddie awakes sometime later in a hospital bed. A male nurse is sitting by the headboard.

      "Good morning, Comrade," he says.

      "Good morning. Do you have a name, or should I just call you Comrade?"

      "You can call me Comrade N."

      "How do you do, Comrade N."

      "Oh, I'm just peaches. You, on the other hand, are in bad shape. That little trick you pulled--the heart attack? They won't let you do that again. These guys have torture down to a science. It's impressive--I know lots of species, and you guys, you're like--I don't know, abacus-level? But in this one area, you do really well.

      Freddie tries to get out of the bed and collapses to the floor. He drags himself towards the wall as N talks.

      [FP: As he speaks, I get out of bed.
      Me: You spent your health down to -11? You can't get up.
      FP: But remember, I think I'm lucid dreaming.
      Me: Okay, you       try to get up, and you collapse to the floor.
      FP: Then I crawl to the window. Do I see anything?
      Me: There's no window.

      ...hm. Maybe I kinda did explain the consequences, just not directly.]

      Freddie crawls back to bed. "So what's your plan, old chap?"

      "I dunno. I don't have plans. Well, I have schemes, I guess."

      "What's your scheme?"

      "I'm just here checking up on you."

      "Why are you interested in me?"

      "A tiny, tiny part of me is interested in you. How did you like meeting your old girlfriend?"

      "That was different. You didn't give me much background, just something about me becoming President and killing my aunts. Seems unrealistic. Although I could kill Agatha..."

      "Things change."

      "Perhaps you should work on getting a better author."

      "I don't know what you're talking about."

      "All the literary allusions scattered around your fantasy world..."

      "Oh, that. It's not a fantasy world, it's plenty real--I mean, look at you, more than half dead."

      "Says the lord of magic, who can do anything he wants..."

      "Doesn't work like that. I guess I forget sometimes who I'm talking to; you couldn't understand."

      "Are you planning on keeping me here and amusing yourself?"

      "I don't know. Was kind of intrigued to see what you would do to save your girlfriend."

      "Well, the thing is, I think my girlfriend is dead."

      "Well, it's true, you buried her..."

      "No, the one here. I'm pretty sure she's dead--coup, anti-coup, firing squads, that sort of thing."

      "Naw. They haven't got up to the vaporization stage yet--they still want to torture her. And Shakhti--I'll call him Shakhti, easier for you--does what I tell him to do."

      "How is it he's here and remembers me?"

      "He's a--what can I say--a devoted servant. He occasionally wants to do his own schemes. I tolerate it."

      Freddie laughs. "I don't know whether to believe you or not."

      "I'm just an Outer God asking some questions is all."

      "Well, we seem to be at an impasse, since you can do whatever you bloody well wish--"

      "It really doesn't work that way. I can't just do 'whatever I bloody well wish.'"

      "From my extremely limited perspective."

      "Yes! That's correct. Anyway, in about 30 seconds they'll come through the door, this time with the equipment they need to keep you alive. That is, unless you want to do something about it."

      "Well, then I hope the door opens and I'm back in Arabia."

      "Well, that's what you want. What are you going to do?"

      "I'll crawl through the door, since apparently I can't walk."

      "Right. Well, see you in the funny papers, then, Freddie."

      The door opens. N is no longer there.

      "Room 101," says a guard. They frogmarch Freddie down to the subterranean room. Jackson is strapped to the other bed. She's clearly been beaten.

      "Hullo, Jax. Apparently they're torturing you to torture me. It's terribly exciting."

      Shakhti comes out onto the platform. "We're all here again."

      "This seems to be some kind of personal torture device," says Freddie.

      "Yes?"

      "Well, the question is, are you torturing me, or torturing Jax?"

      "Let's find out, shall we?"

      "I think you're torturing me," stage whispers Freddie.

      "That's an interesting theory," says Shakhti as he cranks the machine over again.

      [Round the mulberry bush again. FP tries to spend 11; again I don't insist he explain how (why? WHY?) but have them revive him immediately and then wire him into some medical equipment. (This was getting stupid on both sides now.) FP then asks for a First Aid spend to kill himself. I ask how, and he says he bites through his tongue.

      Step back. FP was basically trying not to be in the torture scene. But why? THAT was a better question to ask here; was it because he didn't want to do a torture scene, didn't like Freddie being put on the spot, or because he was trying to win D&D? It's hard to say, which is why I should have asked. We both got caught up in a kind of "simulationist endless loop" where rather than using our superior tools to manipulate the fiction--the ones Trail of Cthulhu explicitly provides--we fell back into the deadly step by step insertion of details familiar to anybody who's played traditional games, especially ones with their roots in 1st gen RPGs.

      I'm going to explicitly ask people not to do this next time, and pay attention myself (I hope).

      I beat myself up quite a bit in this thread, mostly because I really care about doing this as well as possible; this is an art for me, a sometimes serious one. That said, I'm doing something right; CP continues to show up even though he hates Gumshoe, it seems. This is me watching the game-day film, and fretting over each missed tackle or wayward ball or insert your physical metaphor of choice here.]

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 14)

      Freddie wakes up in a hospital room again. His hands are shackled to the bed. Shakhti is standing over the bed.

      "Blakely, you will not be allowed to do that again."

      "Thasht's whasht yoush shaid the lasht time. By the way, do you find thish frushtrathing?"

      "Not at all, I enjoy this game of cat and mouse. But to ensure your compliance--"

      A thug steps forward with a large sledgehammer. He smashes Freddie's hands. Freddie blacks out again.

      He comes to back in Room 101. His hands are a swollen ruin, clearly untreated.

      "Ah, Freddie," says Shakhti, "we were trying to play nice with you--do things in a civilized manner."

      "No, you're trying to torture me and break my spirit."

      "Yes, but in a civilized manner."

      "Just get on with it, Shakhti."

      "Yes, normally I'm supposed to get you to believe in the Party and everything, but I really don't care." He turns the dial.

      Freddie steels himself, reassuring himself that it will all be over soon.

      [I allowed a Reassurance buy by FP here; not really kosher, though.]

      "Your spirit is strong."

      "Just put a bullet in my head already."

      "Not yet. I want you to hear something."

      They wheel Jackson in; she's clearly been beaten for days.

      "General!" says Shakhti.

      "Comrade," says Jackson bitterly.

      "Mr. Blakely is dead, isn't he?"

      "Died in the '50s."

      "How did he die?"

      [CP: VD!]

      "She probably shot me," says Freddie.

      "I ordered your vaporization," says Jackson, stunned.

      "I figured that out days ago."

      "That doesn't bother you?"

      "Oh, I knew Jax very well. It's the sort of thing she'd do. I imagine I was a ponce."

      Shakhti and Jackson stare at Freddie, incredulous.

      "Oh, and Jackson?" says Freddie, "of course I forgive you."

      Jax begins to cry. Shakhti starts to scream in frustration. "This isn't how it's supposed to go! This isn't the way it goes! This isn't how it works! I--"

      His face changes to that of N.

      "You really are amusing," he says.

      "The only thing that makes any sense is that you're trying to torture Shakhti," says Freddie.

      "You know, the problem with you Blakely? You're always happy where you are. I mean, you won't even make me an offer to get out of this! Most people make me an offer."

      "Oh! Mr. N, please get me out of this."

      "For what?"

      "I'm fantastic on the piano."

      "You are fantastic. But not that fantastic."

      "Look, N, so far as I can tell this whole thing involves that goat with a thousand young. You're not even involved."

      "No, this is my gig, though you wouldn't understand. Chuckles does--he knows what happens when we open the Gate and bring cosmic weirdness down to ol' Planet Earth. Your lives will all be so much more interesting, what's left of them."

      "Why do you care about me?"

      "Because you're poking around, and you're going to ruin the surprise! It's not like you can stop it, but it's more fun when people don't know what's coming."

      "So just let me go! I don't even know what it is I'm supposed to do to be stopping you! If I do, you'll have something to be interested in, and if I don't, then you have your fun! Plus like you said, I'm happy wherever I am--so why not send me home?"

      "Yeah, but I need some skin out of this. Nothing bad's happened to you."

      Freddie looks at his hands.

      "Okay," says N, "but that was just people. Seems to me that if I give you something, I gotta take something. Tell you what. You were close with Jax, right? I'll give you a little taste."

      A sandstorm swirls around Freddie. His hands are smashed ruin. He stumbles forward into a dugout, where Pearkes is hiding, and passes out.

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 15)

      Somewhere in the 1960s...

      A few days after his meeting with Dancer, Charleston is sitting in Noor's room, listening to her read from the Al-Azif. To the disappointment of both, no spell that they try and cast work. This is puzzling to them both.

      There's a knock on the door. Charleston lets in a man who hands him a package. "I was told to deliver this."

      "Thank you. This is for your trouble."

      He hands the man a few coins. When the man looks up, his face has changed to that of the being they call N.

      "Two cents? Seriously?"

      "Why, what did you expect?"

      "I expect a lot more from you, Chuckles. Wanna chat?"

      "What do you want?"

      "Just making my rounds, checking up on everyone. How do you like this place? How's the magic working?"

      "Great! I can make a card appear here, a card appear there, a coin come out of your ear..."

      "Pro tip: if you're going to lie to people, learn to shield your mind from telepathy. Only one spell is going to work here."

      "First, I demand my two cents back."

      "Fine."

      Charleston starts to choke. Eventually he manages to dislodge the penny that suddenly appeared in his trachea.

      "I hurt you because I love you the most. You're the one who understands."

      There is a popping noise, and suddenly they are standing on top of Mount Diablo, some 60 miles from San Francisco.

      "So how's it been going?" asks N.

      "All right. There was a thing with a bomb, and I met a very near relative, which was a trip. Frankly, I don't know which of us is better off."

      "He's a big time gangster."

      "Gangster--who cares? That's not what matters."

      "Exactly! You get it! Pearkes would never understand that."

      "Yeah. Though really, there's not a lot of room left up in my brain. I have to start writing things down to remember them. I'm lucky I remember that!"

      "I could fix that--your brain, that is. Of course, you wouldn't really be human anymore..."

      "That's okay. Is there a bench? Someplace to sit down?"

      "Sure." N snaps his fingers, and Charleston finds himself on the observation deck of a very tall building, taller than the nearby Empire State Building. (He doesn't recognize it, of course, because it hasn't been built in his time yet.) Out in New York Harbor, where the Statue of Liberty used to stand, is a statue of Adolf Hitler giving the Nazi salute.

      "Hey, there's that Hitler guy."

      "Yeah, he's a chum. Welcome to Todt Tower, built by Albert Speer's guys. What's your plan?"

      "I was going to head out to Colorado."

      "I don't think you should do that."

      "See, now it sounds interesting."

      "You know, I was probably very much like you once."

      "See, that's the thing about a good memory. You spend too much time thinking of the past."

      "You're right. Let's live in the moment. Pearksie and Blakely have both found their way home."

      "Home is wherever I find myself."

      "Can't argue with a man who knows himself. So, you ready to come work for me?"

      "Work? See, I was thinking of finding somebody to think they were in charge and give me an excuse to go places and make things go wrong."

      "Yeah, work."

      "See, I'm not sure that I could work for somebody who always knows when I'm lying."

      "Just have to learn to shield your mind."

      "But then you won't know if I'm really working for you, will you?"

      "Everybody ends up working for me eventually, especially when they try to do magic."

      "I can do magic!" says Charleston, flipping a deck of cards between his hands.

      N holds out a palm. The cards fly through the air and land in a neat stack in his hand. As they skate past his eyes, Charleston sees N's face on every one, strobing through an animation of him making a rude gesture.

      "So..." says N, "you are going to come work for me?"

      "It's just not a job offer that's particularly enticing for me."

      "Let me spice it up for you then."

      He throws Charleston off the side of the building.

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 16)

      Somewhere in the 1960s...

      "Aaaaaaah," says Charleston, immediately grabbing the ledge and holding himself up easily.

      "That would be harder to do with no hands."

      "And easier with three hands!" He scrambles back up to the deck.

      "All right. I guess somebody around here has to have free will," says N.

      "Two cents, sir?" asks the messenger. Charleston glances around.

      He's back in Noor's room.

      "You know what? Here's a dollar bill. No more hard objects."

      Noor is sitting up in bed. She closes her book. "I think I am too tired to read any more, Charleston."

      "That's all right. Say, you interested in a job? I hear someone's recruiting; just not a good fit for me now."

      "I think I'm too sick to do any work."

      "I'm sure medical treatment is included."

      "Could we talk about this later?"

      "Sure...sure. Just keep it in the back of your head."

      [Assess Honesty tells CP that Noor is lying about something, but he doesn't know what.]



      Later that night Charleston is finished getting ready for his trip to Colorado, now that his travel papers have arrived. He goes upstairs to get Noor, so that he can take her to the hospital. She is sitting in bed, with a book on her lap.

      "Oh, I was just reading," she says. Charleston looks around.

      The room is pitch dark.

      "Can you help me out of the bed?"

      "Sure, sure." He lets her stand up slowly and put her weight on him. "Where are we off to next?"

      "I don't know...I haven't been able to figure anything more out. Can you help me down the stairs?"

      "Of course." He notices that she is having trouble walking. As they reach the top of the stairs, she trips and begins to fall. Charleston nimbly grabs her, noticing that she tripped because she didn't seem to know the stair was there.

      "What do you see now, Noor?"

      "I don't see anything at all, Charleston. I am blind."

      "How were you reading, then?"

      "I was pretending. I didn't want you to be worried."

      "I would have read to you, Noor. Nothing should get in the way of the research. I'll take you to the hospital--they'll make you right as rain. Or you could take that job offer..."

      "Who would I be working for?"

      "Ah....that person we met at the party, before we got here..."

      "Oh. That's not so good, is it."

      "Well, Noor, it looks like your hands are tied here. The hospital could perhaps delay the inevitable."

      "Why don't you not take me to the hospital? Take me with you instead."

      "If that's your decision."

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 17)

      Somewhere in the 1960s...

      They motor out into the darkness, fleeing San Francisco, driving through the dawn up into the Sierra Nevada, winding down the narrow and poorly-maintained mountain roads. Morning finds them burning across the Nevada desert. Somewhere east of Salt Lake City they cross the frontier into the Rocky Mountain States. Around 10 pm, Charleston finally stops in a motel just south of Cheyenne, Wyoming. Inside the packet from Dancer he finds an address, and he consults his map while huge trucks roar by on their way east down the German-built autobahns.

      According to the back flap of The Grasshopper Lies Heavy, Hawthorne Abendsen lives in a fortress, surrounded by barbed wire and machine gun emplacements. But the address Charleston drives to the next morning turns out to be an ordinary suburban house. Shrugging, wakes Noor up and wraps a shawl around her.

      "Put your head on my shoulder," he says, grabbing his violin case and leading them up to the front door. He knocks on the door.

      A red-headed woman cracks open the door. "I don't know you," she says.

      "Greetings..."

      She slams the door shut.

      Charleston knocks again.

      The door cracks open. "I have a gun," the woman says.

      Charleston holds up his copy of Grasshopper. "I want to talk to the author of this book."

      "Lots of people want to talk to Hawthorne. Why should I let you in?"

      "What reason would you like to hear?"

      She slams the door shut again.

      Charleston knocks for several minutes.

      "WHAT!" screams the woman, yanking open the door until it catches on the chain.

      "I just started reading this book yesterday and I'm impressed with the market penetration it's made!"

      SLAM!

      "Seriously!" shouts Charleston. "I feel I know what is going to happen in that book without even reading it!"

      Pause.

      There is the sound of a latch being lifted.

      The door creaks open. "What's your name," says the woman, leveling her shotgun at him.

      "Charleston. Are you the author?"

      "No, I'm his wife."

      "Did you read the book?"

      "Yes."

      "Did you like it?"

      "I think--I think Hawthorne found a happier place for us all to be. It's just a shame it's not true. You're a very strange person, aren't you? Anyway, come in."

      "Thank you. Come on, Noor."

      "What happened to your friend?"

      "She got sick, and then blind. She's Indian--wait, I'm in the Rocky Mountain States? an Arab. Egyptian."

      "Oh. Didn't think there were many of them left around. I always wanted to visit Egypt, but never got there before the war, and now..."

      She leads them through a rather kitschy living room and into a stereotypical writer's study. Paper and typescripts litter a desk next to a manual typewriter; handsome bookshelves fill every wall.

      A man enters, smoking a cigarette. "Caroline said I should talk to you."

      [Actually, I didn't remember the name of Abendsen's wife, so I used Virginia in play--based on my suspicion that the character of Abendsen is based on Robert A. Heinlein.]

      "By the way, she know how to use that thing?"

      "Yeah."

      "You've got yourself quite a lady. Tell me, did you write any other books?"

      "I wrote some science fiction." He gestures to a shelf of paperbacks near his desk.

      "I see. You don't consider this book science fiction?"

      "Well, now, that's an interesting question: is alternate history science fiction, or not?"

      [Bill, if you're still reading this: I swear to God, Valis, and Horselover Fat that I did nothing to prep that question. I don't know how CP managed to recreate, without even having ever heard of the book, one of its most famous and post-modern/meta scenes. I suspect pink lasers may have been involved.]

      "I don't know--you're the author."

      "It's a question of genre, not authorship."

      "Genre is something for marketing to think about. What do you think about it?"

      "That's a very interesting question. I...think it's very philosophical."

      "Yeah? Well, as I was telling your wife, I feel like I know what's going to happen even though I didn't read it."

      "It's very popular, I'm sure you heard about the plot..."

      "Well, I feel like I've been there. New York, post-war. I don't even think we were headed to a second war."

      "I don't know about that..."

      "Ever been to Egypt? In my mind, it's still there. In fact, it was like I was there just a few weeks ago."

      "You're really not making a lot of sense, so I'm having a drink." He pours himself a glass of Canadian scotch.

      "I love Canadian scotch. Noor, you want some?"

      "It is forbidden to my relig--yes."

      "I'm sure it will help with the pain. I assume there's some pain?"

      "Yes, quite a bit actually--"

      Charleston turns back to Hawthorne. "So why exactly did you write this book?"

      "In a way I didn't. I used the I Ching. Whenever I had to make a decision or had a question, I would consult the oracle."

      "Never trusted that thing when I was a kid."

      "I never knew about it when I was a kid. So we're even. What can I do for you, anyway?"

      "I was sent here to ask you why you wrote it. Before you even used the I Ching, what made you want to write this book, this story?"

      "I was just looking for an idea, and I started to use the oracle."

      "So the I Ching told you to write a book? A book about the Allies winning? Why did it ask you to do that?"

      "I asked the oracle that very question once. I found the answer to be...disturbing."

      "What was the answer it gave?"

      "Why are you here? Who sent you?"

      "Dancer Lee."

      "Don't know him."

      "Then the question doesn't matter, does it? You know, for a book that's so popular, I'm surprised more people don't come here to ask you questions."

      "Why don't you ask the oracle? I have some yarrow sticks here."

      It takes Charleston a while, but when he is done, the hexagram is the one called Inner Truth.

      "Inner Truth--the craziest lie of all!"

      "That's not how I interpreted that at all."

      "How did you interpret it?"

      "That the United States didn't lose the war."

      "Is that the truth, or what the oracle believes? What made you decide to believe it and not your eyes?"

      "The feeling I got."

      "What feeling is that?"

      "Well...it was like waking up."

      "Sounds terrible."

      "I don't know. You seem like a pretty wide-awake guy. You're not from around here, are you?"

      "No. I'm from New York."

      "That's not what I meant. When Caroline said someone was here, I used the oracle. It said something about meeting a stranger from beyond the threshold. And that it was ok to pass through the door."

      "By the way, Dancer Lee has a letter for you to read, after I asked him about the book."

      Hawthorne opens it. "Yeah, that's right." He hands it back to Charleston.

      On the page, in his own handwriting, is the hexagram for Inner Truth.

      "You understand now, don't you?" says Abendsen, quietly. "Is there anything else I can do for you?"

      "Did you ever think about writing a sequel?"

      "There's no need to. I know what the truth is."

      [Curse you Valis! Of course, Phillip K. Dick planned a sequel to The Man in the High Castle but famously never wrote it. Again, not that CP would know.]

      "And you differentiate between truth and reality?"

      "Yeah. I think I do. It's probably safer if you leave out the back way."

      "What do you anticipate being out the front door?"

      "The book's not popular in the Reich."

      "We're not in the Reich."

      "Border doesn't really stop the Gestapo."

      Noor and Charleston stand up. "Noor, do you have any questions for the gentleman? I have a feeling we won't be seeing him again."

      She pauses. "How do we know which is real, and which is the lie?"

      "They're the same thing," says Charleston. They step out the back door...


      ...and into a howling sandstorm.

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 18)

      Charleston stumbles through the storm, carrying Noor, who has passed out. Eventually he stumbles on Pearkes' shelter and together with Freddie they wait the storm out.

      Saturday, 11 April 1925

      They catch each other up on their various adventures. Charleston and Freddie are surprised that Pearkes gave up the Sword of Akmallah, although Freddie is relieved, figuring it was only a matter of time before George used it on them.

      [At this point I charged everyone a point of Sanity for the whole experience.]

      After some searching, they find their camp, or what is left of it. Abd' al-Qazim is sitting on the hood of the halftrack, smoking. "Hey, kindly master, you're not dead."

      "No, just tortured."

      Charleston loads Noor into the touring car. She wakes up, her vision restored but weaker. They drive out to the Bedouin camp, where they rest for a few days, healing up. They make a gift of the halftrack and Russian weapons to the Bedouin as thanks for their hospitality. Then they set out for Aden, hoping to catch a boat to either Europe or Shanghai. On they way, the call at the weather station.

      [CP, to FP: You're living the backstory to Dr. Strange, you know.]

      It has been burnt to the ground. Sheila and Mwimbe are still there, but the Aussie and Maxwell the pilot, along with Wazim and Qusay have been killed by raiders; Mwimbe speculates they were in the employ of Shakhti.

      "Sorry about your father, Noor," says Charleston. He helps her to Wazim's grave; her health is returning, but her illness has left her permanently weakened.

      "You could bring him back."

      "I could. You know I could. You knew that before you asked. You know what that would be like, though, don't you?"

      "You're right, of course. I just would have liked to see him once more..."

      On the way to Aden, Freddie seeks out Charleston. "You know, I found out in that other time that the great love of my life had me killed."

      "Interesting. You say you think it was all a lucid dream, right?"

      "Yes."

      "This is easy then. It was symbolism--you feel incredibly guilty about her death."

      "That does make sense. The whole thing was full of literary symbolism. Needed rather a better author."

      [CP had bought a point of Psychoanalysis, so this was his first chance to treat somebody with it.]

      Tuesday, 21 April 1925

      Eventually they reach Aden. They are stopped by a local patrol. He speaks in Arabic to them. Freddie suddenly realizes that he no longer understands Arabic.

      [In the journal I wrote in character as Jackson, she described gradually losing her ability to speak other languages.]

      "Oh, you are English! I apologize for addressing you in a language other than English. Your passports, please."

      "I'm afraid I was waylaid, and have neither."

      "Then I'm afraid I must turn you away," says the guard, rubbing his hands together.

      "Let me show you some more interesting papers," says Charleston.

      Low on cash now, Freddie goes looking for a telegraph station to set up a credit account. He also sends a telegram to the Foreign Office in London:

      "DEAR AUNTIE EM HAVE JUST GOT BACK FROM FUTURE STOP SPOKEN TO MR N STOP MISS H IS NOT WITH MR S STOP"

      However, when he goes to the bank, he discovers that the account he wanted to draw from was lower in funds than he expected. They give him some cash, and he has George and Charleston drive him back to the hotel they are staying at.

      As they pull up to the hotel, George can see two men in suits talking to the desk clerk. He looks out the door, and points at Freddie.

      Pearkes puts the car back in gear and starts to drive away.

      "What the--" says Freddie.

      "We're going to find a different hotel."

      The two men in suits dash out of the front of the hotel. "Stop in the name of the British Empire!" one shouts.

      Pearkes slams on the brakes and backs up.

      "Freddie Blakely?" asks one of them. "I'm afraid I must ask you to come with us back to the Embassy."

      "What for?" demands Pearkes.

      "Military Intelligence wants to have a word with him."

      "That's all right," says Freddie. "I work for you chaps."

      "We have a legal warrant," says the agent, "from the Ministry of Defense, saying we are to bring Blakely in for questioning."

      Pearkes looks over the orders. He notes that in fact what they say is that they are to bring Freddie in for questioning, and then hold him for deportation.

      "We won't be able to join you at the Embassy," says Pearkes.

      "Our orders are not discretionary."

      "You should never address your superiors in such a manner," says Pearkes. "Mr. Blakely is in my custody, and we will deliver him to you tomorrow. Cheerio."

      [Reassurance spend by PP.]

      "Eight o' clock sharp," says the agent, cowed.

      "I'll be there at 10," says Freddie. "We're not uncivilized. I give you my word as a gentleman."

      [Flattery spend by FP.]

      Freddie decides to call his lawyer, Bradley Grey, back in New York, despite the 10 hour time difference. It takes about an hour, but eventually the connection is made.

      "Hullo...who's calling me at this hour?"

      "Dorian old boy!"

      "Oh for God's SAKE, Freddie!"

      "How's that political race going?"

      "It's going to go great. I'm going to be a great DA."

      "You aren't doing anything this morning?"

      "I'm sleeping."

      "Excellent. I seem to be in a spot of trouble with British Military Intelligence."

      "I could call some people."

      "Good. Contact me in Aden! Abigail is right here, she'll give you the details."

      Several hours later, Grey calls Freddie at the hotel bar.

      "You know how late I was up yesterday? Political fundraisers don't just happen. By the way, I'm charging you for this call, and the two--no, four--hours of work I just did.

      "Here's the deal. There's a private Bill in Parliament to strip you of your citizenship."

      "Why don't they just ask Rollie's father to do it?"

      "They want it above board. I don't have any details yet, just that Baldwin is letting it go through. I don't know why--apparently, there's some political muscle behind it.

      "The other thing is--there hasn't been a legal Bill of Attainder passed in Commons in over six hundred years. So they won't attain your estate. However, they will charge you a fine and back taxes that will bankrupt you. I spoke with your man of business in London. He's trying to liquidate as much as possible and move it overseas, but I'm afraid your options aren't great. You're in a British port right now?"

      "Yes."

      "They're going to seize your passport, stranding you there. I'll see what I can do at State--your best bet is to get a passport from a neutral country, like the U. S. It would probably help you if you could get to England, to see if you can convince some people to support you--but you better either win, or have another way out; they'll definitely keep you from leaving the country. Meanwhile, get a passport, from a neutral country willing to stand up to the British."

      Freddie explains this to the others. "Maybe I could get a Russian passport?" he wonders.

      "There's a better option," says Charleston. "The Germans."

      "I don't know anyone in Germany."

      "You don't need to. You just need to pay someone in Germany."

      \n Bill,

      Excellent questions!

      I had meant to bring one of my I Chings to the session (although I also would have needed to remind myself how to cast the coins; the runes are my magical-thinking source of reassurance of choice) but I forgot. I had an idea of having N bring Charleston to a future street where he would look in the window of a house to see a group very much like our own playing a role-playing game, but I decided to back off that idea. In any case, it would have been easier had my idea of having Gilbert tie together the various fictions come to fruition--I had to kill that idea when GP didn't show up.

      But hey, no time like the present--so I threw some coins and came up with:

      #58: Tui--the Joyous, Lake with a moving line in the fifth place going to
      #54: Kuei Mei--The Marrying Maiden

      Here's the Wilhelm for the moving lines:


      58:\t\xb0 Nine in the fifth place means:
      \tSincerity toward disintegrating influences is dangerous.

      Dangerous elements approach even the far best of men. If a man permits
      himself to have anything to do with them, their disintegrating influence acts
      slowly but surely, and inevitable brings dangers in its train. But if he
      recognizes the situation and can comprehend the danger, he knows how to
      protect himself and remains unharmed.


      54:\tNine in the fourth place means:
      \tThe marrying maiden draws out the allotted time.
      \tA late marriage comes in due course.

      The girl is virtuous. She does not wish to throw herself away, and allows the
      customary time for marriage to slip by. However, there is no harm in this;
      she is rewarded for her purity and, even though belatedly, finds the husband
      intended for her.\t


      ...which come to think of it isn't such a bad description of our two pilgrims!

      As to your other question, I do in fact worry that too much contact with the Big N reduces the menace. My plan, such as it is, is to have his appearances (which should be much shorter and infrequent going forward) be more and more frightening, if possible. There was a bit of a progression in this session--he was helpful to Pearkes, indifferent to Freddie, and of course threw Charleston off the top of a building. (I let CP do his narrative there, although it was a close thing--I could have forced the issue a bit.) Screwing with N is a losing proposition, although just rolling over for him probably isn't a great idea either. Charleston probably has the best strategy in keeping N intrigued with him. He's fickle, however, and ultimately you run the danger that you'll just piss him off to the point of doing something horrible.

      I'm obviously not running a traditionalist game but sooner or later really terrible things are likely to happen. (I haven't forgotten that Charleston made a deal with a certain Titular Titan. That's going to start coming due.) Noor is in the line of fire, as is Sheila, and we still haven't even touched just exactly what Mwimbe's place in all this is. The pot is being stirred; the simmering has begun; soon we'll have some nice terror gumbo.

      Or something. I hope at least as frightening as that metaphor.

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 19)

      Wednesday, 22 April 1925

      Freddie and company begin to make plans to return to the Continent. Knowing Jackson had visited Paris, they begin to lay out plans to take the train to Palestine, a steamship to Istanbul and then catch the Orient Express to Paris.

      [Okay. I leaned on the scale a bit, although I did make it clear that bankrupting Freddie wouldn't hurt his Credit Rating (that's not what it measures, really) and flat out told them they could go to Africa or Shanghai. (CP: I'm tired of the heat.)

      Obviously Paris (the London analogue in this retelling) works better as a destination, but it was a bit forced. The private bill in Parliament, though, that was Shakhti's doing--although who is pulling the strings in England is an interesting question, as getting a Bill like that to actually go to the floor is highly unusual.]

      There is a German consulate in Aden, although it is not much of a going concern. Freddie has no trouble meeting the Consul.

      "I seem to be in need of new citizenship," says Freddie once he has settled in to the Consul's dusty office, "and I thought I might see what opportunities could be found in the German Republic."

      "Are you German?"

      "On the contrary. I am soon to be ex-British. However, I'm probably of German descent, must be a Saxe-Coburg lurking around somewhere in the family tree."

      "German citizenship is by blood, not birth, so it is possible I could help you. I will have to gather some information. It will take some time--our resources are rather limited. Very limited. My resources, that is."

      "I see. Perhaps this could help." Freddie writes out a large check. "Let me give you some references. There was Heinrich...and Fritz...and someone from Stuttgart..."

      The Consul agrees to check up on things and get back to Freddie in a few days. Having started the ball rolling, Freddie heads to the British Embassy to keep his appointment.

      He is met by the two agents. One slips the other a fiver when Freddie appears in the office. They take him in to meet the Ambassador.

      "Stilton old man?"

      "Oh, hullo Freddie." The rather malarial Englishman knocks a bottle off his desk as Freddie comes in. "What're doing to cause Baldwin to get all shirty with me? I'm supposed to arrest you and hold you for deportation. Had to look that word up."

      [Credit Rating spend by Freddie to make yet another NPC a school chum of his. Of course, given where he was educated, it's not that unusual that he knows many British civil servants.]

      "I'm planning to throw myself out of British territory. Seems to save you the bother."

      "I dunno, I was never good at law."

      "You wanted to study butterflies, as I recall."

      "Pater said it waste of time. And this is a very important position, he told me. I am the Consul-General to Aden!"

      "And how many butterfly species are there around here?"

      "Not a blessed one, old man, not a blessed one. I couldn't get the Ambassadorship to Mexico. Monarchs, you know. You want a drink? I'm having a drink. So blessed hot."

      "I'm pretty sure drinking makes that worse."

      "Yes, but then I forget I'm in blessed Aden!"

      "Listen old man, do you think you could hold off on that deportation, until I'm out of your hair?"

      "Wait, I know what that is called. I could release you on your own recognition!"

      "Recognizance, old boy."

      "Right."

      "Seems a bit of a shame you're still in Aden. Perhaps I could get you reassigned, to--British Honduras? Or the Seychelles?"

      "Fantastic." They clink glasses.

      Sunday, 26 April 1925

      The German Consul summons Freddie down to his office. "I have checked those references you gave us," he says. "Jens says he remembers you from that time in Stuttgart."

      "Ah, it was Stuttgart."

      "Yes. He says they have put your picture up in the bar you destroyed."

      "I didn't destroy the whole thing, just set fire to that one bar."

      "Yes. Alfred says you still owe him 500 Reichsmarks."

      "Well, that's not worth a lot anyway."

      "Pre-war Reichsmarks. He said to make a point of that. Berthold sends his disgust. Not sure what that means.

      "I asked all of them about your character. They said you had none."

      "That's a good point."

      "Normally, based on such a report, your application would be denied. However, they all agreed that you are fabulously wealthy. So I am very proud to issue a passport in the name of the Republic (spit) of Germany."

      "It's wonderful to be part of the Weimar Republic."

      "Ja, that's great. By the way, do you speak German?"

      "Not a bit."

      "Then I will just pretend you read all of this."

      "Jawohl!"

      \n Lisa,

      I really wasn't sure. Had GP shown up, I would have brought him in as an outside force going in to help rescue the other PCs, but that didn't happen.       \n
      \n Sympathy -- it's hard when you tailor the plot to the group, and then you don't get the full group.

      I don't have a problem with FP establishing that Freddie would die for Jax. That's totally awesome and tells you something about him that you want to abuse the hell out of.

      But.

      So, back when I was running my first Cthulhupunk campaign (no relation to SJG's GURPS Cthulhupunk), a friend was helping me come up with a masterplan or three -- one for Nyarlathotep, one for Nodens, and one for the true author of the Necronomicon, willing to destroy 90% of the population to save the world, and willing to destroy 100% to deny Nyarly and Co. victory. And he was running his plan by a friend of his, concerned about some holes in it.

      His friend said something along the lines of, "This will work. What you have to remember is that this idea of POW? And POW points? That's a game mechanic. It's not the fiction. It's not the world. Characters in the world aren't going to think "Everyone can spare at least 2 points of POW, probably more, so we can power the mcguffin without killing anyone." That's not how it works. It works by eating Life Energy -- by eating a life or a soul. The PCs can't metagame this, and you don't need to let the players do it either."

      Similarly, FP may be thinking "Okay, I can have Freddie go down to -13 Health", but that is utterly meaningless in the game world. The important thing is that Freddie's trying to die. Freddie also doesn't know that he's FP's character. So, you need to establish a few things with FP -- Freddie, being a character, not a person, doesn't get a vote.

      1. The mechanic you described is descriptive. It is not proscriptive. If you don't want to bump off the character, it's totally fine to say, "No, Freddie can't metagame and do precisely X points of damage to himself. Basically, his goal is to die, right? Unfortunately for Freddie, these people are good at stopping that sort of thing, particularly given his situation."

      2. If you are okay with FP offing Freddie, break the fourth wall. Say to FP, in plain English, "Okay, whatever Freddie may think, I am telling you as the GM that this is not a dream. If Freddie dies here, he is permanently dead, no resurrection, no nothing. Is this what you want? If not, tell me what you want to achieve here (you, not Freddie, eve if there is some bleed), and we'll figure out what happens."

      3. The game is going somewhere icky, which happens in some CoC / ToC / Cthulhu Dark games. Some players don't want to deal and either don't want to be seen as wussing out or are crap at communicating "I want out -- this is beyond my comfort level." They need a way to say, "Stop -- get me out of here". Whether that's the X-card, whether that's a discussion before the game about what they don't want, whether that's you saying in the "this is how it works" spiel "And if at any point, we are going somewhere you don't want to go, tell me, because I cannot read you mind and will not know if you don't tell me", they need a way to signal "Stop. I am not cool with this."

      If that happens, it doesn't matter whether it's "I'm squicked by the description" or "I don't want my character to be in this kind of situation" or "I don't want to be forced to have my character do X". You stop. If it's "I'm okay with the what, but I need a fade to black here," cut the scene and work out the end results -- or work out that you're not going to specify details. If it's "I don't want my character forces into this situation", stop, find a quick resolution, move on, and, after the session, find time to sit down with the player and say, "Okay, here are my expectations about what will happen in the game and how things will get bad." I'm not talking spoilers, you understand, but I am talking genre expectations.

      4. Okay, so the immediate situation has been dealt with. Good or bad, I'm assuming it's at least Good Enough to keep on playing. But, you're concerned, and I think rightly so, that when you move into Bad Things Happening, one or more players will be unhappy. I don't care whether this is because of a D&D mentality or genre expectations. The point is, you want X, and one or more of the players may want Not X. Talk about this now.

      If one or more players is firm about Not X, you've got choices. You can go really pulpy and break your world. If some players are good with X, you can let those who aren't live a semi-charmed NotX life. You can decide that the campaign won't work and stop, which is a sad option, but a better one than trying to force X on players who want Not X. But, you need to know where you stand. Does a player want his PC's beloved NPCs to have script immunity? Does he insist on always coming out on top? Is he fine with a dramatic death? Some things you can compromise on -- I had one player determined to save an NPC's dog. She was fine with the NPC dying. Okay, I could work with that. The dog was saved. I had another player with multiple PCs, one of whom had supertech devices and lived in a homebuilt fortress. That one, I told the player, was essentially a patron / NPC, just one played by someone who was't the GM. I couldn't plot for that character in the world I was running.

      Sorry if I'm babbling; I am fighting off a head cold. (At least, I hope I'm fighting it off.) It's just that the growing darkness is something that's only going to become a bigger issue as the game goes on, and making that fun to play can be a challenge outside of a convention one-shot.

      \n Lisa,

      Yeah, absolutely. As I said in the write-up, when FP pulled that I should have stepped back and pointedly a) asked him how that worked in the fiction and b) flat-out told him that whatever he was in, the effects were real and dead would be dead. Again, Vincent handles this really well in AW and its descendants; but I hadn't read AW yet, just had a "I've followed some discussions" understanding of it. Actually reading it was a really profound experience in understanding how to structure things.

      Yanno, though, he wasn't dying to save Jax. He was dying to get out of the situation entirely. Like I said back then, I'm not sure if it was a line-crosser, or just wanting to "win." (Either is valid, though for different reasons.) Whether Freddie would die for Jax...that's an excellent question. Oddly enough, something like this came up between us in another game, one PP GMed. It was the Pathfinder Adventure Path "Carrion Crown." PP, who as you can imagine, likes combat-heavy encounters, turned everything up to 11 at the end, throwing dragons and hordes of undead at us. Of course, I had a bow-focused Paladin as my PC, and in case you don't know Pathfinder, they're basically insta-killers for...undead and evil dragons.

      Anyway, my PC died during the encounter. Before the Final Boss fight. So I was pondering what to do. I kinda felt that his arc should end with him dying; I'd switched PCs during the campaign, and justified it retroactively by having him want to avoid dying to rid the world of evil, and instead settle down with his husband. Blah blah blah call to adventure, and I brought him back for the finale.

      I finally decided to use a Hero Point to avoid death. Came back, finished off the last Bosses, and then when I was done, said (IC) that it was time for me to move on--the idea being that he had been given a reprieve to finish his mission but after that he'd have to let death be permanent. Now, I liked that, but FP, oddly enough, had trouble accepting it. It was kinda funny, really; I kept insisting that no, Jack died, he was moving on to the next phase, and FP kept saying, your god probably would send you back the next day.

      Take of that what you will.

      Anyway, I'm going to have a GM...I originally typed "lecture" but that's not right. Rap session? Something where I talk about what I'm thinking of WRT the game (no NPC is safe, inevitable betrayal, the bad guys having significantly more resources, murderhobo lifestyle impossible in the developed world) and also talk about what to do about Going Places folks are uncomfortable with. I'll probably introduce some kind of X card (right now, I'm thinking maybe a red-suit playing card for each player) to help avoid issues. Now's the time, with two new players coming into the group.

      I should probably ask for advice about how to structure that talk, so I'm asking for advice about how to structure that! The X card bit I can grab from the web, and the rest will probably boil down to...make sure the plausibility test comes from the fiction, or fictional models, not the game mechanics, Does that make sense? Like, if this is something that Bourne or Buffy & Xander or god help us Quartermain might do/not do, that's where we lead, and justify that with the mechanics. The other way around won't work. I already plan to insist that things get done in the fiction, and no "I spend X Reassurance" and that's it. I mean, I'm all for letting the mechanics handle things, but I need to know what's happening in the fiction. You don't want to roleplay it? S'fine, tell me what you want to have happen and I'll give it some consequences and away we go.

      But it's gotta be something. It can't be just a spend with nothing explained.

      Structurally, I'm planning to do a couple of things like take regular breaks and shut down earlier rather than later. I have board games for when we're done, if folks want to hang out! I think a lot of times I get in trouble when I don't pull back, and taking breaks will probably help keep me focused. And, you know, taking a step back.

      It's really going to come down to "focus on outcome, not on process." Or, tell me what you want, and then let's figure out how that does or doesn't happen. I'm tired of the many-stepped goat thing I mentioned a while ago--that is, putting little details step by step into the fiction, leading us to ludicrous places.

      \n Yah, that makes sense. Have you read Sorcerer? It's the game that first introduced me to the idea of conflict resolution vs combat resolution. You're playing a ladies' man? And you flub a roll? Okay, this shouldn't mean the character forgets to be suave, but it does mean something goes wrong, so what's the goal? Or, as I later learned, the X-Y problem. (I forget if I've defined that here.)

      What we used to do was break for dinner, which was a nice way to ground and chat out of character. This works if one starts gaming around noon on a weekend (for values of noon which might be 2pm) and breaks for dinner around 6-8pm. Another useful trick is the bathroom break. One of my first gms used that whenever he wasn't sure what to do next.

      But definitely, with two people coming in, you've got an opportunity to recalibrate and talk with folks. I'm not sure how one does this particular kind of talk, apart from the X-card. I guess one can say, "In games like D&D and Pathfinder, there's usually a way out, but this isn't the case for Call / Trail of Cthulhu"? What kind of experience do the new gamers have?

      \n So, I managed to put together an Agenda, Principles, and Moves set!

      All thanks and praise for this must go to our own @Mcdaldno for his incredibly useful guide to hacking the * World Engine, Simple World. With that in hand, I was able to throw this together...in like five minutes. Made total sense.

      Agenda

      \u2022\tMake the players\u2019 characters\u2019 lives not boring.
      \u2022\tPlay to find out what happens.
      \u2022\tSacrifice and Loss are the price of Saving the World
      [My custom Agenda, and kind of the heart of what I've been reaching for.]

      Principles

      \u2022\tSprinkle evocative details everywhere.
      \u2022\tMaintain Menace.
      [One of the headings in the Trail of Cthulhu book; there's a sorta buried Principles section on pp. 200-203.]
      \u2022\tAddress yourself to the characters, not the players.
      \u2022\tMake your move, but misdirect.
      \u2022\tMake your move, but never speak its name.
      \u2022\tLook at your NPCs and ideas through crosshairs.
      \u2022\tName everyone, make everyone human.
      \u2022\tAsk provocative questions and build on the answers.
      \u2022\tRespond with challenging circumstances and occasional rewards.
      \u2022\tBe a fan of the players\u2019 characters.
      \u2022\tThink offscreen, too.
      \u2022\tSometimes, reflect a question back upon the players.
      [These next two are adapted from the section in the ToC book I mentioned above:]
      \u2022\tTailor Situations to the PCs and their Backstories
      \u2022\tAny Direction is Forward

      Moves

      \u2022\tSeparate them.
      \u2022\tPut them together.
      \u2022\tPut someone in a high-stakes situation.
      \u2022\tAnnounce off-screen badness.
      \u2022\tAnnounce future badness.
      \u2022\tTake away one of their Things.
      \u2022\tDemonstrate one of their Things\u2019 bad sides.
      \u2022\tGive them a difficult decision to make.
      \u2022\tTell them the possible consequences and ask.
      \u2022\tTurn their move back on them.
      \u2022\tMake a move from one of your Dangers or Fronts.
      [The following three are my own custom GM moves:]
      \u2022\tThreaten a Source of Stability
      \u2022\tAttack a Pillar of Sanity
      \u2022\tBarf forth Cthuliania

      So, that looks like a good start, I think? Feedback earnestly and urgently desired! I'll probably work on some notes to my lecture tomorrow or Saturday morning, along with the rest of my prep, such as it is. Lot of stuff more or less out of the book is what I anticipate for the next session.

      I'm pretty sure I won't do the Fiasco playset idea this time, but will do a flashback sequence set in 1922 involving Charlie Kane's summer mansion on Long Island, a wild party, and the reunion of Jax and Freddie, who has been crashing the party all summer hoping to meet her. And yes, I know, but when you steal, steal from the greats, right?

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 20)

      From Aden, they sail up the Red Sea, transferring in Port Said for a steamer to Istanbul, and then on the Oriental Express to Paris. Freddie spends that leg of the trip trying to revive his college German by speaking to the several Germans riding on the train with them.

      Along the way, Freddie discovers that Mwimbe still has the Dagger of Thoth, which he fears had been lost in whatever mystical universe he had been thrown by Nyarlathotep. "Of course, Mr. Blakely," Mwimbe assures him. "I keep all of our most powerful artifacts."

      "Good show. By the way, if you meet Thoth, stick him with that. He's a bit of a prig."

      "Trust me, I am acquainted with the nature of the Dark Lord."

      Pearkes has shed his uniform in favor of a three-piece suit. The utter cronyism of Parliament's attempt to strip Freddie's citizenship has left him disoriented. "We're supposed to stand for principles," he complains.

      [I'll say this for PP: it's pretty perfect that George only noticed the downside of Empire when it hurt one of his friends.]

      "Ah yes, Colonel Pearkes," says Mwimbe. "Your Empire stands for many principals. Imperialism. Colonialism. White supremacy. So many fine principles indeed. You bring your government where it is not wanted, that too is a principle."

      "By the way, Mwimbe," says Freddie, "what nation are you a citizen of, anyway? We'll need to know when we cross the border."

      "I am a subject of the British Empire."

      "Then why are you so down on it," says Pearkes in a low voice.

      "Because that is an honor I have always tried to decline."


      Eventually they reach the French border. There are orders to stop Freddie, but between his German passport and a few bushels of francs spread liberally around, they are able to make their way to Paris. As soon as they get settled, Freddie calls his aunts.

      "Roland, what disgrace have you brought on this family?"

      "Hullo Agatha."

      "I can't even go out anymore. A private bill?"

      "What's Baldwin got to do with this?"

      "I don't know, but he's letting it go through. Lady Spencer's boy, Winston, is trying to stop it."



      Paris! the City of Lights! According to her journal, Jackson stayed here for over a month, speaking with Edouard Gavigan, the head of the charitable Penhew Foundation, claimed to have been pursued by a cult, and was ultimately rescued by one of her contacts, Mickey "Scoop" Mahoney, publisher of an Irish Nationalist paper.

      They decide to look up Mickey up near Place R\xe9publique. The office is nothing particularly impressive. Various shabby looking writerly types are sitting in it, smoking. The young male secretary looks up as they enter.

      "Can I help you?"

      "We're here to see Mr. Mahoney."

      "D'ye have an appointment?"

      "Not in the slightest, but we're here about a young woman named Jackson Elias."

      "Ah, Miss Jax? I remember her. Just a minute."

      Not long after the door to Mahoney's office opens. A stooped man wearing very thick glasses shambles out, followed by a stout, ebullient Irishman in his fifties. "Listen, Jimmy, 'riverrun, past Eve and Adam's, from swerve of shore to bend of bay, brings us by a commodius vicus of recirculation'--it's not what we're lookin' for this week. Try again in a bit. Oh, and Sylvia down by Shakespeare's says she has a check fer you."

      "What ho, Mahoney?"

      "Ah, you're the one about Jackson. Who's this?"

      "He's my driver. He's also a reporter."

      "There's no way in hell he's a journalist. Come on in."

      Charleston feels the same way about Mahoney--there's no way he's a newspaperman. He has the look of a killer.

      "Now, gentlemen, I knew Miss Jackson very well. I was fond of the old girl. So I'm asking you very calmly and carefully, why are you following up on her?"

      "Sort of following in her footsteps, I think."

      "Everyone here was very sad to hear about her passing. And if someone was trying to prevent her from stopping the thing she wanted to stop, we'd take none too kindly to it."

      "Not at all. We're trying to stop that...person from taking over the world."

      "I don't know anything about that. She was following some leads. Put her on the trail of Edouard Gavigan, big muckety muck."

      "You know, we met Hypatia Masters."

      "That's not possible, is it? Seeing as she's as dead as Jackson."

      "She claimed to be very old, and was certainly insane."

      "Hrm. Well, if you're following up on her, you'd best start with Gavigan. Very well to do Frenchman. You're about up to his class, I guess. And if you want, I can look into this Gavigan a bit, see if I can shake anything out about him."

      With his money running lower than usual, they are forced to take quarters in a mere four-star hotel. Freddie's man of business contacts him with news that he's liquidated some more assets. "Don't worry old boy, I'm putting it in the American stock market! Safe as houses! We'll make a mint!"

      \n I love the Joyce reference, as I'm a Joycean.

      So, what are the fronts you've got? I've never actually run *World, and the variant I'm most comfortable contemplating running is MonsterHearts, totally not what you're looking for here, and doesn't seem to do fronts the same way.

      \n I'm in that horrible minority (I mean, here) that hasn't read Monsterhearts. I must remedy that at some point, especially since I found Joe's quick-n-dirty guide to hacking AW so useful.

      I'd post the fronts up here except they're, you know, active and all :-) and there are some surprises for my players built in.

      However:

      The front I used in the most recent session was called The Paris Brotherhood. I put four dangers under it; three aren't particularly spoiler-ific, thus:

      Edouard Gavigan (ambitious cult-leader)

      Tewfik al-Sayed (also ambitious cult-leader, with some moves borrowed from the Arcane Enemy section of Dungeon World)

      Hypatia Masters (mystical being, e.g. Arcane Enemy)

      I did a countdown clock for each, rather than Grim Portents. I think that may have been a mistake, or I don't really know how to do a good countdown clock--the examples Vincent gives basically have no difference between start and 9:00. Now, that's okay--you can have dread-building stuff going on--but I think I'd be better served by just doing the Grim Portents without a clock.

      We did a couple of things this most recent session that I liked. One was using the Marvel Initiative (name who goes next, basically). I'm thinking of actually adapting something like that for the regular gameplay. I've already decided that I want to step up the pacing by making the basic unit of time "about a week" rather than "about a day"; time's kinda crawling, and the PCs are on a clock (though they don't know that) so I'd like to make the time pressure a bit more...pressing. I'm thinking of doing something like including a "GM turn mechanic" as a good way to better simulate horror. That is, I'll let the players go around the table, but then I'll also get my own "turn" to do...whatever. One of my moves. This will tend to make the PCs a bit more desperate, which I like.

      I also think that what I really want is noir, not pulp, as the dominant genre of the campaign; it's a better fit for my vision. I need to talk to the players about that.

      All in all, the most recent session went pretty well, and I liked what the new players brought to the table. And I'll write it up, soon! I have about one more chapter in Episode VI; it's the whole interview with Gavigan debacle, which I'm a bit embarrassed to have to do again--it wasn't a shining moment for anybody concerned, I think.

      The Fiasco playset in Episode VII was kind of fun, I'll provide details when the write up begins. I made a pretty professional layout for it, which I will also make available.

      \n If you've not read Monsterhearts, I'm thinking maybe you should wait until after the campaign. I mean, I love it dearly, but it is so not the feel you're going for here.

      Eternal Lies is Noir -- but, in some ways, compatible with Pulp. The colors are muted, the tone is more desperate -- but there's often a sense that there are rare good people who will make the sacrifices necessary to keep an admittedly corrupt world safe for a few more years. Masks, as written, feels more Pulp, but it can totally be run Noir. It's just that, as you said, you'll need to talk to the players about that.

      I really need to reread Apocalypse World. I'm drawing a blank on how one does Fronts and forgot it had a countdown clock -- I remember that from Monster of the Week (which, IF you want yet another game jumping up and down inside your head begging you to use its cool stuff, is a better fit for what you're doing than Monsterhearts is).

      \n Steve, I think you're on the money there, or rather: DW shows you how you can use fronts for a lot of things, including campaigns, while AW (as is the case with everything in the book except for the general stuff about the Consequences Engine) is precisely tailored for the kind of world Vincent was making. Which is great, really--I mean, it's brilliant writing--but if you're shamelessly stealing stuff, it requires more work :-)

      Lisa, I think I'm going to have to snatch up Monster of the Week--that thing looks bloody awesome, and could just be the "one-shot * World game" I've been looking for; I'm the spillover GM at our Tuesday meetup, and I've wanted to run a * World game but have been kinda down on the idea of a perpetual series of First Sessions.

      It's looking like there's a possibility that we'll get sessions in on the 7th and 21st, yay! Though more work!

      I'm finding a tension between trying to do a fully reactive * World type setup and the needs for an investigative game to have staged scenes. What I'm thinking of doing is prepping a few scenes with Investigative clues in them, key them to the fronts, and let that stuff happen or not. This is basically how Masks is written, after all, and close to the recommended structure for a Gumshoe game. (To be honest, I find the spine + scenes structure of Gumshoe to be a bit potentially railroady; I prefer a more robust decision tree, like what Justin Alexander does.)

      Noir versus pulp is an interesting distinction; Noir is definitely a subset of pulp, but there's some key distinctions. I'm going to have to think about what those are. It helps that I'm re-reading "The Big Sleep"; I'm a huge fan of Chandler.

      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 21)

      Tuesday, 5 May 1925

      Based on the notes in Jax's diary, they decide to investigate a nightclub called Le Pyramide Bleu ("The Blue Pyramid"), which Jackson had tied to the cult searching for her.

      The club is in the Latin Quarter, near the Mosque of Paris, on the Rue Monge. Arriving, the group discovers that it is frequented mainly by Egyptians. The decor is very tacky faux-Egyptian. Charleston tries to bring Noor in to translate what the clientele and waitstaff say in Arabic, but after a few shouted words between her and the maitre d', she refuses to go in.

      "They called me a [gender slur] who sleeps with a bunch of [racial slurs]!" she huffs. "And then they told me to go and do a sexual act with the pigs who brought me."

      Off to their typical warm welcome, Freddie and company enter.

      "Messieurs, bienvenue a votre club, je suis raivissant--oh, you're English. What can I do for you?" the owner, a stout man named Abdul Nawisha, says as they sit down. "We have the finest entertainment--belly dancers, all genuine Bedouin straight from the desert."

      Pearkes notices that Nawisha had come over from a table where an elegantly-dressed French businessman was sitting with many papers, asking Nawisha to sign them. Over at the bar, a couple of policemen are talking in rapid French to the bartender.

      "I don't speak French," replies the bartender, in Arabic. Even though Freddie doesn't understand Arabic anymore, he can tell that the bartender is just trying to blow them off.

      "Orange juice, please!" orders Freddie. "And a whisky! What ho, fine members of the constabulary!"

      "You are English?"

      "You'd think that, but I am actually German!"

      "As a gentleman," says one of the policemen, "I think you should go to much better clubs. I can think of three. The Green Monkey--"

      "That place is terrible," interrupts his partner. "Now, the Graceful Rabbit--"

      "Overrated!" They argue for a while, while Freddie takes notes.

      "In any case," says the first cop, "There are criminals here. We are investigating a murder, which is not all that interesting, really. We have found three girls, now, floating in the Seine. All of them were dancers here. Word in the quarter is that there are two other women who have been murdered who have some relation to this place."

      While Freddie is talking to the cops, Charleston, who always watches the door, sees a well-dressed Egyptian man in a fez walk in. Nawisha fawns over him as he guides him to a private table. As soon as he is seated, the show begins, a fact Charleston notes with interest.

      "Check out the guy in the fez," he says to Freddie, who promptly heads over to speak with the newcomer.

      Nawisha intercepts him. "You do not need to be speaking with him."

      "Just wanted to buy him a drink."

      "He does not need anyone to buy him a drink."

      Freddie brushes past and sits down at the man's table.

      "Who are you," hisses the man. "Why are you disturbing my peace?"

      "I thought of all the men in this bar, you had the highest qualities, and I was wondering if I could have a word with you."

      "Why have you brought a British soldier to this place?"

      "He's Canadian."

      "That does not impress me."

      "My name is Blakely."

      "I am Tawfik al-Sayed," says the man slowly, as if he's trying to place Freddie.

      "I was hoping to have a moment of your time outside this bar?"

      "What could possibly induce me to do that?"

      "I happen to server certain British interests, and was thinking that the opportunities--"

      "I am a spice merchant. I have suppliers around the world. I am an ambitious man but I have no need of such opportunities. And in any case I have a man of business for such matters." He gives Freddie a card.



      Charleston goes out in search of Noor. Most people don't want to talk to him, but eventually he tracks her down to the Mosque of Paris. Soon Freddie and Pearkes join him, waiting outside of it.

      "Have you been murdered?" asks Charleston when she finally comes out.

      "I think I would have remembered that."

      The walk through the streets of the Latin Quarter. "Several Egyptian girls have been murdered," says Charleston.

      "But I am not Egyptian! I am perfectly safe."

      "Don't look now," says Pearkes quietly, "but we're being followed."

      A small figure is keeping pace with them, sticking to the shadows. Charleston doubles back around and starts to follow their pursuer. He easily slips up to her--as he realizes that this is one of the belly dancers from the club. He tugs on her pony tail.

      "Don't hurt me! Please don't hurt me!"

      "Relax!"

      "Oh God! Don't--"

      "What? No, nothing like that." Pearkes and Freddie rush up.

      "Messieurs," says the girl, "my name is Yalesha. You don't know what goes on at that club."

      "I think I have an idea," says Charleston. "Girls get murdered."

      "You do not! Girls are murdered--or they vanish. Ten in the year since I started working there. Al-Sayed likes me, and that has saved me so far, but I think soon he will stop liking me, and then I will vanish too!"

      "Are you pimped out?" asks Freddie. Yalesha slaps him.

      "I just want to know if there's a way to get you out of there," he mutters, rubbing his jaw.

      "It doesn't work like that," says Yalesha. "We are kept in an apartment building, always under guard. I was able to slip away just for a moment. I must go back soon. But I am very scared. The time of the moon is coming, and that is when the girls vanish!"

      Before she scampers away, Pearkes gives her a hundred francs in small denominations so it looks like she was working. They head back to the hotel, where they find a note saying that Edouard Gavigan would be happy to meet them the next day.
      \n

      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 22)


      Wednesday, 6 May 1925

      They drop by Mickey Mahoney the next morning. "What can I do ye fer?"

      "Two questions," says Freddie. "What do you know of this Gavigan?"

      "Supposed to be from a good family out in the provinces, went to the Ecole Diplomatique. I could look into him for you, won't know for a day or so."

      "Second, do you know this Tawfik al-Sayed?"

      "Just an Arab merchant. Could have an operative, er, reporter look into him."

      "Do you know anything about these murders in the Quarter?"

      "Aye, some say there's more and they're being covered up."

      "Charleston says that there are at least ten."

      "That would make a good headline! We'll have to chase down the leads."

      "Two policemen, Jacques and Andre, that I spoke with last night, might have something to say to you."


      Fondation Aubrey Penhew is located on the Rive Droite, near the Rue Richlieu and the National Library--a pretty high-powered address. A pleasant young secretary addresses them in lyrical French, and introduces them to Baldur von Hasselbach, a doctoral student.

      [von Hasselbach was a character in a one-shot, Cthulhuesque Risus game I ran a few years ago. PP would have been the only one who remembered him, and he didn't. So much for shout outs.]

      "I'm a countryman," says Freddie. "A proud citizen of the Republic of Germany."

      "Ah, well. Republics come and go. As I am sure no Frenchman would need to be reminded."

      "Don't you guys have tons of Reichs?" asks Charleston.

      "Yes. Two so far. Shall we begin the tour?"

      He takes him upstairs, around the extremely well-appointed library which is devoted to archaeology, specifically Egyptian archaeology. Baldur switches effortlessly between French, German, English and Russian as he introduces the various visiting scholars.

      Gavigan's office is lavishly furnished in Second Empire style. The man himself is a distinguished person in an impeccable suit, in his late forties, with gray hair at his temples. "Gentlemen, please, sit down."

      Freddie does the introductions. "I am pleased to meet you all," says Gavigan, "although I am a bit...how you say? At sea? as to why you are here."

      "Doing a favor for an old friend," says Freddie. "Erica Carlyle."

      "Ah. I see. The Carlyle family has been a great friend of the Fondation, just as Sir Aubrey was a great friend of them. Erica is a patroness of our society. Of course, we lost poor Sir Aubrey."

      "And Mr. Carlyle."

      "Yes. And Mr. Carlyle. He was...not a gentleman by any means, Mr. Blakely."

      Gavigan tells the same story as the group has already heard about the Expedition, with a notable addition. According to Gavigan, Roger was spending all his time with this mysterious woman M'Weru; in fact, it was Hypatia Masters who suggested they leave Egypt, to flee the developing scandal.

      "Yes," says Freddie, "Hypatia told me something about that, but she was rather mysterious about the whole thing."

      "You spoke with her before the expedition?"

      "No, about three weeks ago."

      "Mr. Blakely, why do give me the lie? Hypatia Masters is dead, Sir Aubrey is dead..."

      "Let's just say that a woman who looked very much like the Miss Masters I remember spoke to me, and she was convinced she was Hypatia."

      "I am not surprised. Just as there are Anastasias in all the capitals of Europe, some impostor must be posing as her. I have read the autopsy reports. I assure you they are dead. I am afraid you have been taken by a confidence artist, much like poor Roger. This M'Weru woman was one such; she absconded with the Expedition's funds. That is why Sir Aubrey and the rest were in the jungle, where they were slain by tribesmen."

      [FP tries to Assess Honesty, but I tell him Gavigan is especially implacable. I tell FP that if he makes a spend, I'll let him know when Gavigan slips.]
      \n

      \n
