      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VI: The Windmills of Your Mind (Part 23)


      "I have a confession," says Freddie. "Erica also sent an American reporter to look into this. A woman names Jackson."

      "Jackson Elias? I read about her death. But I do not think we met...but now that you mention it, yes, I did meet a young reporter. This may have been Elias. But I had nothing more to tell her than what I've told you."

      [This was the tell.

      And NOW we begin the sequence where FP tried to use Interrogation. Or Intimidation. Or something.]

      Pearkes notices that there seems to be another room adjoining the office, perhaps accessed through a concealed door in the closet. He gets up and locks the office door.

      "I thought we would have a private conversation," he says. "Ask you some personal questions."

      "I think this interview is over," says Gavigan. His hand slips under his desk, and Charleston notices that he seems to be pushing some kind of hidden button.

      "I think it's just beginning," says Pearkes.

      Charleston runs to the door and reverses a chair under it. Pearkes punches Gavigan.

      "Pushing the button was an error," he says.

      Banging comes from the door. "Aidez-moi!" shouts Gavigan. "Au secours!"

      Pearkes unlimbers one of his Colts and points it at Gavigan's head. "You're going to shut your mouth and listen very carefully to what I have to say. You understand?"

      Gavigan looks at him with a defiant glare.

      "Tells us about Jackson Elias," shouts Pearkes.

      "She's dead. She came here, and asked strange questions. She said Carlyle Expedition members were still alive. I told her she was insane. She looked insane. She acted insane. They are all dead!"

      "Jack Brady is very much alive," says Freddie.

      "I do not believe you about Hypatia, but Brady may be alive. I have tried to track him down. He is very hard to find. He is out in the Far East somewhere."

      "Why do you have another room?" demands Charleston.

      "It is a storage room, it is easier carry artifacts between rooms."

      "Did you kill Hypatia? Is that how you are so sure she's dead?"

      "I had nothing to do with any of them! I was Sir Aubrey's protege! I worked with him for many years! I mourned him deeply when he died!"

      "We're going for a walk," says Pearkes, as he drags Gavigan into the next room.

      "You are idiots," gasps Gavigan. "If you let me go now, I will not call the police."

      "We could let you meet Hypatia," says Charleston, "then you won't call the police either."

      "Or I could introduce you to my .45," says Pearkes.

      "You are as crazy as Jackson," says Gavigan.

      The "secret room" turns out to be a storeroom, filled with boxes and bookshelves. A large Egyptian sarcophagus is in the center. There is a door on the left wall; although it is closed, it seems to lead out into the main entrance.

      "As you can see, gentlemen, this is a storage room. This is why I like to have a communication with it. I think we should all leave things where they are and you should go."

      "I think that's a great idea!" says Freddie.

      [Right here, now, this is where I should have been for sure doing a GM move. I should have been doing them all along--on the recording, I don't think I once said, What do you do? which means I wasn't setting up moves. Here, I should have "told them the consequences, and asked"--along the lines of, the police will be here very soon, do you leave now, or stay and risk arrest.

      Had I been doing more of that, this would have been less nuts. Looking at it again, it wasn't so bad--as far as these things go--and I did several times give them a chance to get out of the situation. It was mostly PP continually digging the hole deeper.]

      Pearkes picks up a small statuette.

      "That is four thousand years old!" croaks Gavigan.

      "Maybe you should listen, then?"

      There is a pounding on the door to the entryway. "Police! Come out now!"

      "Qu'est-ce que c'est la probl\xe8me?" asks Pearkes.

      "I got a big problem, Mac!" shouts someone through the door. "You are holding one of my citizens! We want you to step out! Now!"

      "Do me a favor," says Freddie. "Scuff up his knuckles, and punch me in the nose."

      "With pleasure!" says Pearkes, and pops Freddie in the nose.

      They open the door.

      "You will please raise your hands."

      "I would like to register a complaint against this man," says Freddie, gesturing with his head at Gavigan. "He struck me."

      "We will make all decisions about who will receive complaints. All of you step out."

      The police cuff Freddie, Charleston, and Pearkes. When they find Pearkes' brace of pistols, they cuff him behind his back, hard.

      [CP wanted to fight at this point, which probably wouldn't have been a TPK, immediately. But it probably would have ended his involvement in the campaign--an Anglophone Chinese-American in Paris probably wouldn't be able to get far.]

      Freddie swears out a complaint against Gavigan for hitting him when they get to the police station, but Gavigan swears out a complaint for kidnapping, criminal menace, assault, and attempted murder. Freddie gets tossed in a holding tank; Charleston locked up with the violent offenders; and Pearkes gets claimed by a man from the Embassy, backed up by some MPs.

      Freddie manages to get sprung after a night, and a day or so later springs Charleston. He hires a lawyer.

      [Here's where I got a bit annoyed; the PCs (led by FP) seemed confident that their story--Gavigan punched Freddie--would somehow protect them. I don't really think I was off-base by being skeptical about this. Gavigan was a highly influential member of a pretty corrupt ruling class, and had already pressed his "hey, guys are going to hit me" button on his desk. With no witnesses, I find it hard to believe that nay magistrate would countenance the PC's counter-charges; they were, after all, an annoying Englishman with an arrest record as thick as a phone book in Paris alone, not to mention his other cities of residence, a loose cannon British officer who had already been reprimanded by his own commanders, and a teenaged American with a criminal past. Given their utter lack of connections to French society, they were, to put it politely, f*cked.

      Of course, they could have done stuff about this. FP consistently forgets that his "class ability" is to turn Credit Rating into contacts.

      And most of all, I messed up by not following the Principles. My only weak excuse is that I hadn't written them down yet.]
      \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n

      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n

      \n
      \n
      \n Right. No updates! Sorry. Went away for a family reunion that turned out to be less fraught than I'd feared, and this week has been busy--I've decided that I should do prep, not writeups, this week.

      Last post was the end to Episode VI. I have Episode VII in the can, just have to do the writeup. And Episode VIII is this weekend! Yikes!

      I've been thinking more about pulling in * World influences. I thought they definitely helped last session--having my card with moves in front of me helped me a) see how many of them I do instinctively and b) when I got stuck, helped ground me.

      I've also been gaining the conviction that the most important legacy of the * World games is to make "What do you do?" the standard ending of every GM utterance. Or as a larger principle, the GM can never close an action. Players close actions; GMs push the consequences. Just about every bad GMing situation I've either perpetuated or suffered under can be traced back to this. The whole Gavigan interrogation scene simply doesn't happen if I remembered this and used moves, specifically the most useful of all moves: Tell them the Consequences, and Ask. "You can try and do an interrogation here, but he's likely got ways to call for help, and his staff is just outside, so you're likely going to have to deal with the police. What do you do?"

      Yeah. Hindsight etc.

      I'm thinking of doing something that Vincent mentions in passing in the Custom Moves section of AW--he did a "roll + stat, and then pick some of the following" as a session introduction. I was thinking something like this:

      Dear ALPHONSE,

      For 1 XP, choose one; for 2 XP, choose two; for 4 XP, choose all three:

      * Your cover is blown
      * Keeping your head down is stressful: -4 Stability
      * Anton is missing

      ...customized for each PC.

      Was planning to do this as a reward system--Gumshoe simply has no parallel to the Fail/Partial/Success system in *World, being essentially a diceless system--but was also wondering if I could do it as a Stability roll ("Make a Stability Check with a TN of 5. If you succeed by 5+, choose 1; if you just succeed, choose 2; if you fail, all 3") since my original impetus was to bleed Stability from the PCs, but I'm not convinced that's a good idea, and giving rewards seems likelier to get buy-in.

      \n
      \n Be careful here, as Gumshoe isn't *World. Not everything will translate as well as Fronts and Principles. I think you're onto something with "The GM can never close an action." The way Josh and framed it, when thinking about places where our games stalled, was "The person who asks the question should not be the one who answers it."

      Also, there's sometimes too much emphasis on not saying "no" as a GM. Essentially, part of what you needed to say was "No, what you are trying to do will not work, because you are totally ignoring common sense and how reality works, even in a game." It's well and good -- and usually desirable -- to frame that as "Okay, if you do that, understand he's already summoned the police, the walls are not soundproof, and no one will believe your word over his. Expect to get arrested." I think this is "Tell them the consequences and let them choose."

      And, that's a great principle. But, it is useful to remember that it also means, "No, you cannot have your PCs do whatever you want and have them succeed fully and walk away scott free."

      And, do recognize that all of this discussion is far, far easier to do outside the session than when you're up to your armpits in alligators, er, players.

      \n I don't think "What do you do" is something special to AWE, it's a fundamental principle of roleplaying. GMs have been saying it from the start. AWE does bring it to the front and try to ensure that it's said more often (although if you listen to AWE actually plays, it's not as ubiquitous as Vincent might have it). An equivalent in GUMSHOE is to always have open leads. I always make sure that there is some mystery which affects the PCs which is left open. Usually I'll try to have two or three open leads. These are almost exactly the same thing as fronts.

      Returning to the XP thing, this sounds similar to the way in which drives work, except the rewards (and costs usually) are stability. Just in our last session one player followed his character's drive, gained to stability, and then lost 6 as a result, as well as 2 Sanity. Obviously a defining moment for that character and which is going to have strong repercussions quite soon.
      \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n

      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Lisa,

      All good points. You are correct in your identification of the move. I think my original framing was slightly more open--not "expect to get arrested" but "expect that you will need to deal with his help, which includes the police." At the very least they would have asked more questions.

      I'm still not sure I'll pull the trigger on my little consequence menu, although I don't think it's out of frame for Gumshoe. So the best thing to do is--democracy! Ask folks if they would like to try it out. So I guess that's what I'll do.

      Steve, I'm definitely not saying that AW invented "what do you do" (and I'm pretty sure Vincent would agree with that!) But the emphasis on it--it's really drilled in the text, no matter if the actual is not as intense as the ideal--is really useful; I don't think many other game systems, even Fate (although the new edition seems to go this way as well) emphasize including that at the end of every GM statement. Too often, gaming examples show the GM doing what I call closing an action--player asks/attempts/wants something, GM responds, and then it ends. Of course, the player then makes a new question/attempt/need, and the cycle repeats.

      It's more subtle to do stuff the * World way, where everything has a consequence, and that consequence keys into actions--less cycle, more flow. But I won't rehearse that here; I think most of us have a grasp of what the World engine does.

      The point being, in the Gavigan scene, rather than do stuff like ask the players what they were doing, point out what could happen, etc., I just dropped a flat fact on them. You interrogate G in his office, you are now in jail. In AW terminology, I went straight to a hard move without setting up a soft move. You might argue that the PCs "handed me a situation on a golden platter" but it was still bad form.

      (You might also argue that PP was doing the same thing by ignoring the other players, but that's more okay on his end than mine.)

      A GM not having open-ended actions--in other words, dishing out consequences without asking for a player response--I think that's where the bad situations in most of the games I've been in have been created.

      I'd like to get Drives in more often; probably the best way to do that is to carrot them more. I can probably do that with a pincers maneuver, i.e. do more to attack their Stability, which will drive them towards finding ways to refresh it via Drives.

      To be honest, the thing I have the hardest time working in are the PIllars of Sanity. I mean, I understand them in principle but the rules are a bit hazy on what would trigger the shattering of a Pillar. So, if folks here have some advice on that I'd appreciate it. (It doesn't help that my players haven't chosen the world's most interesting PIllars.)

      \n A bit fuzzy headed (and gming tomorrow), but I'm wondering have you done the "Here is the sheet of things that call for a stability check"? That's where you hand players a copy of the sheet, and while you call for stability / sanity rolls as seems appropriate to you, often, the players will gleefully call for themselves to make the rolls. Hand a player agency to beat his PC up, and often, he's harder on the poor guy than the cruelest GM.

      \n In our games players usually deal with all the stability loses themselves, it's a good way of involving them. It doesn't always work at Cons, if the players are further up the powergamer spectrum.

      Regarding the hard move in Gavigan scene. There was a window for them to escape, having seen the button being pressed, and so they made a choice to stay. Soft move -> Hard move. Seems fine to me. Are your players the kind whose characters rarely run away?

      The rules for stability are a bit muddled in the main book but are better explained in the Keeper's Resource Book. This explains that if the narrative* causes the destruction of a pillar, the character looses 6 Stability and 2 Sanity. If a character has lost 3 Sanity, they can cause a pillar to "crumble from within", removing it without any further loss. Losing all pillars increases difficulty numbers by 1 (which is not so interesting).

      *I usually take this to mean that the character expresses something counter to their pillar. So if they have Science Will Explain It All, and after passing through a gate, express the opinion that this breaks causality, and the second law of thermodynamics, it's probably safe to say that the pillar has gone. It's fine for the players to handle this themselves too.

      \n Okay. A few things first! Steve, thanks for that. I'll have to ponder it. So far my group (with the exception of FP) seem generally resistant to the idea of Stability checks, especially for murderhobo activities, so I'm not sure how well that would work. So I think I'm absolutely going to have to try it!

      As for Pillars, Charleston has had two crumble, but other than that I haven't been successful in attacking them. (I also need to update them on my master sheet--I don't think I actually have them for everybody.) Still, it's a pretty abstract thing to come to grips with: Freddie has "The Aunts must be obeyed" as a Pillar, and I'm not sure exactly what to do with that yet.

      I ended up handing out my little AW-like consequence sheets, telling everyone they were completely optional, and everyone ended up going for them. So that worked. I don't think I'll do them every session, but they seem good for sessions where they've moved, or some time has elapsed either in the real world or in game.

      \n Well, maybe I phrased that poorly. I have occasionally gotten pushback on asking folks for Stability checks for violent stuff. That's been less of an issue with PP reduced to possible infrequent guest player. CP grasped the magic system pretty well and seemed willing to trade stability for spells in the most recent session.

      I think I'll print out the stability chart & hand it out to folks, following GBSTeve's advice and see what happens. Even if they underbill their Stability, I can survive a session like that.

      Folks have different expectations about Cthulhu games. BP clearly wanted something really purist, which I can't run. (I mean, seriously--The Big N as lounge singer?) Some folks like the 20s setting--I think that's FP's draw, as it lets him play Bertie Wooster. CP likes the group and likes his character. OP is probably traditionalist provided he gets a healthy dose of pulp to show off his hardboiled PI. JP...just likes RPing, and has fallen into the sunny, slightly inept sidekick. (I chose Elisha Cook, Jr. as Jimmy's character portrait.) GP is much the same, except with a laid-back, more competent sidekick character.

      And I like the group! So I have to balance my own wants (dark angsty sacrifice-laden noir) with theirs (heroic mostly pulpy fights against alien Big Bads). So it ever goes; my Pathfinder game never really explored my feminist socialist utopia setting, as I felt I needed to give them some kind of Pathfinder-like experience.

      I do have some...stuff planned for Gavigan's final response moves. (Spoiler alert--Tewfik dies rather surprisingly in Episode IX.) I've already given FP a hard choice in Episode IX, and I plan to have Gavigan demonstrate just what ruthless looks like in Episode X. So that will bring it back to darker stuff.

      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Prologue Part 1)

      [So! New players, two: I will call them JP and OP, after their characters--Jimmy Wright and Francis O'Donnell. Only FP of the regulars made this session, which was just as well--a good way to break them in.

      Once again I went to the Fiasco playset to generate a relationship map. I almost didn't--I had been working on a vaguely Gatsby-esque playset with lots of locations and such, and it wasn't gelling. Then suddenly it occurred to me that if I wanted a party setting, then I should ditch the All Around New York stuff and just do a party playset.

      Here's the playset, including the modified Tilt and Aftermath. It looks a bit professional, even!

      Here were the relationships we generated:

      Freddie-Jimmy: Remittance men Freddie and Jimmy are corrupt scions of good families.
      Jimmy-Francis: Private Eyes Jimmy is the inept tyro, Francis the more knowledgeable veteran.
      Jimmy-Jackson Elias: Reporter and photographer Jimmy does freelance photography, that's how he knows Jax
      Francis-Freddie: Flappers They dated the same flapper--until Francis found Freddie with Jordan
      Francis-Jackson: Cousins Didn't expect that, worked out
      Freddie-Jackson: Secretaries That was a stretch--we decided Jax had gotten a job as the secretary to the mysterious host of the party, not knowing that it might be Freddie

      Location: The Master Bedroom
      Needs:
      Francis-Jax: To Get Away...with murder
      Jimmy-Jax: To Get the Truth by...finding out who's throwing these parties
      Object: The Stag Film of a Popular Actor

      Obviously we had too many relationships; we rolled some extra dice.

      I was worried that I wouldn't catch lightning twice by going to a playset again, but it worked out pretty well. Thanks to Jason Morningstar for Fiasco, the most fun you'll ever have making a relationship map!]

      In the summer of 1922, a mysterious gentleman rented a mansion on Long Island and began to throw wild jazz parties. Everyone who was anyone went to them, or crashed them at the very least. Scott Fitzgerald dropped by and began to think about story ideas. Various gangsters filtered in and out, dropping off Canadian whiskey while grooving to jazz.

      Upstairs in the mansion's master bedroom, Freddie Blakely, dissolute ex-pat Englishman, is rooting around for the owner's secret alcohol stash when he is surprised by Francis O'Donnell, a private eye, veteran of the great war, and tough guy.

      "Donnie old boy! Is that you! Haven't seen you since Jordan's apartment that day!"

      O'Donnell sighs. "Is that Glen?"

      "Nothing so prosaic. This is a Kentuckey whiskey, I believe."

      "Just pour."

      "Sorry, I only seem to have teacups."

      Freddie and Francis go downstairs, where Freddie catches sight of someone furtively trying to slip in among the crowds. "Why, Jimmy Wright!" shouts Freddie. "Are you here moonlighting as some kind of clandestine photographer?"

      "No! Just here for the party!" Jimmy says, desperately trying to get away from Freddie.

      Francis catches sight of Jackson slipping in the crowd and drags her into a closet.

      "Jesus, Francis! What the hell! What are you doing here--and in that suit? Didn't you get your war bonus?"

      "Henry said you were in trouble."

      "I'm always in trouble."

      "I'm here to get you out of here."

      "I just got here! Besides, I need to meet the guy throwing these parties. I'm supposed to be his secretary. It's a big story, and I don't have a book subject yet."

      "This is more important."

      "Look. If you're going to report on the Thuggee cult, you may have to do some things. It's a ritual murder cult! I may have been implicated. I took care of it!"

      "All right. Listen. I'm tailing you. If I don't like what's going on, we're leaving."

      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Prologue Part 2)

      Sometime later Jackson finds Freddie. She is reading from a little pink slip of paper. "I'm supposed to report to...oh. Freddie Blakely."

      "Jackson Elias! Aren't you supposed to be killing Russians or something?"

      "Russia was ages ago. I wrote a book; I'd say you should read it, but you don't read. Besides, did you ever meet John Reed? Guy had his head so far up his--well, anyway. I'm trying to report on the guy throwing these parties."

      "Well, it's certainly not me."

      "Riiight. How are you Freddie. I haven't seen you since Paris, after the war."

      "Right. Just before I got thrown into prison for fomenting insurrection."

      "Hey, I didn't say anything, I just wrote a story, got a hundred bucks from the UPI."

      [We only did one scene each in the first act (believe it or not, that was the entire first act!) I randomly distributed the remaining dice, and we went with the "Soft" or "John Hughes" Tilt.

      JP and OP got to choose and went:

      Deception: Misplaced Trust
      Sex: A Surprising Turn of Heart

      Okay, I wheedled for the Turn of Heart, as it worked best with the meta plot.

      "Scotty old boy," says Freddie, slurring his words a bit as he puts an arm around Jimmy, "I think we should have an adventure. I do know a lot of people at this party, and they would like to have their picture taken."

      "Will they have their clothes on?"

      "If you ask them to, I suppose they'll put them back on. Ah, my friends the vaudevillians! Julius old man!"

      "Freddie. Howya doin'? This clown here says we should go into pictures. I told it would never work. We need sound."

      "Especially for Arthur," says Leonard Marx, idling over by a piano. "Besides, once you do a bit in a film, you can never do it again! It would ruin our stage act."

      [We had some discussion of where to go next--OP floated the idea of moving forward to after the party, but I argued for preserving the Aristotelian unities. I also suggested that I could bring in some campaign elements.]

      Jimmy spends some time taking pictures. Eventually she corners a young socialite and her lawyer friend.

      "Get that camera out of my face!" screams Erica Carlyle. "My brother's been dead for three years! Stop bothering me!"

      "Jimmy," says Francis, grabbing him by the lapel, "let's take a walk."

      "Sue those bastards, Bradley!" screams Erica as Jimmy gets dragged away.

      Focus on Jimmy Wright: black sheep of a good family, managed not to go to war in '17, but dropped out of lawschool anyway. And his aggrieved un-mentor, Francis O'Donnell: working class stiff made good, altar boy, med student who dropped out to go to France. A study in contrasts.

      Francis met Jimmy a few months earlier. He was on an adultery stakeout when he kept getting some inept young man who was clearly tailing his mark in all his photographs; it seems that Jimmy, having read a few pulps, decided Private Eye would be a good way to make some money without working hard. Eventually, tired of having his cases wrecked by this would-be competitor, Francis began to teach Jimmy his trade. Now he has trouble keeping the guy out of his hair.

      "You can't go taking pictures of people when their lawyers are standing next to them!" hisses Francis.

      "Hi, Bradley Grey, attorney-at-law!" says a young man, walking up to them.

      "Jimmy, go take some pictures of Freddie Blakely. He's some useless hanger-on. Over there, by the vaudevillians!"

      "You mean those guys he's playing strip poker with? The Marx Brothers?"

      "Wait, Jimmy Wright?" says Bradley. "Didn't we go to law school together? How are you? Practicing law?"

      "I'm working on another job now."

      "That's great. I may have something for you..."



      The stars are finally beginning to fade when Jax walks out on the pier to take the air and clear her head. At the end of it, next to a blue light, she sees a figure standing.

      "Freddie?"

      "Ah, Jackson! Bit chilly out, don't you think? I seem to have lost most of my clothing."

      "Take my wrap."

      "Thanks."

      "Is this your place?"

      "Don't be foolish. It's illegal to have alcohol."

      "Yeah, but is it your place?"

      "Not technically. One rents, you know."

      "You never wrote me. All those months when I was reporting from the front, with the Germans trying to blow my head off."

      "I tried to write you, but I didn't know where you were."

      "What are you doing, Freddie? Why are you in New York?"

      "Well, I knew this bloke, you see? Going to marry some cove down on Bleeker Street. Agatha didn't take to that. Well, I failed spectacularly--they live up in Westchester, expecting their second--and I thought it best not to go back to England given that the Aunts would have my entrails on a platter. What about you? I thought you were in Russia?"

      "Nope. Was in India, for a while. Anyway, been four years since I was there. And like I said, John Reed has his head up his..."

      "You seem to know a remarkable number of men like that, Jax."

      "Yeah. Must be a character flaw," she says, with a pointed stare.

      "Not me. I couldn't find my ass with both hands if I sat on it."

      "You were never going to marry me, were you."

      "On the contrary, I thought I gave it a good go. You had a larger number of positive characteristics. You are rather entertaining, and you'd cause Agatha's head to explode."

      "Typical of you, Freddie. I never heard anything else than that from you." She turns to go.

      "I'm...rather fond of you, old girl."

      She stops.

      "You're not going to go and leave your shawl out here?" asks Freddie. "I still need it. You might as well stay until I don't need it."

      "You are the most infuriating man I know," says Jax, sitting down next to him and putting her head on his shoulder.

      Back at the tattered remnants of the party, Bradley corners Jimmy again. "Jimmy. I heard you're doing some investigations these days. Let's just say a client of a client of mine is investigating...that girl you came in with. It could be worth your while if you could provide some information about her whereabouts, what's she doing...that sort of thing."

      "I'm familiar with her," says Jimmy slowly.

      "There could be three...maybe four figures in it for you."

      "A client of a client?"

      "Let's just say a large organization with multinational reach. Who might not like certain books that she wrote about...certain parts of their polity."

      "Something tells me that this is a bad thing to go into...though, four figures..."

      "Low four figures, Jimmy. Drop by my office tomorrow."


      Francis is standing by the swimming pool. Jimmy finds him and explains Bradley's offer, hopping with excitement, blissfully unaware that Jax is Francis' cousin.

      "You tell them..." says Francis, slowly, "that Jax is going back to Russia. You make sure they know that, all right? Make sure that's what they believe. Russia."

      "Okay! Thanks, Frank!"

      "Don't mention it. Wait five hours, then tell your friends that."

      "Easiest grand I ever made!"

      \n A quick note:

      For the Paris episodes, I'm trying to use titles from French songs. This one is from "Les Feuilles Mortes," the song made famous by the great Yves Montand; Episode VIII is "Les pas des amants d\xe9sunis," from the same song, and episode IX (which I hope will wrap up the Paris section) will let Serge Gainsbourg get the last word, from his tribute to "Les Feuilles Mortes", "Chanson de Pr\xe9vert": "Les amours mortes n'en finissent pas de mourir."

      \n Gainsbourg seems a bit modern. My favourite French period song is Vive les bananes with the brilliant line "Meme les plus meconnus parmi les hommes celebres, aprecient les vertus de ce fruit sans verterbres" but it's not particularly appropriate.

      \n Au contraire, Steve, given how much Gainsbourg deconstructed his own contemporary genres (and especially in "La Chanson de Pr\xe9vert"), I'd say he was...post-modern. And so, utterly appropriate :-D

      Point of fact, I think of the songs I've used as inspiration for episode titles, only "L'Internationale" was even approximately contemporary. I may even insert "Les Feuilles Mortes" into the actual game world--I can't find a date for when Pr\xe9vert actually wrote it, as opposed to when it was published (1946, in Paroles), so it's not such a stretch that somebody might have picked it up as a song subject. Kosma was nowhere near Paris in the '20s, but...I allow myself one major anachronism per session. And technically, this is an alternative timeline.

      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Prologue Part 3)

      "To hell with you, Frank. I just got back to New York," Jackson says when Francis tells her he's taking her to Paris.

      "It's not safe here. There are people after you."

      "Let them come! I'm perfectly safe from the Brits here! It's not like they have an extradition treaty or anything!"

      "Actually, Jax, they do."

      "Damnit. And my mother was Canadian, so technically I could be a British subject." She brightens up. "Don't worry, Francis. I got it under control. I know the guy throwing these parties, he'll take care of it. And then there's always Charlie if that doesn't work."



      "What do you mean I gotta go?" shouts Jax at Freddie.

      "Seems like the obvious solution. If you stay in New York, you can't be protected."

      "Are you going to Paris with me?"

      "Heavens no. The Aunts would destroy me! It's only twenty miles across the Channel!"

      "To hell with you. To hell with all of you. To hell with you, Frank. And Jimmy, you're not getting paid by me!"



      Jax storms off just as the sun comes up. A rather mousy looking woman finds Freddie standing sorrowfully by the gate.

      "Good morning, Mr. Blakely. The agency sent me, you have a position open for a secretary? My name's Sheila--Sheila Brisbane."

      "Adelaide?"

      "Sheila."

      "Abigail?"

      "Sheila--forget about it. You'll get it eventually."

      "Great party," says Bradley Grey, leading an inebriated Erica out to his car. "Say, Freddie, you could probably use a lawyer. Here's my card."

      As they drive away, Erica says to Bradley, "Are you sure you want him as a client?"

      "Absolutely. He's some rich guy from England--good family, he'll never get in trouble. I'll milk him for his retainer, easy money!"


      [Aftermath! Here were the results:

      Jimmy: 18 Black, lucky bastard!

      Jimmy does get paid, even though Jax never goes to Russia. With the money he gets from Bradley Grey, he starts his own agency--James Wright Investigations, James Wright, Esq., proprietor. He continues to do jobs for Bradley and his rich clients, eventually setting up in reasonable style in Midtown.

      Francis: 7 White, pretty good.

      Jax doesn't get arrested, somehow. Occasionally Francis sees ads for Jimmy's agency. Eventually, he gets fed up and moves to Paris, where he finds a decent cold water flat in Montmartre while he studies for the French bar. He sets up as a private detective and meets a newspaperman named Mickey Mahoney.

      "Always good to meet another son o' the sod. Ye speak Irish?"

      "Just Latin."

      "I don't speak a word of it either, have to bring the boy in to translate for me when we do the Irish edition. Listen, I could use a boy like you, likely lad for certain errands."

      "I don't move women."

      "Ach, that's for the damn English! We'll get along famously, you and I..."

      Freddie: White 0, Disastrous!

      The disastrous result of his long-planned for reunion crushes Freddie. His parties become a bore, and people stop coming. His Aunts finally find out about his extravagance, and cut him off; he turns to working for Dahlia's spiritualist rag, The Golden Sentinel, and drinking until publicly disorderly.

      Jax: White 6. Not too bad.

      Jax's book does well. She begins to compile evidence on Erica Carlyle's brother...

      And then she dies, in February 1925.

      In Paris, Francis--now working exclusively as a PI, following the death of his wife, reads about Jackson's death in the International Herald Tribune. He is shocked to see pictures of Freddie sitting in the front row at Jax's funeral. He finds out from her editor about Jackson's investigation, and begins to make his own followup.

      Then one day at Mahoney's office he sees Freddie Blakely again. And Jimmy Wright.

      Jimmy is in Paris because of Bradley Grey. "Listen," the candidate for District Attorney had told him in New York, "Erica's really upset about this whole Jackson Elias mess. She doesn't want anybody poking around into her brother's death. Between you and me, the guy was a waste of air. So, go see if you can chase down the leads Jackson was following and let me know what you find so we can get ahead of this. Why don't you start in Paris?"

      [And that's how I brought the new players into the game.]

      \n I like the flashbacks. I've run the non-mythos adventure from the MoN Companion, and am trying to figure out which versions of which handouts to print for next time. Yours are lovely, but I didn't gender flip Elias, and I don't know how mean I want to be to him (you know, apart from having him die horribly). I love the French MoN handouts, and would like to own a copy of the book, but most of the handouts are in French, obviously, which isn't ideal for my purposes.

      I like the "Easiest grand I ever made" line. For Freddie... I might be tempted to have N. offer to return Elias to life, all happy to be with Freddie and sane enough and all, for the small cost of ceasing to thwart N, maybe thwarting others' attempts to thwart him. Thing is, for this to work, FP needs to be willing to either accept or reject this -- either is totally fine -- rather than try to game the system so Freddie gets Elias _and_ thwarts N. Some players are cool with this, but others don't like limited options and try to break them open. Of course, even that's fine if one is willing to run with it, but Noir, even NoirPulp, should mean there are costs and no free lunch.

      How much does N. intend to play with Freddie, given he's already peeled away a language, just as he did with Elias?

      \n Shan't give away too much, but I will think about that with regard to Freddie. BTW, he loses French in Episode VIII, and will continue to lose languages every so often; N sees it as a bonding experience.

      I like making props, and it's a Cthulhu RPGing tradition to have them, so I put some work into them, especially the journal; I'll have to show you the actual (as opposed to electronic) version some time. Feel free to rip off anything I've done; a find and replace could fix a lot of my gonzoness.

      My own thinking about N and what he's up to and how much he cares about what the PCs do is...evolving. I mean, why would he even bother, right? He could always just show up, manifest in one of his really bad forms, and scrape what's left of the PCs off his shoes later. But he doesn't do that. Point of fact, it's his human minions that seem to be the ones investing effort in getting rid of the PCs. This requires some pondering.

      Jimmy's Drive is Bad Luck, but his seems to be manifesting as "stuff going okay for me and raining poo down on everyone near me" which is fun for the gameplay. Francis brought some noir intensity to Session VII (he missed the following session, but we got GP and CP back). So the group dynamics seem to be shifting nicely.

      As for Freddie and your idea for tempting him...there's a zero percent chance, IMHO, that FP wouldn't try to game it, at least not at first. OTOH...well, wait til the Episode VII writeup. I built up for a while towards the Sheila situation hitting the wall, and it's going to be interesting how that plays out in Episode IX.

      \n Who plays Jax?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

    • \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n

      \n
      \n Sheesh, kind of a big omission, right?

      Louise Brooks. One of the few actors who was contemporary to the story.

      I lampshaded that during the Fiasco portion of Episode VII--we never really got the stag film into the story, but we did talk about it, and I mentioned that since Jax looks like Louise Brooks, it would be amusing if the stag film was of Louise Brooks:

      "Hey, is that--"

      "NO!"

      From what I've read about Louise Brooks, it was hardly an impossibility that such a thing existed.

      \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n

      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n

      \n
      \n
      \n
      My own thinking about N and what he's up to and how much he cares about what the PCs do is...evolving. I mean, why would he even bother, right? He could always just show up, manifest in one of his really bad forms, and scrape what's left of the PCs off his shoes later. But he doesn't do that. Point of fact, it's his human minions that seem to be the ones investing effort in getting rid of the PCs. This requires some pondering.
      \nA few thoughts.

      Lovecraft didn't worry too much about total consistency, given this was a mythos, a myth cycle, and such things ted to have odd gaps. When one gets a full blown campaign, these gaps start to become an issue.

      N. is generally inconsistent from the beginning. Why is he trapped inside the pyramid for centuries? I mean, this is a being who can teleport his priestess from Kenya to the USA, inserting full knowledge of 20th century USA culture and technology into her head. Why did he wait until the 20th century to set up getting himself freed? I mean, sure, we can go with "He had to wait until the stars were right", but that's a bit weak.

      It can be useful -- when I ran my original campaign (not CoC, but a homebrew I called Cthulhupunk, at least two years before SJG came out with GURPS Cthulhupunk), in my game world, N. was imprisoned until 1925, and that explained why mythos things were only now coming to a head. There was a lot more weirdness than the mythos out there (I used NightLife, among other things), so that worked well.

      But also, one of the reasons we love N. and keep coming back to him is that he's got personality. He's a tempter. He loves to corrupt. Sure, he could blast the PCs, but it's just more fun to corrupt them. And, if he can't do that, it's more fun to have them watch as all their efforts fail. You've turned that up to eleven with what he did to Jax -- that's sadism as an art form.

      (Compare to the first Hellblazer movie, where the villain kept a victim or two alive because he respected them and felt they deserved to see what he was trying to bring about -- it's not a normal or sane thing, perhaps, but it was internally consistent and justified keeping one character alive as something other than idiot plottig.)

      N. as artist is another reason he doesn't just destroy his enemies, wave his hand, and make what he wants happen. As a friend of mine put it, he's a grandmaster of chess, but he doesn't want to sweep in and win in a gauche, brutal way. He wants to play out the elaborate game he's planned, leading his opponent into ever more complicated traps. Sure, if he's worried he'll actually lose, he can pull out the brute force (unless you decide he's amused enough to give the monkeys their victory for a few decades or milennia, but as long as he's confident, he will do a slow game, pausing to pretend he's playing fair as he allows his opponents to react. His minions don't get this about him, and are convinced they have to help his plans along -- and he no doubt encourages this. Or maybe he doesn't.

      The things that seem to have surprised him were Charleston turning him down, Pearkes giving him the sword, and Freddie being... well, Freddie.

      But yes, is there a real possibility of victory for the PCs? Or is everything they do foreseen? What will your group accept? How bleak -- or surreal -- do the players want things to get?
      \n

      \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n

      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n
      \n
      \n

      \n
      \n Meanwhile, I'm rereading New York again, to prep for Sunday. I've decided that I don't like what was done with Huston. I mean, here's this guy, ahead of his time in some ways -- studying with Freud and Jung at a time when their theories were radical and often looked down on. And he ditched an old career -- and a wife -- to get that far, even before the Imelda Bosch mess. I'd forgotten that, because it's completely irrelevant as written.

      This is a man who was suave and dangerous in the right ways to become the confidante of many of New York's monied families, again, in an age where what he was doing as a psychoanalyst was looked down upon.

      And... he wants to rule the world so he can indulge himself. He globe trots with thugs who have nothing better to do than take potshots at the PCs. Or, he sits in Australia and cackles manically while admonishing his minions to practice their Shrivelling spells for the test. Complete disconnect.

      I mean, if you've got The Stars Are Right, look at "Nemo Solis Sapit" for a lovely way for a psychoanalyst to go round the bend due to mythos knowledge. I'm tempted to try to work that line -- but I don't want to get away from the core of Masks.

      It also occurs to me that Imelda Bosch's her death was news, even if the suicide angle was hushed. Presumably, she was of some means. I don't know how much time I want to spend playing with that, given I'm running on Sunday. Huston presumably started the affair. Certainly, he broke it off. Why? As far as I can tell, he doesn't feel guilty about any of it, merely afraid that the scandal will come out.

      Does he really want to rule the world? This seems more like someone wanting to be an eminent gris. And he probably thinks of himself as a ladies' man, apparently not without justification. Certainly, this is a far cry from the wild eyed nigh drooling figure in the thumbnail sketch.

      Penhew's weird, but his weirdness gives me more of a handle on him. He wants to be a pharaoh. Pretty much everything flows from that. Masters is too simple, and I'm not sure how much I want to change, if anything, there, but at least the pieces fit the puzzle.

      It's actually fascinating to compare Masters and Huston. She had an abortion. He drove a lover to suicide (indeed, one could decide he actively drove her to suicide, using his knowledge of her psychology...). Masters is consumed by guilt and wants to undo her deed. Huston just doesn't want to get caught. Masters slots easily into the role of mother-to-be, while Huston wonders what his role will be. Masters is being destroyed by being given what she wants and realizing The Awful Truth. Huston... well, yes, suddenly he's testing Shrivelling spell casting. Hm.

      \n
      \n I agree that Huston is underwritten; probably some of that had to do with the original decision to cut the Australia section when Masks came out.

      I haven't done anything with him in game yet, although I think the time is coming. Realistically, he could be one of the most dangerous opponents the PCs face--a sorcerer, and a psychologist; he could keep one step ahead of them constantly, and taunt them to maximum effect.

      Since I have no urgent need to preserve fidelity to the text--ahem--I have of course changed around more than a few things, although I'm still working on how to get Huston in; I think I'm approaching the time to start. I kind of like the idea of him being the chessmaster troubleshooter. Of course, I've got other stuff going on in my game. Hypatia clearly has an agenda, and seems to be using the PCs as her cat's paws to take out members of the conspiracy she doesn't like (she admits as much in Episode VIII)--but why?

      Actually, but Why? is an excellent question. As I said at the beginning of this gonzo quest, I find the motivations and the characterizations of the NPCs to be one of the weakest things in most RPG writing. Masks is better than most, but still no exception. And I've always had a problem with the apocalyptic cult thing being over-used. Lovecraft actually had relatively few of those, and relatively few head-wound crazy sorcerers; even Joseph Curwen had motives that were not "end the world as we know it."

      In fact, "destroying the world just cause" is basically the motivation only in "The Call of Cthulhu" and that's because The Big C is better than anyone at driving folks around the bend in ways that are useful to him. For long-form entertainment, it kind of sucks as an answer; I think that there's a reason that a) Lovecraft never wrote any novels and b) his novellas don't use "crazy" as the rationale for why humans are doing what they do.

      But that's just me. My project is to tear this sucker down, after all :-)

      \n Another way to answer "Why?' is to go a little Derleth and view the Earth as the prize / game board for a game between Nodens and Nyarlathotep. In this case, Nodens should not be too nice a guy. A friend of mine helped me with that sort of thing in my first Cthulhupunk game (PM me if you want details, as they don't really belong here).

      \n
      \n Given that anti-colonialism is a major theme of the campaign, the "cults as underdogs" thing will come in. That said...it's a bit too easy, and too dismissive, to just have it be the cults. (One of the conspiracy members is very much anti-colonial, but that hasn't gotten into play yet.)

      Thinking about it over the weekend gave me some good ideas...which you'll have to wait to see; spoilers, and I'd like them to cook a bit more. I just want--need--there to be some kind of reason that can be given for why the conspiracy wants to pull this off. After all, according to the Masks text, if the gate opens the GOOs show up and use humanity as sushi or something. Why folks would want to kick that off...I just can't see it. You're forced to fall back on a) they are driven completely 'round the bend by what they've learned and so make a completely irrational choice or b) they're being lied to by the entities in charge.

      A) is dramatically unsatisfying; it's the "just because" rationale. But sucks a bit too, as it means the conspiracy, which is supposed to be sooo scary and have at least one chessmaster, isn't smart enough to figure out that they're dooming the human race and themselves. You can make that work in a story, but it definitely diminishes the Bad Guys and usually is used only to set up a Heel-Face Turn or a Just Desserts ending.

      And those are great! But not what I'm trying to cook up. I want to get some NPCs with psychological depth and motivations that PCs could respect. Of course, some of that is driven by the Ha Ha! nature of doing a reboot like this, where occasionally you need a dramatic reversal or two, or other deep variation from the source. (Like, for example, I've pretty much decided on the idea that Gavigan isn't magic. I like the idea of somebody getting to the top of the cult without being a sorcerer; and it reinforces my mental image of G as incredibly determined and willing to do whatever it takes to come out on top.)

      Anyway, my US$ .02, for what it's worth. I understand I am basically incredibly far from anything remotely purist, but I embraced that destiny a long time ago :-)

      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Part 1)

      Monday, 11 May 1925

      After a few days in the clink, Freddie manages to hire a lawyer with the right requirements (Sorbonne graduate, name with a de in the middle.) He springs him and Charleston. Colonel Pearkes is not in any French jail; Freddie's lawyer speculates that he has been removed to England.

      He drops in on Mickey Mahoney's office near Place R\xe9publique. There he runs into Mickey's "boy", Francis O'Donnell, and Jimmy Scott, who "keeps pesterin' me for an interview."

      "Scotty! Donny! Good to see you again!"

      "Ye know each other?" says Mickey, incredulously.

      "We've met before," mutters Francis.

      Mahoney shakes his head. "Listen, Freddie. Gavigan's lawyer would be very interested in meeting with you. Like to iron the whole mess out. Meet him at La Tour d'Argent today, for lunch. Says you're paying. You should go with him, Francis me boy. You--" looking at Jimmy--"I don't care what the hell you do."

      "He can follow us and keep an eye on me keeping an eye on Freddie," says Francis.

      "Now listen," says Mahoney. "What I'm gonna say next can't leave this room. And by that I mean, if I hear that any of you have said anything about it, it will be one of the last things you do.

      "So this Mr. Gavigan, he's a piece of work, isn't he? This Edouard Gavigan may claim to be a graduate of the Ecole Diplomatique and have dinner with the President twice a year at the Elys\xe9e Palace, but he's no Frenchman. He was born Eddie Gaffigan. An Ulsterman, and a bad 'un. In 1915, he was a bombmaker and assassin for a pro-Independence militia. But in 1916, during the rising, he was in a unit of the British Army, one commanded by our old friend Sir Aubrey Penhew. Seems this Gaffigan betrayed some members of his old unit, led them into an ambush and they was all massacred."

      "So he switched sides," says Freddie. "Why haven't some of his old friends tried to--well--"

      "I happen to know that there have been at least three attempts on his life, by some boys who knew what they were about. Not only did all three fail, but the lads were never heard from again. He's rich, aye, and tight with everybody important in the Third Republic, but what that would do to keep him out of a coffin, I don't know. Has an impeccable reputation as a philanthropist. So, not the kind of man to be frightened by sticking a gun in his face.

      "Now, this Mr. Gavigan happens to own, via a bunch of dummy companies, a castle in Ireland, just south of the Ulster line--"

      "That must piss you off," says Jimmy.

      "You have the American talent for understatement. He also has a villa on some island near Venice, and has some kind of connection to the fella that owns the Blue Pyramid nightclub--or rather, owned; it's being sold to some American. If you'll be needing transport to either, I've got a plane that can take you."



      "I still can't believe you never told me you're Jax's cousin," says Freddie, entering his hotel suite.

      "I think I've spoken about fifty-nine words to you in my life," says Francis. "So it didn't exactly come up."

      "Well, you look nothing like her."

      "Freddie--Mr. Blakely--is there anything you need?" asks Sheila.

      "I'll need to change--oh, and clothes for Scotty and Donnie here, I'm meeting with this Gavigan fellow."

      "Oh. You're going to lunch? I guess I'm not invited."

      "Well you could come. In your capacity as my personal clerk."

      "I'm much to busy anyway, and I have nothing to wear." She heads downstairs to hail a cab.

      "Do I need to tell you to give yourself a raise again?" shouts Freddie after her.

      "Already did!"


      When Freddie gets downstairs, the manager meets with him. Very apologetically, he tells Freddie that he must leave the hotel. When Freddie asks for recommendations, the manager hems and haws. Freddie soon gets the picture: he's socially radioactive, and none of the better hotels will have him as a guest.

      "We're getting kicked out?" huffs Sheila. "Fine. I will take care of it. This is ridiculous..."

      [And with this, I declared the long guerrilla campaign for Sheila Brisbane's soul.]


      At La Tour d'Argent, Jimmy gets a table near the private room Gavigan has reserved for Francis and Freddie. Blakely is kept icing his heels for over an hour before finally getting led to the table. Jimmy notes that there are couple of men obviously keeping guns under their coats standing guard on the private room.

      [I've never managed to eat at La Tour d'Argent; take a look at the link to the menu above and you may guess why! It is said that the wine cellar could keep the restaurant supplied for years even if all the wine in the rest of the world vanished.]
      \n

      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n The thing is, do all of the cultists really, truly believe that opening the gate is the end of everything? I don't think they all do. The anti-colonialism you've already covered. I remember a friend telling me about her parents being Communists and explaining that, when this happened, there were a lot of disenfranchised folks in the USA who believed that Communism was the only thing that offered hope of positive change. Later on, she said, it became clear, at least to most, that the Soviet Union didn't really give a dang about supporters in the USA beyond what those supporters were prepared to do for them.

      For some, there's the become-part-of-a-god bit or become part of True Reality. And I'm sure others delude themselves into thinking they'll be rewarded in ways that make sense to them. Huston, as written, believes he will rule the world and hasn't grasped that the world will be a burnt cider. Penhew wants to be a pharaoh and is convinced this will be his just reward. And, strictly speaking, he's correct, according to the text. It just doesn't mean what he thinks it will mean. It's a bit like sending Psyche down to Hades to ask Persephone for Beauty. The Beauty of Hades doesn't mean what Persephone thinks it means.

      There's the religious aspect. Maybe I don't particularly like the idea of the End Times coming, but I believe they will come -- Crowley wrote in Magick Without Tears (which I'm told is as close as he gets to being straightforward in his writing) that he didn't like the message of The Book of the Law, but whether he did or not, that's just how things were.

      Either way, it's both fun and useful to ponder the motives of cultists. And then it gets disturbing when looking at insane behavior of the supposedly normal...
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n I ate at Tour d'Argent years ago, when my family went to London and Paris for vacation. I don't remember much beyond it was delicious food.

      So, how did this begin the battle for Sheila's soul? Is she actually being tempted by the dark side of the force?
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n For various reasons I've been downplaying the religious aspects of the Mythos stuff. It was there with Shakhti's followers, but then Shakhti's cult wasn't underclass, it was a club for the powerful and he used religion pretty obviously in its role as the handmaiden of state action. (Plus, he may be sophisticated, but at bottom he's still the Bronze Age ruler of a small city-state.)

      I think it's impossible to separate the cults as Lovecraft depicts them from Lovecraft's own well-known racism. I mean, they're always furtive, usually swarthy foreigners infiltrating upright society and bringing it down. (Yes, okay, the Mi-Go cult in "The Whisperer in the Darkness" isn't, but then they have an actual rationale--they sell out part of the planet in exchange for a lot of power; same goes for the Great Race's helper cult.) Sometimes your source material...isn't so awesome, so if you're reinterpreting it, you have to take pains to avoid those pratfalls. (Ronald D. Moore, white courtesy phone please.)

      It happens in all kinds of stuff. I'm a huge Chandler fan, and I understand why Farewell, My Lovely was his own favorite novel--in a lot of ways, it's the best written and most intriguing, with a ton of good characters and the most homoerotic scene in the books, which is saying something. But my goodness, the racism in the book is appalling--maybe not "The Horror in Red Hook" bad, but still pretty awful.

      The battle for Sheila's soul...well, spoilers, so you'll have to wait for more updates, sorry. However, I wanted to explore the idea that there are more ways to attack a Source than just physical or mental assault. Sheila was always in a kind of bad place--hopelessly in love with a man-child who himself was in love with a ghost. So if somebody just gave her a little push in a different direction...well, her relationship might crumble and expose Freddie.
      \n

      \n
      \n

    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n
      \n
      \n\nSeptember 2013 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Part 2)

      Freddie and Francis are ushered into a private room. Gavigan is sitting with his weasly looking avocat.

      "Monsieur Blakely, thank you for coming. I hope we can put these...contentious circumstances to rest," says Gavigan.

      "No worries, Eddie, I'm sure it will be fine."

      "Ah, Mr. Blakely, I know you have been in l'Am\xe9rique for some time, but here we do not go for l'informalit\xe9. But if you wish to call me Edouard, we are on that level."

      "Of course, Mr. Gaffigan."

      "Ah, I know your French is not so sophisticated, but it is pronounced Gavigan."

      "Well, I did learn it in Lyon."

      "Wonderful food there. The other qualities are somewhat lacking."

      "This is Mr. Francis O'Donnell, my...avocat."

      "Ah, your lawyer. I'm afraid I don't recognize the name from the court papers. No matter."

      "It seems that much like the best hotels, the best lawyers are suddenly unavailable to me."

      "What can I say, monsieur? In Paris, one must always be aware of one's social position. Some things--such as threatening an important member of society in his office--are not done. And the Colonel, could only be your associate, after all. And much as it pains me to say so, your own history with the constabularies of several cities have created an arrest record that would make a passable Russian novel."

      Outside, the maitre d' and a large waiter come up to Jimmy. "I'm sorry, monsieur, this table has been reserved. Tragic oversight. But you must leave. The meal, do not worry about it."

      "Monsieur would not want to make a scene," purrs the waiter.

      "I am a lawyer," starts Jimmy. "A very good one. And if you kick me out--on your fault--you will have hell to pay."

      The two speak rapidly in French. They look at Jimmy. Finally they slink away.

      [Intimidation use by Jimmy.]

      "So, monsieur," continues Gavigan, "this social disaster, should be ended. I am happy to offer you a settlement now that the Colonel has returned to England."

      He hands Blakely a paper with a large figure written on it.

      "That's quite generous," says Freddie.

      "You misunderstand," says Gavigan, "you will pay me."

      Francis and Freddie confer.

      "We are also willing to negotiate," says Gavigan, "although you are clearly wrong. Right now this is a civil matter, but--Devil's Island is lovely this time of year."

      "I would think you'd be a bit generous, given that I prevented you from coming to harm," says Freddie.

      "I was in no real danger," says Gavigan.

      "And I was the one who was hurt. I still have the bandages."

      "I am willing to waive the fee, if you tell me about this alleged meeting with Hypatia Masters."

      "Would this be easier if I switched to French?" says Freddie in French.

      "Yes, although you speak it like a whore," says Gavigan in the same language.

      Francis, who is fluent in French, nods blankly and acts as if he does not understand.

      "Tell me about Miss Masters," says Gavigan. "It is impossible that you have met her, but I wish to know what it is that you saw."

      "It was more along the lines of one of those, whaddaya call 'em, effing lucid dreams. I met her in a dream, in Arabia."

      [I turned off my French accent at this point, and FP switched into a slangy intonation to match his "Lyonaise" accent.]

      "What do you mean?"

      "One minute I'm in Arabia, the next in a nightclub. Middle of Arabia."

      "Near a place called Irem?"

      "Don't know. But it was quite definitely a dream, because in the Empty Quarter, there aren't fountains of water."

      Gavigan switches to English. "I'm sorry, sir, this is no longer a matter for the lawyers."

      "If we stay in French," says Freddie, "Francis can't understand us. He's thoroughly American."

      [Reassurance buy by FP.]

      "Irem of the PIllars is a fantasy, it does not exist. And you claim you met Hypatia Masters in a dream. What did she say she was planning to do."

      "Something about world domination--changing the fate of things--returning...mostly she spoke to Mr. Chiu."

      "One other thing. I believe you met a contact of mine in Egypt. Omar Shakhti Bey."

      "Ah, that bastard. He tried to kill me."

      "Do you know his current location?"

      "I assume in his villa."

      "You give me the lie, sir. He is missing."

      "Well, in my dream, Hypatia killed him. But that was just a dream."

      "Very well. I hope you find the agreement satisfactory, as it will avoid prosecution and the stripping of a large portion of your wealth."

      "Or yours. I was the injured party."

      "Mr. Blakely, I will be frank. This is the Third Republic. If you think you can find a magistrate willing to swear out a complaint against me, you are welcome to try. But you are not French. My attorney will contact your...attorney."

      "He really has a degree."

      "Yes. They give out all kinds of degrees in America."

      [Francis has points in both Law and Medicine--his story is that he dropped out of Med school to go to the war, and studied law in Paris.]

      Freddie and Francis leave just as Jimmy's lunch arrives. Freddie tries to join him, but the waiters wave him off--sorry, almost time to close til dinner--and we just can't let people sit anywhere you want? What are you, some kind of stinking democrat?

      "A dream?" says Francis suspiciously as they slide into a taxi.

      "Some kind of magical fugue state. He knows I lied, but only about it being a dream. Though it does make it clear why Mickey's friends never came back."

      They head back to the hotel they were evicted from, but they have neither a room nor a forwarding address--apparently Sheila did not leave one.

      "I have a couch," says Francis.

      \n So, basically, Sheila's ticked enough to have walked out, at least for the moment, after telling her boss she'd take care of it?

      I'm curious about the relationships between the cult members. I mean, I get, more or less, the Hypatia-Omar dynamic, but I don't quite see where Gavigan fits into it. Mind if I borrow your background for him, even though I'm going to keep the London setting?

      \n Go right ahead! I think it adds a fun dimension to him.

      Sheila doesn't vanish this episode. Mwu-ha-ha...

      I'm still working on the various relationships, and some are spoilerific, but: M'Weru and Shakhti were deadly rivals. M'Weru is N's favorite, and she can generally use that status to cow the other members of the conspiracy--except for Shakhti, who was old and powerful enough to not care. (She could influence him, but only by calling on N himself, which was galling.)

      Hypatia gets along with M'Weru, and didn't like Shakhti; there are hints that they had a centuries-long rivalry. Whatever Hypatia did to become...Hypatia...seems to have annoyed Shakhti, most likely because it ramped up her power level and somehow has left her a more-or-less free agent.

      Gavigan's been the public face of the cult since Penhew "died" in 1919, and de facto head of all operations in Europe. This gives him an enormous amount of power, but he has to balance out the various rivalries--M'Weru doesn't take orders from anyone, and now that Hypatia's back Gavigan has major headaches. He seems to have gotten along well enough with Shakhti (probably because he let Shakhti run his own sphere as he saw fit) and Tewfik is his main cult resource (Tewfik is also a sorcerer, unlike Gavigan.) Tewfik presents his own problems as he was Shakhti's protege and more devoted to him than he could ever be to a European adventurer like Gavigan.

      Huston and Penhew haven't made any appearances yet, and I'm working on their relationship. Penhew seems to be letting things stay hands-off as he works on his own projects. Huston...I have some ideas on that, but they should come in to the next couple of sessions.

      There's also a mysterious figure behind the rest of the conspirators. Jax only called him the "Old Man" and nobody knows anything about him as of yet; I'm pretty sure the PCs don't even realize he exists. (If folks actually read the diary closely, they would realize that the appointment Jax had at the Hotel New Yorker was with him. Folks don't read closely.)

      I have basically worked out what exactly the conspiracy is up to, and it seems to make sense to me, but I'll probably be rewriting that right up to the end of the campaign.

      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Part 3)

      Francis and Freddie head back to Mahoney's. A thin, dour young man is walking out of Mickey's office as he arrives.

      "Sammy me boy," says Mahoney, "journalism not's for you. Why don't ye go back to Dublin, get a teaching job, then maybe come back in a few years. Plenty o' writers could use a good secretary, and you could write yer own stuff at the same time. God, oh, knows that we'll be waiting fer ye when ye get back. Ah, Francis me boy!"

      "We have some information," says Freddie. "First, Mr. Gaffigan does not like to be called Gaffigan. And also why your associates never came back. But first--do you believe in magic?"

      "Do I look like a leprechaun?"

      "Then never mind."



      Back at La Tour d'Argent, a blond woman walks in and asks Jimmy if he had seen an annoying Englishman. "Sheila Brisbane, Mr. Blakely's assistant. Good to see another American--I don't speak any French, and we just got kicked out of our hotel..."

      "How are you alive and sane?" asks Jimmy.

      "It's been pretty close. I was attacked by Arabs in the desert, and I think some Egyptian wanted to kill me. Freddie's mixed up in something, and I just want to go home."

      Jimmy passes over the bottle of Napoleon brandy the appreciative staff brought him.

      "Thanks." Sheila sighs. "Let's just say that you can't compete with somebody who's dead, you know what I mean?"

      "It's unfortunate what happened to Jax."

      "Waitaminute--you know Jax--you know who Freddie is? Listen, if you see Freddie--because apparently I'm not important enough to tell personally--tell him I got us into a tourist hotel on the Left Bank--"

      "Listen. I don't work for Freddie. I'm sure we'll find him."

      Sheila swigs out of the bottle. "Muriel's right. Why am I chasing after this guy? I could go back to the States, make something of myself...maybe meet somebody who will actually marry me. Yeah, Muriel's right. He's supposed to be all torn up about Jax, but she's been dead for months and she didn't even like him anymore."

      [Dr. Mwimbe's full name is Muriel Khadijja Mwimbe. Back in Episode V I laid the groundwork for this--while they were on M's blimp, I made note that they were spending a lot of time together in the lounge, and of course they were alone at the weather station while Freddie and Co. explored Irem.]

      "You know anything about her death?"

      "Just what was in the papers. But when she came back out of nowhere, and weird stuff happened. Her diary is crazy."

      "Uh...do you happen to have it? Could I borrow it?"

      "You know what? Go right ahead." Sheila digs out Jax's battered journal and hands it over to Jimmy. "Just get that back to me, in case his nibs asks me for it."

      "Take some time off, Sheila. I'll keep Freddie off your back."

      "Thanks. What's your name?"

      "Jimmy. Say, you want to have a drink tonight?"

      "That would be lovely." Jimmy walks her to a M\xe9tro station, and then drops the journal off to get a typescript made of it.



      Freddie and Francis talk for some time, about Jax, and her quest, and whether Francis believes in magic (he doesn't). And Hypatia Masters, and her duel with a five thousand year old vampire.

      Francis asks about the Blue Pyramid. He treats the idea of human trafficking with disgust. "And these guys are the ones after you here and in England?"

      "That seems to be about the size of it."

      "I have a friend who knows quite a bit about the nightclub life in Paris. I'm going to run this by him."

      Francis finds his partner Guy Forgeron at his favorite cafe. "Fran\xe7ois! This is Bunny, and this is Jen. They are American co-eds visiting Paris! Isn't that fantastique?"

      "Listen, Guy. Do you know about this place the Blue Pyramid?"

      Guy of course knows it well. He explains that there is a man who "owns" it--an Egyptian named Abdul Nawisha. But the real owner is a spice merchant named Tewfik al-Sayed, another Egyptian.

      "But the thing about Le Pyramide Bleu is that it is being bought, buy some American--nobody seems to know exactly what is going on."

      "Thanks, Guy. I'll call your wife soon and tell her I sent you on a stake-out."

      "A job--oh, I see what you are doing. Tell her I love her. Now girls! This drink is called absinthe..."

      On the way to the M\xe9tro, Freddie suddenly finds several of these posters plastered everywhere:

      \nEpisode VII: Mais la vie s\xe9pare ceux qui s'aiment (Part 4)

      "Oh Donnie, hello old man," says Freddie as Francis enters the tiny apartment. Freddie is smoking at the tiny window. Across the narrow alley Francis' neighbor waves at him.

      "Bon soir, Fran\xe7ois." He hands Freddie back a bottle of wine they are sharing.

      "Martin has great insults!" says Freddie.

      "You hear about that crazy American, Shipley?" Martin asks Francis. "He's making lots of money."

      Francis nods at Martin--like many inhabitants of Montmartre, he's a painter. "Haven't heard of him."

      The apartment is small, but well-kept, perched on the top floor of a dilapidated but neat building. A communal bathroom is at the end of the hall. Inside the apartment there is a living room with a small kitchenette. Two couches face each other--Freddie is to sleep on one; the other looks like it is frequently used as a bed. A tiny bedroom in the back holds a brass bed, carefully made up, that shows no signs of having been slept in recently at all.



      Jimmy meets Sheila at a tourist bar on the Left Bank. "How's it doing?"

      "Better. I talked to Muriel, that always makes me feel better."

      "Who is this Muriel?"

      "She's a doctor--an African. She's traveled with us since New York. She's really brilliant--she's a medical doctor, she studied with Jung, and an anthropologist. She makes me want to do more with my life, you know? I mean, I could be more than a secretary. I went to teacher's college for two years! I could be a teacher! Or a doctor! It's not like I'm living in my mom's world, I mean, I can vote now."

      "Here's your journal back."

      "Oh, thanks! I wasn't sure I was going to see that again, actually."

      "I am an honest man."

      "I know that now." Sheila pauses. "Listen, Jimmy, are you going back to the States anytime soon? Because I kinda want to go home. I love Paris, but I don't have anybody to do it with. I mean...in Cairo he said he was going to spend a lot of time with me, and protect me...but I haven't seen much of him since."

      "Well, you know...we have really short lives."

      "I know! People have tried to kill me. You're right. I'm going to book a trip back, make Freddie pay for it, then give him my resignation. No wait. I'm going to spend a week in London first! Then I'll go home."

      Tuesday 12 May 1925

      "Listen, Donnie, you're a private eye. Do you think you could turn up Sheila?" says Freddie first thing in the morning.

      "Sure. Let me go to the bar first."

      From a caf\xe9, Francis calls Mickey, who tells him that Sheila found a hotel in the 6th arrondissement. Francis tells Freddie, bills him for an hour, and tells him to meet him by Jimmy's hotel, the Lutetia, at four o'clock.

      Freddie drops in at the new hotel. "What ho, Adelaide?"

      "Where the hell have you been? Oh, whatever. It's not like you care. I'm taking the day off and going to the Louvre. If you need me to do anything, that's probably unfortunate."

      "Is there something I've done?"

      "No. That's really the problem. Anyway, I'm late to go see art."

      Freddie convinces Sheila to let him go with her, desperate to placate his secretary and self-described most important person in his life.

      Francis picks up Guy at his house. Forgeron looks like he's been sleeping on a couch too. "Those American girls have no inhibitions! I barely escaped with my life! And then Marie nearly killed me--what did you tell her?"

      They head up to Mickey's place, where they run into Jimmy. Guy promises to set up Jimmy with his brother-in-law Gaston, who can show him the city. (He tells Francis in French that Gaston can use the money.) After swallowing his anger that Jimmy didn't follow Gavigan and his men, Francis tells Jimmy to go found out what he can about Gavigan--nobody knows him at the Foundation, so he can slip in.

      "Arshewyeharoun' Paree," mutters Gaston, as he picks Jimmy up.



      At the Louvre, Sheila and Freddie study the Egyptian artifacts. They find a bas-relief.

      Freddie blinks.

      The faces are familiar to him.

      Penhew.

      Huston.

      Masters.

      And...a strange woman, matching the photograph of "Vanessa" that they found in Jax's diary.

      The relief dates from the time of Cheops. Freddie can recognize the style and it seems correct to him.

      [Art History from Freddie, then he spent some Flattery to talk to one of the curators.]

      "You're not the first person to ask about that piece," says the man, a young grad student. "About a year ago, this American woman saw it and started to scream. Very unusual, we had to call a cop to talk her down."

      "Let me guess. About this high, brunette?"

      "That's the one. I told her that the piece was very well dated, although to be honest, we don't know what the stone is; it's resisted all analysis. All we know is that it's...green. Maybe manufactured, although by a process we have no knowledge of."

      "Very strange."

      "Well...you know, about four years ago there was a break-in here. They say some robed figures were chanting around it, in some weird language. Probably Arabic. But I think that's just what they do to haze me. Still, it's a great honor to be working for the Penhew Foundation..."
