      \n Yeah, but they were Chekhov's bombs--I said way back in Episode VII that Gavigan had been a bombmaker. Also, too, sometimes it's interesting to throw the PCs own methods back at them :-)

      More seriously, Gavigan is cold and ruthless. When he decided it was time to cut bait and move on to the next section of his plan, he acted quite deliberately to destroy his opposition completely and cover his own tracks. (Destroying the Foundation headquarters was a move to both throw suspicion away from him and towards the PCs and to destroy any evidence of his own activities.)

      \nEpisode X: Et l'oc\xe9an de l'oubli brisant nos c\u0153urs et nos t\xeates (Part 3)

      Thursday, 18 June 1925

      They fly to Venice. Francis has managed to fill out (or forge) the paperwork to not only admit them to Italy, but authorize the rather large number of guns they are bringing into the country. ("Of course, Signor. A Browning Automatic Rifle is often required to hunt hippos.") Fortunately, Fascist bureaucracies do enjoy paperwork.

      [Bureaucracy spend by OP. I went and fetched my map of Venice from my last trip there at this point.]

      After docking the plane, they take a quick vaporetto trip to St. Mark's square and locate a modest penzione to lay low in. "You guys need to come up with a plan that doesn't involve me bludgeoning my way through Venice to get to Gavigan," advises Francis; he's a two-fisted investigator, not a drawing-room detective.

      Henry hits the streets--er, canals. He looks up another reporter he knows, Michelangelo Simonetti. Francis drops by on the Carabinieri, to see if they have heard of Gavigan. They tell him that he is a frequent visitor, and has a place "out in the lagoon". Jimmy does what he does best--go out and meet random people, with an uncanny ability to find the right people to talk with.

      [Streetwise--er, Canalwise for HP to have a contact who would be useful; Cop Talk--er, Carabinieri Parlare by OP to meet the cops, and Oral History for JP.]

      Jimmy ends up falling in with some gondolieri who tell him that Gavigan has his own personal water taxi. None of them like his pilot--an Austrian named G\xfcnter, who is pretty stand-offish. They easily give him a description, however. They also say he holds large parties every couple of months, and G\xfcnter transports large groups of people out to the lagoon during that time.

      Simonetti is the crime reporter for the Corriere della Sera newspaper. "Enrico, come va? You find any ghosts under the bed yet? What are you doing in Venezia?"

      "Everything confirms my belief in reality so far. I'm looking into the death of Jackson Elias. Do you know anything about an Edouard Gavigan?"

      "Ah, yes, I heard about the death of Signorina Elias. As for Signor Eduardo, he just got back a few days ago. He doesn't come to the city that often. He has a private villa on the island of Torcello. Used to be a big deal fifteen hundred years ago, before the canals silted up and the Huns came. Anyway, he lands in a plane and heads straight out there, but I can take a look into things if it would help."

      [Real place, real history--Torcello was the major settlement in the lagoon until the events related above happened. I'm developing a lost city theme here. I pulled up a satellite image of the island on my tablet at this point.]

      They decide that they need to 1) scout out the island and 2) follow G\xfcnter around for a day. Francis drops by Jimmy's gondolieri contacts to pick up on G\xfcnter's trail, while Henry and Jimmy rent a boat for some sightseeing. Francis also hits on a plan to track down Gavigan's alcohol suppliers, to see if he can find any patterns or other connections.

      [Accounting spend by OP.]

      Friday, 19 June 1925

      The charter floats off the island of Torcello's northwest coast. Jimmy gives the captain orders to "float casually." Henry snaps photographs from the stern. He can make out a large, boxy villa set back from the shore in a grove of trees. Men armed with shotguns and teams of dogs patrol the beach.

      They swing around the island and make a landing to the east of the villa. They scout up ahead, trying to find a covered route to the main house. Through the trees, Henry can just make out an Egyptian obelisk behind it.

      Francis finds out that G\xfcnter lives on the island, but he does come into Venice to buy supplies--Gavigan orders a lot of booze from Harry Cipriani's. He finds out that large orders for alcohol and food have been placed for delivery in the next day or two. It seems that a party is imminent.

      Francis spends the rest of the morning going from apothecary to apothecary getting large doses of arsenic, strychnine, and cyanide.

      [Streetwise + Reassurance + Medical + 1 point Pharmacy spend. Then OP began to talk about possibly poisoning the wine deliveries. Sigh. PCs and mass murder, amirite?]

      In the afternoon G\xfcnter finally arrives. Francis, waiting at a gondolieri caf\xe9, catches sight of him. He trails the Austrian as he drops in on several stores, arranging deliveries and picking up supplies. At one point, Francis overhears G\xfcnter mentioning that he will be making several runs out to the mainland that night to bring people to the island.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n

      \nEpisode X: Et l'oc\xe9an de l'oubli brisant nos c\u0153urs et nos t\xeates (Part 4)

      Back on Torcello, Henry and Jimmy continue to scout. They can only get so close to the villa--at a certain point, there's nothing but open ground (surprise!) and Jimmy is pretty sure that he can see people in the second story watching the tree line at all times. They notice an electrical generator attached to the house, providing its power. Henry catches a better look at the obelisk--it is on a slight hill, and surrounded by a broad open plain. Based on the pattern of growth of the grass around the obelisk, Henry guesses that larger groups of people gather there fairly regularly.

      Then he catches sight of the bones--piles of bones at the base of the obelisk. They look vaguely human.

      "Jimmy, look at the bones!" he says.

      [The bones are only observable via Outdoorsman. Jimmy doesn't have that, so he shouldn't normally have to make a Stability check--but his Bad Luck meant that Henry pointed it out to him.

      Henry was somehow at 0 Stability by this point, so he narrated the story of his hat (his Symbol) which was worth a 2-point refresh.]

      They watch for a while and get a rough count of the number of guards at the villa--somewhere between 8 and 12, all armed with rifles or shotguns--not double-barreled hunting guns, but good old M1912 "Trench Cleaner" pump actions. Many have sidearms as well.

      [They could have gotten a basic layout of the villa with Architecture--for those of you playing at home, that's the "find secret doors" skill--but neither of them had it.]



      The entire group reconvenes at the penzione. "Here's my plan," says Francis. "I hope someone has a better one.

      "A frontal assault seems impossible. But there's a party tomorrow. I've acquired a large amount of poison."

      Jimmy stares at Francis, mouth agape.

      "The only way we can get to Gaffigan is by poisoning the wine," continues Francis.

      "I'm not poisoning an entire party," says Jimmy.

      "That's all right, provided you have a better idea. Gaffigan attacked us personally, and Hypatia--who is not innocent by any means--did not deserve this."

      [Francis is overprotective towards women.]

      Everyone is lost in their own thoughts for a while, digesting what Francis had said. Jimmy clutches his rabbit's foot, asking it--as he usually does in times of stress--for any insight. The rabbit's foot, however, tells him what it always tells him: "Jimmy, you're the rest of the rabbit."

      Henry wonders if he should tell the rest of the group that while they were in the hotel in Ireland, one night he heard Dr. Mwimbe sobbing her eyes out in her room. He hesitates--he doesn't know them or the doctor very well.

      Francis steps out onto the balcony and smokes a cigarette. He swigs down the last of the Jameson he brought with him from Ireland. He looks down at his lighter, lost in his memories.

      [JP and OP took their Symbol refreshes here.]

      They begin to discuss the plans. Jimmy is adamantly against poisoning everybody, but seems to think it might be possible to target Gavigan specifically. Henry is willing to entertain all ideas. Suddenly, he recalls a detail about the obelisk that gives him pause--Egyptian obelisks didn't normally have iron rings driven into them.

      "I think we're better off not stepping foot on the island at all," he says.

      [Hard Driver time, though, for Henry--Thirst for Knowledge and an occult reporter with his first evidence of the occult? Yeah, he had to go, and picked up 2 points of Stability.]

      They begin to put together a plan. Gavigan doesn't know Henry at all, so he could possibly be inserted into the party staff--he speaks French, so sommelier suggests itself. However, he doesn't know much about wine.

      [CR 3 for Henry. He doesn't know wines.]

      Jimmy tries to teach Henry a few basics, but it's been a long time since he dined that well. Francis thinks for a while, and then decides to go pick up the actual sommelier.

      [I thought with Streetwise he might go to the laundry or a tailor, but instead OP decided to go after the actual employee!]

      Gavigan has a regular wine butler for his villa, but for a party this big he hires a sommelier. Francis goes looking for him.

      Jimmy heads down to the carabinieri. With his usual luck, he finds the right guy right away--the detective who handles the cold cases and unsolvable murders. Specifically, the ones where a dead Arab girl occasionally washes up on shore. Jimmy realizes that this is where all the girls taken from Le Pyramide Bleu have been taken, and that Plan C (dropping a bomb on the villa) will probably kill a bunch of innocents. (And poisoning the wine might do so as well, if the cultists get the girls drunk.)

      Saturday, 20 June 1925

      The night before the New Moon

      At lunch, Francis finally spots someone who could be his target--an elegantly dressed man who speaks Italian with a French accent. When he angrily sends away a bottle of wine, he knows he's got his man.

      Francis plops down across from him and rips away his copy of La Prenza.

      "Come va," says the man, angrily. Francis refuses to respond. "Tu veut quelque chose? You want something, mac?"

      "You're going to call in sick tonight."

      "I don't know what you're talking about."

      "That's fine. It's not in your interest to go. Your life is not worth even that much money."

      "What are you saying? Are you threatening my life?"

      "What do you think I'm doing?"

      [1-pt Intimidation spend.]

      Of course, Francis knows he's actually saving the guy's life in all likelihood. He shows the sommelier some stories about the Blue Pyramid and some pictures of the obelisk. The Frenchman agrees not to go, helped by Francis packing his bags for him.

      Together, they return to the penzione. Jimmy calls in a tailor to alter Claude the sommelier's suit for Henry's frame, and Francis brings in a shady engraver to make a copy of Claude's invitation for Charleston, who has decided to infiltrate the party as a cultist. Infiltrate, that's the ticket, yeah.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      • \n
    • \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n\nAviatrix \n\n\n

      \n
      \n
      \nEpisode X: Et l'oc\xe9an de l'oubli brisant nos c\u0153urs et nos t\xeates (Part 5)

      They begin to finalize their plan. Charleston and Henry will infiltrate the party, while Francis and Jimmy will do a commando-style raid on the house. They'll use Joyce and her plane to evacuate anyone they find from the island. Jimmy prepares a disguise for Charleston, making him look older, and they dress him in one of the several yellow robes they have acquired between Cairo and Paris.

      Henry receives a crash course in wine from Claude the sommelier, and then dresses in the summer formal white jacket.

      They work out a signal between Charleston and Henry--if Henry calls out for the "wines of Castemere", that will be Charleston's signal to start killing. As a backup, they give Henry fake glasses so that if Charleston can't hear him, Henry will put on the glasses.

      Henry meets G\xfcnter at 4 pm. He has his credentials checked, and then boards the boat for Torcello along with the rest of the servants. While Charleston--er, "Master Pan"--waits for his turn to be ferried out to the island, Francis and Jimmy take their chartered boat out to the east coast of Torcello and begin sneaking cross country.

      Henry mills about on the villa grounds once he arrives. A large banquet is being set on tables outside. Summoning up as much aplomb as he can muster, he gives orders for the wine. He sees some girls being led out of the villa and then chained to the obelisk.

      "Don't worry," says a goon. "This is all part of the show. They're dancers."

      Around 5:30, Charleston meets the water taxi for his trip to the island. A surprisingly well-heeled crowd is shuffling on board, including several Chinese gentlemen. When he gets to the island, he finds a place to sit and drink some wine. He notices people wheeling out five machines that vaguely resemble spotlights. Supervising their installation is Henry Clive.

      Gavigan finds Henry. "Claude, yes? Didn't I meet you in Paris?"

      "Possibly."

      "Anyway, I need something dry for the Italians, something sweet for the Germans, and I don't know what the Chinese are drinking. But this is important--for my personal table, only these three bottles. You have no discretion in that, understand?"

      "Oui, monsieur."

      "Good. There will be something extra in your envelope at the end of the night."

      Meanwhile Francis and Jimmy manage to sneak up to the house, using the chaos of the party to sneak past the guards. As they approach the villa, they hear the sound of horns blowing--something like a shofar.

      The partygoers make their way to gather around the obelisk. At that point, the strange machines begin to project eerie green beams in the air, which converge at a point above the obelisk. Charleston studies the projectors and the point they converge on--it's some kind of portal, but it seems somehow different than other portals he's studied.

      [Cthulhu Mythos spend by CP. I let him choose how much Stability he wanted to lose--he went for a 3-point loss, so I told him not only was it a portal, but that it was different. Had he gone for the full 4-point loss, I would have told him it opened up a direct line to Azathoth.]

      Charleston also notices that some of the engravings on the obelisk and the various decorations seem to resemble some of the signs he saw in the temple of the Cult of the Bloody Tongue in New York.



      Jimmy and Francis easily bypass the locks on the villa doors. They enter the great hall of the building and begin to look for a way to the basement. Jimmy recalls Gavigan's predilection for secret rooms, so together they search the fireplace. Francis finds a passageway down to a "panic room", a secret chamber with no exit.

      Jimmy finds a stairway leading down to a corridor lined with cells. At the far end is another room that looks like some kind of workroom. Five girls are being held in the cells.

      "Shhhh," whispers Francis as he works on the unlocking the cells.



      Gavigan begins to give a speech. "We must remember our losses this year," he says. "Omar Shakhti. Tewfik al-Sayed..."

      The Arabic contingent looks annoyed at the mention of their fallen leaders.

      Henry pours some wine into a decanter and adds some poison to it. He hands Gavigan a glass, who holds it idly in one hand. He looks around at the extremely rich and important people gathered at his table. He nods at them and they drink a toast to him--from the special three bottles he specifically ordered Henry to use.

      Then they all drop dead, except for Gavigan. "Au revoir, mes amis," he says. He seems to notice the glass in his hands.

      Gavigan raises his glass. Henry begins to sweat slightly. For a second the rim of the glass touches his lips. Henry holds his breath. Gavigan is about to drink. His face darkens. He sniffs the glass.

      Then he stares at Henry. He makes a quick hand sign and some guards begin to make their way towards Henry.

      [It was a Filch test to successfully switch out Gavigan's glass for one with poison in it. The TN was 6. HP spent both his Filch points and rolled a 3, for a 5 total--so close. For the record, I'd have let them kill Gavigan had they rolled higher.]

      \nEpisode X: Et l'oc\xe9an de l'oubli brisant nos c\u0153urs et nos t\xeates (Part 6)

      "Mon Dieu," says Henry. "That was not quite the right wine. Bring out the red wines of Castamere!"

      Gavigan shouts in Aklo at his goons--Charleston understands him, but almost nobody else. "Kill the sacrifices, prevent anyone else from leaving."

      Several men draw out knives and advance on the girls chained to the obelisk. Two men with shotguns head towards Henry. The crowd begins to mill about. Henry pounces on one of the men with the shotgun and tries to wrestle the gun out of his hands.

      ["Two people, one gun" is the rule here--a Scuffling contest for control of the gun. I don't love this rule--contests eat points at a hideous rate; I'm thinking of house ruling it as a one-round zero sum contest.]

      The gunsel snarls and rips the gun from Henry's grasp and then smashes the butt of the gun into his face.

      Charleston raises his hands and begins to chant in Aklo. Nothing happens for a while. Back in the penzione, Noor watches Charleston's gun raise out of its violin case and begin to assemble itself as it sails out of the window.

      "Already?" she says to herself. "It's not even 6:30."

      The gun sails several miles across the water before slipping into--over--what the hell is it doing to Charleston's arm?



      In the basement of the villa, Francis begins to lead the girls up to the surface. He hands a flask of absinthe to Jimmy. "Go burn everything down here," he says.

      Jimmy runs down the hallway and enters Gavigan's work room--a bigger and grander version of the secret room he had found under the Fondation headquarters in Paris. Hideous paintings hang from the wall, and arcane symbols are carved into the floor. Weird chemical and alchemical devices fill several large tables.

      On a desk in the corner of the room, Jimmy finds a fat ledger book that he slips into his satchel. He also finds a very small book, printed on flash paper, filled with groups of seemingly random letters. He sucks his breath--this must be the one-time pad codebook!

      He grabs the little book and then splashes alcohol on everything in reach. He sets a fire and retreats up the hall, confident that it will take a while for the fire to catch. So he is somewhat surprised when a fireball from the room behind him knocks him flat in the hallway, which quickly is engulfed in flames.

      [Jimmy's Bad Luck hits here--the room was filled with weird chemical vapors, and lit up much faster than he expected.]



      The stock of the Tommy gun has transformed into tentacles that wrap around Charleston's arm. Instead of a 50-shot drum, it has a pulsating blue egg sack. When he fires the gun, it shoots tiny eggs into its targets--eggs that immediately hatch into hideous little tentacled arachnids.

      [This was all CP--he built off me reminding him that he hasn't yet listened to Cthulhu--you know, the guy he sold his soul to--and so he spun up this truly horrifying description of his gun. I was left wondering if his own Source of Stability could itself provoke a Stability check.]

      "I forgot to feed it!" says Charleston, apologetically. "I never had a pet before!"

      By "feeding" he means that he has to kill an indiscriminate number of people, of course.

      Henry barely has time to get to his feet when he sees the five girls chained to the obelisk get their throats cut by Gavigan's men. Then as Charleston begins to fire at random into the crowd, he and the gunsels hit the deck.

      Francis and Jimmy manage to run out of the villa, which is now completely engulfed in fire. Men with guns converge on their position. Francis runs at them, leaps up, and spins around, firing at one of thugs with his pistol. As he rotates, his trenchcoat whirling open, he draws his sawed-off shotgun and fires both barrels at another thug. He lands on one knee, doves unaccountably fluttering around him, glowing pink in the dying light of sunset.

      Then the villa explodes behind him.

      [Special guest director: John Woo.

      OP came up with the move, and we all got into the HK spirit on it.]



      Something begins to come through the portal. Henry decides that discretion is definitely the better part of valor and tries to take off. He has just reached the edge of the clearing when a crowd of people bowl him over. He watches an elephant-sized, insectoid, featherless bird creature flap through the portal and into the sky, screeching horribly, accompanied by a hideous stench.

      [TN 6 Fleeing check; Henry just missed it. Tant pis--wasn't his day. Charleston managed to blow his Stability check rather badly here--he spent, but failed anyway to drop to -1 Stability: permanent 1 pt rating drop, loss of a point of Sanity.]

      Another one of the creatures--which Charleston recognizes as a Shantak--comes through the portal. The two of them feed on the corpses of the girls.

      Charleston looks around for Gavigan, and spots him running towards a boat waiting on the beach, with Clive in tow. He also notices that the people Gavigan had poisoned have begun to get up and chase the still-living members of the party. Much worse, the people that they bite to death tend to get up themselves and begin to chase anyone living nearby.

      [Gavigan was working on apocalypse zombies.]

      \nEpisode X: Et l'oc\xe9an de l'oubli brisant nos c\u0153urs et nos t\xeates (Part 7)

      Francis and Jimmy reach the other side of the island along with the five girls they rescued. As Joyce taxis the Fokker in towards shore, Francis fires off a flare to signal for their charter boat to come in to pick the rest of them up. He tells Jimmy to take the girls aboard the plane, and soon it soars into the darkening sky.

      An elephant-sized flying creature flaps grotesquely into the air to intercept the plane.

      "What the fu--" says Joyce. Stunned at the appearance of the Shantak, she goes limp. The plane begins to dip. Jimmy races to the cockpit.

      "You've got to snap out of it!" he says. "Remember, uh, booze--and lady friends--and you've got to get home to get them! So fly the plane!"

      [Reassurance spend by JP. Since this is Joyce-as-a-NPC, she has mundane Stability--probably about 4--but I often don't even roll for NPCs in a situation like this. She got stunned by the Mythos shock.]

      "Right, right," mutters Joyce. She pulls back on the stick and the plane begins to climb again. But the Shantak keeps pace, shrieking as it follows the plane higher.

      Jimmy races to the back of the plane. "Dump some fuel!" he shouts at Joyce.

      "Not sure that's a great idea, but..." She hits the emergency fuel release.

      Jimmy opens the door on the side of the cabin. For the first time he gets a good look at the monster, and he screams long and loud at it.


      "This is not reality!" shouts Henry. "Not reality!"

      [Henry is based on Sam Neill's character from "In the Mouth of Madness".]

      He and Charleston eventually rendezvous with Francis and wade out to the boat. They begin to motor across the lagoon, watching the Shantak chasing the plane.

      "That looks like our plane!" says Charleston.

      "It is our plane!" says Francis. "Jimmy and the girls are on it!"

      Charleston considers casting the Hoy-Dhin chant, but remembers that Shantaks fly through the void of interstellar space and so can't be suffocated.



      Jimmy, ever practical, stops screaming and rummages in the crate of guns that Francis bought in Ireland. He pulls out a Browning Automatic Rifle and rests it against the door frame.

      [Preparedness roll by JP]

      He pulls the trigger and runs out the entire magazine in a single long burst. Bullets rip into the creature; many bounce off its tough hide, but a few manage to hit the eyes and beak, enraging it. It springs forward, diving into the spray of fuel.

      One wing reaches out and smashes into the tail of the plane--

      As Jimmy calmly drops the BAR--

      --the plane begins to tumble and then drop into a steep dive--

      --and draws a flare gun from his coat--

      --the girls scream as the plane begins to drop. The Shantak shrieks and juts its head forward--

      --as Jimmy loads the flare and fires it at the creature--

      --the explosion lights up the sky. The Shantak howls in pain and confusion and turns away--

      --as Jimmy drops the flare gun and pulls the door shut--

      "Brace for--" says Joyce. The plane smashes nose first into the water before she can finish. Jimmy sails down the length of the plane and smashes into a bulkhead.

      [JP had some very lucky damage rolls here--the BAR actually did damage to the shantak, which isn't easy (it has very high armor.) The fuel-air explosion also did close to max damage. His bad luck hit here again, though--I said that Jimmy could either brace himself for the crash, or close the door. The former would have kept him from taking damage, but flooded the plane and killed Joyce and probably most or all of the girls. Jimmy decided to take the damage. He's a Big Damn Hero.]



      Francis guides the boat towards the crash. Burning oil floats on the water. The plane has settled a bit by the nose, exposing the tail and the rear hatch. Charleston leaps out of the boat, jumping from bit of wreckage to piece of flotsam, and nimbly hops up onto the plane. He throws open the hatch. Henry and Francis follow, picking their way through the wreckage.

      Jimmy dives under water and swims into the cockpit. He cuts Joyce free from her seat belt and then hauls her back into the tail. Francis and Charleston pull them out into the water and start ferrying them back to the plane. Francis pushes through burning oil, shoving wreckage out of his way as he personally carries three girls to safety. He flops back into the boat when he is done, completely exhausted.

      [Francis has a low Athletics score--he had to piggyback on Charleston's roll to get over to the plane. To take a girl back to their boat was a one point spend per girl; this would have made it difficult for Francis to swim back to the boat himself. FP asked if he could spend Health instead, and I agreed, at a 3-to-1 ratio. He spent 9 points, going to 0 Health.]

      Henry and Charleston begin to swim back to the plane, but the oil and flames disorient him. Henry panics--he's exhausted and can barely swim--and the two of them begin to slip under the waves.

      [Henry was out of Athletics, which caused the piggyback check TN to go to 5; Charleston failed and they began to drown. Both took damage the first round of drowning.]

      Charleston makes a supreme effort and makes it back to the surface. He rolls out of the water and into the boat, then reaches down and pulls Henry in behind him. As the boat races away towards the mainland, riding about a foot above the water, the plane explodes behind them.

      [Special guest director: Michael Bay. Stuff just blew up this episode.]

      \n And at that point, I looked at the clock, and even though we'd slotted another 15 minutes for the session, I opined that I didn't think I could come up with a better stopping point than this.

      All in all I thought it was a pretty good close to the Paris chapter. The number of explosions was higher than even I anticipated, but what the heck--this was an action episode. The team of Jimmy and Francis once again proved to be the People Who Move the Plot. I've already told both their players that if they somehow manage to survive the campaign, I want to do a spinoff with them--I might run "Shadows Over Filmland", with J & F as private eyes in 1930s Hollywood...

      \n Missed these before.\n
      Clever -- I may borrow the explosion thing, at least as far as the Foundation is concerned. What is his plan, again? Mind, if Hypatia survived the blast, I'm not sure who I'd bet on in a war.

      The chemical back up is / was a real thing?
      \nThis was, more or less, Gavigan's master plan:

      He knew that he was at a bit of a disadvantage in the Conspiracy--not a sorcerer, and probably never going to be able to advance beyond where he is now. He knows the other factions are maneuvering to come out on top if and when The Big N's master plan kicks off.

      What he decided to do was take the existing "magical technology" he had access to in order to produce a Doomsday Weapon--something he could hold over the rest of the conspiracy, some weapon so terrible that he could win just by threatening to use it.

      What he went for was Apocalypse Zombies. Zombies have already been shown to exist, but only via a long enchantment process. But Gavigan had access to a werewolf or two; so what he was looking for was a way to cross the contagiousness of lycanthropy with undead animation. This was why he kept such a tight lock on Eloise, and why he dispatched sorcerers to study/sample her.

      Of course, being Gavigan, he had another line running through this. By using Eloise to create the mystic apocalypse zombie contagion, his plan was to imprint the zombies created with a willingness to follow/obey/love him. Sympathetic magic and all that. He was also working on "suicider" strains that would "die" after a certain period of time.

      This was hinted at in places. The thing in the box that Jimmy encountered was an apocalypse zombie prototype. There was his interest (beyond his love for her, of course) in Eloise. Had the PCs been more intrigued, they could have found more of this out.

      The opening of the gate on Torcello was both a rehearsal for the main event and the necessary catalyst to finally kick off the apocalypse zombie tests. After that demonstration, he could show the rest of the Conspiracy what he was capable of.

      Hypatia's return was a major threat to all this; he rightly assumed that her presence in Paris was a direct threat to him, and she certainly was moving fast. She had begun to recruit her Amazon corps to be her fanatically loyal followers, and she was muscling in to pick up the cultists left in limbo by the death of Tewfik. Of course, from Gavigan's perspective, the PCs sure looked like they were pawns of Hypatia aimed at him, no matter what the other members of the Conspiracy told him. This finally provoked him to take them all out in a single stroke--this was mostly clinched by his confrontation with Francis, but Gavigan is never afraid of the bold move.

      As for chemical timers, they are indeed one way to set a time bomb--during WWII the British used them extensively as a way to smuggle bombs into places where mechanical timers would be noticed or inconvenient. (The bomb used in the attempt on Hitler's life was of this type--they wanted to avoid any ticking noise.) While I don't know much about bombmaking, it seemed reasonable to me that a belt-and-suspenders guy like Gavigan would want to make sure that even if the mechanical trigger was blocked, the bomb would still go off.

      \nEpisode XI: Tonight That's Where I'll Be

      [So! New player for this session--we'll call him KP. I hoped he would be a permanent addition, but sadly this turned out to be his only session. We miss you, KP, and by the way, what was Kafka like?

      You can tell I thought this would be a long-term addition because hey, I wrote yet another Fiasco playset. For this one, I decided to try a few new things.

      First, even more than the other playsets, I wanted to generate ties to Jackson Elias. With that in mind, I already had my subject--Jax's last birthday party in New York City, shortly before she left for Africa. Then, to strengthen that even further, I made all the locations have to do with her--and I added a bit of a twist.

      You see, while each location was tied to a specific place, over half of them were tied as well to a specific       time--each of the temporal locations was an incident in Jax's life. I've included notes on the PDF to explain what each of them meant.

      I don't think I've ever seen that in a playset before, so hey Jason Morningstar, if you read this thread have a look! Unfortunately, it makes the playset really tied to my own work (it actually included the specific backstories of several PCs), but feel free to hack the idea if you want. I mean, I guess if you ever wanted to follow in my footsteps and run your own version of my hack...well, for God's sake, stop! This thing is driving       me to distraction :-)

      I don't have my notes on the playset setup handy, so I'll do the locations & relationships from memory and fix them when I can. I asked that we stick to only setting scenes in the locations chosen, and we did except for some stuff FP put in.

      Jimmy--Fritz: Novelist and biggest fan

      Jimmy--Francis: Private Eyes (natch)

      Francis--Fritz: Snitches

      Jax--Fritz: Shared accommodations for a while

      The locations:

      Jonah Kensington's Apartment: Site of the party, July 1924

      The White Star Line Pier July, 1924. I had thought this would be where people would say goodbye to Jax, but FP went a different direction.

      Archangel, Russia: Jax corresponded from here in 1919

      Miskatonic Amazon Expedition February, 1920. Jackson accompanied the expedition and used the material she gathered for her first book.

      The Workers' Accident Insurance Institute offices, Prague Sometime in 1920 or 1921, Jackson stayed here while en route to India.

      We had an object as well, a traveller's atlas that came with a small leatherbound journal. This was Jimmy's present to Jax, and she ended up writing her infamous journal entries in it.]

      July, 1924. The White Star Lines Pier

      As Fritz Krakauer, author, steps onto the pier, catches sight of Freddie Blakely, whom he had known briefly while in England.

      "What ho, Felix! Haven't seen you since that night I saw you and Alma, and those two other fellows...are you still so flexible?"

      "Not really. It is good to see you."

      "I suppose I'm here to take you to the party."

      As they get into a cab and head towards Washington Square, Franz tries to hunch down in the seat.

      Jonah's Apartment, Washington Square. July, 1924

      Jimmy steps into the crowded apartment, full of smoke and stuffed with people. Booze is everywhere.

      A woman in a white dress pushes her way through the crowd to him. "Jimmy! I'm so happy you came!"

      "Jax! Happy birthday!"

      "Thank you, Jimmy." She leads him into a less noisy part of the room. "Were you able to look into that stuff on the Carlyle expedition I asked you to check out for me?"

      "Uh, Definitely. You know me!"

      He hands over a rather thin folder.

      "Oh," says Jax as she scans the contents. "I was hoping you'd be able to get the psychiatrist's files on Carlyle."

      "Well, you know how psychiatrists are...confidentiality and all that..."

      "Yeah, but they're all dead, right? So who cares? I thought you were a pretty persuasive guy, Jimmy."

      "Ah...yeah...sorry...am I supposed to mingle?"

      "Yes, Jimmy, you're supposed to mingle. I think that Francis is here."

      At that moment Fritz Krakauer enters the apartment. He looks around nervously and soon comes face to face with Jackson and Jimmy.

      "Jimmy Wright."

      "Fritz Krakauer."

      Jimmy boggles. "Are you the one--who wrote that--I'm your biggest fan! I loved that book you wrote!"

      "I dunno," says Jax. "I thought it was a little derivative of Kafka."

      "Nein! Not Kafka! It was all mine!"

      "I'm a private investigator myself," says Jimmy.

      "A very dangerous occupation."

      "Not really. Most danger I face is when a client is late paying me."

      "Well, since you have a very safe job...allow me to show you this policy," says Fritz, opening up his suitcase.



      Jimmy wanders around looking for Francis, clutching his life insurance policy. "Francis!"

      O'Donnell ducks out of the shadows. "Hello, Jimmy," he says with a sigh.

      "Francis, this is my favorite author!"

      Francis stiffens when he recognizes Krakauer. "How nice to finally meet you he says."

      "Yes," says Fritz, "how nice to meet you as well."

      The Amazon, February 1920

      Rain pounds down upon the forest. A figure, dressed in jungle khakis, looms out of the mist, a Thompson wrapped in oilcloth slung over a shoulder. He walks briskly to a cabin made of corrugated tin and throws open the door.

      Inside is a man tied to a chair, with a bag over his head.

      Francis O'Donnell pulls the bag off the man's head. "WHERE'S JAX!" he screams.

      "I don't know!" sputters Fritz Krakauer.

      Paris, 1923

      Fritz Krakauer closes his book and sits down. The nice woman from the Socialist Artist's Council stands up. "Thank you, Monsieur. We all enjoyed that reading very much. And now, our meeting is concluded. Please enjoy the refreshments."

      There is polite applause all around. A young woman comes up to Fritz's table. "That was such a lovely book, monsieur, although I'm afraid I didn't understand it very well. I'm a singer, you see, and not that literary. That's more my husband's interest."

      Trying to hide his disappointment that this beautiful girl (who is actually talking to him) is married, Fritz looks up from his tea. "Thank you, Frau--"

      "O'Donnell," she says. "Isabelle O'Donnell. My husband is an American. There he is, over in the corner."

      Hearing his name, Francis looks up from the notes he has been taking on this meeting of possible subversives (surely his clients in the Deuxi\xe8me Bureau will be interested). He glances at Krakauer, and then stares--first in surprise, and then in a glare of menace.

      Krakauer tries to hide behind his teacup.

      Prague, 1920

      A young brunette woman walks up to an apartment building and begins ringing a doorbell. The name on the plate next to the buzzer is Franz Krakauer.

      After several moments of buzzing, the shutters on an upstairs window are thrown open and a young man's face appears. "Are you Fritz Krakauer?" says the woman.

      "Ja?"

      "Jackson Elias, I'm the one who's taking that room your family has to rent. Hey, I read your stuff. I thought it was pretty good. A little derivative of Kafka."

      "Why does everybody keep saying that? I've never even met him! Now I'm sorry, fr\xe4ulein, but I'm late for work--"

      "Oh, I'll walk with you." She waits until Krakauer, carrying two suitcases and a bundle of papers, emerges from the front door.

      "What is your profession, Jackson?" asks Krakauer as they walk towards his job at the Workers' Accident Insurance Institute.

      "I'm a writer."

      "Very dangerous profession, ja?"

      "You know, it is for me."

      "Perhaps you'd like some insurance? I have some at a really decent rate."

      "I don't think I need Czechoslovakian insurance, thanks."

      "Ah, but you are in Czechoslovakia, are you not?"

      "Well, how can I argue with ironclad logic like that? But I really don't need a policy." She looks up at the building. "Say, doesn't Kafka work here?"

      "Does he? I've never even heard of this man Kafka."

      "Shall I meet you for lunch? I have some people to meet--spiritualists mainly. I'm writing a book debunking them."

      \nEpisode XI: Tonight That's Where I'll Be (Prologue Part 2)

      Jonah's Apartment, July 1924

      "Jax! Jax!" says Jimmy, wandering around the party, clutching a prettily-wrapped package. "Oh, hi Freddie."

      "What ho, Scotty. Still investigating?"

      "Yes, I have my own office now. I'm a private investigator."

      "Didn't you use to work for me? I seem to remember giving you a paycheck."

      "You give everyone a paycheck."

      Archangel, Russia, 1919

      Snow swirls under a dark and cloudy nighttime sky. Three figures walk towards a stone cottage. One of the men shoves open the door.

      Inside is a man tied to a chair, with a bag on his head. The man reaches forward and rips off the bag.

      "Where's Jax!" shouts Freddie.

      "I ain't telling you nothing," says Francis O'Donnell, struggling futilely against his bonds. "You're with the Reds."

      "Comrade Freddie, should I shoot him?" asks Alphonse Gilbert. He is wearing the uniform of a Commissar.

      "You're all using her!" spits Francis.

      "Using her!" says Freddie. "I want to marry her."

      "What?"


      [That was the end of Act I. The tilt was:

      Quotable: I have a cunning plan.

      Folly: A single moment of miraculous luck.

      I had wanted to do quotable for a while.]


      The White Star Line pier, July, 1924. The day after the party

      "Thanks for bringing me down here, Herr Wright."

      "No problem. Freddie was...well...tied up."

      "Ja, you mean that horrible fight he was having with Fr\xe4ulein Elias?"

      "Right."

      They walk along the water, watching a ponderous steam liner fight the tide towards the pier. Jimmy glances around casually, and then freezes.

      "Fritz, you see that black car down there?"

      "Ah, the one surrounded by all those Italian gentlemen?"

      "I recognize some of those guys. That's Lucky! And that guy of his, Al something...the cleaner, they call him. They only bring him around when the have to tidy up a crime..."

      Jimmy's eyes go wide. "Come on, Fritz!"

      "What are you doing? Where are we going? Why are you throwing me off this pier--"

      A tremendous explosion tears up the decking all around them. Jimmy swan dives into the water. After a very long time he surfaces, dragging Fritz with him. Soon they have clambered out of the water and lay exhausted amid the burning wreckage.

      "I can't believe I saved my favorite author's life!" beams Jimmy. "Boy, it's lucky for you I was there."

      "Lucky," says Fritz, and coughs up a pint of brackish North River water.

      The Amazon, February 1920

      "If I hadn't had lunch with her," begins Fritz for the hundredth time, "I wouldn't have been fired for being late, and then I never would have gone on this insane expedition with her, and then I never would have made the unpleasant acquaintance of you, O'Donnell. How do you carry this thing?" he moans, trying to shoulder his enormous Enfield rifle.

      "Everybody get down," shouts Francis, shouldering his Thompson. There's a flash of white in the clearing ahead, and he fires a burst.

      Jackson falls down on the ground, knocked back by the bullet that has just grazed her shoulder. "Is there anything you do that doesn't involve me getting shot?" she screams at Francis.

      "Get down!" he bellows, charging forward with a scream.

      Fritz chucks his rifle into the bush and chases after them.


      Some hours later, the three of them are holed up in a different hut, which is surrounded by several paramilitary troopers.

      "You goddamned idiots," says Jax. "Do any of you speak Portuguese?"

      "What were you even doing down here?" barks Francis.

      "I was on a university expedition!"

      "Right. A university expedition to Communists!"

      "What?"

      "These are all Marxist revolutionaries!"

      "Good for them!"

      "Why were they chasing you around, then?"

      "Nobody started chasing me until people started shooting at them!"

      "My bad," says Fritz.

      "Wait," says Francis. "I think they're going to--"

      There is a shout from the woods. Twenty or thirty soldiers charge forward. Francis pulls the trigger of his Thompson, but the magazine is empty. Horrified, he realizes that they'll all be overrun--

      Until the Marxists run straight into a minefield the government forces had planted the night before. Explosions rip through the forest. The hut is knocked completely down, leaving a mostly intact Jackson, Francis, and Fritz.

      "I can't go anywhere with you," say Jackson and Francis simultaneously.



      The explosion makes Jimmy a hero. He gets hired by even more high profile clients.

      Francis is decorated for his work in Archangel. He has the pleasure of putting Freddie on the boat back for England, where the F. O. wants to talk to him. He decides to stay in Europe for a few months, rather than going back to America, and boards a transport to France.

      One night, he is out smoking on the deck when he sees a young woman in a nurse's uniform singing quietly in French. He is amazed--in the moonlight she is the most beautiful person he has ever seen. Silently, he offers her a cigarette.

      "Thank you, monsieur--"

      "O'Donnell." He looks in her eyes. "Francis."

      "My name is Isabelle..."

      \nTonight That's Where I'll Be (Part 1)

      [So that was the Fiasco playset. Not as brilliant as some of our other work--the Wild Party was probably the best of the three--but enough to go on. I think the concept was sound, but I probably needed to do more footwork to sell it. Also, FP really doesn't get Fiasco--I mean, he understands it, he just doesn't like to frame dramatic scenes.

      Anyway, on to the actual episode, which features the return of Freddie Blakely, the final resolution of the Gavigan storyline, and a homecoming for Dr. Mwimbe. The episode title is a bit obscure, unless you know that I was raised on Long Island, and that the action takes place in Zanzibar...]

      ...sometime before...

      Freddie gradually comes awake in a metal hospital bed. He has vague memories of loud noises, bright light, and people yelling at him. He notices James Gardner, formerly of the Clive expedition, sitting on a chair next to the bed, chain smoking as usual.

      "Hullo, Gardner, this Egypt?"

      "M wants to see you," he says, standing up.

      Freddie is led to a large conference room. He has no idea where he is, other than a vague idea that he is underground. Paintings line the walls, of groups of people. One painting has someone who looks very much like M. The people in it are dressed in fashions from about thirty-five years earlier.

      "Gardner, is that our boss?"

      "I've discovered that it's best not to ask questions."

      Tea is brought. They're still English, after all.

      M finally comes in.

      "What ho, Auntie!"

      "Mr. Blakely, did I ever give you any indication that you should attempt to contact the Foreign Office?"

      "You didn't give me any forwarding address."

      "Let's follow that chain of thought, shall we? Mr. Blakely, did I give you the impression that I worked for the Foreign Office."

      "I rather thought you did."

      "No, Mr. Blakely. I work with the Empire, not for it. Our interests happen to coincide at the moment. It was easier for Colonel Pearkes to believe the connection was more direct."

      "Well, I'm not a citizen of the Empire."

      "As far as that goes, you may yet be one. It seems you gave a most remarkable speech at Commons."

      "I don't remember that."

      "Indeed. It was good enough that Baldwin allowed a vote of conscience and the Bill failed on third reading. Winston was very impressed."

      She picks up an envelope and opens it. Pieces of a passport flutter down. "However, it seems you are not a citizen of the German Reich. It turns out they made a mistake in the paperwork. And at the moment, your British passport has been confiscated. Fear not, we will get you out.

      "Unfortunately, Mr. Blakely, since you did not confront your attackers, we don't know who was behind it, except that they are very highly placed indeed. I am sure they have not forgotten you, however."

      An elderly woman enters the room. "Ah, Mrs. Broadmoor," says M. "Mr. Blakely, I apologize for being rude, but you probably are noticing the room getting rather dim right now..."

      Everything goes black for a while. Groggily, Freddie slowly comes to.

      A somberly-suited man is standing in front of him, wearing a bowler hat.

      Nothing unusual, thinks Freddie. He has a green apple for a head. I can deal with that. Must be the drug.

      "These drugs are amazing," he says aloud.

      "Ah, monsieur, you suffer from a misapprehension," says the...man? in a heavy French accent. "You are in a dream, not a drug stupor. You are here to meet...ah, well, here she comes now."

      M comes walking up out of the gloom. As she does, Freddie can see things more distinctly. He seems to be standing on the shore of a very still lake, at evening when the sky is still lit even as night creeps in under the eaves of the forest surrounding them.

      Something seems indefinably younger about M. Freddie realizes then that she is not wearing her trademark red scarf; he'd never seen her without it before.

      "Come walk with me, Freddie," she says. "I'm sorry about all this, but it was the only way we could be sure of having a secure conversation."

      They walk for a while along the shore. "Freddie, I'm afraid we're going to have to cut you loose now."

      "What? You never even gave me any orders! I was left to fight Russian gangsters and whatnot."

      "You do live a most interesting life. Fortunately you have a most excellent valet."

      "Why don't you hire him then?"

      "We did. He came looking for you, and almost found you. We admired that initiative."

      [Freddie decided to make Alphonse his new Solace, to replace Sheila; I got the okay for this from GP.]

      "Well, don't worry," says M. "We'll send you back to your friends."

      "And my personal secretary?"

      "I'm sorry, we don't know where she is."

      "I see. Is there anywhere you want me to go?"

      "Don't worry, we'll take care of all that."

      "Well, is there anything you want me to look into?"

      "I shall miss these conversations."

      "I won't! This is an exercise in frustration! You're worse than N and H put together!"

      "What a remarkable compliment," says M, as the dream begins to fade away.

      \n

      \nTonight That's Where I'll Be (Part 2)

      Athens, Greece. Thursday, 25 June 1925

      Francis steps out of the murky atmosphere of the taberna. Even at this late hour, Athens bustles around him; the sound of singing, loud conversation, and cursing swirls around him. He yawns, and stretches his back. The trip to Athens--48 hours of hell, from Trieste to Athens via several ferries and a backbreaking ride on a Greek bus--still isn't quite forgotten by his stiff muscles.

      Suddenly, he spins and draws his automatic. A man step out of the shadows, holding a gun on Francis.

      "Well well well shamus," says Eddie Gaffigan, "imagine meeting you here. D'ye wanna get a drink?"

      "Sure."

      "What do you want to do, count to three and we'll both holster our pieces?"

      "Sure. One..."

      "...Two..."

      They both pause.

      "Ah, if you're going to shoot me, you're going to shoot me," says Gaffigan, putting away his gun. He enters the taberna. Shrugging, Francis holsters his gun and follows.

      They order drinks. Francis grabs an ouzo, and Eddie orders wine. "I've been a Frenchie so long I can't stop drinkin' the stuff," he says. He's returned to his native Northern Irish accent, Francis notices.

      "Ye wouldn't happen to know where Eloise is, d'ye?"

      "No. Sorry."

      "Ah, 'tis to be expected. You're probably right, it wasn't a good plan. I had a way to control G\xe9vaud, but there were too many unexpected vectors on that."

      He pushes away his glass. "We're not so different, shamus, you and I. I just made some different choices that were probably wrong, a long time ago."

      "I would say that it's not too late, but in your case, I really think it is."

      "I can't disagree with you there, Francis. What d'ye say we finish this thing?"

      "I think we're finished."

      "Oh, we're not finished, not you and I. You won, don't get me wrong, it's all over with me now. It's for Eloise, no matter whose fault it is. A man's gotta do something when the love of his life gets kidnapped."

      [I am not ashamed to have stolen that sentiment from the last five minutes of The Maltese Falcon, possibly the best acting Humphrey Bogart ever did.]

      "And yet instead of chasing after her, you went to Venice to take care of business."

      "Boyo, you have no idea of the forces you're up against."

      "I really don't."

      "All I can tell you is, when it comes to the Carlyles, not a single bloody one of the bloody expedition is dead. People are going to tell you it's Penhew you have to watch out for. I worked for him for many years. The man is seriously crazy. He's into things I can't even imagine. But I don't even think he's the one to worry about."

      He looks at Francis with a mad glint in his eyes. "They're going to be coming for you now, boyo. You have a very big name to ye. The organization's gonna be looking for you."

      "Well, if you could find me, it shouldn't be hard for them."

      "The thing is I'm a wee bit better at infiltration than they are, which is how I found you."

      "I'm going to be honest with you. I need to find out what happened to my cousin."

      "Well, we certainly tried to kill her in Paris. We almost did, except for your little friend the newspaperman. I hear they buried him in an envelope."

      "If I find out anything in the course of my investigation about Eloise, I'll tell you."

      "No, boyo, I think we need to have it out right now--"

      There's a popping noise. Gafigan looks down. Francis has his silenced pistol out--the same pistol Gavigan had thrown him back in Paris.

      "I was right," he says, slumping down. "Not so different."

      Francis jams the pistol into his waistband, and quickly sneaks Gaffigan's wallet out of his coat. He tosses a few bills on the bar.

      "Sorry about the mess," he says, and leaves.

      [So, I wanted to give the PCs some closure on Gavigan, and not keep him in my back pocket; too many not-quite-dead villains drags things down and robs the PCs of their initiative.

      Gaffigan/Gavigan was at the end of his rope. His entire life had been one long game of raising the stakes, until somebody finally came to call his bluff and it all came crashing down. He most definitely had a death-wish.

      I had a vision of a nifty gun fight on the moonlight Acropolis (actually impossible, because it was the new moon at this point), but OP cut to the chase in a much more entertaining way. Given a chance, Gaffigan would have tried to kill Francis for sure--but he was really out of options no matter what, hunted by the cult, bereft of resources, and Eloise irretrievably gone. So RIP, Eddie. You were fun to play.]

      \nTonight That's Where I'll Be (Part 3)

      Thursday, 30 June 1925

      Freddie awakens with a start. There is a loud knocking...somewhere.

      He tries to look around, but everything is absolutely black. The air is stuffy. He tries to move his hands, but soon discovers that he is in an uncomfortably coffin-shaped area.

      There is a ripping noise as nails pop free. A prybar bashes through the boards of his..box...and nearly smashes his noise. The bar swings down, and the lid to the box is pulled away.

      "Hallo Mr. Freddie, hello Mr. Freddie, hello Mr. Freddie!" says Billy. "Miss M said I'm to take care of you."

      "Oh good. Where are we?"

      "In the Red Sea, sir. Approaching the Somali coast, I should think. Billy's kept your cabin nice and ship-shape, he has."

      "Does this mean you work for Miss M?"

      "No sir! Miss M made me better. Billy's much better now!"

      In ship's saloon, Jimmy is poring over several textbooks on mathematics, psychology, and history. He glances up as Fritz Krakauer enters the room from the deck. Behind him, Freddie Blakely stumbles in.

      "Scotty. Felix. What ho."

      "Jimmy?" says Fritz.

      "Freddie!" says Jimmy.

      "I'm off to my cabin, I'm knackered," says Freddie. "Billy, do I have a passport?"

      "No sir! That's why we had to put you in the box, sir!"

      Freddie enters his cabin. Gilbert is sitting in the corner, smoking. He has already laid out clothes for Freddie.

      "Gilbert, I understand I've been fired and you've been recruited. Do you have any idea what I'm supposed to do?"

      "Can't talk about that."

      "I see."

      Someone pounds on the other side of the cabin wall. "Keep it down in there!" shouts Francis. "I'm trying to brood."



      They all meet later in the saloon. Francis plunks down a bottle of whiskey. "Gavigan's buying," he says.

      "I suppose you're in on the great assassination plans," says Freddie to Fritz.

      "No, I don't know anything about that," says Fritz, "although I'm sure I will hear about it soon. I've been around the block."

      "Right, Austrians and assassinations," says Freddie. "Say, could you provide me with something to get me into Zanzibar?"

      "A Czech passport would be difficult. But let me see..." Fritz grabs a suitcase, opens it, and shakes his head. He opens a second suitcase, looks through it, and then closes it. He opens a third suitcase. "Ah. Finland. There's like eight people in the country, it should be easy."

      Freddie checks with his man of business via telegraph. He discovers that what liquid wealth that could be moved has been shifted into the American stock market. "Safe as houses! We'll make a mint!"

      Jimmy is poring over a package sent to him by Bradley Grey, his lawyer employer back in New York. They include some transcripts of psychotherapy sessions Roger Carlyle had with Dr. Robert Huston, fellow member of the Carlyle Expedition, and some notes taken by Jackson Elias during her stay in Zanzibar that Jonah Kensington had forwarded to him.

      He also has succeeded in decrypting the message he found in the ruins of the Fondation Aubrey Penhew, using the notebook he found in Gavigan's Venetian villa. Francis had to help him with the final translation:
      \n

      Avez-vous des changements pour Lovelace? J'esp\xe8re qu'elle sera fini en Ao\xfbt. Le baronnet m'a dit que Babbage projet a \xe9t\xe9 achev\xe9 la semaine derni\xe8re, il n'attend plus que les syst\xe8mes de guidage. Nos amis les ont d\xe9truits. C'est b\xeate - ils ont fait des probl\xe8mes pour nous depuis trop longtemps. Je me suis dit que le plan de M'Weru est trop risqu\xe9. Certes, si la situation ne s'aggrave, je vais prendre les choses en mains propres.

      ==================

      Do you have any changes for LOVELACE? I hope that it will be finished in August. The baronet told me that project BABBAGE was finished last week; he waits only for the guidance systems. Our friends have destroyed them. It's stupid--they have made problems for us for too long. I have said to myself that M'Weru's plan is too risky. Certainly, if the situation gets any worse, I will take matters into my own hands.
      \n[I also have the notes from Jackson but I'll have to scan them in. Writing the Huston sessions was a lot of fun.

      "Dr. Mwimbe," says Jimmy, "Do you know anything about someone named M'Weru?"

      "M'Weru? It is a Gikuyu word that means white. Should I know who this person is?"

      "Just wondering. Jax mentioned her name."

      Wednesday, 1 July 1925

      Freddie finds Dr. Mwimbe standing by the rail, watching the sun rise behind the islands of the Zanzibari archipelago. "Can you smell it, Mr. Blakely? That clove smell? Those are the islands of my home. You are welcome to stay at my home."

      "You still have a family house here?"

      "I do."

      "I am deeply honored."

      "You should be."



      Zanzibar! The exotic Spice Islands! Once the capital of the Sultanate of Oman! Now a British protectorate, stripped of its mainland possessions, but still maintaining a sultanate.

      The European population is small, under a thousand people. The caste and color system prevails among the locals--Omani Arabs on top, then the Zanzibaris who claim Persian descent, and then mainland Africans. It is the origin of the Swahili language.

      [I actually found a book from 1920 on Zanzibar--thanks, Google Books!]

      The oldest part of Zanzibar, the Stone Town, is known for its old houses, with elaborately carved doors in the Indian tradition. This is where Dr. Mwimbe takes her companions.

      "Doctor, what is the socially appropriate form of our relationship?" asks Freddie.

      "You are my guests. The common people I do not care about, and the nobles have too much respect for me."

      "I was more worried about what your family would think."

      "My family are mostly dead. It will happen to all people in time."

      "Depressingly true."

      \n Thanks Lisa! For the actual prop, I signed each letter. (With my fountain pen. For authenticity.) Each one has a progressively more exasperated signature, to show Bradley's increasing frustration :-)

      I also left some notes on the decrypted message--one supposedly from Jimmy ("Francis! What does it mean?") followed by Francis' note on the translated sheet ("JIMMY! LEARN FRENCH!") I thought their respective players would appreciate it :-)

      \n
      \nTonight That's Where I'll Be (Part 4)

      Dr. Mwimbe's house is deep in Stone Town. The door is even more elaborately carved than the other doors in the neighborhood, showing signs of Indian and Persian influence; Charleston notes many signs in the twisting patterns that he has seen in the Al-Azif: protective spells, spells calling on the name of Nyarlathotep, as most incantations do.

      They are met at the door by an elderly African man in a butler's uniform.

      "Imani! Wie geht es dir, mein lieber Freund?" says Mwimbe with obvious pleasure.

      "Ganz sch\xf6n, meine gn\xe4dige Frau," says the old man. "Sind sie unseren G\xe4ster?"

      "Ja."

      Fritz and Freddie, who both speak German, look at each other and shrug.

      "Maybe that's the only language they have in common?" says Freddie.

      Mwimbe's other servant is a young Frenchwoman, her cook. "Enchant\xe9e, messieurs," she says, curtseying. "Madame, je dois pr\xe9parer le d\xe9jeuner pour vous?"

      "Non, pas maintenant."

      The house is two stories high, built surrounding a large courtyard with a fountain. It has relatively few doors--most passages are left unblocked for ventilation--except for a large room with locked double doors on the second floor, next to Mwimbe's excellent library.



      Fritz and Francis head for the Port Warden's office to see if they can follow up on when the Ivory Wind was supposed to arrive in Zanzibar. Fritz, well-schooled in the ways of bureaucracy by stint of working in an insurance agency and having grown up in Austria-Hungary, secures a promise to get the records in a few days.

      [Bureaucracy spend by KP.]

      Freddie heads for the harbor and catches a ferry to Dar-es-Salaam, to chase down the leads from Jax's notes. He wanders around, asking after Jax, and using his connections to try and get appointments with the local officials.

      Jimmy checks into local business records, using Jax's notes as a guide. She discovers that a single shipping company supplied the Carlyle expedition with most of their equipment. It's run by an Indian family; while everything is in her uncle's name back in Bengal, locally it is run by a woman named Dil Chandra Thakur.

      It turns out that the Ivory Wind has shipped items from Thakur's warehouses back to Emerson Imports in New York.

      Jimmy asks around about spiritualists and magicians. He hears that there is a tradition of sorcery and witchcraft on the island of Penga, the northern island of the Zanzibar archipelago. He also finds out that a local white woman, Mrs. N. Smythe Forbes, is very interested in spiritualism. With his characteristic understated charm, Jimmy gets invited to a s\xe9ance being held that very afternoon.

      "Is there anyone you wish to contact?" asks Mrs. Forbes, a pleasant, grandmotherly woman.

      "Yes, you!" says Jimmy.

      "But I am not on the other side! Oh, wait, I see. Is this to be a formal interview? We could go to my offices." She indicates the sitting room she uses to publish her English-language paper, The Star.

      "Off-the-record," says Jimmy, who feels he is getting good at this journalism stuff. "Oh, whatever I ask, try not to freak out."

      "I've peered through the veil, young man, I doubt there is anything you can frighten me with."

      "Excellent! Have you ever heard of the Cult of the Bloody Tongue, or M'Weru?"

      "I've never heard that name. The Cult is legend; they say it is a witch society on Penga. I don't believe it; you know those [racial slurs], very superstitious."

      "Do you remember the Carlyle Expedition?"

      "Oh yes, it was very exciting. Strange people though. We never saw Mr. Roger, he was always ill. Come to think of it, we never saw Miss Masters. I suppose you can guess what was going on. Sir Aubrey was very nice to me. He was interested in looking for a lost city somewhere in Africa; I put him in touch with our Mr. Jarmyn. Now, young man, you can't fool me. You're a reporter, aren't you? Are you from the Kane syndicate? We'd dearly love to have our little Star as part of the Kane syndicate."

      "Actually, I work for a man named Freddie Blakely."

      "Mr. Roland Blakely? The publisher of the Golden Sentinel? We don't get it very often, but I read every word! Such brilliance! Next you'll be telling me you know Wo Fong, the author of so much Oriental wisdom!"

      In a flash, Jimmy realizes this must be Charleston. He remembers Sheila telling him once that she wrote down random things he used to say and published them in a column. "It's a small world."

      "Wait, Mr. Blakely is here? Could you come down and grant me an interview? I'd be happy to give you free access to all of our files."

      Jimmy makes his way back to Mwimbe's house and searches through her books. He finds a mathematics textbook and finally locates an entry on Babbage and Lovelace. Charles Babbage designed a mechanical calculator, called the Difference Engine, and Ada Lovelace was the first to realize that it would be possible to create instructions that would allow you to make the Difference Engine calculate many different kinds of problems. Checking his cryptography notes, Jimmy realizes that the search for such a mechanical device could be revolutionary in the field of coding.

      "Hey Francis, this technology could replace computers!"

      "Those guys who add up columns of numbers?"

      "Yeah!"

      But what does it mean? Why would the conspiracy be interested in such an obscure subject?

      [1 point History and Cryptography spends by JP.]

      \nTonight That's Where I'll Be (Part 5)

      Friday, 3 July 1925

      As it turns out, Captain Montgomery, commanding officer of the Dar-es-Salaam garrison of the King's African Rifles, is an old classmate of Freddie's--in fact, he introduced Montgomery to his wife. They meet for tea.

      "Listen Blakely, I could get in a lot of trouble helping you. Still, I owe you for pulling me out of the mud in Eton. What can I help you with?"

      "It's a matter of my former fiancee."

      "Which one, old man?"

      "An American. I was rather infatuated with her, and she's left me a few instructions in her will--she's a reporter, you know. The Aunts made me a publisher, did I tell you."

      "Good show, I suppose."

      "So it's the Carlyle Expedtion--"

      "Good Lord, Freddie, that old thing? It's a closed book. Nobody wants to hear about it."

      "Except my fiancee, and Rotten Roger's sister, Erica."

      "That shrew?"

      "Well, I know her husband-to-be."

      "Poor bloke. I'll look into our records and get back to you. Talk to you in a few days."

      [Credit Rating spend by FP]

      Freddie heads back to Mwimbe's house. "Wie geht's, Imani!"

      "Ganz gut, mein edler Herr."

      "Excellent, excellent, keep up the good work."

      "Zum befehl, mein Herr. "

      "Doctor Mwimbe! I've found the most remarkable things on the mainland. An old friend who hates me--"

      "That is not very remarkable, Mr. Blakely."

      "Not at all, true. It seems this Ivory Wind ship carried things to Emerson Imports in New York. The very establishment that recommended you to us."

      "I would authenticate artifacts for Mr. Emerson."

      "Grey market goods?"

      "I would never do something so illegal. Mr. Emerson was typical of white men dealing in African artifacts, he could not tell the difference between a forgery and an item of great value. He paid me a commission, which helped augment my salary from Columbia. I need not mention that my salary was lower than that of the other professors."

      "I'm surprised you were on staff, to be honest."

      "The School of Anthropology is somewhat more liberal than the rest of the college."

      [More or less true; they certainly hired female faculty much earlier than many universities.]

      "I also learned some Indian woman has something to do with that ship."

      "We think we should go in and close her down," says Francis. "She has a connection to Gavigan, and whatever Jax was up to."

      "Oh, Francis, I'm meeting my old friend Montgomery in a few days. Mind tagging along?" says Freddie.

      "I found out from the local newspaper lady about the Cult of the Bloody Tongue. Oh, I dropped your name," says Jimmy to Freddie. "She wants to meet with you!"

      "Nobody wants to meet with me!"

      "I know! But she's an exception."

      "I think I should come to that too," says Francis. "It could be a trap. Fritz, you come with me. Find a place to hide this." He hands Krakauer a large revolver which he hides in a briefcase.

      "Doctor, could you see about getting us a meeting with this Thakur lady?"

      "An Indian? That might be difficult, but I could give you a reference--"

      "This isn't really my wheelhouse," says Francis, "but I think it's yours. You have a very nice establishment. Couldn't we have a party to draw her out?"

      "A party? With an Indian? I guess that could be done," muses Mwimbe. "Very well. She may even be a Muslim for all I know. I don't know anything about Bengalis, my servants were always Gujaratis."

      [If you are playing along with the original Masks, Dil Chandra Thakur is my replacement for Tandoor Singh--ridiculous name, and a ridiculous character. Thanks to the Masks Companion for the suggested replacement. The spelling of her last name is important--Thakur is often Anglicized as Tagore (like Rabindranath Tagore); she rejects even that slight concession to English sensibilities. Her first names are a riff on a character I played in a fantasy game named Delshandra--she was from an Indian-style culture, so I eventually worked out that her name was really Dilchandra and merely poorly pronounced by everyone. Dil means heart in Hindi, and chandra means moon.]

      Later that day, invites are sent from Dr. Mwimbe's house to all the best people in Zanzibar for a dinner party next week. Everyone accepts--including the Sultan.



      Freddie is somewhat agog at hearing that the Sultan is coming. He asks Mwimbe what language is appropriate for speaking with the Sultan.

      "Arabic."

      "Suppose you could no longer speak Arabic."

      "Then you must use English."

      "Is that appropriate?"

      "I suppose if you could learn Kiswahili in six days..."

      "Six days may be cutting it a bit close," says Freddie. He hires a gang of little children to follow him around and point at things, telling him their names.



      Francis spends some time ingratiating himself with the local police force, who are dropping by every day to prepare the security arrangements. The British officers in charge of the Zanzibari police are happy to bring him in on the arrangements, clearly recognizing a tough guy. Not without a few "That's all well and good, sir. But this Africa, sir. This is Zanzibar."

      [Cop Talk spend by Francis.]



      Saturday, 4 July 1925

      The Zanzibar Star is not much of a going concern--Mrs. Smythe-Forbes runs it out of her house, publishing a single-page broadsheet every day--usually.

      "Mrs. Smythe, how wonderful to meet you," says Freddie.

      "So nice to meet someone who understands the other side."

      "I myself have been to the other side. I found it incredibly disturbing."

      "They ask a lot of questions!" says Fritz.

      "I happened to bring the Carlyle files from our morgue. And this is Mr. Jarmyn, and Colonel Endicott."

      "Ah, Colonel--"

      "GOOD TO MEET YOU, BLAKELY!" bellows the Colonel. "YOU HAVE THE LOOK OF A CAMBRIDGE MAN."



      "Well, yes--"

      "NEVER WENT TO UNIVERSITY MYSELF, WASN'T WORTH MY TIME. YOU KNOW COLONEL RHODES?"

      "I knew a Colonel Pearkes, a Canadian--"

      "AH, CANADIANS, NO USE FOR THEM. SOFT PEOPLE."

      Fritz crawls out from under the table and sits back down with a sheepish look. Francis finally decides to put his gun back in its holster. The Colonel is a rather overpowering presence.

      [In fact he always talks in ALL CAPS. I came as close as possible to yelling while doing the Colonel's voice.]

      "Neville Jarmyn, Mr. Blakely, good to meet you. You want to know about what the Carlyles were looking for, and I can tell you. The Lost City of the White Gorillas!"

      "Really?"

      "Yes, my ancestor had the skin of one--well, what was left after he burned it for some reason."

      "Was it on a mountain?"

      "Why, yes, I believe the Lost City must be on a mountain. It was supposed to be in the Congo, but I believe they moved. To one of the lost worlds of Africa."

      "What's a lost world?"

      "NGORONGORO, OLD MAN," says the Colonel. "I HAVE A LODGE THERE. AMAZING PLACE, GIANT VOLCANIC CRATER."

      "Amazing. Well, we'll have to come. Say, is this mountain called the Mountain of the Black Wind?"

      "SUPERSTITION," says the Colonel.

      [FP: No, Colonel, I wish to know more, can you speak to it?

      Me, as the Colonel: WELL, I...PERHAPS IF YOU SPENT SOME POINTS FROM ONE OF YOUR POOLS!

      FP: Colonel, let me flatter you some more...


      They speak with Jarmyn and the Colonel. In response to a question from Jimmy, Jarmyn indicates that there seems to be some relationship between the Egyptian myth of the Black Pharaoh, and the stories in Tanganyika about the Black Wind. While they talk, Fritz goes through the Carlyle file.

      [KP: I copy down or filch whatever I think we need.

      Me: ...our you could borrow it. No, no--you're player characters, please continue with your criminal activities.]

      Freddie offers Mrs. Smythe-Forbes a regular column in his paper. Stars in her eyes, she readily agrees to let them borrow whatever they want.

      [As it turns out, KP has a friend who went to Ngorongoro. Small world.]
