      \n\nJuly 2014 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n Fascinating. I also find that prepping NPCs for fights is annoying, even when it's a published thing. Relationship maps, though -- I love those. And, when I'm doing an improvised campaign (still likely using published material from others), over time, a convoluted family tree kind of coalesces. I think it's the combination of Lovecraftian gaming and having reread Lord of the Rings many times, including the appendices.

      I'm pondering the M'Weru, Huston, and Magister roles in the back of my head, as folks are still in Shanghai. I'm hoping to use the "Bloody Botany" bit from the Masks Companion, which does a nice job of making Ho Fong more comprehensible to me.

      \n Yeah, Lisa. I mean, I don't run a pickup game without a relationship map between the PCs, so I owe the villains at least as much.

      In the end, the campaign was really a showdown between a bunch of powerful women (Jax, Hypatia, Mwimbe) and I'm pretty cool with that :-)

      \n
      \nThe Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep: An Afterword, of Sorts (Part 3)

      So my hack of the campaign was well underway. But what I was doing--at first without realizing it--was in fact a reboot. This became more obvious as I began discussing it here, where at some point I realized I was crossing Ronald Moore BSG with Joss Whedon Buffy.

      How to Hack a Reboot: A Primer

      Reboots are tricky things.

      If you deviate too far, no one will recognize what you've done. Leave things too much the same, and people will wonder what the point of the whole exercise was.

      We seem to be living in the Age of the Reboot, most notably (for geekdom) the Ronald Moore BSG and the JJ Abrams Star Trek. Both men made fairly bold choices in tinkering with canon, although I think only one of them managed to improve the project in the long run. (Sorry, JJ.) Let's talk about what I did in rebooting Masks.

      Probably the most important step in rebooting something is to take a look at the theme of the piece and then decide what themes are more relevant to you and your audience--and perhaps comment a bit on the original work. In the case of Masks, the campaign as a whole was pretty advanced on the subject of racism, to a lesser degree on colonialism, and not at all that good about sexism and homophobia. Since the last two are fairly dear to me, I knew that in my game I'd emphasize both of them more. I also felt that ramping up the examination of colonialism was called for, both as a commentary on the modern economic world and to create some tension between the Pulp tropes of the benevolent colonial powers and the actual horrors of colonialism.

      Let's address the queerness of Masks first. Honestly, when I played the campaign, I just naturally assumed that Roger Carlyle and Jack Brady were lovers; I mean, when you look at the actual text, Roger's decision to use all his resources to free a roughneck ex-Marine is very weird and never properly explained. I guess I assumed there was a subtext there. I've actually been surprised to discover this seems to be a minority view! However, I decided to make this explicit; Episode I made several mentions of the suspicions that Jack and Roger were lovers.

      Now...I had some other ideas on how to push it. Roger's transness was a bit of a delicate and personal subject to me, and I hesitated including it; but for whatever reason, it just clicked with me, and plus it allowed me to have an ongoing low-level mystery (who was Vanessa?) that kept people guessing. For the record, my conception had Roger Vane Carlyle as having always been trans and Erica having been more accepting of this when they were younger; thus she knew full well who Vanessa was--not her dead brother so much as a secret about him that she found embarrassing.

      (Odd, when I talk about fictional trans people my pronoun usage is terrible. Roger was always Vanessa; M'Weru and the Big N just gave her what she most desired.)

      The campaign actually ended up being pretty queer. In my mind, Hypatia certainly was some kind of omnisexual who probably preferred women and had been Mwimbe's lover at some point; there's Desmond Motombo and Captain Hardekker; Joyce Summers; and of course Taro Isoge. (In the regular campaign, he's a Japanese Naval Intelligence officer--and maybe in mine, as well. Though gay. Very gay.) Even in Jax's diary I had an episode where she was helped out by a gay couple.

      ...and that leads me to the women, and most especially to Jax.

      I'm not sure when the idea of flipping Jackson Elias' gender came to me. It was fairly early on--probably as I was reading the campaign all the way through for the first time, and looking for ways to give women more roles. Whatever was the cause of the inspiration, it hit like a thunderbolt and was the single most important thing I did in the reboot. If I had changed nothing else, I think having a female Jackson Elias would still have had major changes on the campaign.

      For one thing, it made me like Jax more. I probably couldn't have written the diary had I not been writing it as a woman. Having Jax be a plucky feminist making her way in a man's world gave me both insight and a nice cliche to hang my portrayal on. And then, purely by random happenstance, FP ended up being Jax's former fiancee! Think of how much came from that simple die roll! (I'll touch more on the Fiasco playsets later.)

      Perhaps most importantly, having made that major break, I felt...empowered to make others, large and small, which fed into my decisions both on how to manipulate the actual text and in how the NPCs were motivated.

      Whatever else, it made Jax live and breathe for me, and that made it much easier for me to accomplish one of my major early goals: to make Jackson a living character for the players as well, to make them feel her absence and give them a real reason to press on.

      I've already touched on what I did for M'Weru and Hypatia; let's just say that this was in the spirit of the changes I made with Jax. Likewise, it made it easier for me to punch up Erica Carlyle from annoying socialite to a hard-headed business woman, cheated by her gender from assuming her rightful place at the head of her family's business. (The regular text seems to assume she's Roger's younger sister; I made her the older sister, and so doubly cheated of her inheritance.)

      After that, deepening the investigation of colonialism wasn't too hard; I just needed to play it up in Egypt and then Tanganyika. Having Mwimbe around to issue acerbic commentary to the players kept it fun for me, and in any case the regular text is fairly good on racism. I decided early on to include the Nautilus (seriously, it's in Jax's journal if you look for it), which is another symbol of anti-colonialism. (Making Marlowe the captain was a later inspiration, but one that made a great deal of sense.)

      Finally, although not crucially, there was the character of Nyarlathotep him...her...itself. The nightclub entrance was an old, old idea, probably one of the first I ever had about the campaign, and fit with how I wanted to portray the Messenger: sarcastic, omnipotent, and always in on the joke. These things he does are games to him; he doesn't have a stake in how they finish, merely in how they're played. At the same time, I did want to preserve some sense of menace from him, which I tried to do in his later appearances, especially when he appeared to Jimmy on the ship and the Rev in Australia and Singapore.

      So armed with my revised NPC relationship map and my rebooted sensibilities, it was time to start playing the game...

      That was the second version. Not exactly as things ended up playing out, but surprisingly close, all things considered; dated from well before the start of the campaign.

      I haven't either forgotten this thread or finished my afterword, just been a bit busy

      \n
      \n
      \nThe Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep: An Afterword, of Sorts (Part 4)

      I had my campaign mapped out, and now I had to choose a system.

      My initial choice--and in keeping with the whole "do less work" plan for the campaign--was to just use Call of Cthulhu. And in fact I ran a preliminary session--a somewhat hacked "Dead Man's Stomp"--for PP and CP under CoC. (At the time, I had some cockeyed plan of running a few introductory sessions. We only did this one, but it introduced female Jax and Charleston Chiu to the world.)

      But I soon began to have issues with the CoC rules. They're crunchier than you think. There's no out of the box point-buy. The language rules are all messed up. Even if we avoid the "missed Spot Hidden roll" problem--and I agree it's not as big a problem as some make it out to be, especially with the clever design of Masks--I wasn't a huge fan of the system.

      So I went looking. At one point I was thisclose to doing a Fate conversion, although lacking Fate Core it probably wouldn't have been that great.

      Ultimately I went with Trail of Cthulhu, not least because someone had converted three of the chapters to the Trail rules. (Which reminds me: I need to finish the conversion I started of the last two, as a service to humanity.) I seemed to get Trail right off the bat, although it seems I took a more expansive view of what buys could do than the core rules supported. (Later Gumshoe games have tended to support my view, though.)

      This is skipping ahead a bit, but I might as well talk about some of the things I observed about the Trail rules in the course of play:

      --The standard Sources of Stability rules aren't awesome, and are particularly unsuited for Masks. The version in Night's Black Agents is pretty much superior in every way, and I'd recommend anyone interested in long-term campaign play to adopt them. The only place the standard rules might be better would be in a "monster of the week" style game, as it makes the "your relative just died" opening to many CoC adventures a little easier to justify ("one of my sources thought he saw a ghost...")

      --The Contacts rules in NBA should probably also come in to Trail, I think they're thematically appropriate with some reskinning.

      --Maybe it's my group, but folks didn't like the Stability checks at all. Up above somewhere I discussed the idea of making them a fixed cost rather than a roll, which I think would work better.

      --The contest rules are not awesome. I started to avoid contests because they were an unfair drain on the PCs resources, in my opinion. This may vary by playstyle, of course--in a more Purist game, they probably make more sense. (But I pretty much am incapable of being a Purist GM.)

      ...but otherwise I thought they worked very well. CP didn't love the resource management aspect, although I think some of that may just be packaging--we all kept very complicated character sheets going when we played Pathfinder.

      \n
      \n
      \nThe Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep: An Afterword, of Sorts (Part 5)

      I don't know if I did anything particularly innovative in the campaign--my reskinnings and gender-flips are in the playbook of most rebooters--but I did have one good idea that I am proud of: using the Fiasco playsets to create character background.

      I am of the firm belief that a lived backstory is going to be better than even the most detailed canned backstory. It gives the players a common reference point, and in the no-pressure environment of the Fiasco playset everyone could just freeplay their characters.

      The randomness of the playset...is a more delicate subject. I'm not sure it's a better fit than, say, the Pathways system of Cortex Plus Drama. Folks need to be onboard with it. And yet...we got a lot of mileage out of some of the more interesting rolls. Most important, of course, was Freddie's relationship with Jax. In the first half of the campaign, when the sessions were haunted by her presence, this gave things a poignancy that I don't think I could have planned out. And it also built some tension into Freddie's relationship with Sheila. (Having tension around FP is good--he's a master of deflection, so I looked for ways to pull him into dramatic situations.)

      Likewise, Francis being Jax's cousin added a touch of sweetness to a very bitter character, I think. It gave us a glimpse into the side of Francis that could have been happily married.

      And as it turned out, not having CP available for any of the Fiasco runs was a great foreshadowing for how disconnected Charleston would turn out to be.

      I made three playsets for the game. (I worked on another two, but those were basically hacks of existing playsets and not custom-made like the others.) The first was pretty straightforward; I'd decided that the end of WWI made sense for the first time these characters would cross paths, so I threw together a bunch of cool stuff I brainstormed.

      The second playset was more fun, although I struggled more with the writing--I was working on a Gatsbyesque New York playset, with locations scattered around the Big Apple, including of course a party on Long Island. It wasn't very inspired. Practically the night before the session I finally realized that what I really wanted was just the party, and with a little work I could map all the locations to the party itself.

      Of the three we did, that one was my favorite, not the least because it introduced Jimmy and Francis, and we saw the Jax/Freddie romance for about the last time.

      The final playset, however, I'm rather stupidly proud of, because it tried to break the mold by having all the locations be points in the life of Jackson Elias. As such it's not really playable outside my campaign, although I think the idea deserves more exploration. The actual game wasn't as good as I would have liked--we never got a chance to develop some of the weirdness around Franz--but the mirror reflection captures of Freddie and Francis were some of my favorite moments out of all the Fiasco gaming.
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n

      \n\nAugust 2014 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nThe Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep: An Afterword, of Sorts (Part 6)

      One thing I didn't really expect was the amount of player turnover I had.

      I knew that PP would be moving eventually, although at first we thought he would move about a year later than he did. It does me no credit to have been relieved that at least I wouldn't have to deal with Pearkes anymore. (CP actually advised me to kill Pearkes off after the first session. I'm not sorry I didn't follow his advice, but I would have saved me some headaches...)

      Pearkes was just a weird scenario. Somehow PP and I--who usually had no issues--weren't talking the same language in-game. I'm really not exactly sure how it got so bad, although it was mostly my fault that it did. About the only thing I can fault PP for was something I hadn't really figured out yet--to wit, that if you're planning to have your PC make a major life change (and all along PP told me he was intending George to break out of his Imperial chauvinism), you need to do it very early. This is one of those places where the weird interaction between being both participant and audience in an RPG comes in.

      Or more basically, play the character you intend to play as soon as you can, because being a jerk for forty hours will wear thin.

      I made one huge mistake with Pearkes that I blame Bill White for. (Just kidding, Bill.) That was killing off Sam Steele so quickly. PP got penalized there for having made the only usable list of Sources of Stability, and I wanted to kill one off early. But it was a horrible mistake. Sam could have been there for much longer, letting PP boss him around to his heart's content and needing therefore to boss the other PCs around much less.

      Losing BP early on ended up not being as big a deal as I feared it would be. While I enjoy playing with BP, and had some plans for Blount as the "audience-identification" character, the core chemistry between PP, CP, FP and I carried us through, along with GP, whose dry wit and easygoing manner made him very enjoyable to game with.

      And then of course, we lost PP and I somewhat haphazardly recruited OP and JP from my Tuesday night group.

      And they ended up making the campaign.

      By the time JP joined, GP was mostly out of the picture, and JP quickly took the same slot. She is an absolute delight to game with, especially when you're a GM--she's always willing to bite on a plot hook, her easygoing and funny manner relaxes everyone, and most of all she doesn't mind risking her character. FP and CP--FP especially--were always more cautious or willing to hold back and wait for me to explain things. But JP always went at the story hard.

      OP is a different matter. His primary PCs tend to be near-sociopathic manipulators, but my experience has always been that as good as he is at playing those kinds of characters--and he's very, very good at playing them--he's even better playing good guys. Francis was easily the most layered character, the one who had the best arc, and in a lot of ways the solid pillar that I built the second half of the campaign on. It was really fine work and I frankly can't imagine the campaign now without him.

      It was a neat trick, replacing half the cast midway through the game, but we somehow pulled it off, and built a group with excellent chemistry. (Currently we're playing in CP's 13th Age game. I'm a sociopathic fire sorceress. OP is a manipulative elf who's totally not a necromancer. JP is everybody's fixer and FP is the world's dumbest fighter. It's a lot of fun.)

      Since I'm handing out compliments to my players, a word about FP and CP.

      FP had the time of his life with Freddie. He had always wanted to play Bertie Wooster, and he ate it up. In retrospect, I think the citizenship angle I played wasn't really an awesome move, although the "Freddie Blakeley, feared terrorist" angle ended up being an excellent running gag. I was trying to find a handle on FP, and it wasn't really working--but I shouldn't have been going straight at his central character concept. By the end of the campaign, though, Freddie finally started to have a bit of an arc.

      This was another example of me getting stuff wrong, by the way. I let FP's remarkable charisma--and his Freddie accent is spot on, perfectly plummy and a comic masterpiece--make me try and use him as the campaign's dramatic center. (Of course, until OP showed up, he was the best choice.) But drama isn't FP's thing, and I shouldn't have tried to pigeonhole him.

      About CP, what can I say. He never forgot he was in a horror game. He is a very, very funny person and this comes through in how he played Charleston. The Rev was likewise about 200% more brilliant than anything I could have come up with on my own. And...well, you saw how things ended.

      He won the damn campaign.

      About the only thing I can fault PP for was something I hadn't really figured out yet--to wit, that if you're planning to have your PC make a major life change (and all along PP told me he was intending George to break out of his Imperial chauvinism), you need to do it very early. This is one of those places where the weird interaction between being both participant and audience in an RPG comes in.

      Or more basically, play the character you intend to play as soon as you can, because being a jerk for forty hours will wear thin.
      \nOh, a thousand times this. I have yet to see the "I plan for my character to eventually have this change in heart or status" actually pay off, and I've seen it completely fail and ruin that player's enjoyment too many times to allow it as a GM any more. Start off as the character you actually want to play, not that character's chrysalis.

      There is a closely related fail state, where everyone assumes their characters will meet during play and become best buds (as opposed to having met before play and formed relationships already), which in my experience INEVITABLY leads to something going wrong during the initial meet that sours relations forever. That is complete poison for a "PCs against the world" kind of setup.

      (my last RPG horror story involves BOTH OF THOSE HAPPENING AT ONCE, so yeah, I am pretty sensitive to those issues now)

      I wish you and your group even more good gaming (and hopefully more AP reports).
      \n

      \n Thanks, Joe. I read that bit of advice about getting the change of heart done quickly (I believe the recommendation was during the first session) Somewhere. If I get a chance I'll see if I can find it.

      I don't have plans for a major campaign anytime soon, although I'm gathering resources for something I call "Angsty Clones and their Anime Masters" that will probably be in Cortex Plus Drama. I'll probably hold off on that until the 13th Age campaign finishes.

      I do have a project I'm working on that I hope to get off the ground; the working title is Symphony in Grey: A Whitechapel Drama. It's a test run with Cortex Plus Drama for me--the premise is that the PCs live or work in Whitechapel during the "Autumn of Terror" in 1888, when the Ripper was doing his deadly work. Won't be a police procedural, although I hope to have one detective in the mix, more a high class drama with the killings as backdrop.
      \n

      \n\nLisa Padol \n\n\n

      \n\nAugust 2014 \n

      \n
      \n I haveseen a late chane of heart work, BUT, each time, the circumstances were game-specific. I can go into that in detail later, as I am at LonCon3. I don't thinkany of my examples involved moving from jerk to not-jerk, however.

      I have had good games where PCs met for the first time in game. But, outside of pregenerated PCs the players first see at the game, I think doing character creation as a grouo is key. Possibly more on that later.

      Canned backstory or hidden backstory can work, but you need to use certain techniques that make it feel less like that, and again, maybe more later.

      Oh, and I want to be in both of those games, or at least read about them.

      Breakfast calls.

      \n\nAugust 2014 \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \n
      \nThe Post-Modern Masks of Nyarlathotep: An Afterword, of Sorts (Part 7)

      So, finally, I had my system, I had my ideas, and I had (in a changeable way), my players. What could go wrong?

      I'll leave it up to you to judge what did or didn't. But here's a few things that surprised me, a few things that I wanted to happen but didn't, and some notes on my favorite sessions.

      I never expected CP to take Charleston down the path of sorcery. Lord knows he resisted my attempts to actually bring Charleston into the world of sorcery, although to be fair, "Noah Cross" was a bit of a trap. But as noted above, CP never forgot he was in a horror game, and I guess he decided that somebody had to go insane.

      Likewise, the Freddie-Jax romance and how it ultimately played out was a shocker from the first. I still haven't asked FP why he decided to focus on Sheila and lose Jax, although I'm sure he'll have a very reasoned response. But in the early part of the campaign it carried the emotional weight of the drama, so I must thank him for it.

      I had hoped to get more India into the game, but when I decided that session 17 would wrap the campaign there just wasn't time. In any case, it was a bit of a silly fake-out, and I could have easily dropped it in a pinch.

      Random stuff that I imagined but never happened: a moonlit shootout between Gavigan and Francis on the Acropolis; Francis time-travelling thanks to Hypatia back to the day Isabelle died; Dr. Mwimbe being discovered in Egypt, and promptly using magic to make her discoverer into a duplicate of herself before setting the duplicate loose naked and without Arabic in the desert; the Black Sphinx; M and Hypatia walking down a quay in Paris; more stuff with the Dreamlands; Alphonse Gilbert navigating the fictional worlds trying to free the other PCs; Charleston working as a photographer in California during the late '60s; and the final double-Fiasco playset, where the PCs would start at the opening of the Flamingo in Las Vegas, 1947, only to be transported midway to 1983 London where they were all actors on the ITV series Masks, written by Larry DeTillo--and they would all be actors who had the same first name as the actual players. (That last one would be the prize Easter Egg on the Blu-Ray set.)

      My favorite overall episodes were probably IX (Francis and Jimmy vs. the werewolves), XII (Clipper ship!) and the first session. Episode VI (Metafiction!) comes close but just misses the satisfaction of the others. The finale was very good but a bit rushed. Episode X (Venice!) had the best explosions and a true action-movie finish.

      These were my favorite NPCs to play: Hypatia, especially with Freddie; Jax, with anyone; Billy and Mickey, because I could do accents; and Dr. Mwimbe. Honorable mention should go to poor Sam Steele.

      And of course Nyarlathotep.

      I'm not sure how he came off, to be honest, but I enjoyed the everliving daylights out of playing him. I guess I saw him as some kind of Coyote or cosmically powerful Bugs Bunny--always in on the joke and not really caring who won or lost so long as he held all the cards. I know there was a danger of him coming off as too jokey, so I tried to keep the hidden menace buried just below the surface. I consciously gave him a break for a while after Episode VI, to keep him from getting too familiar; IIRC, it wasn't until Episode XII that he made a reappearance, and that was unscheduled (had the players not decided to pursue the "what killed that freighter?" angle, he wouldn't have shown up at all.) But his later appearances--nearly always centered on Charleston--let me pursue the menace more closely. In that regard, the meeting between "Omar" and Charleston in Australia and then in the jail cell in Singapore were my favorite bits--especially the latter, where I got to fence quite nicely with CP.

      In the end, I think I saw N as a bit of a tragic figure. He's always going to be alone--he is uniquely who he is, and no one will ever really approach his level. His hard sell to Charleston can be interpreted as trying to find someone, anyone he can talk to. And in the end he failed at that.

      Not that he cares, really. Throw this hand in and deal another. There's always another game in town.




      A few words of acknowledgement:

      First, to Larry DeTillo and Lynn Willis for writing the adventure. My apologies for the folding, spindling, and mutilation.

      To Pelgrane and their fine stable of writers for giving me the game I needed.

      To Bill White, for flattering me with his attention.

      To Lisa Padol, for becoming my friend, and letting me play Joyce again.

      To everyone who commented, because you flattered, taught, and helped me each and every one of you.

      And most of all to my players, because it was for you.

      \n Thanks!

      I'm currently prepping for tomorrow's session of my Masks game, trying to figure out what spell one player would be most likely to have his PC use in a disturbing, creative, and corrupting way so that I can give it to his PC before the raid on Gray Dragon Island (and the "Bloody Botany" scenario from the Masks Companion), whether my latest thought about what to do with Hypatia is actually a good one (she came to her senses, either didn't have the child or destroyed it, which means that a) the pregnant PC is pregnant by Nyarlathotep, not be some nameless lesser Outer God and b) Hypatia is a random factor, potential ally -- and potential threat to the pregnant PC), what to do vis M'Weru (who's currently by default sitting on her mountain) and whether that question should be answered as "have Tewfik bodywarp and take her place, freeing her to infiltrate the party, perhaps in the guise of saving the pregnant PC from Hypatia, if I go that route".

      But, tomorrow, I'm expecting relatively simple combat. I just need to figure out how to corrupt the PC learning magic by giving him something he'll use.
